PARIS, Aug. 6.--There were three deaths from cholera at Marseilles and three at Toulon last night. Seven returned fugitives have so far died. The Siecle says the Government has determined to demand the suppression of the quarantine along the Italian frontier. If Italy refuses to grant this demand, reprisals are threatened.

The moon shone brightly last evening for the first time this week. Every one in the Seventh Ward knew that this phenomenon was due to the fact that the Pleasant Coterie had its annual field day yesterday. This title was merely nominal, however, for in the faces of the coterie the venerable Jefferson Association reflected its light.

The cry of "Stop thief!" rang out from at least 50 throats about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon as a young man started on a dead run across the park toward the City Hall. A fleetfooted policeman headed the pursuing crowd, which swelled to at least 500 in less than one-fifth that number of seconds.
ALBANY, Aug. 6.--The Republican campaign was opened here this evening by a large ratification meeting at Music Hall. The hall was so crowded that an overflow meeting was organized outside.

A middle-aged, innocent-looking man boarded a Grand-street car on Monday evening to go to Desbrosses-Street Ferry. His air of benevolence and solid comfort attracted the attention of two stylishly dressed young men who were lounging around Grand-Street Ferry. One was tall, with a spare, smooth-shaven face, a keen eye, and a long nose.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 6.--The body of Lieut. Lockwood, who perished in the Greely expedition, will be brought here for burial on Friday or Saturday. The funeral services will be held at St. Anne's Protestant Episcopal Church, and the interment will take place in the cemetery, where the family has a vault. Lieut. Lockwood has two sisters whose husbands are in the navy residing here.
Secretary Folger has returned to Washington from New-York, and was at the Treasury Department to-day.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6.--The sound of the fog horns is heard again to-night, much to the chagrin of the yachtsmen. The day, however, was pleasant, but quite sultry. Owing to the dampness of the ground, no polo was played this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6.--Capt. John W. Clous Twenty-fourth Infantry, has been relieved from duty in the Department of Texas and ordered to proceed to join his company in the Department of the Missouri.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 6.--Mr. Blaine started to-day upon his pilgrimage through the State of Maine, and at the outset has met with a very cordial reception in its leading business city. WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 6.--News has been received of the death at his cattle ranch in Montana of Benjamin Maltby, son of Douglas F. Maltby, President of the Novelty Manufacturing Company of this city.

PARIS, Aug. 6.--The French Resident at Hue has been instructed to recognize the new King only upon condition that he accepts the treaty between France and China concluded by M. Patenotre, French Minister to China.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Aug. 6.--Charles Walters and Abe Buzzard were instantly killed and Frank Walters fatally injured at the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company's Indian Ride Colliery this afternoon by a fall of top coal.

According to the books in the Coroner's office David Ogden Wotherspoon's death was "suicide by a pistol-shot wound in the right temple." His friends and many of his relatives had not the slightest suspicion that he took his own life until it was mentioned in the newspapers yesterday morning.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 6.--Samuel H. Drew, ex-County Prosecuting Attorney, was arrested last night charged with embezzling $8,000 from Mrs. Elizabeth Cox. Drew was her attorney and agent for several years.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 6.--Mr. H.B. Miller is less confident to-night than he was reported to be last night of being able to reorganize the whisky pool. He had a conference with the spirit men this afternoon and will to-morrow meet the highwine men.

HALIFAX, Nova, Scotia, Aug. 6.--The news of the wreck of the steamship Amsterdam, of the Netherlands-American Steamship Line, was brought here this evening by the Dominion Government steamer Newfield, which has just arrived from a tour of inspection of lighthouses. A motion to secure alimony and counsel fee from Dwight C. Golder was made before Judge Beach, in the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday, on behalf of Mrs. C.R. Golder.

Alexander William Reichman, of Galveston, Texas, cook at the Hillmeyer House, Far Rockaway white bathing yesterday afternoon way dashed by the waves against the iron pier, sustaining a fracture of the skull. He was rescued by Fritz Jager, of the Hoffman House, but died a few minutes after reaching the shore.
It is now stated by Southern papers that it is all a mistake about the Scottish crofters being dissatisfied with their North Carolina homes and intending to remove to South Carolina.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 6.--At the meeting of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers to-day a resolution was unanimously adopted indorsing John Jarrett for the position of Chief of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, and respectfully requesting President Arthur to sign the commission at his earliest convenience.

LONDON, Aug. 6.--The advanced Liberals held a noteworthy meeting in London to-day. The House of Lords was the subject of their deliberations, and they resolved to establish a league which should labor for the reform of that ancient body.

Jay Gould resiged from the Presidency of the Wabash, St. Louis and Pacific Railway yesterday, and James F. Joy, one of the Directors, was elected to succeed him. The Directors adopted the report of a special committee appointed to devise a plan for reorganization and passed a resolution directing the revenue officers to take such steps as they may deem best to promote the design of the plan.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Aug. 6.--A special agent of the secret service in the Pension Department has been in the city for the last 10 days, and left by rail last night for Washington. He stated to a Post reporter that a regular organized system of swindling has been in operation in the pension business for some time.

TRENTON, Aug. 6.--So little interest was manifested in the Republican State Convention, at which candidates for Presidential Electors were selected to-day, that not more than half the seats in Taylor Hall were filled. The morning hour was spent by those of the delegates who were here in the preliminary caucuses.

BOSTON, Aug. 6.--The American Political Alliance has issued a call to the councils of the United States to make secret nominations for President and Vice-President. These nominations will be "audited" by the Executive Council in Boston, Sept. 5. "Americans to Rule America" is the watchword of the alliance.

BATH, Me., Aug. 6.--The missionary steamer Morning Star was launched at noon today by the New-England Shipbuilding Company. She is owned by the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions. She is expected to be ready for sea by Sept. 10.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 6.--To-night was the occasion of the tenth annual children's carnival, given at Leland's Ocean hotel. The gloom and rain of the past two days were followed by bright skies and balmy air, which brought out the largest gathering of any of the events of the season.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 6.--Investigation shows that the much vaunted Blaine and Logan Club of Irishmen in New-Haven is composed of 63 members, and is very insignificant in quantity and quality.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 6.--Jonas Masterson and wife quarreled Monday night. He picked up a strap with a large buckle on one end and swung it over his head to hit her. Thinking it would cause him to stop his attack she took up her 18-months-old child and had it before her. The child received the blow on the head and early this morning died from the effects. A Coroner is investigating the case.

Angel was called upon to decide the ownership of two goslings which were quacking a duet, one with a deep "barrel" tone and the other with the articulatiun of a piccolo.

LONDON, Aug.6.--The Government scheme for the temporary relief of the Egyptian Treasury includes the renewal of the Rothschild loan of 1,000,000 and the reduction of the expenses of the administration.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5.--The final meeting of the Local Committee of Arrangements for the recent Republican National Convention was held at the Pacific Hotel this afternoon and the financial report made. The report, naturally enough, is largely made up of a review of things by no means new.
WASHINGTON, Penn., Aug. 6.--A colored laborer employed on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, working as Vance's, this afternoon put a ball through his head. The cause of the rash act is not known here.
A woman, who said she was Sarah Bernhardt, of No. 107 Clinton-place, was charged with disorderly conduct at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday by Officer George Noll, of the Eighth Precinct.

"The sweetest baby I ever saw in my life," said Mrs. Keizer, a nurse living at No. 523 West Forty-eighth-street, yesterday. The woman referred to an infant, apparently about 2 months old, which she held in her arms, and talked to in the orthodox tootsy-wootsy manner.

WHEELING, West Va., Aug. 6.--This city is a total wreck financially, besides being saddled with a bonded debt of $700,000, which is about all it can carry under the law, which limits the issue of bonds to 45 per cent of the total valuation.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 6.--The nineteenth annual meeting of the Buffalo Driving Park Association opened to-day. The attendance was fully 4,000. The track was in first-class condition and very fist, but a strong wind blew in the faces of the horses coming home. Pools were sold without hindrance.

SEA BREEZE, N.J., Aug. 6.--Joseph Richmond, a fisherman, and an unknown man were drowned here yesterday. They were engaged in catching bait in a small creek when they accidentally stepped into a deep hole and sink out of sight. Fishermen who saw the men sink secured grappling irons, and, after dragging for an hour, succeeded in recovering the bodies.
LE ROY, N.Y., Aug. 6.--A convention of the people of this part of Genesee County was held yesterday in the Opera House here, to consider the county's attitude toward the Woman Suffrage bill.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 6.--John E. Bryant managed to secure his bond as Marshal of Georgia by retaining Gen. Longstreet's chief Deputy, Mr. Mitchell, in charge of the ohio, as heretofore. Mr. Mitchell, consequently, will be a much more important figure than Bryant when business is to be transacted.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 6.--The Lee family gathering closed its session here to-day. There was an attendance both days of about 250. Permanent officers were elected as follows: William H. Lee, of New-York, President, with 40 VicePresidents, and Charles E. Lee, of Rochester, Secretary. About 50 of the company went to Farmington this afternoon to visit the grave of John Lee, their English ancestor, who was buried there 200 years ago.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Aug. 6.--Reports from the village of Matamoras, in Pike County, Pa., give the particulars of some remarkable freaks of lightning which occurred there during the thunderstorm of yesterday. The flashes of lightning and peals of thunder were almost continuous for more than half an hour. Lightning struck the roof of Seymour Coykendail's residence, making a large hole near the chimney.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 7.--The continued rains have made much havoc with the smaller fruits in Central Connecticut. One West Haven farmer claims to have lost $200 on raspberries alone. TROY, N.Y., Aug. 7.--About three months ago Mary Richards, an attractive young woman, secured a first-class room at the American House, and said she intended to be a permanent boarder and that in a few weeks her mother would also arrive and stop there.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 7.--The public here is greatly stirred up over the proposed increase in the area of the city reservoir at North Bridgeport, obtained by raising the dam some six feet.
Twenty-first Pennsylvania District--The Hon. C.E. Boyle, Democrat, renominated.
Complaint was made before the Recorder of Paterson, N.J., against Thomas and Kate Spaniel, yesterday morning, for being drunk and disorderly.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Aug 7.--A difficulty occurred last night at Halpin's station, on the Louisville, New-Orleans and Texas Railroad, above this city, between Col. Duncan and Tom Allen, which resulted in the fatal shooting of the latter. A woman whom both men claimed was the cause of the difficulty. Duncan escaped.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 7.--Robert Pickford, of Pickford Black, agents for the Netherlands-American Line at this port, started for Sable Island to-day, taking along a gang of men, to save the cargo of the wrecked steamship Amsterdam. If the weather continues fine a large part of the cargo will be saved. The survivors are lodged in immigrant sheds here, and ...

PETERSBURG, Va., Aug. 7.--The Planters and Mechanics' Bank, of this city, closed its doors on the morning of May 19. A heavy run had been made on the bank the Saturday preceding its failure, and an attempt was made to renew the run on Monday morning, just before the bank doors were closed to the public. The bank, according to many authorities, had been in a shaky condition ever since the panic of 1873.

There was a very slim attendance at the Methodist camp meeting at Sing Sing Heights, yesterday, owing to the rain and the damp and muddy condition of the grounds.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Aug. 7.--The Republican State Executive Committee met at Jackson to-day. Among the assemblage there was quite a number of Greenbackers and Independents, who were there by invitation.
WYTHEVILLE, Va., Aug. 7.--The Court of Appeals to-day decided the case of Wise against Bigger and others.

LONDON, Aug. 7.--In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Gladstone stated that the Government had no intention of offering any counsel to the Egptian Government or of adopting any financial scheme until Lord Northbrook shall have visited Egypt and made his report.

The new divorce law in France, which was announced to go into effect on the 1st of August, forbids, in the second article, the making of any report of the proceedings, a penalty not exceeding $400 being imposed.
There is a little Shoshone papoose here, only 4 years of age and not much larger than a pickle jar, who evinces wonderful aptitude for molding images out of mud and clay.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 7.--A large crowd was present at the races this afternoon. Two purses were offered--$200 for the 2:40 class and $300 for the 2:26 class.
BERRYVILLE, Va., Aug. 7.--Andrew Lewis, a colored man, was this morning detected following Miss Erskyne, a highly respected young woman.

An animated meeting of the New-York Petroleum Exchange was held yesterday afternoon for the purpose of considering the subject of amending the constitution of that Exchange so as to permit the members to trade in stocks, bonds, and other securities.
Search is being made by the police for John O'Brien, 9 years old, who has been missing since Monday. The parents of the lad live at One Hundred and Forty--fourth-street and Brook-avenue.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 8.--Jay Gould's handsome hotel and club house on Charles Island, opposite Milford, is burning. The flames were discovered at midnight. The steam yacht racing party held a banquet there yesterday, but all had left when the fire was discovered.

A burly ruffian who says he is John Daley and that he "works on the railroad" went into a "dive" at No. 51 Bowery shortly before midnight last night, and drawing two revolvers announced his intention of cleaning out the establishment.

A Hindu outlaw of the genuine Robin Hood type has for some time been baffling all the attempts which the Indian police have made to capture him.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 7.--Marcellus Baker, of Linklean, had been a cataleptic for years. A few days ago he was riding on a mowing machine, and was seized with a fit. He fell to the ground in front of the knives, and was cut to death.

Capt. Williams, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, has under arrest Micheal Kelly, who says he lives at Bayard-street and the Bowery. Kelly is suspected of robbing dwelling houses, first hiring rooms in them and then plundering them when an opportunity occurs.

SHARON, Conn, Aug. 8.--While Pike County farmers mourn because of the raids of bears on its sheepfolds, the farmers of this quiet little town up in the wilds of Litchfield County mourn with equal vigor the frequent raids which have of late been made on their hen roosts.
There is a serious quarrel in the narrow ranks of the Theosophists, and Mr. C.C. Massey has resigned his fellowship in the London lodge. It is all about a miracle.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8.--George Wilson, a young music teacher of Camden, N.J., was committed to jail without bail in that city this morning, charged with having committed a criminal assault on Mrs. Elizabeth Budding, of No. 232 Division-street, Camden.

BUENA VISTA, Ga., Aug. 8.--Mr. Stringfellow, aged 22, secured for wife Mrs. Allen, a rather decrepit widow of 50. They reached town at 5 o'clocK in the morning, woke up the Rev. Dr. Leonard, and were married at once. The old lady, in explanation, said she was married that way the first time, and liked it best.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 8.--The Board of Visitors of William and Mary College held a meeting here last night to devise some plan by which the old institution could be relieved. There were present Judge W.W. Crump, Rector;

For several days past a family of Hungarian gypsies have a attracted considerable attention in Castle Garden. The family consists of Joseph Freier, his wife and three children, and his mother and brothor. They dress in loose, gay, gypsy fashion, and are quite dark. Joseph said that they were formerly fortune tellers, but that they proposed to earn an honest living in this country.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 8.--A libel suit for $50,000 was instituted to-day against the Alta California by Sarah A. Sharon, plaintiff in the Sharon divorce case. The alleged cause is the publication of William M. Hilson's statement accusing her of forging what are known as the " My Dear Wife" letters.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 8.--The annual meet of the Eastern Archery Associated closed at Cranston's, near West Point, this afternoon. The shooting generally was not as good as last year, the totals in every round being less.

Jack Dempsey, who recently fought with Fulljames on Staten Island, was arrested yesterday afternoon in the Bowery by Detective Sergt. Rogers, and a Staten Island constable. He was taken to Staten Island, where a Fulton Market butcher became his bondsman in $700 bail, and Dempsey returned to his customary haunts last evening.

The following case was tried by the Police Magistrate in Hamilton recently: J.R. Cameron accused Mrs. G.M. Hunt with creating a nuisance by wheeling her baby carriage persistently in the front of his door.

Mrs. Carolina Norcas, whose husband keeps a lager beer saloon at No. 91 Oliver-street, was arrested by the police of the Fourth Precinct yesterday on the charge of passing counterfeit money.

A ghastly scene occurred to-day within the prison at Stein. This morning a convict named Ferdinand Baumgartner, who several months ago murdered a prison warder, was to be hanged for the crime in the courtyard of the prison.

The business failures throughout the country in the last seven days as reported to R. G. Dun Co., of the Mercantile Agency, by telegraph, number, for the United States, 206, and for Canada, 26, or a total of 232, as against 251 last week, a reduction of 19. The Western and Pacific States supply nearly half the failures reported. Casualties in the Southern States are very few comparatively, especially in Texas.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 8.--An inquest has been held concerning the death of young Cheney Ames, who shot himself through the heart yesterday at Elmore's Corners, town of Esopus, Ulster County, in the presence of Miss Freer, to whom he was engaged to be married.
The Barnes family is to hold its tenth annual reunion in Bridgeport, Conn., on Thursday, 21st inst.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 8.--The attendance at the annual circuit races to-day was larger than on any previous day.

According to the report just published by the Minister of Finance the merchantile marine of the Russian Empire consists at the present moment of 6,383 vessels, of which 5,779 are sailing vessels, with a capacity of 657,574 tons, and 604 steamers, having 111,802 tonnage and 30,612 nominal horse power.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 8.--A number of steamboat and railroad men met here to-day for the purpose of establishing a daily line of steamers between Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, and Mount Desert, stopping at Bar Harbor, making a short rail and steamboat line between Boston and Nova Scotia over the Maine Central and Eastern Railroads.

Edward Pfestner, an immigrant, arrived here a year ago and found a home in Ohio. A few months since he sent his wife, Anne, money enough to bring her out to him. Early in July Anne arrived here on the steamship St. Germain, but disappeared immediately after her arrival with a fellow-passenger named Gustav Engler.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 8.--Postmaster Merchant prepared to-day and forwarded to the Postmaster-General a full statement concerning the charges and statements made by the committee appointed by the Postmaster-General to examine into the conduct and condition of the New-Orleans Post Office. The way in which Mr. Stephen B. Elkins has projected himself into the councils of the National Labor Party was made public at a meeting of the Executive Committee of that party at Clarendon Hall last evening.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 8.--The attorneys of J.C.S. Harrison to-day filed a petition applying for a writ of habeas corpus, the object being to secure a reduction of the bail demanded.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8.--Ex-Senator McDonald, of Indians, was here to-day on private business. He speaks freely of the outlook in his State. "The campaign has not yet opened," he said, "but active preparations are being made, and it will be one of the most closely contested struggles we have ever had. Cleveland will carry the State, but we shall have to fight for it.

SARATOGA, Aug. 8.--In most places hackmen are content with depriving one of whatever worldly goods he may possess, but in Saratoga this season their object seems to be to kill or maim as many people as possible.

The Post Office Department is packing a fine collection of postage stamps and envelopes in handsome frames for shipment to the expositions of Cincinnati, Louisville, and New-Orleans.

PARIS, Aug. 8.--During the 24 hours ending at 9 o'clock to-night 24 deaths from cholera occurred at Marseilles. The record of the hospitals at Toulon for to-day is as follows: Admissions, 9; discharged, 8; deaths, 3; under treatment, 86. There were two deaths from cholera to-day at La Seyne.
Third South Carolina District--D. Wyatt Aiken, Democrat, renominated.

The total receipts from the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge for July were $40,545, against $12,595.42 for the corresponding month last year. During the month 333,800 persons crossed the bridge on foot, 624,900 traveled on the railroad, and 47,696 vehicles carried 95,392 persons across.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 8.--John W. Mackay denies the truth of the statement telegraphed last night from Naples of the engagement of his daughter Eva to a member of the Colonna family.

LYONS, N.Y., Aug. 8.--The village of Clyde, in this county, is making preparations for receiving the remains of William A. Ellis, one of the dead of the Greely expedition. Ellis was a son of Mrs. George Vanderpool of that place,

CHICAGO, Aug. 8.--There was a good attendance at the races to-day. The weather was fair and cold and the track fast. MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 8.--The little village of Kewaskum, Washington County, was the scene of a double tragedy yesterday. John Funder, a laborer, and Frank Rossie, a clerk, both employed by Rosenheimer Brothers, merchants at that place, got into a quarrel in the afternoon.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Northern Pacific Railroad will be held the third week in September. The books for the transfer of common and preferred stock will close Aug. 23 and reopen Sept. 20.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 8.--Important steps have been taken during the past week in this city, looking to the still closer unification of the extensive interests represented in the recently organized association of vapor stove manufacturers of the United States.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 8.--It has been evident for some time that trouble was brewing between the Salvation Army and a class of people in the city, and several hostile demonstrations have been made.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn. Aug. 8.--James Abbott, alias Francis Stevens, alias David H. King, was arrested here to-day. He is wanted for forgery, bigamy, and theft.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 8.--The July output of Lake Superior copper mines is as follows: Calumet and Hecla, 2,250 tons; Quincy, 231; Atlantic, 185; Franklin, 175; Huron, 116; Allouez, 100; Peninsule 63; Copper Falls, 50; Wolverine, 40; Hancock. 38.
The sun shone with unwonted brilliance on the picturesque buildings and verdant swards of Governor's Island yesterday.
DANBURY, Conn, Aug. 8.--It is expected held the Connecticut Convention of Firemen to be held here Tuesday will be largely attended.

LONDON, Aug. 8.--A dispatch from Foo Chow to the Times says: "The American Minister will arrive at Shanghai to-day. The Chinese remain firm. Further concessions on the part of the French will alone secure peace."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 8.--Gen. John A. Logan arrived at West Point at noon to-day, and was met at the wharf by Gen. Merritt, who escorted him to his cottage, where Gen. Logan's family have been visiting for several days.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 8.--Mr. John W. Davis, assistant to Acting President Robert Garrett, of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, was today appointed by Gov. McLane Police Commissioner to succeed the late Gen. James R. Herbert. Mr. Davis was formerly connected with the Pennsylvania Railroad.

"Johnny" Jourdan, a, famous burglar and bank sneakthief, was a prisoner yesterday in a cell at the Central Office. His arrest was made in rather a singular fashion.

Among the passengers of the Inman steamship City of Chicago, which sails for Liverpool to-day, are Lieut. W.W. Griffin, of the Royal Army; Mrs. Herbert Inman. Herman Koch, Dr. James Coldham, the Rev. Edward G. Thurber, the Rev. B. Davies, and the Rev. James O'Connor.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 8.--A dispatch to the Times-Star from Lexington, Ky., says: "Mr. Holt, Republican, has been elected Appellate Judge by a majority of 1,000 to 1,200 in a district heretofore Democratic by 1,200 to 2,500."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 8.--The storm has cleared and the bright sun was seen all day. The day was also delightfully cool. The yacht race was the event of the day, and the result is told in another column.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 8, via Galveston.-- The Official Journal denies that the Government intends to change its policy relative to the stamp taxes. The merchants claim that this means a continued stagnation of business and no Government revenues from customs.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 8.--The german at the Ocean Hotel to-night had been looked forward to with high expectations for weeks. The first figure was called at 9:30 o'clock, and the dance was kept up until midnight, when the floor way given up to "everybody and their partners."

CHICAGO, Aug. 8.--The New-York residents of Minneapolis, Minn., to the number of over 100, met this evening and effected a permanent organization under the name of the NewYork Association of Minneapolis.
Gen. Cuvier Grover, United States Army, is at the Albemarle Hotel.

Daniel Flynn, an old man, who claimed to have been in the British Army for 21 years, landed at Castle Garden on Thursday. He says that some time ago he became too old for service and was given a small pension.

Joseph Pinshauer, a pawnbroker's clerk, of No. 338 Stanton-street, was arraigned at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday afternoon on a charge of disorderly conduct, preferred by Officer Wheeler, of the Broadway squad, for James Brewster, of No. 304 West Twenty-first-street.
Bessie Parker, the 7-year-old daughter of William Parker, of Islip, Long Island, complained to her parents on Wednesday evening that she had been assaulted by Henry Sweezy, a man nearly 70 years old.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 8.--Secretary Johnston to-night officially announces the disbandment of the Iron and Oil Baseball Association, formed in Pittsburg last December.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 8.--Charles E. Courtney, the alleged sculler of Union Springs, rowed against time over the mile course on Irondequoit Bay to-day, and made an alleged mile in 5:12 , the fastest time on record.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8.--Arrangements were completed to-day for the reception to be given in this city to Archbishop Ryan, of St. Louis, who yesterday received from Rome the brief translating him to the See of Philadelphia.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 8.--Notwithstanding the threatening weather of the morning, there was a good attendance at the races to-day, the ladies being present in large numbers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8.--It is expected that by the close of working hours to-morrow the main shaft of the Washington Monument will be completed and ready for the roof. The shaft will then have attained the height of 500 feet.

NEW-LONDON, Aug. 8.--The managers of the new State Baptist seaside resort at Niantic, a few miles west of this city, are arranging for a brand temperance mass meeting in the Tabernacle at an early date in this month. There will be delegates from all the temperance societies in the State, and a great audience is expected. The chief attraction will be a speech from St. John, the Prohibition candidate for President.
Two thousand persons assembled on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon to witness a game of baseball played there between the NewYork and Boston Clubs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8.--Col. William B. Royall, Fourth Cavalry, will, on the expiration of his present leave of absence, stand relieved from duty as a member of the Board of Officers convened by special orders Feb. 9, 1884, and will then proceed to join his regiment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8.--The Solicitor of the Treasury has prepared for the Attorney-General statements exhibiting the results of suits against delinquent officers of the Government in the fiscal years 1880, 1881, 1882, and 1883.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 8.--Holmes, Lafforty Co., dealers in live stock at the East End Cattle Yards, failed to-day for about $100,000.

Postmaster Pearson has been notified by telegraph from San Francisco that the steamship Oceanic sailed from that port last Thursday with mails for China and Japan, the latest date forwarded being July 31.
POINT PLEASANT, West Va., Aug. 8.-- There seems to be an organized plot in this part of the State to destory the growing wheat crops, a large number of men being engaged in the work.
ROME, Ga., Aug. 8.--While plowing in a field, 50 miles down the Coosa yesterday, Mr. Nyman plowed up $250 in American and Spanish coin.

BUFFALO. N.Y. Aug. 8.--George W. Morrison, the keeper of a curiosity shop and second-hand boot store in this city, was shot in the abdomen by a customer in his store this afternoon, and died a few minutes after. It is supposed that the shooting was accidental.
DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 8.--The Assignee of the E.T. Barnum Iron and Wire Worke has filed his statement of assets and liabilities of the concern.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 8.--President Thorner, of the Cincinnati Unions, to-day made a contract with McCormick, pitcher; Briody, catcher, and Glasscock, short stop, members of the Cleveland Club, to leave the Clevelands and play the remainder of the season with the Cincinnati Unions. The men played their last game as members of the Clevelands here this afternoon.

Franklin J. Ottarson, one of the veteran journalists of New-York, is now lying critically ill in Bellovue Hospital. He is about 75 years old, and has fairly worn himself out in harness. He has been an editorial writer, correspondent, critic, managing editor, versifier, and reporter.
LONDON, Aug. 8.--A Blue Book containing correspondence relative to Egypt has just been published.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 8.--The Mahone Republican State Committee and 40 or 50 other leading members of that party were in conference with Mahone to-night to map out the work of the campaign in Virginia.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Aug. 8.--Gov. Hale, of Wyoming, last night issued a proclamation establishing quarantine on the southern and eastern boundaries of the Territory, to prevent cattle shipped from Texas wholly or in part by rail from entering; the order also applies to cattle from any point affected with contagious diseases. The proclamation is to remain in force until Oct, 1.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 8.--John H. Gaffney, of this city, a member of the staff of umpires of the Massachusetts Association, has been appointed League Umpire by Secretary Young and ordered to report in Boston to umpire the Boston-Providence game to-morrow afternoon.
BOSTON, Aug. 8.--The Democrats to-night opened the campaign by a double ratification meeting.

ASHLAND, Penn., Aug. 8.--A horrible accident occurred at Connor colliery crossing, near here, at noon to-day, in which four lives were lost and one person fatally injured.
MILWAUKEE, Wis, Aug. 8.--At the Milwaukee-Minneapolis game yesterday, Pearson, the pitcher for the Minneapolis Club, while delivering the ball, broke his arm above the elbow.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 8.--A dispatch from Washington says that Major Butterworth, who was yesterday nominated by the Republicans of the First District for Congress, is in doubt whether he can accept.

In this country we are gradually getting rid of the system of fees. It has been abolished at the best theatres, and, though it may be years before we shall attain the common sense and simplicity of the American principle, yet even at our hotels there are signs of growing improvement.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 8.--The Northwestern Baseball League, that started out under such favorable auspices, is in a bad fix all round, and six of the fifteen clubs composing the organization have disbanded.

VERSAILLES, Aug. 8.--The Congress of the two Houses of Parliament to-day continued the discussion of the committee's report on the bill for the revision of the Constitution. Further scenes of a disorderly character occurred.

NEW-LONDON, Aug. 8.--The anniversary of the battle of Stonington, in the war of 1812, at which time a British fleet threw a cartload of shells into the streets of the old salt water borough, killing one goose, is to be celebrated tomorrow by a parade of the Fire Department, fireworks, and varied anniversary features. The shells that were thrown into Stonington were fainted and labeled and they now adorn hitching posts of the "first citizens."
The Directors of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad met yesterday, but, contrary to the expectations of some persons in Wall-street, they did not adopt the new plan of financial relief.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 8.--The coke operators are loud in complaints about the depressed condition of their important industry. Notwithstanding the strenuous efforts put forth by the syndicate to bolster it up, the trade continues to fall off.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8.--John B. Hurling Co., wholesale dealers in laces at No.48 Madisonstreet, made an assignment to Abram J. Moore. No schedule was filed, and Moore, the Assignee, who is a non-resident, refused to talk.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 8.--A discovery has been made at Burgessville, Ontario, which has caused great excitement in the district, as it bids fair to convert a quiet agricultural district into a busy forest of tanks and oil works.

PANAMA Aug. 8, via Galveston.--The Star and Herald reports that an epidemic of malignant and pernicious fever is prevailing at San Carlos, a village 39 miles from Panama. Nine deaths occurred in from 24 to 37 hours. The inhabitants are panic-stricken. It is believed that the epidemic is due to intense malarial poisoning.

Joseph Rindell, a German tailor, 51 years old, made an attempt to commit suicide yesterday in rather a novel manner by chopping his head with a small hatchet. Rindell, who lived at No. 85 Avenue B, is married, but has no children.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8.--Inquiries made at the Post Office Department have developed the following facts in connection with the financial irregularities and disappearance of Assistant Postmaster Col. Morton, of Brooklyn.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 8.--News has been received of a destructive prairie fire, about 150 miles northeast of this place, on the range between Denver Junction and "The Frenchman," The burned district extends about 30 miles along the Platte River and back from the river a great distance, covering a portion of the Jed Brush, Governor Routt, and Bruce Johnson ranges. It has inflicted a great loss upon the stock interests of that region.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 8.--Word has been received in this city of a movement looking to the forced reduction of pig iron stocks throughout the country, by the combined banking up of all the blast furnaces in the United States from Sept. 1 to Nov. 1.
John G. Whittier has sent a contribution to the Massachusetts Republic Campaign Fund, and says in the accompanying note that he is "not prepared to abandon Republicanism."

Mr. SCHURZ'S powerful speech at the meeting of the Brooklyn independents has elicited comment in all quarters.

A party of 11 Brazilian immigrants arrived yesterday from Rio Janeiro on the steamship Derwent. The men say that they have a little money left and that they wish to find homes somewhere in the United States.
A novel spectacle, and one not without its pathetic features, was presented yesterday on Kensington Fields, Liverpool, when the famous Wombwell's Menagerie passed under the hammer of the auctioneer.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 8.--The Rev. Dr. Potter, of New-York, recently elected Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Nebraska, will preach on Sunday in Trinity Cathedral, this city. The visit excites much interest among Episcopalians.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 8.--Richard Torley, aged 65 years, an old resident of this city, was found under a train of coal cars here to-day, with his head severed from his body. It is supposed he went to sleep on the track.

NEW-LONDON, Aug. 8.--The American Yacht Club has abondoned its contemplated trip to Newport, and will end its first regatta here early to-morrow morning.
ANNAPOLIS Md., Aug. 8.--Lieut. Lockwood's funeral has been postponed until Tuesday. The body may arrive here to-morrow, and in that case will remain in St. Anne's Church until the funeral.

LARIMER, Penn., Aug. 8.--There is great excitement here over a rumor that James Colford, who disappeared eight years ago, was murdered by a saloon keeper named Patrick Maloy, and his body thrown into an old well, which was shortly after filled up. The well will be examined. Malcy is now serving a term in the penitentiary for the murder of Miles Miles at Braddock about a year ago.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 8.--This afternoon the Brooklyns and Virginias placed their second game here, in the presence of about 1,500 persons.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 8.--A fire, probably caused by a cigar stub, destroyed a sleeping car in Barnum's circus train at this station today. Chang, the Chinese giant, lost all his clothing, jewelry, two watches, numerous so ivenirs and much money. Cameron, Chang's manager, is out nearly a thousand dollars in cash, besides clothing and jewelry. A duplicate car will arrive at Erie to-morrow from Bridgeport. Barnum's loss is $5,000.

HOTEL KAATERSEILL, New-York, Aug. 8.-- At the closing of the orchestral concert in the parlor last evening the figures of President Arthur and Judge Strong were prominent features in the hotel corridor, where they stood engaged in conversation for some time.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 8.--There is still nine-tenths of the Scott liquor tax unpaid, and to provide for the payment of the police, who are largely supported by the fund, the recommendation will be made to the Council that $200,000 be borrowed by the city.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 8.--The State census was taken in June. Complete returns have just been tabulated at the office of the Secretary of State and they show the aggregate population to be 1,855,785. This shows an increase over the United States census of 1880 of 227.639.

TOULON, Aug. 9.--One death from cholera occurred here to-day. The record of the hospital to-day was: Admitted, 6; died, 1; cured, 4; under treatment, 77. There was one death from the disease at La Seyne.

BOSTON, Aug. 9.--In an interview to-day Gen. Butler said of the Democratic leaders: "I saw they complained that I had deserted the Democratic Party. There is no way of satisfying them. The last time they complained, it was that I had captured the Democratic organization. Be it so: then I have only let my captives loose.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9.--Many Democrats are speaking freely and bitterly in condemnation of the City Committee's course during the present campaign, some going so far as to say that it looks as if the design is to help the Republican bosses to carry out their plans to the letter.

CARLISLE, Penn., Aug. 9.--Conductor Frank Small and Fireman Fuller Thompson were killed by an accident to a train on the Gettysburg and Harrisburg Railroad, near this place, at noon to-day. The train consisted of an engine and seven cars, and contained the companies from the western part of the State ...

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 9.--The absence of George Decamp, attorney for the German insurance Company, has necessitated an adjourn ment of the committee appointed by the Governor to investigate the serious charges alleged against him and Receiver Varnum. The committee will meet next week at the State Capitol, and in the meantime efforts will be made to discover Decamp's whereabouts and enforce his attendance.

MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 9.--In a collision yesterday on the Louisville and Nashville Railroad near here, and which was caused by a flagman going to sleep, the locomotive and tender, after jumping the track and knocking a loaded flat car aside, ran along a high embankment and safely crossed a trestle, the wheels hardly making any impression upon the cross ties. Curiously enough all this occurred on a curve of the road. No one was hurt.

A score of demonstrations have been made by the Liberals in favor of the Franchise bill, and almost as many meetings have been held by the Tories in advocacy of the rights of the Lords and the sacredness of vested institutions.

The Convent of Our Lady of the Rosary, conducted by the Sisters of the Third Order of St. Dominic, in East Sixty-third-street, near Second-avenue, now contains 270 children from 4 to 14 years of age. The branch of this convent known as the Johnson Place, at Sparksville, Rockland County, has 48 children, in charge of Sister Pauline.

HELENA, Montana, Aug. 9.--Linn McFarland, a prominent sheep man of Judith Basin, was found dead on Thursday, 35 miles north of Billing, in the smoldering ruins of a log house. There was nobody about the place. McFarland was on his way to Billings with a team and appeared to have stopped to feed. He was probably murdered by Indians, as several roving bands have been in that vicinity recently.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 9.--As to the Fletcher Sharpe failure Receiver Wallace said to-day that the depositors ought to be reasonable happy, as the assets are so valuable as to require the attention of the competent appraisers for two weeks in fixing upon a nominal valuation.

Michael Mulroy, the manager of John Daly's saloon, at No. 103 Bowery, discharged the bartender, Michael Maher, about a week ago. At 2:30 A.M. yesterday Maher entered the saloon and sat down to a table with Mulroy.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Aug. 9.--The steamship Lydian Monarch, Capt. Huggett, from London for New-York, 21 days out, with a general cargo and 162 passengers, put into this port at noon to-day. One of her engines collapsed when she was six days out. She will sail for New-York to-morrow.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 9.--The Ontario Bureau of Industries, which was formed a short time since by the Provincial Government for the purpose of gathering statistics of the state of trade, , has issued its report for the month of August.

The Independent Republican Committee of Massachusetts have addressed a circular to the voters of that State, giving the reasons why Blaine is not a fit candidate for the office of President. The country is brought face to face with the question, say the committee, whether the President of the United States shall be an honest man.

BLOCK ISLAND, Aug. 9.--Last Wednesday bluefish struck in with a vim, and those fishermen who happened to be on the ground enjoyed rare and profitable sport. The next day many boats went out and brought back from 50 to 200 bluefish each.

LONDON, Aug. 9.--William O'Brien, editor of United Ireland, still refuses to pay the 3,050 damages awarded against him to Crown Solicitor Bolton in the libel suit recently decided at Belfast. Mr. O'Brien was asked this evening what he intended to do about the matter.

SCRANTON, Aug. 9.--Edward Smith, a boy of 14, fell into a rapidly revolving coal screen at the Dodge Colliery to-day and was terribly mangled. Both his legs were broken, and as soon as the machinery was stopped to extricate the lad he was dying. He expired in a few minutes after he was taken from the screen.

It was reported in Wall-street yesterday, and quite generally believed, that W.H. Vanderbilt's recent trip from Saratoga to this city was to advance the necessary $4,000,000 to pay off the floating debt of the New-York Central Road. He is said to have taken the company's note for the money advanced, with the option of exchanging it for debenture bonds at a stated price.

The peach season is at least 10 days earlier this year than in 1882. The Troths are all off, and in Sussex they are shipping early Crawfords. By Tuesday Crawfords will be on here. The season so far has only confirmed what we have said for the past two months, that we would not have as large a crop as in 1882.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9.--A special to the Post-Dispatch from Hope, Ark., says: "Monroe Taylor shot Jasin Hyatt last night for defaming the character of the former's wife. Both are wealthy farmers. Hyatt is mortally wounded."

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Aug. 9.--George Scudder, of this city, 21 years old, committed suicide to-night by shooting himself in the head with a revolver. He was a most estimable young man, and the tragedy creates great excitement. No cause can be assigned, except, perhaps, mental aberration.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 9.--The trick of another of the ingenious gang of swindlers who have been "working" the Hudson River counties for two months, and thereby reaping a harvest of dollars from farmers, clergymen, pious maiden ladies, and others, came to light today.

LONDON, Aug. 9.--A group of Parisian capitalists, headed by M. Freycinet, will join with the Russian concessionaires in constructing a railway from the Caspian Sea to Bussorah, in the Persian Gulf. The Czar and the Shah of Persia will support the scheme.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 9.--A general shut down of all the cotton mills here has been decided upon, and will begin on Monday. The only mills not approving of a shut down are the Border City, Pocasset, King Philip. Union, Narragansett, and Sagamore, but it is quite likely that they will stop within a week. The cause of the closing of the mills is dullness of the market for print.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 9.--McCormack, Briody, and Glasscock, of the Cleveland League Club, who have jumped to the Cincinnati Unions, will play in that city to-morrow.

READING, Penn., Aug. 9.--The Eightyeighth Regiment, Pennsylvania Volunteers, held a reunion at Central Park, this city, to-day. The survivors of the three companies from Berks, which belonged to the regiment, went to the railroad station, and escorted the Philadelphia delegation into Town with a band of music.

The fashionable craze among the Atlantic steamships is to "beat the record." The struggle is to reduce the time across the Atlantic, from shore to shore, to six days. The palm of victory rests now with the Oregon, which has made the distance between Sandy Hook and Queenstown in a few seconds over six and one-half days. But is it not time to pause and seriously consider the consequences of this development of speed?

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 9.--The special train which conveyed President Arthur up the Ulster and Delaware Railroad to the Catskills was run at a high rate of speed, the trip being the fastest on record on that railway.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 9.--The petition for the writ of habeas corpus in the case of John C.S. Harrison was granted to-day, and the writ is returnable forthwith, before Judge James C. Sent, of Frankfort, who had been called in to hear the case.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Aug. 9.--About a dozen convicts have escaped from a plantation directly opposite this city, and have lodged themselves in a cane brake a few miles below the city. ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 9.--At 10 o'clock this evening the remains of Lieut. Kislingbury, of the Greely expedition, arrived in this city by the West Shore Road. A strange and indefinable odor pervaded the baggage room of Dodd's Express Company, at Cortlandt-street Ferry, yesterday morning. It was impossible to class it under the head of any known nuisance. It was unique and intolerable. It bore a close resemblance to the aroma which proceeds from sauerkraut at the time the succulent dish has reached that stage when, as the Germans say, it "can't smell no smelter."

The valuation of property, as returned by the Assessor, is as follows: Real estate, $488,130,700: gain, $9,811,800; personal, $194,517,300; loss, $9,596,500; total, $682,648,000; net gain, $215,300.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 9.--On Thursday night there was a severe frost in some parts of Northern Michigan. The damage has not been ascertained.

QUEBEC, Aug. 9.--Capt. McLeod, of the bark T. Canning, writes from Bis Island that on the 5th inst. his pilot, Peter Lapierre, of Quebec, anthored his ship on a bank never before discovered, about mid-channel between Mal Bay and Cape Diable. The bank was discovered by throwing the lead in a thick fog. The place has been christened St. Pierre Bank.

Philip Cheetham, who died recently at Stockport, in England, is believed to have been the oldest living Freemason. He was in his ninetyseventh year, and was initiated on Oct. 3, 1811. He had been Past Master at Stockport since 1841, and was Secretary of the lodge for over half a century. His Masonic jubilee was celebrated in 1861.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 9.--In Norfolk County last night a colored man named William Artis was shot and killed by a colored neighbor named John T. Hill. Hill says he thought Artis was stealing melons from his patch, but the facts do not substantiate the charge. A large party of colored people gathered about Hill's house and would have lynched him had not the officers in charge of the prisoner hurried him away.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 9.--A convention of the Burgomasters and Councilors of all the communes in the country assembled in the Town Hall in this city to-day. The room was crowded and much enthusiasm was manifested.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9.--The Department of Agriculture reports the condition of cotton improved in Virginia, Tennessee, Mississippi, Louisiana, and Arkansas. The improvement is especially manifest in Mississippi and Louisiana. In North Carolina and Georgia its average status is unchanged since the July report.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 9.--Gen. Logan has accepted an invitation to visit this city on Thursday next. He will be received by the Grand Army posts of Jefferson, St. Lawrence, and Oswego Counties. His visit will have no political significance. It is proposed to take him down the river on a fast yacht and entertain him to the best of the ability of the Grand Army of the Republic.

This report occasioned a heated discussion, but was finally adopted.

Ex-Mayor Edward Cooper has resigned the position of Chairman of the Democratic State Executive Committee. His reasons are briefly given in a communication which he has sent to the Secretary. QUEBEC, Aug. 11.--During a celebration of mass yesterday in the parish church at St. Sylvestre a messenger arrived and announced the sudden death of Peter Hanley, a merchant. Quite a commotion occurred, and several people left the church. One member of the congregation, Narcisse Letourneau, received so severe a fright that his reason left him and has not since returned.
The extent to which partisanship can blind even a student of history is curiously illustrated by Mr. Thorold Roger's paper on the House of Lords in the August Fortnightly.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 11.--Israel Blatchky, a young Hebrew, who has been in business here for three years past, took strychnine this forenoon and died in two hours. From letters in the suicide's pockets it is learned that he had been an unsuccessful lover, and that he procured the poison at Harlan six months ago.

MADISON, Ind., Aug. 11.--The steamer Mamie Glass, while towing a barge on the Ohio River in front of the city at 9:30 this morning, exploded her boiler and immediately sank. The engineer, George Kellar, and Joseph Lickliter, were killed, two men, named Werhle and Chandler, were injured, and Commodore William Wolf escaped. Kellar's body was recovered.

BLACK RIVER FALLS, Wis., Aug. 11.--The Winnebago Indian is the most conspicuous object of interest about here at present, owing to there being about 1,000 of them attending the payment of the Govermnent annuities.

PARIS, Aug. 11.--The Journal des Debats says that the monetary conference will meet in Paris on Oct. 25. The Latin Monetary Union will be continued, provided the amount of silver coin shall not be increased, and each State undertakes to redeem its silver at the expiration of the period to which the union shall be extended.

SARATOGA, Aug. 11.--Other towns may have been perturbed by the shocks of an earthquake yesterday, but in Saratoga they existed only in the over-sensitive brains of the local editor. There was not enough earthquake here to make an aspen quiver.

The office of St. Mark's Hotel, on Brighton Heights, Staten Island, was besieged all day yesterday by a constant stream of tradespeople, waiters, and hotel employes. It had been reported that William H. Du Hay, lessee of the hotel, had disappeared, leaving a large number of debts unpaid.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 11.--Eliza Hayes died to-night from the effects of a half ounce of arsenic, taken this morning, with intent to kill herself. Her husband, who is a barber, went on an excursion Sunday without her knowledge. This morning she threatened to get even with him. They had been married only a few months. She was 19 years old, and formerly lived in Cleveland.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11.--Myriads of locusts have appeared in Vera Cruz, Mexico, and notwithstanding the immense quantities of them that have been killed great destruction to the crops has resulted.

The Sir Joshua that the Duke of Marlborough is offering to the nation for purchase is not that of the second Duke and family, as stated by the Standard, but of George, fourth Duke, and family. The picture was painted in 1777, Sir Joshua then being in his fifty-fourth year.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 11.--Three sudden deaths took place in this city and suburbs within the past 24 hours. Felix Kaiser, widower, aged 28, was found dead in bed in his boarding house of hemorrhage of the lungs; Mrs. Catharine Sehnelskie, a Polish married woman, died during last night in childbirth, and Josiah Hasbrock, a prominent and wealthy farmer residing at NewPaltz, was found dead in bed this morning.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 11.--West-bound passenger rates are badly demoralized here. The tickets to Kansas points are selling at $5, a cut of nearly $9. A party of 283 persons from Eastern Indiana passed west to-day, traveling on round-trip tickets to points in Southwest Kansas, for which they paid $12 each, a cut of 66 per cent. The Eastern rates also cut and tickets are sold at a reduction of $2 and $3.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 12.--This morning a freight train on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad ran off the track on a trestle near North Buffalo, killing the fireman, named Leonard. The engineer saved his life by jumping from the train while it was in motion. Several cars were badly wrecked.
The two hundredth anniversary of the settlement of Worcester, Mass., is to be commemorated on wednesday, Oct. 15, and the City Council has appropriated $5,000 toward the expense.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 12.--Owing to the lack of telegraphic connections the full particulars of the assassination of four Mormon Elders, the killing of a member of the band of assassins, the shooting of a Mormon sympathizer, and the wounding of a lady on Cane Creek, Lewis County, were not received until to-day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12.--During the temporary absence of the Chief of Engineers, col. John G. Parke, Corps of Engineers, will, by direction of the President, act as Chief of Engineers and perform his duties.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 12.--Notices of a reduction of 5 per cent. in the wages of the weavers in the Barnaby Gingham Mill in this city have been posted. The reduction goes into effect on the 16th inst. and is made on account of the depression of the market for their goods.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 12.--At Granville the roofing slate already manufactured is amply sufficient to supply the demand for a year to come. The prospects are that part or all of the mills will stop the manufacture of slate soon until there is a demand for it.

VILLA RICA, Ga., Aug. 12.--Mr. W.W Williams, of Villa Rica, has sold his farm to a mining company of Louisville, Ry. This makes the third company that will soon be at work here. The gold mining fever in this section is rising.
BELLAIRE, Ohio, Aug. 12.--At 12:30 o'clock this morning four men left this city in a skiff for the West Virginia side of the river. The load was too great for the boat, and just after ...
GRANITE FALLS, Minn., Aug. 12.--A terrible accident happened here to-day. While two men were engaged blasting with dynamite the charge exploded, killing one--Robert J. Hight-- almost instantly.

EUFAULA, Ala., Aug. 12.--A controversy having arisen among local politicians as to whether John Kelly voted for Tilden and Hendricks in 1876, and the charge being made and denied that Tammany Hall would not support Cleveland and Hendricks, Mr. Kelly was written ...

During the approaching session of the Grand Lodge of the Independent Order of Odd Fellow, which is to be held in this city, it is proposed by his friends of the press to tender to Brother A.O. Bunnell, of Dansville, Livingston ...
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 12.--Lighthouse Inspector Hutchins has partially investigated the charges against some of the officials on Sable Island in relation to the alleged improper ...

The Republicans in Maine are making a strong effort to carry that State at the September election by a good majority, and they seem to be fairly united. The two Senators and four Representatives in Congress, the latter being all candidates for re-election, are going to stump the State with vigor and will have the aid of a number of imported speakers.

Dr. Thaddeus J. Keane, the House Surgeon at St. Vincent's Hospital, was the complainant yesterday at the Jefferson Market Police Court against Joseph Gallagher, aged 19, a waiter, who says that he lives at No. 262 Bowery.

MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 12.--The Italian bark Richetta, Rivera, master, loaded with timber and lumber, and awaiting a crew in the Lower Bay, was discovered early yesterday morning on fire aft. The towboat Rolla hastened alongside and put hose on board.
LIMA, Aug. 12, via Galveston.--The exile of Senor Quimper, a member of one of the party of Commissioners which sought to arrange a peace between Gen. Caceres and Gen. Igtesias, ...

The sun was just rising from a poultryyard in Morrisania when a small boat shot out from the pier opposite the penitentiary on Blackwell's Island and bowled swiftly toward the foot of Forty-seventh-street.

Mr. Henry N. Beers, the active leader of the Council of Political Reform, was sitting quietly in his residence at No. 216 East Fourteenth-street, yesterday, when he heard his servant, Matilda Nilson, scream for help.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 12.--Arthur Griswold, a chronically insane patient at the State Insane Asylum, committed suicide to-day by jumping from a window of the fourth story of the building, receiving injuries from the effects of which he died shortly after.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 12.--With bright and clear weather on this the second regular day of the second meeting of the Saratoga Association the attendance was the largest of the season.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 12.--The story that Charles B. Henry, a member of the Greely expedition, was shot for stealing rations and that his body was eaten by his comrades, has caused considerable excitement here. Henry's real name was Back. His sister and friends in this city will push an investigation.

Pressmen Samuel Wood and Charles Koeler, who are employed in Dick Stecker's printing house, at No. 252 Mercer-street, were cutting the edges of pamphlets shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon on the top floor of the four-story brick building which is occupied by the firm, when they saw a black column of smoke arise from beneath them and fill the cutting and binding room, where there were 25 girls employed.

NEWFIELD, N.Y., Aug. 12.--A letter from a resident of Havana, N.Y., to a gentleman in this village tells the following very singular story: A year ago this month a note was left at the drug store of Dr. McCorn, in Havana, by a boy who said he had been hired by a man to deliver it.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 12.--A fair attendance was present at the opening of the August trotting meeting in this city. On the programme for the day were races for the 2:30 and 2:21 trotting classes and an attempt of Westmont to beat his record ...
Counsel for John Carpenter, who was convicted on July 5 of murder in the first degree, for killing his wife Mary, and was sentenced to be hanged on Aug. 29, filed an appeal yesterday ...

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Aug. 12.--In a fight between colored people at Sterling, a negro woman, whose favor was in dispute between two suitors, was shot and killed by one of them. Mr. Halsendorf, a merchant, was probably fatally wounded by a flying bullet. He fired at his supposed adversary, wounding him seriously.

WATKINS, N.Y., Aug. 12.--Between 4,000 and 5,000 people have been in attendance at the regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen on Seneca Lake, in Watkins, to-day, the first day of the regatta.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 12.--The date when the peace-loving and military-tax-hating Quakers of Ledyard will hold the seventeenth annual meeting of the Connecticut Peace Society has been fixed for Aug. 20 and 21.

After the Colwell Lead Company had begun to make an excavation for a vault in front of its premises at Sixth-avenue and Thirtyninth-street the Metropolitan Telegraph and Telephone Company found that some of its poles were likely to drop into the hole.

Commercial travelers stopping at the Astor House have been missing their goods for some time past from the show room where they were displayed, and Patrick Kenny, the elevator man, was arrested on suspicion.

There recently arrived at one of the hotels in Paris a young woman named Pauline A--, who paid a week's rent in advance and two days afterward was found hanging behind the door in her room. Life was extinct. In her dress was found a pocketbook containing 60,000f. in bank notes.
Major-Gen. William Hoffman died at his home in Rock Island, Ill., yesterday, after a severe illness of two weeks. The deceased was born in New-York City and was 76 years of age.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 12.--The day of the Salvation Army in New-Haven is apparently drawing to a close. Its experiences in this city have been varied and its success in making converts invariably poor. Among the singing soldiers who were cut in the Sunday night row was Capt. Hunter, the Commissionary for the State of Connecticut.
Lieut. Campbell, the British officer whose desire to thoroughly investigate New-York life recently led him into difficulties, appeared yesterday at Castle Garden dressed in a good suit of clothes.

The Independent Steamboat Company, running boats from Starin's pier to points along the North Shore of Staten Island, continued yesterday to make excursion trips on schedule time despite the injunction proceedings of Monday.

HOTEL KAATERSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 12.--At 10 o'clock to-night the Opera House adjoining the Hotel Kaaterskill was the scene of brilliant and fashionable gathering in honor of President Arthur, a ball being tendered by Mr. George Harding. This was the crowning event of the present season.
FOUNTAIN CITY, Minn., Aug. 12.--William Kurt and Jasper Keller, farmers, quarreled about cattle to-day, when Kurt shot the other dead. The murderer was taken to Alma to prevent his being lynched.

At day break yesterday morning Patrolman Charles H. Albertson, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, while at Broadway and seventeenthstreet, noticed a young man coming down Broadway carrying a well-filled valise.

The Monmouth Park Association was favored yesterday with a good day and track for almost the first time this season, and in consequence the races were interesting to all the participants, spectators, judges, timers, bookmakers, jockeys, and possibly the Horses.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 12.--Reports obtained by the Troy Times of the condition of the harvested and growing crop throughout a large portion of Northern, Eastern, and Central NewYork and in Vermont and Western Massachusetts show that the hay crop is from one-half to two-thirds of an average crop.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 12.--The Fifth Congressional District Democratic Convention meets in this ancient town to-morrow, and bids fair to be quite an interesting and spirited gathering. In fact, no convention held in the champion apple-whisky county in the Union could very well be other than spirited.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 12.--The Allegheny Baseball Club is negotiating with the manager of the Cleveland nine for the transfer of the remaining players of the Cleveland Club to this city.

TALLULAH, Ga., Aug. 12.--Lemuel T. Williams, Division Superintendent of the Atlanta and Charlotte Railroad, committed suicide today at Terra by taking morphine. Overwork is supposed to have been the cause of the rash act. He was one of the most popular officers of the road. He leaves a widow and one child.

The interesting and impassioned Senator BLAIR, of New-Hampshire, has reappeared in Washington to remark, gloomily, that he supposes Secretary CHANDLER and ex-Senator ROLLINS will be candidates for the Senatorial vacancy in New-Hampshire to be occasioned next Winter by the expiration of his own term.
HURON, Dakota, Aug. 12.--The unsecured liabilities of the Bank of Huron, which made an assignment yesterday, is understood to be about $8,000, mostly to depositors.

MARSEILLES, Aug. 12.--In the 24 hours ending at 8:30 this morning there were 11 deaths here from cholera. One death occurred in Toulon to-day. More persons have been attacked than on any day recently, but the character of the disease is much milder than formerly.
The agent of the Netherlands-American Steamship Company stated yesterday that he had received further information from the stranded Amsterdam. There was still some hope of saving the vessel.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 12.--A man who registered at a hotel here under the name of John W. Johnson, of New-York, died in the hospital last night from the effects of chloral, supposed to have been taken with suicidal intent.

McKEESPORT, Penn., Aug. 12.--During the temporary absence of their mother to-day two young Swedish children attempted to pour a can of coal oil on the fire in the kitchen stove at their home, and in the explosion which followed both children were fatally burned.

Richard Elias, who keeps a store at No. 825 Broadway for the sale of what are known as Parisian diamonds, was taken before Justice Kilbreth, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, charged with the larceny of a diamond ring.
HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 12.--At the Hudson Driving Park to-day the race for the 2:27 class trotters was won by Harry Mills. Troublesome took second place, W.K. third, and Leon Boy ...

CIRCLEVILLE, Ohio, Aug. 12.--Three children named Robert Wood, Louis D. Wood, and Kate Shaw, all under 10 years of age, living on a farm near South Perry, Ohio, were burned to death to-day in a barn, where they had been smoking, and which they had set on fire.

From time to time reports reach the press that the Postmaster-General is devoting himself to an overhauling of the bureaus of his department, the results of which will shed considerable credit upon the close of his administration.

ALBANY, Aug. 12.--The programme for Gen. Logan's trip through the State was finally completed to-day. He will leave Herkimer on a special train for Utica early Thursday morning, accompanied by his wife, ...

CHICAGO, Aug. 12.--The establishment of the Chicago Wire and Iron Works was closed by the Sheriff to-day, on a writ of attachment taken out by Graham, Emlem Passmore, of Philadelphia. The concern is a branch establishment of the E.T. Barnum ...

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 12.--Samuel Drew, ex-Prosecuting County Attorney, who was arrested last week on a charge of embezzlement, was dismissed this morning, the prosecuting witnesses failing to appear against him.

Father James McCarthy, the priest who was on Monday committed by Justice Power at Jefferson Market Police Court to Blackwell's Island in default of $400 bail for his good behavior on a charge of disorderly conduct, remained a prisoner in the Jefferson Market Prison during the night.

Just before the close of the afternoon session of the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday a well-dressed lady, stout and good looking, appeared before Justice Kilbreth, and applied for a warrant for the arrest of Mrs. Florence C. Mayo, the proprietress of the Imperial Hotel, at No. 3 East Fourteenth-street.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 12.--The Democratic Convention of Lackawanna County, held here to-day, was one of the stormiest political gatherings ever addressed in Pennsylvania, owing to the fierce contention for the Judgeship, which has been waged on behalf of Judge Handley and Mr. Edward Merrifield.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 12.--The substitute race of the New-York Yacht Club over the triangular course to Sow and Pigs Lightship and Block Island, returning to the starting point at Bronton's Reef Lightship was begun this morning.
Postmaster Pearson has been informed, by telegram from San Francisco, that the Steamship Australia arrived at that port on Monday last with mails from Australia.

The Executive Committe of the Democratic State Committee met yesterday at the Hoffman House, and elected William E. Smith chairman in place of Edward Cooper, resigned. The other officers are: John O'Brien, Secretary; ...
DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 12.--The Republican State Convention meets in this city tomorrow to nominate a full State ticket. The entire interest centres in the nomination for Governor.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 12.--James M. Marvin called to order the Saratoga Monumental Association at the United States Hotel this morning. Letters of regret at their inability to attend were read from George William Curtis, S.S. Cox, Charles K. Graham, and others.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12.--This was the fourteenth regular day of the midsummer meeting at the Chicago Driving Park. The weather was very warm, the track fact, and the attendance good.

A young woman who was taken to Bellevue Hospital on Monday night from a drug store at Forty-seventh-street and Fifth-avenue was the object of much interest yesterday, because, although poorly and dowdily clad, she was comely, young, intelligent, cultured, modest, and mysterious when questioned about as attempt she had made to destroy herself with laudanum.

ASSOUAN, Aug. 12.--Orders have been issued for the preparation of a camp for a British regiment at Wady Halfa. Forage for 700 horses has been sent to that post. Everything indicates an early advance from Cairo.

BRADFORD, Penn., Aug. 12.--After years of overproduction of petroleum in the Pennsylvania oil regions and the failure of several attempts to bring about an organized cessation of production until such times as the state of the ...
FORTRESS MONROE, Virginia, Aug. 12.--The Hon. Robert T. Lincoln. Secretary of War, accompanied by Gen. Tidhall and staff and a number of the officers of the garrison, paid a visit to ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 12.--To-day the Derby Railroad Directors elected Joel A. Sperry, of this city, President, and George P. Cowles, Director, to fill the vacancies caused by the death of J.H. Bartholomew.
LANCASTER, S.C., Aug. 12.--For some time past a feud has existed between the family John Bowers and that of B.F. Welsh, on account of the manner in which Bowers has spoken of the elder Welsh.

Ah Yeam, a Chinese laundryman, quarreled with his boss, Ah Sink who lives at No.116 Canal-street, and is a younger man. Yeam thought that Sing was trying to cheat him in a money transaction yesterday at 11:30 A. M., ...

The announcement that yesterday would be the "great temperance day" at the Sing Sing Camp Meeting had the effect of drawing a large attendance, many being present from the adjacent country and this city. Among the latter were the Rev. Dr. J.P. Newman and the Hon. Chauncey--Shaffer.
In the American Yacht Club race the Rival won the first prize in the second class. She was sold the day before the race by J. M. Seymour to J.A. Baker, his business partner.

At last there has come from a court of competent jurisdiction a declaration that telegraph and telephone poles and wires are street incumbrances, and that the Legislature never had power to authorize their maintenance against the will of individual landowners.
Selina Winton, the young woman who tried to drown herself by jumping from a Jersey City ferryboat on Monday night, was yesterday sent to her home at No. 46 Wales-avenue.

PORTSMOUTH, Aug. 12.--The recital of this new phase in the already frightful story of the last Winter of the Greely party, how men crazed or stupefied by the pangs of hunger and the terrible cold, fed on the bodies of their companions, is here in this quiet town so closely interested in the unhappy expedition received with a general feeling of horror.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 12.--The arrest of Morris L. Cohn, a prominent Chicago merchant, who was yesterday arraigned and held for trial in $10,000 bond to answor numerous charges of forgery, has created a genuine sensation in Hebrew circles over the Northwest.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 12.--The Grand Grove of Druids of the United States met in its twenty-fifth annual conclave here this morning, 156 subordinate lodges, with a membership of ...

The Virginia Club was badly defeated by the Metropolitans on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Richmond men took a lead of 4 runs in the first inning and managed to hold a good advantage over the local players until the fifth inning, when the "Mets" batted hard and, assisted ...

BOSTON, Aug. 12.--The general impression here that the Butler Presidential candidacy is princivally directed to helping the Blaine and Logan ticket is receiving confirmation by many significant facts.

Very few of the crew of the two relief vessels which reached Greely's desolate camp were a permitted to see the bodies of the dead. When their condition was discovered and the horrible fact was apparent that cannibalism had been resorted to, the officers of the two vessels took every precaution to keep the fact from the sailors.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 12.--The announcement that Senator Henry L. Dawes, of Massachusetts, would address the Republicans of this village drew together at the Englewood Athenaeum to-night about 300 voters, and half that number of ladies and boys.

Now that the appreciable phenomena of Sunday's earthquake have been gathered in the newspapers the event is beginning to get the benefit of scientific inquiry. The fact is noted that the extent of the shock coincides with the geological formation known as the triassic rocks, which reach, in narrow regions, parallel to the coast line, from Nova Scotia to North Carolina, and from the ocean to the Alleghanies in their widest range.

When GREELY went into voluntary exile on the northern shore of Lady Franklin Bay he was confident that his colony could remain in safety for two years within 500 miles of the pole. He was anxious only about his departure at the end of that time.
MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 12.--The members of the British Association are arriving here in great numbers.

AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 12.--A queer case of "conscience money" has occurred here. Some days ago A.D. Millerd, a piano tuner, not supposed to be wealthy, paid to the City Treasurer the sum of $900, giving as his only reason "that the assessors had slighted him."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12.--The account in THE TIMES of the extremities to which the Greely party was reduced to sustain life was the chief topic of conversation in the War and Navy Departments to-day.

ELMIRA. N.Y., Aug. 12.--The city was thronged to-day with colored people from this State and Pennsylvania. At 2 o'clock a parade of fire companies and of the Palmer Guards of Ithaca and of other civic orders took place. The line of carriages following the parade was a long one. The procession formed on Lake-street and marched through Water, Main, and Clinton streets to the City Park, where the principal exercises were held.

A national convention of the Ancient Order of Hibernians, called by Hugh Murray, County Delegate of New-York, began its session yesterday at No. 232 West Thirtieth-street. Fitteen States were represented, including NewYork, New-Jersey, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, Maine, Connecticut, Delaware, Illinois, and Indiana.

Many spectators were attracted to Camp Farnsworth, at Fort Wadsworth, yesterday morning, when the band of the Twelfth Regiment played lively music at reveille. As the deafening racket made by the drums ceased, Col. Jones poked his head between the flies at the entrance to his tent and surveyed the members of his command. They were taking their morning ablutions behind their respective tents.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 12.--The Millers' Association has sent out to its buyers in the country the opening prices to be paid for new wheat. The prices are as follows, based on delivery at Minneapolis: No. 1 hard, 85 cents; No. 2 hard, 80 cents; No. 1, 75 cents; No. 2, 70 cents.
Pat Rooney, "comedian," of Harlem, lately became the proud possessor of a Yorkshire poodle, about which he boasted to everybody whom he met on the Rialto.

There was a well-attended meeting last evening of the Democratic General Committee of Kings County, in the Athenaeum, on Atlanticavenue, near Clinton-street, Brooklyn. Augustus van Wyck presided, and in a long address spoke of the Democratic platform and the Democratic candidates.
In the case of George F. Cummings against the New-York Concert Company, limited, (the Casino case,) the attorney for the Aronsons obtained an order last Suturday giving ...
