Mr. and Mrs. John F. Trow celebrated their golden wedding yesterday at the home of their daughter, Mrs. Aaron Carter, Orange, N. J. Mr. Trow is the publisher of the City Directory, and for years has been well known in New-York.
The seventh annual picnic and summernight's festival of the Grand Lodge of the Kesher Shel Barzel, a prominent Jewish beneficiary organization, was held in Jones's Wood yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12, 1884. Mr. De Meissner, the Second Secretary of the Russian Legation here, has been transferred to the same capacity to Switzerland, and will be succeeded at the Lgation in this city by Alexander Greger. Mr. De Meissner married a daughter of Rear-Admiral Radford, of this city.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12.--A special dispatch from Jefferson City to the Post-Dispatch says: "Chairman O'Day, of the State Central Committee, called the State Democratic Convention to order at 11:15 A. M. After a prayer, Mr. O'Day congratulated the ...
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 12.--O.A. Dorman has received a letter from Capt. John Traynor, who sailed from this port recently for Europe in his dory.

Before the sailing of the Greely relief expedition the principal officers were made honorary members of the American Yacht Club. A set of colors were presented, to be planted on the highest point reached, and the club ensign was intrusted to the expedition.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 12.--At 10 o'clock A. M. Chairman Gawley called the Labor Convention to order James Connolly, of New-York, presented the report of the Committee on Permanent Organization, with the declaration that it had the unanimous sanction of his committee, ...

PARIS, Aug. 12.--The Voltaire gives the following account of the French operations in China: "Admiral Lespes blockaded Kee-Lung on Aug. 5. The Chinese attempted to repel him with a battery of Krupp cannon.
A richly clad boy about 5 years old was found wandering along Third-avenue last evening by a policeman, who took him to Police Headquarters.

Officer Ward, of the Eighth sub-Precinct, Brooklyn, arrested Bartholomew McGarry, of No. 1,004 Fourth-avenue, on Monday morning, for violation of a city ordinance, for which offense McGarry was fined $5.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Aug. 12.--One of the staples of this part of the country is the huckleberry crop. Usually there are thousands of bushels of this excellent berry picked in the adjacent mountains, and those which are not consumed here are shipped to New-York and to Buffalo.

About two years ago THE TIMES gave an account of the lodging houses for men established by the Society for Improving Workingmen's Homes of this city, and at the same time it contrasted these houses with the average ...

Some of the Directors of the wall-Street Bank admitted yesterday that Cashier Dickinson was a defaulter, and that the deficiency would be in the neighborhood of $300,000. Nothing could be learned of the missing Cashier's whereabouts.

AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 12.--A keeper and a patient ran away together last night from the State Asylum for Insane Criminals. Each ward of the asylum has two day attendants, but only one is on duty from 7 to 10 o'clock in the evening.

SARATOGA. N.Y., Aug. 12.--This has been a busy day with the committees of the American Bankers' Association. Their reports are unusually important, and will abridge the business of the convention so as to allow due prominence to be given to the silver question, bank currency basis, and other topics which are to be discussed in the next two days' sessions.

LONDON, Aug. 12.--The case of Mr. Sheldon, the Englishman who is alleged to have been kidnapped in Kansas and to be held for ransom was brought up in the House of Commons today. Arthur Arnold, Liberal, member for Salford, made it a subject of inquiry.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 12.--Judge Hughes, of the United States Court, has rendered a decision in the case of John P. Fauve against the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners.
CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 12.--Charles Crowley, aged 104 years, died at Suncock yesterday. He was a native of Ireland and the oldest person in this State.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 12.--The coal miners sent to the fourth pool to persuade those working at the reduction to come out arrived at Woodsrun late last night, and the men went into camp.

Miss Emma Eloise Ridley, daughter of Edward Ridley, of this city, was married last night at Pleasantville, Weschester County, to Mr. Richard Mott Collins. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Henry Spencer, Pastor of the Episcopal church at Tarrytown.

The call for an international convention at Washington, on Oct. 1, to decide upon a prime meridian has excited the apprehension of the New-York and New-Jersey branches of the International Institute for Preserving and Perfecting Anglo-Saxon. Weights and Measures, lest the convention may also attempt to force upon this country the metric system of France.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 12.--On Sunday morning the Rev. Robert Hardin was assaulted in a public road while riding in his buggy at Hooper's Mills, by "Dock" Wallace, George Argrove and Jacob Fuller, and severely cut with a large knife.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 12.--The village of Hunter, in the Catskills, in Greene County, is just now greatly agitated over the elopement of Mrs. James Hyde, an attractive woman of about 30 Summers.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 12.--The special committee of the Board of Trustees of Hamilton College appointed to consider the difficulties between President Darling and the Faculty began its work in this city to-day.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 12.--The published charges that the Plympton Manufacturing Company and Inspector H.T. Sherry, all of this city, had been the cause of the Post Office Department being defrauded out of $200,000 on account ...

LONDON, Aug. 12.--In the House of Commons this evening the Appropriation bill passed its third reading. Lord Randolph Churchill denounced the enormous growth of the outlay of money, and attacked the management of the Right Hon. Hugh C. Childers, Chancellor of the Exchequer.

William C. Rhinelander took a livelier interest yesterday in the proceedings of the Lunacy Commission, which sat in the Judges' chambers in the Court of General Sessions, to determine the question of his sanity.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12.--The weather continues fair, but rather cold for the hotels. Lulu Hurst had a large and fashionable audience at the Casino to-night. She amused and surprised the young bloods, who were present in large numbers.

POPLAR RIVER, Montana, Aug. 12.--The following are additional details of the Muscle Shell fight: A party of stockmen and their employes, under the leadership of Granville Stewart, left Fort Maginnis on July 5 for Bates Point, 20 miles west of Muscle Shell, to destroy the headquarters of all the horsethieves, highwaymen, , in that section.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12.--At Philo, near Champaign, Ill., last evening, Miss Gertrude J. Boomer passed out through the kitchen, closing the door after her.
An informal conference of members of the Brooklyn Protective Tariff Club and the Anti-Monopoly League and Labor Party was held in Prosser's Hall, Brooklyn, last evening.

OLEAN, N.Y., Aug. 13.--On Saturday, James McGregor, of this place, a salt and oil well tool dresser, met in Washington, N.Y., a salt well driller named Richard O'Neill. There was an old feud between them.

Margaret Young, a respectable Scotchwoman, arrived from Glasgow yesterday on the steamship State of Georgia, with her three children. She expected to meet her husband at Castle Garden. He came here about 11 months ago, and having saved a little money, sent for his wife.

A rectangle of Chinese lanterns ran around a raised platform full of campaign music and young Democrats at Forty-ninth-street and First-avenue last night.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Aug. 13.--At the trial of two brewers of this city, this afternoon, before a Justice of the Peace in a country township near by, a mob of 200 attacked a prosecuting lawyer named W. H. Bailey, stripped his cloting off, and tarred him.

Berliner Strauss, manufacturers of neckwear at No. 481 Broadway, went around among their creditors yesterday to endeavor to get a settlement, and proposed to pay 25 cents on the dollar in three and six months. WASHINGTON, Aug. 13.--Orders have been issued from the Navy Department for the vessels of the Greely relief expedition to land their surplus stores at the navy yard, New-York, and to remain in commission at that port until further orders.

Mrs. Florence G. Mayo, the proprietress of the Imperial Hotel, No. 3 East Fourteenthstreet, whom Mrs. Editha L. Dis Debar, one of her guests, is endeavoring to have adjudged a lunatic, was at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning to answer the charge preferred by Mrs. Dis Debar.
TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 13.--The Salvation Army was mobbed here last night and pelted with rotten eggs.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Aug. 13.--The Kilgour Blue Stone Company have just completed arrangements to give their employes of the various quarries operated by them an excursion to Coney Island on Friday next.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 13.--The preliminary arrangements for the coming professional-amateur rowing regatta are being made. It is proposed to offer very liberal prizes, from $2,000 to $5,000, and to pay the expenses of the oarsmen.

The lawn tennis tournament among the members of the Staten Island Cricket Club was continued yesterday. The courts were surrounded by a very large throng of spectators, two-thirds of whom were ladies. Two very interesting matches took place in the third ties of the gentleman's singles.

The affairs of O.M. Borgart Co., bankers and brokers, of Broadway and Pine-street, who failed in the May panic, are still in litigation, and yesterday an action was brought to set aside the assignment.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13.--The revelations regarding the cannibalism of the Greely party created adecided sensation to-day in the neighborhood of the home of the late Sergt. CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Aug. 13.--Seventy men employed in the car shops here of the Union Pacific Railroad Company struck this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13.--Gen. Hazen has concluded to talk no more to the public about the Greely expedition and its attendant scenes of horror, for which he may yet be held responsible when all the facts are given to the public through an investigation.

WATKINS, N.Y., Aug. 13.--Eight thousand people witnessed the second day's races of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen on Seneca Lake here to-day. The grand stand was filled and hundreds of people watched the regatta from the lake shore.

Buyers from all the leading dry goods houses in the country were present yesterday morning at the auction rooms of Wilmerding. Hoguet Co., Nos. 64 and 66 White-street, to attend a sale of 4,000 cases of white and colored blankets.

LONDON, Aug. 13.--Advices from Shanghai of Aug. 12 say: "The Tsung-li-Yamen announces its determination to resist the French demands. Tamsui, on the northwest coast of Formosa, is being defended by torpedoes.

HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 13.--The race meeting at the Hudson Driving Park was continued to-day. In the race for the 2:38 class trotters Lucy Knox was first, Jesso Walters second. Little Wonder third, and Nellie T. fourth. Time-- 2:37 ; 2:39 ; 2:39 . The race for the 2:32 class was not finished.

A stranger left a Third-avenue car at Fifty-seventh-street at 1 o'clock yesterday morning and walked rapidly toward Second-avenue. "That fellow has got your watch," said young Harry Van Nordin, of No. 222 East Fifty-seventh-streat., to Mangus Levy, a furrier, who had been sitting beside the stranger.

The statement of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad for the past fiscal year was issued yesterday. It is as follows: Gross earnings, $14,351,092.81; operating expenses, (61.48 per cent.,) $8,823,782.56; net earnings, $5,527,310.25; ...
ALBANY, Aug. 13.--A letter received from Upper Saranac Lake, to-day, announces the safe arrival of Gov. Cleveland and Dr. Ward at the Prospect Hotel, on Monday.
SANDUSKY, Ohio, Aug. 13.--John Otto, of this city, was drowned near Lakeside to-day by the upsetting of a rowboat. His body was recovered.

The preliminary injunction obtained by Dr. Andrew H. Smith, of Nos. 20 and 22 East Forty-second-street, restraining the Forty-second-Street, Manhattanville and St. NicholasAvenue Railroad Company from building its road ...

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 13.--The Troy Conference Camp Meeting, which will continue until Monday, began to-day at Round Lake. The sermon to-day was preached by the Rev. C.W. Rowley, of Ganajoharie. To-morrow Baba Ram Chandra Bose, the converted Hindu, will address the missionary meeting.
NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 13.--Miles McPartland, an inmate of the counts jail, has become insane, and yet, strange to say, an insurmountable legal obstacle deprives him of proper treatment.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Aug. 13.--News reached here this evening that M. Selig, a prominent citizen of Memphis and senior member of the firm of M. Selig, clothing dealers, was thrown from a buggy near Marysville and killed. Mr. Selig was an ex-Grand Past Resident of the Independent Order of Benevolent Brethren, and was a prominent Israelite in this section. His body will be takan to Memphis to be interred.

Enthusiastic Republicans of the First Ward of Brooklyn gathered in mass meeting in the Atheneum last evening, and listened, with frequent demonstrations of approval, to speeches on the issues of the campaign. Alderman Theodore D. Dimon presided.
Seventh Iowa District--H.Y. Smith for short term and E.H. Conger for long term, Republican. Second Maine District--W.W. Berry, Greenbacker.

Annie Kuntz, a rather pretty German girl, of No. 219 Fifth-street, has been assiduously courted by Matthew Hunning for a long time. The old folks objected to him, and Annie, wearying of his attentions, gave him notice not to call upon her any more.

While Clerk J.N. Kilroy, of Castle Garden, was attending to his duties in the rotunda yesterday, be observed a pretty immigrant girl, who had just landed from the Guion steamship Nevada, waving her handkerchief to a cheerful young man who was unable to get to her by reason of a strong and guarded railing.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 13.--The Common Council Committee on Sawers are receiving bids for the construction of a sewerage system throughout the city, and the contract will be awarded on Aug. 22 to the lowest bidder.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Aug. 13.--Col. Robert G. Ingersoll, who is here on a lecturing tour in an interview this afternoon, said he would take no active part in the Presidential campaign; that he was tired of politics, and had not read either party platform.

The young woman who was taken to Bellevue Hospital Monday night, apparently under the influuence of laudanum, and who persistently refused to give either her name or her history to the public, told a remarkable story to a lady who visited her at her bedside.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 13.--For the first time in the history of this State and, as far as known, in the United States, a colored man becomes the founder of an institution of charity for the benefit of members of his race.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 13.--The latest news from Bayou Goula is that there is serious trouble in Iberville, resulting from the reduction of laborers' wages on the sugar plantations. The hands on all the places between the Ascension ...

On the evening of last St. Patrick's Day 37 gentlemen of Irish birth sat down to a dinner in honor of the Say, and before the feast was ended a committee was appointed to draft a constitution for the St. Patrick's Club of New-York.

On the 15th of March, 1883, a package of money containing $6,000 was abstracted from a safe in the office of the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railroad Company at Amsterdam, N.Y. This was a portion of the money designed for the payment of the men employed in constructing the road at that point.

Samuel Hazard and Harrs Hannah, two curbstone brokers, came in contact in Newstreet yesterday. Mr. Hazard, as the story went, started the fight, which grew out of a dispute over a transaction. Mr. Hannah was not at all loth, however.

There has been considerable rivalry among the Captains of cat-rigged yachts who cruise around in this end of the Sound as to the speed of their respective boats. Yesterday it culminated in an open sweepstake race for catrigged boats, the entrance fee being $50.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 13.--The General Assembly met at noon to-day in extra session. Over three-quarters of the members of each house answered to the roll calls. A joint committee waited on the Governor to inform him that the Legislature was ready to receive any communication he might wish to make, and subsequently reported that he would communicate ...

BOSTON, Aug. 13.--The delegates to the second annual convention of the Irish National League began to assemble in Faneuil Hall, in this city, at 11:30 o'clock this morning. By noon the body of the hall was pretty well filled with the 800 delegates, and the galleries were crowded with spectators.
The Commercial Advertiser contained yesterday afternoon what purported to be the report of an interview with Commander Schley, of the steamship Thetis.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 13.--W.Y. West, of New-Orleans, who was arrested here on Saturday at the instance of the Ames Iron Works Company, of this city, on a charge of embezzlement, to-day effected a settlement and was released.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Aug. 13.--The publication of the story of cannibalism among the Greely party in THE NEW-YORK TIMES created much excitement among the relatives of Joseph Ellison, whose remains were buried here on Sunday.

John Daly, the dynamite conspirator, who was sentenced to penal servitude for life at Warwick, England, on Aug. 1, it has transpired, is the man who figured so prominently in the mock duel with O'Donovan Rossa in the early part of January, 1833.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 13.--Joseph Werrell, a well-to-do groceryman living at No. 215 Norfolk-street, died suddenly this afternoon.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 13.--Since the killing on Cane Creels, Lewis County, of two Mormon missionaries, and John R. Hutson and Martin Conder, who endeavoted to protect them from violence, and David Hinson, one of the mob, diligent search has been made for the two Elders who were taken to the woods.

The New-York team placed another victory to their credit when they defeated the Philadelphia nine on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The New-Yorks batted in fine style. Coleman pitched for the Philadelphia Club, and his delivery was hit safely 14 times, including a three-base hit and three two-baggers.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 13.--Gad H. Lee, President of the village of Waterford, died suddenly early this morning at Bristol, Conn., while on his way home from a reunion of the Lee family. He was 41 years of age and a member of the Masonic organization. Flags are floating at half mast. The cause of his death was inflammation of the bowels.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 13.--A dispatch from Topeka, Kan., says: "The State Veterinary received advises that the Texas fever has appeared at Pottawatomic, Morris, Wilson, and Johnson Counties--making eight places in the State where the disease exists."

MEDINA, N.Y., Aug. 13.--An accident occurred a mile cast of Medina this afternoon by the breaking away of Haskins Bridge, over the canal, just as a steam thrashing machine, upon which were three men, was passing over it.

The boundless affection which "Is it Alive?" of the museum at Rockaway Beach is daily forced to smother while all the world wonders whether or not "it" is alive, has been lavished upon Mr. "Tony" Yreman, the proprietor of the skating rink.

The Bankers' Association, which opened its annual meeting at Saratoga yesterday, promptly took up two of the matters which are of the greatest importance at the present moment--the course to be pursued by banks in a time of panic, and the silver coinage.
On the National Line pier yesterday were Ellen Eaton, an Englishwoman, her husband and brother, all of whom were about to sail on the America.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Aug. 13. --The Government has seized a number of revolutionary circulars in a printing office belonging to Gen. Perez Jardon. Three other Generals are implicated. They were all arrested and imprisoned. Gen. Jardon formerly edited an opposition newspaper, the Constitutional.
PHIILADELPHIA, Aug. 13.--In a contest marked by hard hitting and sharp fielding the champion Athletics to-day defeated the NewYork Metropolitans by a score of 8 to 7.

LONDON, Aug. 13.--Later reports indicate that the thunderstorms which swept over the north of England and Scotland yesterday were of almost unexampled severity. Many buildings in Edinburgh, in Leith, and other cities were partially demolished by the lightning.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Aug. 13.--E. Newton Rowell, who was acquitted last January for killing Johnson L. Lynch, the Utica lawyer, arrived in Batavia last night from the eastern part of the State, where he has been spending four or five days with his wife, whose relations with Lunch brought about the tragedy.

Ex-Congressman J.M. Thornburgh, of Tennessee, is at the Astor House. Congressman William W. Eaton, of Connecticut, is at the New-York Hotel.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 13.--In response to the warrant issued for her arrest Mrs. Dr. Dora B. Chase, whose courses of lectures to "gentlemen only" and "ladies only" have given her much notoriety of late, appeared in the Municipal Court yesterday afternoon.

The election of a Republican (Holt) to the Court of Appeals of Kentucky, the highest court in the State, in one of the appellate districts, over Riddle, his Democratic opponent, is auother chapter in a most distressing piece of history. Kentucky is a Democratic State, and the district in which Holt is elected is Democratic, too; his election, therefore, is an event that has a special explanation.

William L. Wood, a, wealthy widower, who has for 20 years lived at No. 1,107 Myrtleavenue, Brooklyn, has shown frequent signs of a species of melancholia for some months.

At the request of Mr. Martin I. Cooley, of Bates, Reed Cooley, a general alarm has been sent to all police stations in regard to G.W. Lawrence, a banker and merchant of North Manchester, Ind., who on the 6th inst. escaped from the Indiana Insane Hospital.

VIENNA, Aug. 13.--Count Kalnoky, the Austro-Hungarian Prime Minister, wll visit Prince Bismarck at Varzin. Prince Bismarck's health prevented his journey to Gastein.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 13.--There was a large attendance at the second day of Grand Circuit races in this city to-day, for which the programme was the 2:25 trotting class, for a purse of $1,500, divided; the 2:20 pacing race, for a purse of $1,000, divided; the 2:23 class, trotting, for a $1,500 purse divided.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10, 1884. The new silver vault of the Treasury Department is at last completed, and within a few days will receive its first consignment of standard dollars--about five million in all. It will require the better part of a week to make this transfer from the old vault, which is badly overcrowded, to the new one.
"A Reader."--THE TIMES became a twocent paper on its thirty-second birthday, Sept. 18, 1883.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 13.--Thousands of dollars are invested in the grape-growing industry along the Hudson River between Coeymans and Cornwall, and stories have been rife for a day or two that the wet and extraordinary Summer weather experienced so far had greatly affected the growing crops.
The working of a hand fire-extinguisher of a new design was exhibited in front of the City Hall yesterday afternoon in the presence of a large crowd.

SHANERS, Penn., Aug. 13.--An extensive fire occurred here about 1 o'clock this morning. It originated in a block of houses occupied by coal miners, and before it was checked had destroyed the entire block, rendering 14 families homeless. Many of these lost their household goods, and several narrowly escaped death. A spark from a passing engine is supposed to have started the conflagration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13.--Major Alex. M. Miller, Corps of Engineers, has been relieved from duty as a member of the board of engineer officers on the building and repair of levees on the Mississippi River. He will turn over temporarily to Capt. Clinton B. Sears, Corps of Engineers, the charge of the Second District ...

R.A. Allen, Indian Agent at the Blackfeet Ageney. Montana, telegraphed to-day that there were sufficient supplies at the agency for present need. Reports have recently been published that the Indians of the agency were starving.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 13.--The Board of Governors of the Hebrew Union College reelected B. Bettman President. The Rev. Dr. Zindorf, of Detroit, Mich., was elected Professor of History and Hebrew Literature.

BOSTON, Aug. 13.--Access to the convalescent survivors of the arctic expedition at Portsmouth, which last evening had been peremptorily refused by Secretary Chandler and the surgeon in charge, was finally gained to-day by Col. Kent, and the result of his interview was telegraphed to the Traveller, of this city.

The announcement that for the Fall meeting at Creedmoor there will be four new matches and an increase of nearly one-third over last year in the aggregate value of the prizes offered by the National Rifle Association indicates fresh energy in the management of the range.
Dempsey, the pugilist who fought Fulljames on Great Kills Point, Staten Island, was formally placed on trial at the county seat of Richmond County yesterday, in Justice Young's court.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 13.--A large number of responses to the circular sent out by George H. Hull Co., of Louisville, regarding the banking-up project to restrict the production of pig iron are being received daily by Joseph D. Weeks, of this city.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 13.--Frank Williams, a prominent citizen of Buffalo, 57 years old, died suddenly at his house this morning.

GALVESTON, Texas, Aug. 13.--A News dispatch from Cotulla, Texas, says: "Green McCullough yesterday gratified a grudge against Charles A. Bragg, a recent arrival, by killing him with a rifle as his victim was standing in conversation with his back turned. McCullough was arrested. At midnight he was taken out and hanged by a mob of over a hundred citizens."

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 13.--The session of the Seventh Congressional District Republican Convection at Winterset to-day was short and fairly harmonious. Major E.H. Conger, now State Treasurer, was nominated for the full term on the first ballot.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 13.--Town and county caucuses were held last evening and unanimously indorsed the Hon. Charles R. Skinner for renomination in this Congressional district. The Hon. A.X. Parker is also a candidate.

Norwich boasts that there are two square miles of pond lilies not far from its borders. "A party fit to live and with worthy work to do," says the Boston Advertiser, "is benfited, not harmed, by the discipline of deserved defeat."

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Aug. 13.--Lieut. Greely was seen by an Associated Press reporter in his cottage on Seavey's Island this afternoon. He gave an account of the various events of the latter part of the retreat southward from Fort Conger.

SARATOGA, N.Y, Aug. 13.--The attendance at the races here to-day was good. The weather was fine and the track last. MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 13.--Henry Bulmer, one of the Directors of the defunct Exchange Bank, has been committed for trial on the charge of obtaining undue preference from the bank after its collapse.

The dedication of the monument to the memory of Mrs. Eunice Williams, of Deerfield, wife or the Rev. John Williams, who was slain by her Indian captor March 1, 1704, occurred yesday among the Leydon hills with much ceremony, and in the presence of 1,500 people from the surrounding country.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 13.--The Democratic State Convention at Jefferson City reassembled at 10 o'clock this morning and completed the nomination of the State ticket as follows: For Lieutenant-Governor--A.P. Morehouse; for Secretary of State--Michael K. McGrath; for State Treasurer--James M. Siebert; for Auditor--John Walker; for Register of Lands--Robert McCullagh.
There was dreariness and desolation at the pier of the Independent Steamboat Company at the foot of Cortlandt-street yesterday. No jostling crowd of Staten Islanders were brought up in the morning.

LONDON, Aug. 13.--A disatch from Simla says: "Two battalions of British troops, under relief orders for England, are to go to Egypt. The Indian Government opposes the depletion of the British force in India."

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 13.--The opening Republican meeting of the campaign was held to-night at Washington Hall, which was packed with a large and enthusiastic audience, half of whom stood patiently for two hours listening to speeches. Ex-Mayor Tuttle presided and made a brief but stirring and humorous speech.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 13.--The "skin game" of a polished and rather handsome adventuress and her methods were learned by a TIMES correspondent to-night. Her field of operations for six weeks past has been in the Hudson River counties, principally in Rockland, Westchester, Putnam, Dutchess, and Orange.

The grocerymen who toil from early morn until late at night cast aside their aprons yesterday and, with their families, assembled in Washington Paris to attend the third annual picnic and Summer night's festival of the New York Retail Grocers' Union.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES this morning gives the greatest prominence to a statement that the Greely survivors only kept themselves alive by feeding upon the corpses of their comrades. This horrible disclosure has been suspected ever since the party reached St. John's, and there was evident reticence on the part of the rescued men to tell all they knew.

Enough has keen learned about the transactions of Cashier John P. Dickinson to point to the conclusion that he was not alone in the job of wrecking the Wall-Street Bank. The character of some of the loans that he made is indicative of collusion on the part of certain favored borrowers.

AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 13.--William Hall and Michael Fitzpatrick, of New-York, the keeper and convict who escaped from the asylum for insane criminals on Monday night, were captured this evening at Moravia, 17 miles south of here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13.--A gentleman who can be vouched for as trustworthy, and who was at Deer Park prior to, during, and after the conference which the Hon. Stephen B. Elkins had with Greenbackers and Republicans recently, makes some admissions concerning events in that locality which are well worth considering.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 13.--The national convention of the Amalgamated Association adjourned sine die this afternoon after re-electing the old officers as follows: President--William Weilie: Secretary--William Martin, and Treasurer--James Penny. The next convention will be held at Wheeling, West Va., in August, 1885.
MARSEILLES, Aug. 13.--During the 24 hours ending to-night 12 deaths occurred here from cholera. There was one death at Rians.
BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 13.--Fire thoroughly gutted the four-story brick building Nos. 108, 110, and 112 Beach-street, owned by Henry Faxon, this morning.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 13.--A meeting was held to-day at the office of Commissioner Vining, of the Western Trunk Line Association, to consider the withdrawal of the Northwestern Railroad from the tripartite pool, but owing to the absence of the Union Pacific and Wabash Railroad Companies representatives no action was taken.

The exhibit for the Cincinnati and Louisville expositions, which are being prepared respectively on the Thetis and Bear, vessels of the arctic relief expedition, will probably be ready for shipment to-day.
ERIE, Penn., Aug. 13.--About 3 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in the drug store of Brookins Fleming, at North East, in this county, and spread rapidly.

Two days ago the quarterly report of the Commissioner of Public Works was noticed in THE TIMES. It was there in stated that the supply of water from the Bronx River would be introduced into the city next month.
"The Seven Havens" will be brought forward at Niblo's next Monday night to eclipse the glories of "The Black Crook."

Judge Bartlett decided yesterday, in Supreme Court, Chambers, not to grant a stay of proceedings by the Commissioners of Emigration for the return of Aram Slovitz to Europe as a person who, if allowed to remain here, would probably become a burden on the community.
A sub-committee of the Committee of Arrangements for the Butler mass meeting to be held in this city wrote to the Hon. Charles A. Dana, under date of Aug. 12, asking him to preside at the meeting.

NORWICH, Aug. 13.--Two Norwich boys, Alfred Aiken, son of Gen. William A. Aiken, and a son of the Rev. Dr. Jewett, are happy over a service they rendered Jay Gould, in towing his disabled steam launch to the yacht Atalanta, in New-London Harbor, one day last week.
OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 13.--Both the Republican District Conventions of this county today unanimously authorized Congressman Nutting to name the delegates to the Congressional Convention.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 13.--Among the other nominations made by the Georgia Democratic Convention to-day was that of the Hon. Nathan Barnett, for Secretary of State. Mr. Barnett is perhaps one of the oldest officeholders in the world, being now 90 years of age, and having held his present office since 1842.

A greet number of old-time Methodists assembled on the Sing Sing Camp Meeting Ground yesterday, it having been announced that Wednesday was to be devoted to the reunion of the old Methodists, and that the exercises would be conducted as much as possible after the manner of the early days of the church.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13.--This has been a dreary day indeed. A drizzling rain fell nearly all day, and a cold wind blew from the northeast. Fires and thick clothing were in demand. Notwithstanding the disbanding of the yacht squadron, many yards of all descriptions are in the harbor to-night.

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 13.--The Democratic State and Congressional Conventions will be held as follows: The State Contention at Concord on Wednesday, Sept. 10: First District Congressional Convention at Portsmouth on Sept. 11; Second District at Concord on Sept. 10.

The oldest clergyman in the Church of England is believed to be Richard Moore, Vicar of Lund-in-the-Fylde, Lancashire. On a recent Sunday he completed his ninety-fourth year. He was ordained in 1815, and his health is still good. He is also the senior Justice in Lancashire, having been appointed by the Crown in 1820.

ALBANY, Aug. 14.--Gov. Cleveland does not get entirely rid of official work, even in the recessss of the Adirondacks. A letter was received from him at the Executive Chamber to day, transmitting papers removing Orin Sperry, the defaulting Treasurer of Chautauqua County, for maladministration and malversation. The Governor is in excellent health.

NEWBURG, Aug. 14.--The stories sent out from this city relative to the failure and flight of Henry Hall, Sr., the manufacturer of fishing tackle, are said to represent the affair in altogether a wrong light. So far as Mr. Hall's prominence in church matters and active interest in village improvements go the accounts are all right.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 14.--Seventy men employed on the new Fairmount Reservoir on being paid off to-day were informed that their wages would hereafter be cut from $1 50 to $1 25 per day. They all quit work in a body, and some of them grew so riotous that three arrests were made. All is now quiet.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14.--The Metropolitans turned the tables on the champion Athletics to-day in a game that was almost as exciting and well played as that of yesterday, the visitors winning in the last inning by a score of 6 to 5.

A report by the Commissioners of Accounts of an examination of the affairs of the Park Department for the years 1881, 1882, and 1883 was yesterday made public by Mayor Edson, to whom it was submitted on June 21. The Commissioners state that they made a thorough examination of all the books, vouchers, and other records in the department.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 14.--Adam Tillman came from Germany to Paterson about 14 days ago, bringing with him Jacob Hurtz, aged 16. Hurtz had a brother who came from Germany a year ago, and lives on River-street, this city.

Hazen, Chief Signal Officer, has secured the consent of the Postmaster-General to hoist the cold wave flag on Post Office buildings throughout the country to signal, for the benefit of farmers and others, the approach of cold waves. BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 15.--Owing to the endeavor of E.K. WASHINGTON, Penn., Aug. 15.--The careless use of firearms last night resulted in the death of Ethel, the young daughter of James Crooker, who resides just outside the borough of Canonsburg. The load struck the child in the back and passed through, making a fatal wound.

LONDON, Aug. 15.--In the Mineing-Lane markets sugar is extremely dull. Beet root sugar has declined 3d. Refined sugar is in moderate demand at a slight decline. Peppers are firm, but sales are limited.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Aug. 17.--Henry Evans, a colored barber, was shot and killed yesterday evening by Dr. R.J. Kirshner, the County Coroner. The latter has surrendered himself to the police. The killing was done on account of Evans abusing the doctor's father, 64 years of age.

The Queen's Meissonier, "La Rixe," which was sent from Windsor to the recent exhibition of the artist's works in Paris, will go to Germany before it returns to England. The Crown Princess has secured from the Queen permission for it to be exhibited at Berlin.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Aug. 17.-- It is reported authoritatively that Gens. Ramirez, Mejia, and two others, implicated in the recent foolhardy conspiracy, have been shot, by order of the President.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 17.--News reached here to-day of an outbreak in Accomack County, on the eastern shore of Virginia, which was attended with serious results.

A summons has been issued against Lonoon Druilliard, of Dog Point, for fishing without a license. The manner in which Druilliard breaks the fishing law is rather curious. Instead of taking a net and fishing he has a flock of 30 geese.

WILKESBARRE, Aug. 17.--Charles Brown, said to have originally come here from Washington, was arrested this morning by United States Marshal Barring on information furnished by the pension authorities at Washington charging him with fraudulently defrauding pensioners.

Gen. Hazen, Chief of the Signal Service Bureau at Washington, stands officially responsible for the mismanagement and inefficiency which ended in the horrible scenes at Cape Sabine. It is now nearly a year and a half ago...

I have had a long and interesting interview with Mr. Stanley, during which he told me much concerning his work on the Congo. and expressed his opinion pretty freely as to the position of affairs in Africa generally and the probable future development of a continent for which he has done so much.
The Osservatore Romano has published the Latin decree of the Congregation of Rites, confirming the discovery of the remains of St. James the Greater, recently found in the Cathedral of Santiago.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 17.--The attorneys here, hired by the distillers' pool to shut up the International Distillery under the State liquor law, caused two cars to be seized under a search warrant, but after being taken into custody the cars were...

CLEVELAND, O., Aug. 17.--Last evening a man about 30 years old, while standing on the Bee Line bridge, drew a revolver and shot himself twice in the left side, after which he jumped into the river. He was rescued and taken to the City Hospital.

Henry Webster, a sailor who has just returned from a three years' voyage, was arraigned at the Essex Market Police Court yesterday morning on a charge of violating the ordinance against the carrying of concealed weapons.

John Donohue, of No. 530 West Sixtyfirst-street; Charles Connors, of No. 543 West Sixtieth-street, and John Rountree, of No. 555 West Sixtieth-street, butchers, employed in a west side slaughter house, had been drinking together all Saturday night.

The steamship Arizona, of the Guion Line, arrived yesterday after a quick passage of 7 days 6 hours and 12 minutes from Queenstown. Capt. Brooks reports that he left Queenstown on Aug. 10 at 9 A.M., and reached Sandy Hook at l0:52 yesterday morning.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 17.--There are 40 blast furnaces in the Shenango and Mahoning Valleys, and of these 31 are out of blast at present and 9 in blast. Yet, despite this bad-looking state of affairs, the prospects in the valleys are growing better every day.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 17.--The West Shore Railroad ran another of its Sunday excursions, over the Hudson River division, to the seashore to-day. Preachers in one or two places denounced the cowpany's action, as they said it was desecrating the Sabbath. A large crowd of pleasure-seekers boarded the cars at Albany, Catskill, Saugerties, Highland, and Newburg.

"Good morning," chirruped a little Miss in a white lawn dress, as she danced into the office of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children last evening, and extended her tiny hand to a TIMES reporter.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 17.--Postmaster A.R. Johnson, who disappeared from Grantsville, West Va., a few days ago, was arrested by the Government authorities in Covington, Ky., yesterday. He admits discrepancies in his accounts with the Government, and claims that they amount to only a few dollars.
Yesterday was the sixth day of the Methodist camp meeting at Merrick, Long Island. The early train from Brooklyn took about 500 people to the grounds.
PARIS, Aug. 17.--A third duel with swords has been fought between M. Emmanuel Arene and M. Ernest Gudet, journalists of this city. M. Arene was wounded in the arm.

The suggestions to make Gen. Joshua L. Chamberlain, Commander of the Department of Maine, Grand Army of the Republic, next Spring, in view of the meeting in Portland next Summer of the national encampment, will be heartily seconded by every Maine soldier, as he is confessedly Maine's most distinguished representative of the soldier element.
TORONTO, Aug. 17.--The news of Hanlan's defeat by Beach was received here yesterday with astonishment, and at first was generally discredited, but now is accepted as a fact.
A Third-avenue car, which had been jolting along wearily for half an hour, and groaning under its weight of heated humanity, stopped yesterday afternoon at One Hundred and Eighteenth-street.
KINGSTON, Ga., Aug. 17.--Major Zachariah Hargrave was yesterday nominated for Congress by the Seventh District Republican Convention.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 17.--A boy named Cutter, 11 years old, livig near Millersburg, was found dead last evening hanging at the end of a clothes line. Suicide was at first suspected, but it was finally concluded that he had met with an accident while at play.

The quality of the peaches to arrive here this week will be all that could be hoped for. There will be an unusually large supply of Reeves's Favorite, a large, highly colored, deliciously flavored, sweet yellow peach.
Gibbon says, as quoted by the author: "If the eyes of the spectator have sometimes been deceived by fraud, the understanding of the readers has much more frequently been insuited by fiction."

William Taylor, a clerk employed in a silk house in Broome-street, is a patient at St. Vincent's Hospital, suffering from a fracture of the skull caused by being struck on the head with a goblet by Eugene O'Sullivan, a printer, of No. 87 Varick-street.

FISHKILL LANDING, N.Y., Aug. 17.--A convention of the people of the First Assembly District of Dutchess County way held at Swift's Hall here yesterday, to consider the county's attitude on the Woman Suffrage bill, J.W. Spaight, editor of the Fishkill Standard, presided.
BOSTON, Aug. 17.--Mr. Patrick Egan will remove the headquarters of the Irish National League to Lincoln, Neb. He left Boston last night for Lincoln.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 17.--There was no excitement about the camp of the striking miners in the Fourth Pool to-day. Only about 50 men remained in the camp, the others spending the day in the lower pools or drumming up recruits to attend the meetings which will be held to-morrow.
Much of that part of overheated NewYork that did not go to the country or to the seaside yesterday poured into Central Park.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Aug. 17.--The one hundred and seventh anniversary of the battle of Bennington was celebrated here yesterday by a procession nearly a mile long, which included a detachment of fantasticals.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 17.--Reports from the Northwest state that wolves are making fearful havoc among cattle herds on ranches near Calgarry. Hundreds of cattle have been slain.
The steamships Servia, of the Cunard Line, and Austral, of the Anchor Line, which left Queenstown on the same day as the Arizona, both arrived at this port last evening.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 17.--Somewhat unexpectedly the Hon. Thomas A. Hendricks and wife returned home from New-York at noon.

At St. Stephen's Church, East Twentyeighth-street, yesterday morning, the 10 and 11 o'clock masses mere celebrated by the Rev. Dr. Edward McGlyna, Rector of the church.

The Providence Club gained a good lead over the Boston nine last week, and now lead them by four games. Buffalo is third, followed by the nines of New-York, Chicago, Cleveland, Philadelphia, and Detroit.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 17.--The scorching hot weather of the past few days has caused the grape growers along the Hudson Valley to feel easy, as they now feel assured that the immense yield of Concord "berries" on the vines will fully mature before frosts set in late in September. The Irish-American Independents were rather unhappy at their meeting yesterday afternoon at Clarendon Hall, the causes being the very small attendance and an attack of apprehension that the office-holding Irish-American Generals in the Republican ranks intended to capture the organization and run it as an annex to their own schemes.
NEWARD, N.J., Aug. 17.--While bathing in the Passaic River at Avondale yesterday afternoon, Miss Mary M. Nichols, age 21, was drowned. Her body has been recovered.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 17.--Fire broke out in the dwelling house of John Rabee at 1 o'clock this morning from the overturning of a coal oil lamp. A cat sprang against the lamp and upset it, and the oil ran under the bed of Mrs. Rabee setting it on fire. Only prompt work on the part of the neighbors saved the woman's life, and it was with difficulty that she was got out of doors.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 17.--W.M. Fitch, aged 27 years and respectably connected, committed suicide yesterday by shooting himself through the heart. The deceased was an employe of the South Carolina Railway Company. His accounts were perfectly straight, and the cause of the act is a mystery.

The steamer Austral, of the Anchor Line, which arrived last night at Quarantine too late to come up to the city, has on board the team of Philadelphia cricketers which has played so successfully this Summer in England, and the many friends that accompanied the amateurs in their holiday wanderings.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 17.--Charles Steinhoutz, a carpenter, living in Neward-avenue, in this city, and his wife, Mary, indulged freely yesterday afternoon in intoxicating liquor.

At the meeting of the Central Labor Union yesterday the delegates from five unions introduced a resolution that Gen. B.F. Butler be invited to review the workingmen's parade that is to take place on the first Monday in September and also to attend their picnic.

A temperance meeting was held yesterday afternoon in the Pavilion tent, at Clason and De Kalb avenues, Brooklyn, and was well attended. SHANGHAI, Aug. 17.--The Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Aug. 14 addressed a protest to the foreign diplomats here against the action taken by France, and a request for the mediation of their respective Governments. The protest is couched in pacific terms.

WILKESBARRE, Aug. 17.--Francisco Karroski, an Italian, was attacked in an unexpected manner by August Mons, at Latimer, this evening, and was fatally stabbed in the back with a dirk-knife. The murderer at once fled to the mountains, pursued by the coal and iron police, but has not yet been found. No cause was assigned for the assault.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Aug. 17.--For the purpose of obtaining some idea of the general nature and probable value of the scientific observations made by Lieut. Greely at Lady Franklin Bay, an Associated Press agent visited the Lieutenant, at his cottage on Seavey's Island, Saturday afternoon.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 17.--Thomas Williams will start next Tuesday from Racine Junction, Wis., to carry a banner to Mr. Blaine at his home in Augusta, walking the entire way, a distance of 1,833 miles.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17.--An official of the Western Union Telegraph Company was fined $250 yesterday for violating an ordinance prohibiting the erection of telegraph poles and the stringing of wires in the streets. An appeal was taken and the case will be made a test one.
The great break up of old party ties at present taking place in America is a spectacle of which the full significance still remains to be realized. One aspect of the matter, indeed, is very simple.

July 20, O.W. Flecker, farming the Scott ranch, killed a squirrel, from whose mouth he took 891 kernels of as fine and large wheat as we ever saw their actual weight being two ounces less two drams. Eight such mouthfuls are about equal to a pound. Here is a lesson to the farmer who has a thousand squirrels on his farm.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 17.--Mr. Blaine will go to Augusta to-morrow. On the following day he will go to Strong to attend a great Republican jubilee.

BANGOR, Me., Aug. 17.--Joseph Goulding and his 3-year-old daugther were drowned in the Piscataquis River this afternoon by the capsizing of their boat. Three others of Goulding's children were rescued.

LEXINGTON, Aug. 17.--The recent outbreak and tragedy at the Frankfort Penitentiary had its bloody sequel near this city this afternoon, and George Alsop and Theophilus Grave, two of the most daring convicts that were within the penitentiary walls, are now lying cold in death in pools of their blood. Bernard Courtney keeps a liquor store at No. 315 Seventh-avenue. He says that the store was closed promptly at midnight on Saturday. At 4 o'clock yesterday morning Michael McCabe, the bartender, opened the place for the purpose of cleaning it up.
For two weeks past it has been known that H.B. Claflin, the New-York dry goods prince, was negotiating for the purchase of four corner lots on the southwest corner of Curtis and Sixteenth streets.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 17.--Not since the organization of the Republican Party has there been as little activity manifested by the party's leaders in this State two months before an election as there exists at the present time.

Dr. William H. Olin, of Broome County, declines a re-election to the Assembly this Fall. Speaker Carlisle and Senator Blackburn, of Kentucky are each to make three speeches in Florida during the campaign.
BINGHAMTON, Aug. 17.--Much regret is manifested by the residents of Broome County at the announcement made by the Hon. W.H. Olin, D.D., LL.D., that he declined a renomination to the Assembly.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 17.--President Arthur passed the day quietly at the residence of Gen. Sharpe. He did not attend church. It has been one of the warmes days of the season. The President will go to Red Hook, to the residence of Mr. Theodere Timmington, this morning and spend the day and, unless something unforseen transpires, will leave for New-York in the evening.

Two or-three numbers that were comparatively unfamiliar to the frequenters of the Casino concerts were embodied in last evening's programme. The newest was a serenade by Jensen, a very melodious and characteristic composition, originally written for violin, and lately scored for orchestral performance by Becker.
OTTAWA, Aug. 17.--John and Charles Brown, 14 and 17 years old, respectively, were drowned in the Ottawa River to-day while bathing.

Mrs. WELDON'S "personally conducted" lawsuit for damages because of a false charge of insanity deserves attention. The Judge in his charge declared it disclosed a state of the law "calculated to fill everybody who contemplated it with terror and alarm."

ST. LOUIS , Aug. 17.--Mrs. Sheldon, wife of Aflred Sheldon whose disppearance from Kansas City some time ago led the English Government to make inquiries about him, arrived here yesterday, and is stopping with Stephen Sheldon, an uncle of her husband.

LONDON, Aug. l7.--A story is current that Managers Abbey and Grau missed the boat from Boulogne to Folkestone, carrying the Thea troupe. They found that atl the money they had with them was 4, and risked and lost the entire sum in gambling at Mascotte. They were compelled to telegraph to London for funds before they could leave Boulogne.

Her Majesty possesses an immense fortune. The estate of Osborne is at least five times as valuable as it was when it was purchased by the Queen and Prince Albert, about 40 years ago. The Balmoral property of her Majesty now extends over 30,000 acres.

Another "Marvin" safe was recovered from the ruins of the Pennsylvania Railroad Depot at Jersey City a few days ago and contents found intact. Superintendent Fedderson smiled blandly as he extracted a roll of large bills from one of the drawers of the safe. Beyond being damp, they were in perfect condition.--New-york Tribune, Aug. 16, 1884.

The large, handsome, stylish, modern, Gothic edifice that stands at the east end of the street that borders the south side of the Court House square, in Marshall, which edifice bears on a white marble tablet in its forehead the inscription, "First Baptist Church of Marshall." was dedicated Sunday night, the 3d. The Rev. Dr. Pope Yeaman preached the first sermon to which the walls of the church ever echoed.

AMERICUS, Ga., Aug. 17.--Counterfeit silver money is being circulated in great profusion throughout southwest Georgia. Spurious tencent coins are most numerous. They are lighter than genuine coin and bear the date of 1875. Quarters and half-dollars are also very plentiful.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 18.--Henry C. Lewis, of Coldwater, one of the most prominent citizens of Southern Michigan, died yesterday afternoon at Clifton Springs, this State, where he had been for some time on account of his health. He was born in Orleans County, N. Y., in 1820.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 16.--The terrible heat of the past 10 days has had the effect of most effectually drying up and withering the pastures, and at the present time vegetation of all kinds is in a drooping condition.

George Pearson, of Washington, had a singular experience in this city a few days ago. He has two children, Georgie--aged 9 years, and Thomas, aged 7 years--living with friends at No. 56 South Fifth-avenue. He came to New-York to take his children home with him.

The first performance of "The Seven Ravens," which took place at Niblo's Garden yesterday evening, was witnessed by an audience that filled the house. "The Seven Ravens" is a translation of a spectacular play that has long been popular in Berlin and in Vienna, and, in its English garb, is the work of G.P. Lathrop.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18.--The largest number of clerks of the twelve-hundred-dollar class ever given positions at one time under the civil service rules received appointments in the Pension Office to-day. PLYMOUTH, N.H., Aug. 18.--The dryest season since 1870 is now prevailing here. The wells are rapidly giving out, causing much inconvenience. The streams are very low--many of the smaller ones being entirely dry. Rain has not fallen to any extent since May. Crops of all kinds are suffering severely. Grasshoppers are also destroying the crops.

The boat had been used recently to convey striking coal miners to the Fourth Pool camp, and on Saturday was sued for carrying more passengers than allowed by law.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 18.--The miners of Hosie's colliery, at Edgerton, a short distance from Scranton, are on strike. Hungarians were employed to take the places of the striking miners, but they could not do the work, and the strikers are still standing out for their demand.

MOUNDSVILLE, West Va. Aug. 20.--An ex-convict named Charles Riley this morning fired a shot at Col. WASHINGTON, Aug. 20.--Indian Agent McGillieuddy, of Pine Ridge Agency, in a letter to the Commissioner of Indian Affairs, Says that Son-of-No-Water recently attempted to take the agent's life. An article in a cheap publication saying that the Indians had the right to kill McGillicuddy caused the Indian to make the attempt. He was afterward arrested and is now held subject to the order of the Indian Office.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 20.--This afternoon as the 8-year-old son of Michael Hogan was trimming branches off from a tree which he had climbed, the blade of the hatchet flew off and struck his 2-year-old brother on the forehead, splitting his skull open. The child lived but two hours afterward.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 21.--Mrs. Bridget Farley celebrated her one hundred and third birthday last evening at West Stratford. She was born in Ireland and came to this country in 1820. Her physical condition is good, and she does more or less housework. Of her nine children two only are living.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 21.--Joseph McCullough, employed in the machine shop of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Rail road, met with a horrible death to-day.

BOSTON, Aug. 21.--The postponed race between the New-York sloop Cruiser and H.L. Harding's catboat Hornet was sailed this morning, under a fresh west-southwest breeze off Marblehead. The distance was six and three-quarter nautical miles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21.--Paragraph 3, special orders, July 23, 1884, granting Capt. Henry C. Pratt, Thirteenth Infantry, eight months leave of absence from Sept. 1, 1884, has been amended so as to grant said leave to take effect after he shall have been relieved from his present duties.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 23.--The Executive Committee of the Knit Goods Association has sent a circular to the manufacturers of knitted underwear in the United States announcing that a meeting will be held at Saratoga on Sept. 2. The meeting will consider a plan to control the production and strengthen the market, and if 90 per cent. of the whole industry conclude to organize for their mutual protection to perfect the organization.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Aug. 23.--Samuel Lilly, John Oskis, and Charles Nation, with a jug of whisky, went out rowing in a skiff on Lake Contrary, six miles south of this city last night. They got into a fight and upset the boat, and all were drowned. The bodies were recovered today.

The agents of the Hamburg Steamship Line received a dispatch yesterday from Plymouth announcing the arrival at that port of the steamship Hammonia, which left here of Aug. 14. Her voyage was made in eight days and seventeen hours, which is regarded as very quick time. During her rapid voyage the Hammonia burned but 90 tons of coal per day.

LEXINGTON, Ga., Aug. 23.--George Howard and Hawking Colloway got into a fight a couple of days ago, in which Howard stabbed Colloway in the head. CHICAGO, Aug. 23.--While riding in an English cart at his farm near Racine, Wis., this morning, Mr. J.I. Case had a narrow escape from being insatntly killed. BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 23.--Andrew Jackson, colored, foreman in a livery stable, was this afternoon kicked to death by a horse. He was walking behind the animal, when it kicked with both feet, breaking Jackson's breast bone and driving the splintered ribs into his heart. He died within 10 minutes.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 23.--Harriet Jones and six children of Mrs. Prudie Vaughn, all colored, were poisoned to-day and are lying in a precarious condition to-night. They ate some eggs and ham for breakfast and were taken suddenly ill after drinking water. The real cause is unknown.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 23.--A special dispatch to the Picayune from Meridian, Miss., says: "Paddy Ryan, a railroad engineer, was shot and killed this morning. A. J. Bailey and Mike Gerst have been lodged in jail charged with the murder."

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 23.--The Webster County Bank at Marshfield, Mo., has suspended and C.F. Brooks has been appointed Receiver. The liabilities are reported at $40,000 and assets estimated at from $15,000 to $25,000. All the school and county funds, amounting to about $15,000, were deposited in this bank. Speculation in grain is said to be the cause of the failure.

Some of the neighbors are beginning to express the opinion that the girl is possessed of a devil.

LONDON, Aug. 25.--A fire has been raging for three days in Rawa, a town of Austrian Galicia. Three hundred houses have been destroyed, and 3,000 persons are rendered homeless. There is a great dearth of provisions in the town.

Mosquito bites are said to be good for fever patients. Be this as it may the reason why the mosquito prefers a fevered person's blood is that it is warmer than a healthy person's. Female mosquitoes alone are said to draw blood, needing such nourishment to enable them to lay eggs. Dr. Finlay, of Havana, intimates that a mosquito having been interrupted feeding on a fever patient may inoculate with fever germs a healthy person.

Henry George Bohn, the somewhat celebrated author and publisher, died in London yesterday. He was born Jan. 4, 1796, and, after getting an education, sold books in his father's store.

BANGOR, Me., Aug. 24.--Frank Murphy is under arrest for brutally beating and dangerously stabbing William Hicks, a bartender at the Penobscot Exchange Hotel. Murphy demanded a drink, and was refused. He then insisted that Hicks should give him money with which to purchase liquor. Hicks again refused, when Murphy knocked him down and kicked him in the head and body, and then stabbed him in the neck. Hicks lies at the point of death.

The day is drawing near on which the Post Office circular of Oct. 5, 1883, will begin to take effect, and on which the new arrangements for the mail service to New-York will be in force. On the 31st inst. the existing mail contracts will come to an end, and the Post Office will take up, month by month, the fastest and most efficient vessels for the conveyance of the New-York mails.

BINGHAMTON, Aug. 24.--As Martin Conners, a switchman employed in the railroad yard at Susquehanna, 22 miles from this city, was at work early this morning, he stepped from one track to another to avoid a passing train, not seeing that another string of cars was being pushed rapidly down toward him.

The Providence Club still leads in the race for the championship of the League. Boston is second. Four games behind is Buffalo, third, with New-York fourth, Chicago fifth, Cleveland sixth, Philadelphia seventh, and Detroit last.
It is the one absorbing ambition of every well-regulated compositor's life to improve upon his copy. Sometimes he succeeds.

A bottle of whisky was put into the corner-stone of the Court House at Gwinnette, Ga., 12 years ago, and now, as the building is being demolished, there was a great deal of anxiety as to the matured liquor. More than a thousand persons crowded round the workmen, and something like a riot ensued, during which the precious bottle was stolen by some person or persons as yet unknown.
CONSTANTINOPLE, Aug. 24.--Recent Cabinet councils have mooted the question of sending a fresh circular to the powers concerning Egypt.

TROY, Aug. 24.--John Larkins, a nephew of ex-County Clerk Larkins, of Cohoes, while returning from the wake of a friend at an early hour this morning, fell into the Erie Canal at Lock No. 9 and was drowned.
TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 24.--Dispatches from various parts throughout Canada report a cold wave. The mercury has been falling rapidly to-day.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 24.--The Cincinnati banks, which are usually sellers of exchange, have utilized the opportunity offered by the Government of obtaining currency at a minimum, not because there was a scarcity of currency, or that the country banks were calling...

BALTIMORE, Aug. 24.--There is considerable excitement among the colored people of South Baltimore over the death, this morning, at No. 187 Henrietta-street, of Mary Scott, a very respectable colored woman, who was poisoned by her worthless husband, John A. Scott.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 24.--The Mayor has received several letters lately from New-York and Chicago from persons recently visiting this city in which complaint is made of an Italian fruit vender at the railroad station who, in making change for fruit purchased, passed bogus halves, quarters, and dimes upon the unsuspecting travelers.
NEWARK, Aug. 24.--The back doors of a number of saloons were open in East Newark today where none were open a week ago. In come, also, various games were indulged in during the day.
Mr. WILLIAM H. NICHOLS, President of the Brooklyn Young Republican Club, has announced that he will call a meeting of the club to discuss the Presidential question about the middle of next month.

The time when the mails bound to this country from English ports shall be dispatched by the fastest ships sailing on the days when the mails are made up, instead of on the slowest, as has frequently happened, is now near at hand.

FORT PLAIN, N.Y., Aug. 24.--Kate Smulsey is in the same condition to-night that she was in yesterday. She talks faintly to callers. The family claim that the has eaten nothing today. The doctor says she looks bright. Several physicians think she eats slyly. This seems impossible. The one hundred and sixty-sixth day of her fast was passed at noon to-day.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 24.--Fenimore Clayton, of the town of Middlefield, shot and killed his only son, aged 2 years, this morning. Clayton has been a drinking man for several years, and had suffered from delirium tremens for several days prior to the murder.
A few days ago an item appeared in the papars about the neat game which had been played by "Cabbage" Ryan and some associates on Walter McGregor and his wife.

The victory of Kioba over Bonnie Australian at the Chicago Driving Park on Tuesday was doubtless a very satisfactory performance regarded from a sporting point of view, but when considerations of humanity are brought to bear the event was not quite so satisfactory.

TITI SEE, Aug. 7.--Five hundred feet above us rises the bushy crown of the old Hoch Furst, who, though not a very "high Prince" by actual measurement, looks stately enough as he shakes his shaggy crest of dark firwoods over the sunny valleys and tiny hamlets that nestle at his feet.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 24.--Charles Benedict, a comedian playing at the Vaudeville Theatre at Milneburg, Lake End, this city, died suddenly last night. He was a stranger here, and will be buried in the morning by his professional friends. He has a brother living in Chicago and relatives in New-York City, who have not been heard from.

DECATUR, Ga., Aug. 24.--The greatest barbecue that has taken place in Georgia since the war was enjoyed by the citizens of De Kalb County yesterday at Clarkston.

Officer John O'Brien, of the Twentyeighth Precinct, was on patrol last night in East Sixty-fourth-street, a neighborhood that is classed as "tough." Shortly after 6 o'clock Patrick Slattery, a drunken laborer, 45 years old, of No. 410 East Sixty-fourth-street, threw a stone at him without provocation, and then struck him on the head.
WILKESBARRE, Aug. 24.--The Welsh Baptist denominations of Northeastern Pennsylvania are holding their annual association meeting at Kingston.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 24.--The United States steamer Dispatch, with President Arthur and Secretary Chandler on board, arrived at West Island this evening.

A man named Frank Thompson, sometimes called "Col." Thompson, and well known throughout the entire west side, was subjected yesterday afternoon to the humiliating experience of a horsewhipping from Justice Woodman. The affair attracted many spectators, and was enacted on Desplaines-street in front of the Justice's court about 1:30 o'clock.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24.--About 3'clock this afternoon "Chris" Burner, a man of bad character, and another, whose name is unknown, went into the barroom of William Kessler, at the corner of Fifteenth and O'Fallon streets, and demanded beer, which was refused.

LONDON, Aug. 15.--I can never be surficiently grateful to the alarmists who, on Saturday last, sent from Brussels to the London journals such dire predictions of what the morrow was to bring forth, upon the strength of which an all-night journey to the Belgian capital was forthwith made.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 24.--Sundays seem to be the finest days of the week at Bar Harbor. The summit of Green Mountain was visible this morning for the first time in several days. The Bar Harbor churches were crowded with visitors, and a number of church parties drove over to Northeast and Southeast Harbors.

POULON, Aug. 24.--Five deaths from cholera occurred here last night. The increase in the number of deaths is attributed to the hasty return of the inhabitants, especially as a state of infection is still prevailing.

LACONIA, N.H., Aug. 24.--This has been a rough day on Lake Winipiseogee. It was reported here that the steamer James Bell, from the Alton Bay camp meeting, had been ashore. She had about 100 passengers on board. No particulurs are obtainable at present. It is not believed any persons were lost or injured.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 24.--Two years ago George Leonard, of London, Ontario, visited England to see relatives. On his return to Canada he brought with him his sister, a prepossessing young lady, whom he took to live at his home, Mrs. Leonard noticed that George showed more than ordinary affection for his sister,

SHANGHAI, Aug. 24.--The Foo-Choo arsenal was destroyed yesterday after a three hours' bombardment by Admiral Courbet's squadron. Seven Chinese gunboats were sunk and two escaped. The European settlement was not disturbed.

SAVANNAH, Aug. 24.--South Georgia tonight is the scene of intense excitement, owing to a reported negro uprising at Dawson, Terrell County. SARATOGA, Aug. 16.--A syndicate of Democratic politicians and capitalists met by appointment at the United States Hotel yesterday and decided to start a large Democratic daily at Chicago within a few weeks. D. Gilbert Dexter, an independent Republican and at present editor of the Cambridge (Mass.) Tribune, will be the editor. One hundred and fifty thousand dollars was subscribed, and it is expected to largely increase this sum.
A race between rowboats, managed with sails, took place yesterday afternoon in the harbor. The course was from Pier 23 East River to and around the Robbin's Reef Lighthouse and return.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 25.--At the Democratic Convention of the First Legislative District, this morning, Judge Garrick M. Harding was nominated for Assembly. He has been a lifelong Republican, but recently declared himself for Cleveland, and accepts the nomination tendered him by the Democrats.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 25.--Stephen H. Whitmore, aged 23 years, shot his father, aged 65, with a revolver during a drunken quarrel in New-Marlborough, Mass. The ball entered the right jung and lodged in the shoulder blade. Physicians have thus far been unable to extract it. There is no hope of the wounded man's recovery. The murderer is in jail.

NORWICH, Conn., Aug. 25.--The croquet contest closed this evening. Jacobus, of Keyport, N.J., beat Johnson, of Philadelphia, this morning, and Reed, of New-York, this afternoon, thus winning second prize. The consolation prize was won by Johnson. The tournament has been highly successful, and Norwich will probably become the permanent place of the annual contest.

HUNTINGTON, West Va., Aug. 25.--New comes from the Lesage Post Office, on the Nine Mile Creek, in this county, that in a quarrel between George Minors and a young man name Jeffries, last Friday, Minors was shot through the head with a large revolver. TOULON, Aug. 25.--There has been one death from cholera here since morning. There were five last night. One death from the disease occurred to-day at Hyeres find two at La Seyne. The record of the cholera in the Toulon hospitals is as follows for to-day: Admitted, 5; death, none: discharged, 3; under treatment, 47. The panic has revived, and the return of fugitives has been checked.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 16.--The Democrats of the Lackawanna portion of the Eleventh Congressional District held their convention here to-day and nominated Mayor Beamish,of this city, for Congress. The district, which is overwhelmingly Democratic, consists of Carbon, Columbia, Montour, Monroe, Pike, and portions of Luzerne and Lackawanna Counties, and was represented in the last Congress by Mr. J.B. Storms.

CYNTHIANA, KY., Aug. 25.--In addition to the loss of property by the fire at the Abdallah Park Stables yesterday, James Horan, employed in the stables, lost his life. W.H. Wilson, the owner of the stables had his residence burned.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 25.--While going down stairs for medicine, with a lighted lamp in her hand, yesterday morning, Mrs. Jason Smith fainted and fell. She dropped the lamp, her clothing caught fire, and she was fatally burned.

ALBANY, Aug. 25.--Gov. Cleveland is still at the Prospect Hotel, on Upper Saranac Lake. Two days last week he camped out on the shore of a remote and unfrequented pond and enjoyed some fine fishing. He is in splendid health and spirits, and expects to be back in Albany on Friday or Saturday of this week.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Aug. 25.--Hollis McCormick, a native of Batavia, and a merchant here since 1840, was taken home from a doctor's office this morning and died almost instantly. He had been suffering from a severe cold for a few days and his death as attributed to apoplectic pneumonia.

They recommend the dismissal of 16 employes to effect a saving of about $18,000; also, that 9 men and 7 boys, at a cost of $5,000, could replace 20 messengers now employed at a cost of $10,000. Only the inside service has been dealt with.

DIXON, Ill., Aug. 25.--A riot broke out yesterday among the Italian laborers near here. Over 30 men, were engaged in the melee, and knives, clubs, and shovels were freely used. He sold goods on time, securing himself by taking mortgages on real estate.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 25.--At Shreveport, at 3 o'clock this morning, the wharfboat Maria Louise and the steamboat Shields, owned, by the Red River Coast Line, were burned to the water's edge. The fire broke out in the forward part of the Maria Louise, and the flames soon communicated to the Shields. Everything on the two boats was destroyed. The loss is $35,000; insured in New-Orleans agencies. There was no loss of life.

LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 26.--The Greenbackers of the Tenth District of this State, in convention at Bismarck to-day, decided that it was inexpedient to nominate a candidate for Congress, but passed a resolution requesting George M. Jackson, of St. Louis, to run as an independent candidate, and pledging him their support.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., Aug. 26.--Coroner Wright this morning began the inquest into the deaths of the eight men who were suffocated by gas at the Greenback Colliery while driving a hole to the workings of the Buckridge slope to fight the fire in that place.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 26.--Early this morning the Rev. John W. Staub, Pastor of the Catholic Church in the Sixteenth Ward, in this city, committed suicide by shooting himself with a revolver.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 26.--To-day's programme of races at the Charter Oak Park Circuit meeting is postponed until to-morrow on account of the rain. The whole four days' programme is carried forward one day. If the weather clears the track will be in fine condition and fast for this week's races.
There was a lively time yesterday at the auction rooms of Barker Co., in Liberty-street during the sale of goods from the Government stores.

Mrs. McAfee, the lawful wife of Thomas J. McAfee, who was recently arrested in St. Paul, Minn., on a charge of bigamy, is now in Brooklyn, at the home of her brother, William O. Lodge, of No. 138 Bergen-street.

At the continuation of the examination in the contempt proceedings against the managers of the defunct Newark Savings Institution, yesterday, Henry G. Darcy, one of the impleaded managers, testified that he had been a manager of the institution since 1879, and was a member of the Financial Committee.
PARIS, Aug. 26.--Cholera is increasing in Corsica. Four deaths have occurred near Ajaccio.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 26.--Divers will probably examine the Tallapoosa, in Vineyard Sound, to-morrow, to learn the extent of the damage done, and to ascertain if there are any bodies on board.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26.--It is announced that the Kennel Club show, which will be held in conjunction with the meeting of the Pennsylvania State Agricultural Society, will take place on the 16th, 17th, 18th, and 19th of next month. The entries of dogs will close Sept. 6.

Among the visitors at the Democratic headquarters yesterday was Congressman W. E. Robinson, of Brooklyn, who probably has a larger Irish constituency than any man in Congress. He sees no reason for Irishmen supporting Blaine or the Republican ticket growing out of anything that he has ever done to vindicate the rights of American citizens abroad.
BETHLEHEM, N.H., Aug. 26.--The eleventh annual meeting of the United States Hay Fever Association was held here this afternoon.

BUFFALO, Aug. 26.--The Hon. Lewis F. Allen, an uncle of Gov. Cleveland, was questioned to-day by an Evening News reporter, and denied making several statements attributed to him in an interview publishes in New-York recently.
