CAMBRIDGE, Ohio, Sept. 1.--William R. McNutt, 47 years old, a well-to-do farmer of this county, was found hanging from a joist in a room in the second story of his house early yesterday morning. Financial trouble is the supposed cause of the suicide.
In United States Commissioner Griffith's office yesterday Theodore Karlsson, the cabin boy of the schooner Julia Baker, told what he knew of the death of Capt.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept 1.--At the St. Francis Roman Catholic Church here yesterday was begun a mission by the Jesuit Fathers Mc. Guire and McDonald, of Boston.
LONDON, Sept. 1.--Work was continued at Chatham all day Sunday in hastening the preparations for the Soudan expedition.

The Custom House was visited by successive delegations of rag importers yesterday. There was much consternation in consequence of the order issued from the Treasury Department on Saturday prohibiting the landing of foreign rags in any port of the United States for three months from Sept. 1.

Having failed to obtain a permit from the Board of City Works to tear up the streets, the Kings County Elevated Railroad Company contented themselves with digging a hole at the corner of Fulton-street and Clason-avenue.

LONDON, Sept. 1.--A private dispatch from Tien-Tsin says that China is not disheartened in view of recent occurrences. The Government has issued an edict encouraging the troops to fight, and warning the local authorities everywhere to protect non-combatant Frenchmen.
ALBANY, Sept. 1.--There has been a steady stream of visitors at the Executive Chamber to-day. Although Gov. Cleveland has been engaged in official duties, he has received nearly all personally.
LANCASTER, Penn., Sept. 1.--Christian Staup, a German laborer on the farm of John A. Berneman, in Coney Township, was found dying with his skull crushed on Sunday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept, 1.--The second series of games for the Westchester Polo Club's challenge cup was played on the Polo Grounds to-day, the Meadow Brooks, winners of Friday's games, again proving victorious and winning...

Mr. GLADSTONE'S speech at Edinburgh is one of the important speeches of his career. The orator's leadership of his party was never so well established as it is now, when it is not disputed by any English politician. His first "great speech" of the recess will accordingly be accepted as an authentic exposition of the Liberal programme.
The great expectations and sanguine predictions of the leaders in the big labor movement vanished with the dew after sunrise yesterday morning. Out of 20,000 or more workingmen ...
The Grand Jury for September was sworn in yesterday by Chief Clerk Sparks, of the Court of General Sessions. Judge Gildersleeve delivered the statutory charge.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 1.--The Republican State Convention which will assemble in this City to-morrow, will be a quiet one. A candidate for Governor to succeed Samuel W. Hale, Republican, and two Electors at Large, will be nominated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1.--Leave of absence for one month, to take effect from the date of his being relieved from duty on the Recruiting Service, has been granted First Lieut. John A. Payne, Nineteenth Infantry, and leave of absence for two month, to take effect ...
Joseph Patrick, who was 47 years old, hanged himself last night at No. 346 East Fiftyfourth-street. He was a Bohemian, and made cigars for Kerbs Spiess, of No. 1,018 Secondavenue.
COHOES, N.Y., Sept. 1.--This morning the 14 and 18 inch and the Belgian trains, in the Albany Iron Works, in this city, were started up.

The last voyage of the mammoth steamship City of Rome, though free from the ordinary vexations and vicissitudes of an ocean trip, was marked at its close yesterday morning by a tempest in a teapot, which included among its features one round under the Queensberry rules, ...
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1.--The racing was continued here to-day. The weather was clear and warm, the track fast, and the attendance good.

NORFORK, Va., Sept. 2.--The Seneca, a new steamship built for the Old Dominion Company at Chester, Penn., will be launched within a few days. She is about 300 feet long, and will accomodate 45 passengers.

When the lunacy commission in the case of William C. Rhinelander, who shot John Drake, was ready for work yesterday in the Recorder's room of the Court of General Sessions, there was little standing room even for counsel or reporters.

The monthly exhibitions of the NewYork horticultural Society were inaugurated yesterday afternoon in Horticultural Hall, in West Twenty-eighth-street, with a beautiful display, of which orchids, gladioli, dahlias, and lilies were the special features.

The peace-loving inhabitants of Bath, Long Island, were startled on Monday evening by the wild rumor that a coachman and a wiredrawer were preparing to fight a duel near Locust Grove soon after midnight.

L.E. Chittenden and several members of the Anti-Monopoly League of this city have prepared and are circulating a call for a public mass meeting in Chickering Hall to-morrow evening to denounce the course of the Aldermen in giving away the franchise of a street railroad in Broadway.
The perils of street travel in New-York were forcibly illustrated yesterday afternoon in Grand-street by a collision between two open street cars by which several passengers were badly bruised.

BOSTON, Sept. 2.--The naval court of inquiry to examine into the circumstances attending the sinking of the United States steamer Tallapoosa on the night of Aug. 21, was opened this afternoon at the Navy Yard.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 2.--The crowd at the Bay State House to-night is not so large as it usually is on the night before a Democratic Convention.
SCRANTON, Sept. 2.--Much interest is felt here in the sad case of Mrs. John W. Aitkin, of Carbondale, a lady whose insanity is alleged to be the result of cruelty.

DETROIT, Sept. 2.--In the case of the National Copper Mining Company against the Minnesota Company, which has been on trial at Houghton for several days past, having been transferred thither from the Ontonagon Circuit Court, the jury to-day rendered a verdict for the plaintiff, with damages assessed at $11,962.

The interest that had been manifested in the Twin City Handicap insured the presence of a vast crowd at the Sheepshead Bay racecourse yesterday. The races, six in number, were of the most exciting description, and were run off without unnecessary delay.

BURLINGTON, Sept. 2.--The election returns are meagre, almost beyond precedent. Of the 240 towns in the State only 60 have been heard from. These furnish about one-third of the total vote of the State, and they give Pingree, Republican, for Governor, 13,098, and Redington, Democrat, 5,448.
"Adonis" will be produced at the Bijou Opera House to-morrow night by Mr. Henry E. Dixey and Rice's burlesque company.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 2.--Gen. John A. Logan, en route from Chicago to Madison, stopped in Milwaukee two hours this afternoon. A score of Milwaukeeans went part of the way to Chicago to meet the General.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 2.--The will of the late Stephen Salisbury, Worcester's richest citizen, is written on a single sheet of legal cap, and bears date of April 21, 1883.
MADRID, Sept. 2.--Cholera has undoubtedly appeared in the city and Province of Alicante. It was taken there by a family from Cette, France, which reached Alicante by way of Algiers.

WHEELING, Sept. 2.--A serious accident, resulting fatally to John McGowan, occurred in the Belmont Mill to-day. Light men were engaged in hoisting a heavy side plate into a heating furnace when it slipped and struck McGowan, knocking him down and falling upon him.
The semi-annual dividends payable in Boston this month aggregate $5,032,437.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 2.--The fight between Mahone and Gov. Cameron for supremacy in the Senator's party continues with more determination than ever. Each of these gentlemen is using every effort to add to his strength among the followers of their party.

The members of the New-York Club played a poor game in their contest with the Chicago nine yesterday on the Polo Grounds. There were a large attendance, and as Welch and Ewing were to officiate as the "battery" everybody expected to witness a close game.

Michael J. Dady, who expects to receive the Republican nomination for Sheriff in Kings County this Fall, has, through influence at Washington, been able to secure the appointment of a large number of men at the Brooklyn Navy Yard within the past few weeks.
LONDON, Sept. 2.--The Right Hon. Mountstuart Elphinstone Grant Duff has been appointed to succeed the late Lord Ampthill as British Ambassador at Berlin.
BOSTON, Sept. 2.--There have been few delegates to to-morrow's Republican State Convention about to-night, and little canvassing.

Mrs. Maria Marini, wife of Dr. Marini, attempted suicide last evening at her home, No. 117 South Fifth-avenue, by taking carbolic acid. Her act was caused by jealousy of her husband. Her condition is critical.

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 2.--The Evening News suspended to-day because J.F.W. Ruttenber, the proprietor, is under arrest for complicity with J. Edgar Chandler in firing the Mohawk Valley Democrat office at Fonda, destroying $40,000 worth of property. Ruttenber is under $10,000 bail to appear on Sept. 27.

MONTREAL, Sept. 2.--The British Scientists resumed their sectional work this morning, and having in view the advisability of closing this afternoon gave themselves a formidable programme to face. Consequently, a good many of the papers were rushed through.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 2.--The canning mill of the Consumers' Powder Company, situated near Pickville, a short distance from this city, exploded this afternoon, killing a workman named Lyman Kregy. The other persons employed at the works had a narrow escape.
The recent tragic fate of a leading citizen of Chicago has produced a deep impression in that city, and will, it is hoped, lead to a reform in the matter of toothpicks.

Patrick Judge and John Behan were twice arraigned before Justice Daniel O'Reilly yesterday, on the charge of being implicated in the murder of Frederick Kopf, on Sunday. On the second occasion, Frank J. Keller appeared ...
LAWRENCE, Kan., Sept. 2.--The Prohibition State Convention assembled in this city this morning. About 150 delegates were present bearing credentials.

FORT PLAIN, N.Y., Sept. 2.--Kate Smulsey, the fasting woman, remains in the same low condition to-night. The family has received numerous packages of drugs, also prescriptions from New-York, Boston, Philadelphia, St. Louis and elsewhere. She cannot swallow anything, hence the cure-alls are useless. This is her one hundred and seventy-fifth day.
HALIFAX, Sept. 2.--This afternoon a fisherman saw a body drifting below the surface of the water in the vicinity of the wreck of the steamer Daniel Steinman.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Sept. 2.--The Board of Assessors of Warren County have discovered a fraud in Oxford township, owing to a collusion between the Assessor, William M. Syphers, and several property holders.

NASHVILLE, Sept. 2.--Since the State offered a reward of $1,000 for the arrest and conviction of any or all of the mob who shot and killed the two Mormon Elders on Cane Creek, Lewis County, Aug. 12, detectives have made attempts to secure some clue that would lead to important developments. So far, however, no arrests have been made.
LONDON, Sept. 2.--Much interest is shown here in the part which the Canadian boatmen and Indians are to take in the Gordon relief expedition.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2.--The first of the Congressmen who are anxious to kill off the proposed Treasury Department order to keep the plans for public buildings within the amounts ...
Steamship Colon, Lima, Aspinwall 8 ds., with mdse. and passengers to Pacific Mail Steamship Co.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 2.--At the Minneapolis Fair this afternoon Jay-Eye-See attempted to beat his record of 2:10. He was in good form, but the track was very cuppy and slow. The wind blew a perfect gale.
LYNCHBURG, Sept. 2.--W.L. Painter, a leading merchant of Pulaski County, was robbed last evening of $7,500, $5,000 in bonds, and the balance in money and checks.
The will of the late John Glover Adams, a well-known physician, came up for probate in the office of the Surrogate yesterday.

WILKESBARRE, Sept. 2.--District Attorney McGahren having secured sufficient evidence against ex-Paymaster Roberts to cause his arrest, placed a warrant in the hands of a constable this afternoon with instructions to proceed at once to Roberts's country seat and take him into custody.

Members of the Stock Exchange propose to institute an organized warfare against the "bucket shops," which are alleged to thrive only because of their ability to get prompt stock quotations from the Exchange board room.

The absence from the city during the Summer months of a great part of the people who live in flats and prefer not to do their own cooking seems to have put the New-York Catering Company into a strait.

Connecticut is one of the traditional close and uncertain States. In 1875, an unfavorable year for Republicans everywhere, it elected a Democratic Governor by a plurality of nearly 20,000, the temperance question being then a disturbing element.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 2.--This morning Sitting Bull and wife, Grey Eagle, Long Day, Spotted Horn Bull and wife, and the Princess Red Spear arrived from Standing Rock Agency, and will soon be en route for exhibition throughout the East and Europe.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 2.--A pretty careful investigation as to the condition of the Kentucky tobacco crop, made by one of the Cincinnati houses, indicates that the acreage is not as large as has been generally supposed.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 2.--The statement of Civil Service Commissioner Gregory that his son Alfred, recently appointed special pension examiner, had been a bona fide citizen of Georgia for one or two years caused THE TIMES'S correspondent here to make an investigation.

The Commissioners of Appraisal for the parcels of land in New-York County for the new aqueduct met yesterday noon at the office of the Corporation Counsel, No. 2 Tryon-row, for the purpose of organizing.
READING, Penn., Sept. 2.--The Reading Tack Works, a flourishing corporation, was compelled to sell out under a threat of being crushed by the National Tack Association.

The close of the annual shooting festival of the Harlem Independent Schuetzen Corps yesterday was marked by a scene of pleasure and activity. Every married rifleman was accompanied by his wife and daughters, and every bachelor brought his sweetheart.

The Police Commissiomers yesterday directed Superintendent Walling to prefer charges of neglect of duty against Sergts. Buddington, Tuck, and Reynolds, of the Twelfth Precinct, based upon their conduct with reference to the case of a missing man named Orson Burroughs.

TORONTO, Sept. 2.--The commission appointed to investigate the charges against Wilkinson, Bunting, Meek, and Kirkland of attempting to overthrow the Mowat administration by bribing members of the Provincial Legislature, resumed its sittings at Osgoode Hall yesterday.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 2.--Jonas Whispell died at Woodstock yesterday within a few months of being 103 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2.--All the diaries kept by the members of the Greely expedition are in the custody of Lieut. Ray, and no other army officer is supposed to have read them. MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 2.--Stephen Brown, colored, appeared in Meridian, Miss., yesterday, and was wedded by a colored preacher to Mrs. Mollie Thomas, a white woman of very respectable connection.
DETROIT, Sept. 2.--The old-established grocery firm of McKenna Radcliffe, of this city, has failed.

LONDON, Sept. 2.--Sixty-two horses have been accepted for the forthcoming Czarevitch Stakes at Newmarket. They include Mr. J.R. Keene's ch.c. Blue Grass and Mr. P. Lorillard's ch.h. Sachem. The acceptances for the Cambridgeshire Stakes number 88, in which Blue Grass is also included.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2.--Leave of absence for four months, to take effect Oct. 1, has been granted Capt. Charles D. Viele, Tenth Cavalry.

What the sidewalk statesmen of Brooklyn call "a run in" took place yesterday in the hall of the Municipal Building, Brooklyn, between Assemblyman Patrick Burns and James Kerrigan, a clerk in the Register of Arrears office.

BOSTON, Sept. 2.--Melvina Butler, a young woman of 24, while busy in the kitchen of her home, No. 308 Meridian-street, East Boston, just before 9 o'clock this forenoon, was shot and almost instantly killed in what at first appeared to be a most unaccountable way.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 2.--This afternoon it became noised about on the streets that a strange marriage ceremony was to take place in Justice Gleason's office, the contracting parties being a Chinese laundryman and a German-American girl of respectable parentage.
Alexander Fairbanks, 68 years of age, was found dead last evening in his bedroom on the top floor of the flat No. 261 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifthstreet.
WHEELING, Sept. 2.--From Harrison County, near Cadiz, comes what seems to have been a genuine case of broken heart, which caused death under the most mournful circumstances.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 2.--Gov. Hoadly, accompanied by that distinguished citizen and clever imitator of the Sand Lot statesman, the Hon. Allen O. Myers, and other attaches of the Gubernatorial staff, arrived from a circuit of the mines in the Hocking Valley at a late hour last night. Gov. Hoadly finally consented to accede ...

SHANGHAI, Sept. 2.--Letters from TienTsin state that Li Hung Chang, the distinguished Viceroy of Pee-Chee-Lee, has been degraded from his high position and been deprived of his titles. His chief Minister succeeds him as Viceroy. This report needs confirmation before it is accepted as true.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 2.--In a row at Inman last night, in which John Cohen, Reuben Warren, Jacob Hunter, and Jacob and Albert Green took part. Cohen was beaten to death. To-day Jacob Hunter was arrested at Jasper. One hundred dollars reward is offered for each of the criminals.

Despite the statements everywhere current yesterday that active hostilities had broken out among the roads in the trunk line pool, the situation was practically unchanged. It is undeniable, however, that all the indications point to serious trouble both in passenger and freight business in the near future unless heroic measures are reported to to prevent any extension of the demoralization now ruling.
In a glass case in the Standard Museum in Fulton-street, Brooklyn, there have resided together in brotherly love for the last six months a huge black anaconda and a big yellowstriped boa constrictor.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 2.--For some time past the Directors of the Saratoga, County Bank, situated at Waterford, have been considering the advisability of closing up the bank. At a meeting held recently the Cashier was directed to prepare a circular letter addressed to the stockholders asking their consent and authority.

ALBANY, Sept. 2--The State Board of Pharmacy, created by the last Legislature, was organized to-day by the election of Dr. A.B. Huested, of Albany, President; E.S. Dawson, of Syracuse, Secretary, and Clark F. Otis, of Binghamton, Treasurer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2.--Indian Commissioner Price has taken measures for the immediate relief of the starving Piegan Indians at the Blackfeet Agency, Montana. The following telegram was sent to Gov. Crosby, of Montana, this morning:

ALBANY, Sept. 2.--The State Board of Equalization met to-day and heard arguments from representatives of Albany, Columbia, Kings, Orleans, Schoharie, Tioga, and Wayne Counties for a change in the assessment.

The representatives of the Baltimore and Ohio, Bankers and Merchants', and Postal Telegraph Companies discussed yesterday, at the office of the Bankers and Merchants', No. 187 Broadway, means to be employed to assist the last-named company in its present straits.

An elderly gentleman, with gray hair and mustache, was taken suddenly ill on Thirdavenue on Monday and conveyed in an ambulance to the New-York Hospital, where it was found that he was suffering from a severe attack of acute rheumatism.
LOWELL, Mass., Sept. 2.--John Teemer, of McKeesport, Penn., defeated George H. Hosmer, of Boston, here to-day in a three-mile race with a turn.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 2.--Warden Leonard, of the County Lunatic Asylum, was this afternoon subjected to a most rigid examination by the Legal Questions Committee of the Board of Chosen Freeholders, to whom were referred charges made against Warden Leonard's management of the asylum.
A meeting of the paper stock importing trade was held yesterday at No. 126 Duane-street, to take action in regard to the order of the Secretary of the Treasury prohibiting the importation of rags.

A dilapidated looking individual, with a wooden leg, a seedy pair of what had once been navy-blue trousers, a battered old slouch hat, and a red handkerchief, worn neither for warmth nor beauty, but simply to hide certain defects in his under toilet, stood at a corner of Mulberrystreet yesterday and gazed at the strange scene before him.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 2.--The demurrer of the Sentinel in the suit of James G. Blaine was taken up in the United States court, before Judge Woods, this morning, Messrs. Turpie Jones appearing for Shoemaker Miller, Elam Claypool for Mr. Blaine.

William Lewis, a young man who admits that he has served a term or two for crime, surrendered himself to the Jersey City police yesterday. He said that he had been in the service of a railroad contractor at Watertown, Penn., named Patrick Prendible.

Mrs. Mary Devine, of No. 332 DeKalbavenue, Brooklyn, made a charge before Justice Massey yesterday against Thomas Harrington, an elderly man, who lives on the same block, of wantonly torturing her adopted son, a pretty child of 2 years.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2.--To-day was "opening day" at the so-called International Electrical Exhibition in this city, and, like opening days generally, at fairs and the like, it was marked by much bustle and confusion, especially the latter.
READING, Penn., Sept. 2.--The lifeless body of a stranger, of handsome physique and well dressed, was found at 5:30 this morning, lying on the stairway of a saloon at Penn and Seventh streets.
DAVENPORT, Sept. 2.--Several political states which had been formed for the Iowa State Democratic Convention, which meets here tomorrow, were suddenly broken this afternoon, ...

Perfectly unconscious of the many stories in circulation questioning the validity of her marriage to Harold C. De Wolfe, Bebe Vining, the pretty young comic opera singer, arrived in this city yesterday morning from Montreal, where, the day before, Wolfe had been arrested for raising money on worthless drafts.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 2.--Three years ago a company styled the Great Southern Lumber and Railway Supply Company was formed in New-York, and issued a glowing prospectus, having purchased 13,000 acres of poor pine lands in Baldwin County, Ala., at 50 cents an acre.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 2.--The Republican State Convention was called to order by Chairman Gallinger, of the State Committee, at 10:35 this morning, with a large attendance of delegates and spectators. Chairman Gallinger's address was well received. He expressed his conviction that the nominees of the party would receive 5,000 majority in New-Hampshire next November.

NEWPORT, Sept. 2.--The weather is perfect and the cottagers are making the best of it. President Arthur took luncheon with Mr. and Mrs. G. H. Warren to-day, and this evening he was the honored guest at a dinner party given by Mr. and Mrs. William Astor.

READING, Penn., Sept. 2.--Directors Bickel and Shearer, of the almshouse, and Daniel Healy, of Douglasville, each denied to-day the statement made by Director Marshall about Mr. Healy offering to pay $60 to Directors ...
Congressman Spriggs, of Utica, who was among the visitors to the Democratic headquarters yesterday, represents the outlook to be very encouraging in his district.
HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 2.--The Republican State Convention was called to order at 11:30 A.M., in Armory Hall, by Col. Degress, of Austin.
HALIFAX, Sept. 2.--Letters were received here to-day from members of the Hudson Bay expedition dated Nain Labrador, July 30. The party are all well and the Neptune is making good progress.

Another example of the pernicious effects of Summer nights church festivals has recently been brought to light in Brooklyn. About two years ago Miss Ada Thompson, a 14-year-old belle of Cumberland-street, was allowed by her mamma to give a piano recital at such a festival.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 2.--Bishop Pierce is still alive, though so low that it is feared he will not survive the night. He is rational and fully conscious of his condition.
CAIRO, Sept. 2.--Gen. Sir Evelyn Wood has granted Major Kitchener permission to remain with the Mudir of Dongola.
KINGSTON, Sept. 2.--For some time past numerous burglaries have occurred along the Hudson River Valley. It was evident that the work was that of a well-organized gang of burglars.
LONDON, Sept. 2.--The Dublin Freeman's Journal and other newspapers devoted to the Irish cause are printing columns of matter from and about William Henry Hurlbert's pamphlet ...
WATERTOWN, Sept. 2.--Charles S. Gray, an insane hermit residing near this city, got up in the night on Sunday, stripped himself of his clothing, and jumped into a rowboat on the river.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2, 1884. Col. Casey Young, member of Congress from the Memphis, Tenn., district, was riding in a buggy near the capital to-day, when the vehicle broke down, frightening the horse, which ran away, dragging Col. Young some distance.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 2.--The Republican State Convention to-morrow will nominate the present State officers, headed by Gov. Rusk. The platform will strongly indorse the Republican national ticket and platform and lay special stress on protection of American industries.

The annual "Kills" regatta was rowed yesterday afternoon. The course was one mile straightaway on the Kill Von Kull River, directly opposite Elizabethport, N.J. The tide at that point runs very nearly as strong as it does through Hell Gate.

Joseph M. Peace, the fruit dealer of No. 83 Beaver-street, who is under arrest for numerous forgeries, was yesterday arraigned before Justice White in the private examination room at the Tombs Police Court.

LONDON, Sept. 3.--The rumors that a second conference on Egyptian affairs would be held have been revived. In semi-official quarters these rumors are taken to indicate a desire on the part of France to settle the Egyptian question through diplomacy.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 3.--Quiet reigned in the miners' camp at Coal Centre to-day. Since the advent of Sheriff Chambers the aspect of affairs has completely changed.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 3.--George F. Pierce, the senior Bishop of the Methodist Episcopal Church South, died at his home at Sunshine, three miles from Sparta, at about 9 o'clock this morning.

At a meeting of the Dock Commissioners yesterday a communication was received from the Controller stating that after the payment of existing vouchers and the purchase of the wharf property of the Old Dominion Steamship Company the appropriation of $250,000 obtained by the department last May would be about exhausted.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3.--The Western distillers to the number of about 60 met to-day at the Grand Pacific Hotel to reorganize the whisky pool under the name of the Western Export Association.

SHARON, Penn., Sept. 3.--Last evening while six men were blasting a huge piece of iron in the bottom of the stack of the Valley furnace a blast of giant powder was prematurely exploded by a spark of fire from a hammer.

BUFFALO, Sept. 3.--This was the second day of the State pigeon shoot. Clay pigeons were used, as was the case yesterday, the live birds being saved for later contests.

BINGHAMTON, Sept. 3.--Miss Jennie Tracy, the young girl who was recently shot by her discarded lover, Billy Roberts, of Oxford, is growing worse.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 3.--The manufacturers of woolen knit goods had their final session here to-day, and adjourned to meet in Albany, subject to the call of the President.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 3.--The earnings of the St. Paul Railway system for the fourth week of August were $623,000, against $637,000 for the same week last year, a decrease of $14,000.

Members of the Irving Hall and County Democracy organizations in the Ninth Assembly District have united in forming a Cleveland and Hendricks Club, and will hold a meeting to elect officers at the Village House, at Bank and Hudson streets, this evening.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 3.--The trouble in regard to the order of Chief Braun to Consul Schamberg to take down the Austrian flag on the Emperor's birthday is assuming graver proportions than it was at first supposed it would. Baron Schaffer will ask that the case be pushed.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 3.--Ex-Gov. Hendricks addressed an audience of 2,000 persons for an hour and a half at Connersville, to-day, on the fair grounds. Mr. Hendricks's reception was cordial. After repeating substantially the speech that he delivered here last Saturday he closed as follows:

Postmaster Pearson yesterday received a dispatch from San Francisco saying that the City of Tokio had arrived with mails from China and Japan. These mails are due to arrive in New-York for first carriers' delivery Tuesday, Sept. 9.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3.--Mr. Charles A. Kincaid, private secretary of Gov. J. Proctor Knott, of Kentucky, passed through this city today en route to New-York, whence he will sail for Europe on Saturday.

CAMP COUCH, NIANTIC, Conn., Sept. 3.-- In the field manoeuvres of the Connecticut National Guard to-day Capt. Lyon, of Gen. S.R. Smith's staff, had his leg badly sprained by falling from his horse. Corp. Cummings, of Company A, Fourth Regiment, had the fourth finger of his right hand blown off by a shell, and the hand badly shattered.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 3.--The annual reunion of the Chautauqua County Veterans was held at Point Chautauqua to-day, and was one of the most largely attended reunions since the war.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 3.--George A. Halsey has declined the Republican nomination for Congressman of the Sixth District, and the convention will meet again on Wednesday next to select another candidate.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 3.--At Mensey, near Jellico, Tenn., to-day, John Hunt actually beat James Clark to death with a club. The murderer escaped.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 3.--The reunion of the Society of the Army of the Potomac, in this city, has been appointed for May 6 and 7, 1885. Major F. Simon, the Secretary, has received a letter from Gen. Horatio C. King, of New-York, approving that time.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3.--Lewis Keyser, a good-looking boy, about 14 years old, was arrested this morning charged with being implicated in the robbery of a grocery store.
BELVIDERE, N.J., Sept. 3.--Highwaymen last night stopped a wealthy farmer named Butts, near this town, and robbed him of money and jewelry.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 3.--Much indignation is expressed among the members of the Grand Army of the Republic here, which is considered a strictly non-partisan organization, because the Republican Town Committee have sent the individual members invitations, irrespective of party, calling upon the veterans to assist in forming a Blaine and Logan Veteran Club. The movement will injure the Republican chances here greatly.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 3.--The Republican Convention for the Thirty-third Congressional District, which is made up of Niagara County and the Fourth and Fifth Assembly districts of Erie County met at Niagara Falls to-day.

Officers of the Stock Exchange have given the subject of "bucket shops" a thorough investigation during the past two months, and at the meeting of the Governing Committee next Wednesday a plan will be presented which is designed to prevent the "bucket shops" from obtaining prompt quotations from the floor of the Exchange.

ST. JOHN'S Newfoundland, Sept. 3.--The steamship Greenland was burned to the water's edge last night at Harbor Grace. She was towed to Riverhead, where she sank. The vessel is a total loss.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 3.--A remarkable case of congenital malformation of the heart has just been made public at Jackson, in this State, by the death of a boy named Hayes, aged 11 years. He had always been known to his playmates as the "blue boy," and was also designated as "the boy with his heart on the right side."
Gen. David Hunter, United States Army, is at the Everett House. Frederick O. Prince, of Boston, is at the New-York Hotel.

A committee of the stock and bondholders of the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad Company has issued a call for proxies to be used at the ensuing election in continuing the present management in control. The directory, as at present constituted, is in the interest of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company.

MONTREAL, Sept. 3.--The meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science has come to a close, to-day having been devoted to finishing up the work of such sections as had not been concluded last night. KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 3.--Austin Sands, a farmer of Stone Ridge, was recently attacked by a cow whose calf had been attacked by Sands's dog. Sands was seriously injured, one horn tearing a wound five inches in length, and he will probably die. Sands had his child in his arms at the time he was attacked, but this was saved by his wife, to whom he tossed it.

The official report of Edward H. Green, M.D., surgeon of the steamship Thetis, of the Greely relief squadron, on the condition of the survivors of the Greely party when found at their camp on Smith's Sound, and their subsequent treatment, is published in this week's Philadelphia Medical News.

Mr. WARREN GIBBS, Chariman of the Vermont Republican State Committee, is a singularly foolish man. He has sent a dispatch to Mr. BLAINE congratulating him on the effect that gentleman's nomination has produced in Vermont. "The canvass," he says, "was made on national issues."

Mrs. Maria Marini, the prepossessing wife of Dr. Eliseo Marini, an Italian surgeon, of No. 117 South Fifth-avenue, took carbolic acid about midnight on Tuesday night, with suicidal intent, and died two hours later in great agony.

PANAMA, Aug. 25.--The Central and South American Cable Company, in anticipation of further troubles in Peru, recently applied for protection to the United States Government, and their request was promptly complied with.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3.--The Woman's National Equal Rights Party, at its convention held recently in San Francisco, nominated Mrs. Belva A. Lockwood, of this city, for President of the United States. To-day Mrs. Lockwood forwarded to the President of the convention her letter of acceptance.

OTTAWA, Sept. 3.--Official returns show that the number of settlers going into the Canadian Northwest at Emerson has fallen off 16 per cent. as compared with last year, and 51 per cent. as compared with 1882.

COHOES, N.Y., Sept. 3.--A peculiar case that is puzzling the physicians of this city is that of Thomas Witnerston. Recently Witnerston's toes commenced to decay one by one until they are now all gone. The disease, whatever it is, has now begun to eat away his feet.
The programme for to-day at the Sheepshead Bay track consists of six races, with the September Stakes for 3-year-olds and the handicap sweepstakes for all ages as the principal attractions.
ST. PETERSBURG, Sept. 3.--A Russian corvette has seized the American schooner Sophia Johnson at Behring's Island, in Behring Sea, for illicitly selling rum to the natives.

In the Thirty-third Republican Congressional District Convention, comprising Niagara County and all the towns of Erie County, held to-day at Niagara Falls, Col. John B. Weber, of Erie County, was nominated for Congress.

BURLINGTON, Sept. 3.--Returns from 204 towns give Pingree (Rep.) 39,518 and Redington (Dem.) 18,512. Plurality for Pingree 20,879. The independent, Greenback, and scattering vote is only 556. The 36 towns yet to be heard from will give the Republicans about 2,600 and the Democrats about 870.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3.--The lines of the new Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company are being connected with the Western Union system at Bay View, Wis., a suburb of Milwaukee. This confirms the report that the former's Northwestern lines had been absorbed by the latter.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3.--Church Howe, the Nebraska member of the National Republican Executive Committee, is in this city, and had a long and secret conference with Gen. Butler this evening, the purport of which is not made public. Mr. Howe leaves for New-York to-morrow morning.

Solomon Nathan, who says he is a law student, residing in Chicago, was arrested in Jersey City yesterday on a charge of false pretenses. Mrs. Jessie Lewis, a furniture dealer on First-avenue, New-York, is the complainant.
A yacht regatta for open sloops, cabin sloops, and cat boats took place yesterday afternoon off the "Good Anchorage," at Tompkinsville, Staten Island.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 3.--In the unfinished 2:25 class for pacers to-day Billy M. won the first heat in 2:20, Cohannet the next two, in 2:21 and 2:20 and Messina Boy the next heat and the race in 2:24 .

BAXLEY, Ga., Sept. 3.--Two negroes were killed at Appling Distillery, six miles from this place, last night. Dave Lewis and Andy Lewis, brothers, and Ben Lewis were employed to work on Turpentine Farm. They arrived near the distillery last Saturday evening.

Recent deaths occurring at Bellevue Hospital have called the attention of the Board of Health to the sanitary defects of that institution. Miss Tingley, a nurse, and Mr. Hebers Smith, an orderly at the hospital, have died within the past week of typhoid fever.
MERIDEN, Conn., Sept. 3.--John D. Roberts, Chairman of the Greenback and Ben Butler Town Committee, to-day resigned the position, and has come out for Grover Cleveland.

LONDON, Sept. 3.--The inhabitants of the Cameroons country, in Western Africa, are about to present a protest to the London Foreign Office against the annexation of that district to the German possessions, as they prefer British protection.

CARTERVILLE, Penn., Sept. 3.--Clarence J. Woods, a well-known school teacher of this place was to-day fined $225, or one year on the public works, for cruelly beating a little girl, who was a pupil of his.

NORWICH, Conn., Sept. 3.--A mysterious insect is poisoning people by its sting here. Several cases have been reported. The last and worst is that of a little son of Joseph Williams, of Preston, whose whole hand has become greatly inflamed. The poison is now working up the arm toward the elbow. The little fellow is critically ill. A scientist is endeavoring to identify the dangerous insect.

Mrs. Bridget Farley, of Bridgeport, celebrated her one hundred and third birthday Wednesday of last week at the house of Dr. W. F. Hutchinson, in West Stratford.

GRIFFIN, Sept. 3.--Several attempts have recently been made to wreck trains on the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad, near McDonough. To-day a colored boy named Ed Jenkins, aged 12 years, was discovered placing obstructions on the track. He confessed his guilt and is in jail.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 3.--Samuel Roberts, the defaulting paymaster of Charles Parrish, was arrested at his country home today.

The 16-year-old son of the Harbor Master of Antwerp is now in irons on the Red Star steamship Waesland, which will leave this port on Saturday. The waesland arrived from Antwerp last Thursday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3.--The following letter was written by Col. George E. Waring, Jr., accepting the Vice-Presidency of the Independent Republican Club of this city. Col. Waring has never voted any but the Republican ticket except in 1872, when he voted for Mr. Greeley, of whom he was an intimate personal friend.

Julius Mitchell and his alternate, Samuel Andrews, the colored appointees to the West Point cadetship from Congressman Small's South Carolina district, returned to Charleston yesterday, having failed to pass the preliminary examinations at West Point.

COHOES, Sept. 3.--This afternoon William Blair with four other boys was playing near a sand bank on Adams Island when the bank caved in, completely covering Blair and a lad named Jones. The other boys escaped, and gave the alarm. When extricated Blair was dead, but the other injured boy will recover.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 3.--The Minnesota Elevator Company, of Redwing, organized about a year ago, made an assignment yesterday to Judge E. T. Wilder.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 3.--The wife of Frederick Merrill, of Cleveland, early this morning, being crazed with grief on account of the death of her child, shot her husband while he was in bed, and then swallowed a fatal dose of carbolic acid. Mr. Merrill will recover.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3.--The Republicans at the national capital find little to comfort them in the rather meagre returns from the Vermont election which have been received here.

ROME, N.Y., Sept. 3.--The Oneida County Republican Convention to-day nominated John R. Edwards, of Rome, for County Treasurer; J. D.F. Stone, of Utica, for Special Surrogate, and Herbert G. Jones and Edwin W. Raynor for Coroners.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 3.--Intelligence has been received here that the bark Alfred, on a passage from Liverpool to Valparaiso, coal laden, was totally destroyed by fire at sea, off Cape Hare. WABASHA, Minn., Sept. 4.--The Bank of Wabasha, which suspended yesterday because of the failure of the Minnesota Elevator Company, resumed this morning. G.C. Benson and C.F. Rogers, two wealthy citizens of Lake City, advanced money sufficient to meet all demands, and deposits are again coming in freely.

A meeting of the American Bible Society was held at the Bible House yesterday afternoon. Vice-President Charles Tracy presided. Grants of books were made for benevolent distribution in this and foreign countries to the value of $9,300.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 4.--The weather to-day has been red hot. The ball given last night by James Gordon Bennett is the talk of the day. President Arthur and Attorney-General Brewster did not leave until 2 o'clock A.M. Dancing was kept up until daylight. Mr. Bennett gives an outdoor fete at Southwick Grove to-morrow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4.--The Acme Opera Company, which was organized in Chicago about a month ago for a Summer campaign, has gone to pieces in New-Orleans, and the members are getting home as best they can. The troupe consisted of about 30 persons, most of whom were taken from Chicago church choirs.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 4.--The September sun shone more mildly on the State Fair visitors to-day. The crowd was smaller than yesterday, but the cash receipts now guarantee all costs, and to-morrow's gate money will be clear profit. NORWICH, Sept. 4.--The great Falls Cotton Mill at Norwich Falls, in this city, has shut down for a month, throwing hundreds of employes out of work. During the interval the operatives and their families will have to live by their wits.

A new iron steamship for the Old Dominion Line was launched yesterday at Roach's yard, in Chester, Penn. The new vessel is named the Seneca. Her dimensions are: Length, 300 feet; breadth of beam, 42 feet, and depth of hold 2 feet. She registers 3,000 tons and has iron docks. Miss. C. Robinson, youngest daughter of J.H. Robinson, of Baltimore, Vice-President of the company, christened the Seneca.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 4.--The game between the Cincinnati Union and Wilminton Clubs was brought to a close in the middle of the fourth inning, when Umpire Dutton was struck in the mouth by a foul ball and seriously, and it was at first thought fatally, injured. The score stood 5 to 3 in favor of Cincinnati.
The Commissioners of Emigration received yesterday a copy of a dispatch from J.H. Bailey, United States Consul at Hamburg, in regard to the shipping of pauper immigrants to this country.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 4.--The managers of the County Fair held in Jamestown this week had intended to have a political discussion, and so advertised, but the Republicans did not produce a man. Consequently only the Hon. William Dorsheimer, the Democratic champion, spoke in the Opera House. In spite of the intense heat and the consequent discomfort a very large audience listened to his arguments in favor of electing Gov. Cleveland to the Presidential chair.

A few of the creditors of Samuel Lowden, the missing builder, met last evening in Lowden's office, and talked things over in private. They found that they could do nothing, as the accounts were not made out. As no provision was made to pay the bookkeeper for doing this work, it will probably be a day or two before they do find out how things stand. Nothing further has been heard from the missing man.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 4.--A special train for Philadelphia left here to-day with about 300 members of the British Association for the Advancement of Science on board. Capt. Bedford Pim said as the train moved off: "I shall endeavor to have the Lord Mayor and Aldermen of London invite the American Association to the British metropolis in 1886."

Morton on Sunday, during which Frederick Kopf was killed.

ST. JOHNSVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 4.--Emma, the 8-year-old daughter of John C. Shulenbergh, went too near the stove on Wednesday, and her clothes caught fire. The child's mother tried to extinguish the flames, but was very badly--it is feared fatally--burned in so doing. The child died from the effects of her injuries to-day.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 4.--The town of Leicester, six miles from Worcester, celebrated to-day the one hundredth anniversary of its famous academy, which is still one of the most prosperous schools of Central Massachusetts.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 4.--At an adjourned meeting of the Board of Managers of the State Lunatic Asylum in this city Dr. L.A. Tourtellot, of Utica, who had preferred charges, against the officers of the asylum again failed to appear.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4.--The Democrats to-day made the following nominations for county and city officers and for Congress: For Judge of Common Pleas--Thomas R. Elcock, (a renomination;) of Orphan's Court--William B. Hanna, ( Republican and the present Judge in that court;) for City Controller--William N. Hirst; for Recorder of Deeds--William F. McCully. For Congress--In the First, Second, Fourth, and Fifth Districts the nomination of candidates was postponed. In the Third District Samuel J. Randall was renominated.

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 4.--Plentiful rains fell here to-day for the first time in 12 weeks, allaying the fear of a general water famine. In some sections of the city water has been an article of commerce for two weeks past.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 4.--The forty-fourth annual exhibition of the State Agricultural Society was opened to-day. All the departments are filled to overflowing, the entries numbering nearly 4,000, 700 being cattle and 400 horses. It presents the best stove display ever shown. The weather is fine, and the ground is in splendid shape, promising a large attendance for the succeeding days.
Further testimony concerning the report of the Newark Savings Institution's investments, filed with Secretary of State Kelsey, was taken before Vice-Chancellor Van Fleet, in Newark, yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 4.--At the Minneapolis Fair races to-day the attendance was very large, the weather fair, and the track cuppy and slow. The event of the day was a race between the pacers Johnstone and Richball, for $5,000, best two in three.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 4.--At the State shoot to-day there were two contests, each divided into four classes of ties. The shooting was first class and the best done yet. E.H. Moody, of Niagara Falls, won the first prize in the first contest, and the second prize was divided.

A meeting of the St. Nicholas Society was held last evening at the Hotel Brunswick. BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 4--10 P.M.-- Marathon, a thrifty town 30 miles from this city on the Syracuse and Binghamton Railway, is in flames. The fire is burning fiercely and two blocks have already been destroyed. The Binghamton Fire Department has been called on for aid.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4.--The dry goods commission house of Brooks, Miller Co., of this city, have made an assignment ts Edward S. Harlan, a lawyer, at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The firm's rating was about $75,000. Liabilities and assets not yet known.

The Uhlmann divorce case was continued yesterday before Referee Dwight, in the Columbia Law School. The parties to the suit were very much chagrined that, after all the pains they have taken to prevent it, the affair should have got into the newspapers.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 4.--Contrary to its usual custom, the Memphis Jockey Club have decided not to have Fall races. Last Winter's meeting at New-Orleans was a failure on account of the weather and the difficulty of obtaining crowds during the busy cotton season. The circuit being thus broken, Memphis cannot hope for good fields of horses. The same reasons also hold here as at New-Orleans.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 4.--The Veteran Firemen of Philadelphia arrived here from Boston to-day, accompanied by the Weceacoe Band. They were taken by the New-Haven Veteran Firemen on an excursion to Fisher's Island, and to-night a parade and fireworks were given in their honor. To-morrow they finish their excursion and return to Philadelphia.

The village of Sing Sing was gorgeous in gay-colored bunting, flags, banners, and a variety of decorations, yesterday, in honor of the largest firemen's parade ever seen in Westchester County. At least 2,000 men, 15 bands, and 23 fire companies paraded through the various streets over a line of march seven miles in length.

GENEVA, N.Y., Sept. 4.--The death of Secretary Charles J. Folger occurred here at 4:55 o'clock this afternoon at his home on Mainstreet. Although everybody here knew of his serious illness, his death has been a great shock to the whole community.

ROME, Sept. 4.--Evidences of the cholera panic throughout Italy continue to multiply. The populace at Pazzuoli attempted to-day to stop the railway service from Naples. A mob here in Rome drove a priest who had just arrived from Naples away from the city. At Ovieto travelers are refused entrance into the city.

Charles G. Hill, Cashier of the National Bank at New-Brunswick, N.J., failed to appear at the usual hour for breakfast yesterday morning. It was supposed that he had overslept himself, and a servant was sent to his room to arouse him.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 4.--A desperate Conflict between a burglar named Peter Quinlan and John Kearney, the proprietor of a store, occurred here last night.

The Chicago players won another game from the New-Yorks on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The game began in good style and gave promise of a close contest, but Welch and Ewing were both injured and retired in the second inning, and the Chicagos had everything their own ...

At the meeting of the Emigration Commissioners last week a committee, of which Mr. Ulrich is Chairman, was instructed to draw up regulations for the landing of immigrants to be sent to the Secretary of the Treasury for approval.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4.--George Holland, of Evergreen, Montcalm County, Mich., was killed by melon thieves last night. He heard them in his garden, and taking a shot gun chased them out. He shot at one of the thieves and missed him, whereupon the intruder turned, and wresting the gun from Holland, struck him over the head, killing him instantly. There is no clew, so far, as to who the murderer was.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 4.--While Blaine was engaged among the farmers at Manchester to-day some of his friends held a large meeting at Sebago Lake, near Portland. About 5,000 people were present.

A dispatch was received in Wall-street yesterday which stated that W.H. Vanderbilt had perfected arrangements for organizing a new route between Chicago and Portland, Me., to enable him to strike back at the Grand Trunk in the latter's own territory.

Miss. Minnie Maddern signed a contract to play "Caprice" in one of the Brooklyn theatres during the last week in August, but changed her mind and has now concluded to play the piece at the house of another manager. The managers of the theatre with whom she concluded the first contract have sued out an injunction. Miss. Maddern answers that she is only 19 years of age and not, therefore, bound by the contract.

HAMBURG, Sept. 4.--The Hamburg-American Line steamship Frisin, Capt. Kopff, sld. hence to-day for New-York.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 4.--His Excellency, Don Arturo de Marcoartun, a distinguished Spanish diplomat who has been attending the meetings of the British Association, says, in regard to the question of a reciprocal treaty between Canada and the Spanish-American Colonies, that Cortes has this year given to the Spanish Government power to negotiate a commercial treaty in the interest of Cuba and Porto Rico.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 4.--The disbandment last night of the Minneapolis Baseball Club means the death of the Northtwestern League, which has now been reduced to three clubs, the Milwaukee, St. Paul, and Winona.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 4.--Frank Patterson, owner of the opera house here, is missing, and detectives, with warrants for his arrest, are searching for him. He is charged with having forged the indorsements of a number of well-known residents of Monmouth County on notes aggregating over $20,000.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 4.--The answer of the Sentinel company in the Blaine libel suit was filed in the United States court this morning. The defense admits printing and publishing the article complained of in an issue of Aug. 8. 1884, and denies that it was false in any particular.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 4.--Henry Johnson, age 25, colored, who has been in jail one year for burglary, hanged himself with his bed blanket today. When cut down he was unconscious, and blood was trickling from his ears. He recovered, but is despondent, and says he will never leave the jail alive.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 4.--Prominent and well-informed Butlerites state that negotiations are being made looking to a fusion of the Democrats and Butlerites in Wisconsin on both the State and Electoral tickets. Should this be accomplished it would make the contest in Wisconsin a very close one. The Butler men have already nominated a ticket, and the Democratic State Convention will be held here on the 10th inst.
BOSTON, Sept. 4.--The headless body of Dr. Black, the surgeon of the Tallapoosa, was found floating in Muskeget Channel Tuesday afternoon.

FORT PLAIN, Sept. 4.--Kate Smulsey's parents and brother say that up to this evening she has lived 177 days without food. She is in about the same condition now that she was a month ago. Interest in her case in this vicinity continues unabated.

Charles James Folger was a native of the quaint old island of Nantucket. His ancestors, representatives of the best New-England stock, settled there in 1636, when the place was largely peopled with Indians.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4.--The old Republican ring, which was driven from power through the efforts of the Citizens' Committee of One Hundred, is fast regaining control of the city. Strange as it may seem, the great success of the Committee of One Hundred was the immediate cause of its own downfall.

The members of the American and the British Associations for the Advancement of Science will unite in several excursions from Philadelphia to Long Branch next Saturday. One party will reach Long Branch by a special train over the Pennsylvania Railroad, and will spend the day at the West End Hotel, where a dinner will be given.

The assurances that have been given of Secretary FOLGER'S chances of recovery lend something of a shock to the sudden close of his career. That career has not been brilliant, but it has been, as a whole, highly honorable and useful.

BOSTON, Sept. 4.--The Greenback or National Party State Convention, the call for which was issued before Gen. Butler had announced his scheme of a People's Party, was held here today.
E.I. Burritt has resigned as Eastern Passenger Agent of the West Shore route. The city business will hereafter be under the personal supervision of the General Passenger Agent.

There was little air stirring at Sheepshead Bay yesterday, and the heat at the race track was intense. There were six contests decided, and the favorites were more fortunate than on the preceding days, as four of them were successful. In a well-known sporting house at Far Rockaway early yesterday morning about 500 members of the sporting fraternity assembled to witness a hard-glove fight, according to the Marquis of Queensberry rules, between Tim McHugh, of New-York, and Dave Fitzgerald, who hails from Toronto.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 4.--Mr. Blaine's presence at the New-England Fair to-day put a good many extra half dollars in the coffers of the association, although the crowd was not quite so large as yesterday, when a balloon ascension was the principal attraction. Mr. Blaine is the guest of ex-Gov. Smythe. He was driven about the city this morning, and the crowds at the fair grounds were kept waiting for fully an ...
LONDON, Sept. 4.--Mme. Nilsson has signed a contract with Col. Mapleson to sing in England and America for $2,400 per night.

EASTON, Penn., Sept. 4.--Frank Raub, aged 12 years, of South Easton, quarreled with Fred Epstein about a week ago. The boys came to blows, and in the fight Raub was thrown by Epstein. When Raub got up he seized a stone and hurled it at Epstein, striking him in the head.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 4.--Westmont paced a mile to-day over this rather slow track in 2:14, the fastest mile ever made here in harness.
LYNCHBURG, Va., Sept. 4.--Intense excitement exists among the colored population here over the arrest of the Rev. Philip Cobbs on the charge of criminal intimacy with one of his congregation.

The friends and relatives of Mrs. Shaw, of No. 344 Ninth-avenue, who fell down an uncovered companionway on board the steamer Sirius on Wednesday and died from her injuries, are unanimous in the expression of their belief that the owners of the boat are to blame for her death.
WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 4.--The steel nail question has begun to assume a serious aspect.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 4.--Barrett, Waters Lewis, manufacturers and wholesale dealers in wood and willow ware, cordage and twine, made an assignment to-day to Lawrence Maxwell. The firm were rated by the mercantile agencies in July at from $200,000 to $250,000.

A complimentary benefit was given Frank Whittaker, better known as old "Pop" Whittaker, the veteran master of ceremonies, in Clarendon Hall, last evening. Whittaker has met with some reverses of late, and besides losing his arm ...

A reception and exhibition will be given this evening, at 8 o'clock, in St. Paul Evangelical Church, Thirty-fourth-street, between Sev enth and Eighth avenues, upon the occasion of the close of the Summer session of the Free Christian Kindergarten.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4.--In spite of the positive denials made by Sergts. Brainerd and Long, who are now on exhibition at Cleveland, army officers here stick to their belief that the published statements of some of the contents of the Greely party's diaries are substantially true.

HILLSBOROUGH, Ill., Sept. 4.--About two weeks ago John Bartlett, residing at Fillmore, 15 miles southeast of here, bought a box of sardines for his sick daughter. She ate them and was taken violently sick.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4.--"Yankee" Robinson, the well-known showman, died at New-Jefferson, Iowa, at 4 o'clock this afternoon. He was 66 years of age, and had devoted nearly 50 years of his life to the show business.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 4.--Deputy Marshal Jacob Frey, of Baltimore, telegraphs the authorities here that he does not want May White, who is supposed to be the beautiful and penniless young lady who applied for aid here yesterday.

TORONTO, Sept. 4.--County Judge Boyd this afternoon gave his decision in the case against the Holly Company, of Lockport, N.Y., acquitting them entirely of any complicity in the attempts to bribe the members of the City ...

The Hungaria, a new steamship of the Hamburg Packet Line, as now in this port, and will sail for Hamburg to-day. The new vessel is of steel and has been built for carrying immigrants and freight. Her between decks are high ...

Among the passengers of the White Star steamship Britannic, which leaves for Liverpool to-day, are Bishop J. Hobart Brown, of Fond du Lac; the Rev. George William Douglas, of Trinity Parish; Lieut.-Col. Bingham, R.J. Rolston, Samuel Montague, and Dr. Asher.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 5.--A most deliberate and brutal murder occurred at the residence of Col. Charles Parrott this morning. James Greiner had been paying attention to Gretchen Zeling, a beautiful German girl, aged 20 years, and became frantically jealous because of the attentions paid her by others.

RAHWAY, N.J., Sept. 5.--Edward F. Merritt, who was found dead early last Tuesday morning on the stairway of a saloon in Reading, Penn., leaves a widow in this city, and it is indirectly owing to his parents' objection to his marriage that his death is due.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--The Second Congressional District Democratic Convention-- Congressman Finnerty's district--met to-day, and, after several names had been placed before ...
NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 5.--One hundred of the most prominent gentlemen in this city have formed an association for the furtherance of the game of lawn-tennis.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--Information has been received at Springfield, Ill., this evening of an outbreak of supposed Texas fever among cattle near Chatham, in Sangamon County.
COHOES, N.Y., Sept. 5.--The announcement that ex-Assemblyman Delehanty, of this city, has come out for Blaine and Logan, causes no surprise here.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5.--This has proved to be the hottest day of the season here. There was an absence of the regular breezes, and many persons were of the opinion that they never suffered so much in any part of the world as they did upon this memorable day.

VICKSBURG, Sept. 5.--One of the saddest tragedies that ever blotted the fair name of Vicksburg occurred here to-day and resulted in the death of Capt. James T. Metzler, a prominent river steamboat man, and Capt. J.W. Bourne, Deputy Internal Revenue Collector for this district.

On Thursday evening Patrick Kearns, a laborer, residing at Bay Shore, Suffolk County, when he returned home from his work commenced to abuse his wife, and from words he soon came to blows, taking an axe handle and beating her over the head until she fell unconscious to the floor.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 5.--At the meeting of the Common Council to-night Mayor Haynes nominated F.C. Runyon for Auditor of Accounts, vice Charles H. Gleason, resigned. The nomination was confirmed unanimously.

LIVERPOOL, Sept. 5.--A leading grain circular says: "The grain market continues very quiet. There is little change in prices. Foreign and English sorts are firmly held, with an occasional advance. The demand for cargoes is limited.

SUAKIN, Sept. 5.--The rebels attacked Kassala in great force, and were defeated with heavy losses.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 5.--The Chantauqua County Fair has been a decided success. It was held in Marvin Park, the new ground fitted up by Judge Richard P. Marvin.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 5.--A cave-in, covering an area of 95 acres, occurred about 12:30 o'clock this morning at a point near Plainsville, on the line of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, and directly over the workings of the Enterprise Colliery.

William Mehl, aged 22 years, of No. 223 Rivington-street, New-York, was drowned at Glen Island while bathing yesterday, in company with his brother. Coroner Hyler, of Port Chester, held an inquest in the afternoon, and a verdict was rendered in accordance with the above facts.
LEWISTON, Me., Sept. 5.--A great deal of energy was expended on the part of the Republicans of the Second Maine District to make the closing rally of the campaign at Lewiston to-day a grand success.

The new plan to reorganize the Ohio Central Railroad provides for the issue of a new 5 per cent. bond, which shall be exchanged for the old first mortgage bonds, with 20 per cent. in preferred stock as a bonus.

READING, Penn., Sept. 5.--On Wednesday a man named Jacob Riegel, aged 46, died after two days' illness. His young wife appeared distracted with grief, and when asked the cause of her husband's death said that it was cholera morbus.
The programme for to-day's races at Sheepshead Bay is extraordinary as to the number of entries, 92 starters being announced, and most of them are of a high class.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 5.--A leading pork packer remarked to-day that the hog crop in the region tributary to Cincinnati would be late this season in coming in, owing to the partial failure of the corn crop on account of the drought.

The anticipated struggle between Emigration Commissioners Ulrich and Stephenson did not come off yesterday at the special meeting of the committee of the Board of Emigration having in hand the drawing up of rules for the landing of immigrants.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 5.--The cold and backward season has been disastrous to many hotel keepers along the Sound shore. Osborn Southwick's Sea View House, at Savin Rock, was shut up to-day under an attachment, having sunk $4,000 this season.

A judgment for $713,125 72, principal, interest, and costs, was entered in the Supreme Court yesterday in favor of the Marine National Bank and against all the members of the firm of Grant Ward excepting William C. Smith.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 5.--In Alpine Township, nine miles north of this city, Drs. W.H. Dreamhand and Joel C. Parker yesterday exhumed the greater portion of the skeleton of a mastodon 12 feet in height.

The Republican Congressional Committee asks the press to call attention to its desirable line of campaign documents, offered in lots to suit purchasers at the exceedingly low price of from 40 cents to $1.25 per hundred.

BUFFALO, Sept. 5.--Interest in the State pigeon shoot culminated in to-day's events. Mr. and Mrs. Bolan lived at No. 352 Central-avenue, Newark. Mrs. Eilen Ballmore and her husband were their immediate neighbors. Bolan had a contract for stone quarrying, and employed 20 men.

LONDON, Sept. 5.--Mr. Sims Reeves, the famous tenor, has been talking on musical topics to a newspaper man. He declared that Italian opera was dying out.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5.--The Star publishes an interview with a naval officer who was on board of one of the Greely relief vessels, who said:

CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--The political atmosphere of the Northwest, unlike that of the East, is surcharged with the electricity of excitement and enthusiasm. The Democracy of this great region are not only hopeful but confident.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 5.--At the residence of Prof. William Henry Peck, the well-known story writer, a quiet marriage occurred last evening. Miss Myrtis Peck, the Professor's daughter, was the bride and Charles G. Matthews of Charleston, S.C., the groom.

KINGSTON, Sept. 5.--Frank Bates and William C. Odell, the two young men who were arrested in Newburg with a large quantity of silverware, revolvers, , in their possession, believed to have been stolen, have been identified as men who committed an extensive burglary in Sharon, Conn., and have been taken to that place.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 5.--Within the past few days attachments of about $30,000 have been put on the Lacowsic Mill, at Hampden, owned and run by George A. Weber, of Stamford, Conn., who does business in New-York.

LOCKPORT, Sept. 5.--The inventory of accounts in the assignment of Witmer Brothers, well-known bankers at Suspension Bridge, was filed by F. Spaulding, Assignee, to-day. The total liabilities, including individuals, are ...

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 5.--The miners at the Hicbox, Springfield and Wilmington Coal Company's mines have gone out on strike for an increase from 2 to 3 cents per bushel. The neighboring mines are now paying 3 cents.

More discoveries were made yesterday in the case of A. Maas, formerly traveling salesman for Messrs. D. Buchner Co., tobacco manufacturers, at No. 173 Duane-street, who is now under arrest at St. Louis on the charge of forgery.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 5.--A very unusual case has just come to light. Alfred L. Cary, Public Administrator, was this forenoon directed to take charge of the estate of Wilhelmine Riecke, a German woman, who died on Monday ...

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 5.--Reports to the Commissioner of Agriculture from all parts of this State show great damage to the cotton crop from recent excessive rains. The demage is estimated at 20 per cent.

The State election in Maine occurs on Monday next, when Governor, four Representatives in Congress, Legislature, and county officers will be chosen, and a proposed prohibitory amendment to the Constitution of the State will be voted upon by the people.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 5.--The August output of the Lake Superior copper mines so far as reported is as follows: Calumet and Hecla, 2,277 tons; Atlantic, 176; Huron, 118; Allouez, 102; Copper Falls, 59; Hancock, 36.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 5.--The body of Charles S. Hill, Cashier of the National Bank of New-Jersey, who was found dead in his bed yesterday morning, lay all day to-day in a handsome cloth-covered coffin in the parlor of his late home, a three-story brick house opposite Masonic Hall.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 5.--The case of Samuel Roberts was before the Grand Jury to-day, and a true bill of indictment in two counts--larceny and embezzlement--was found against him.

There were 178 failures in the United States reported to Bradstreet's during the week, against 169 in the preceding week, and 142, 121, and 65 in the corresponding weeks of 1883, 1882, and 1881, respectively. About 82 per cent. were those of small traders whose capital was less than $5,000.

Six weary scribes, who for the past three scorching days have been haunting the Barge Office with an amount of interest only equaled by their sense of duty, ascertained with much manifestation of pleasure yesterday that the steamship America had arrived at Quarantine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5, 1884. The Post Officer Inspectors have discovered a shortage in the accounts of the Postmaster at Ashland, Penn., amounting to $408 in the money order department, and $487 in the postal account. The Postmaster has offered to make good the deficit, but the Inspectors have been directed to take charge of the office and arrest the Postmaster.
ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Sept. 5.-- Captain Traynor arrived in his dory at Trepassey yesterday in good health. He intends to proceed upon his Atlantic voyage.

Miss Rose Coghlan was radiant as the morning sun yesterday as she landed at the Barge Office. Her face was wreathed with smiles, and she looked the personification of well-dressed health.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 5.--Funeral services over the remains of Bishop Pierce were held at the Court House in Sparta, this State, to-day. The churches were too small to accommodate the throngs which toured into the town from far and near to pay the last tribute of respect to the dead. Business in the town was wholly suspended, and many places of business and ...

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 5.--Philip L. Garrison, 73 years old, formerly a dentist of Newton, N.J., but for several years a resident of this place, was found dead about 6 A.M. in his son-in-law's barn, in Maple-avenue.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 5.--About 6 o'clock to-night as Miss Carrie Tyler, a school teacher, was passing the residence of Alderman Carlisle, she was attacked by a savage bulldog which sprang from the Alderman's stoop. Her arm was terribly lacerated before the brute was removed. She was taken to her home, where she lies in a critical condition.

WHITE RIVER JUNCTION, Vt., Sept. 5.-- Returns from 240 towns, giving the complete Gubernatorial vote of the State, show the following result: Total vote cast, 62,421. Of this number Pingree(Rep.) received 41,917; Redington, (Dem.,) ...

CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--When the steamer Sheboygan was opposite the Marine Hospital, on her way to Milwaukee, about 9 o'clock this morning, a young man who was standing on the deck with other passengers suddenly threw off his coat, and, before those about him could realize his intentions, he leaned overboard and was drowned.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 5.--At the naval court of inquiry investigating the cause of the collision between the Tallapoosa and the schooner James C. Lowell, the testimony for the schooner having been closed, the testimony for the steamer was opened to-day.

The New-Orleans Times-Democrat at the beginning of the present month devoted a large amount of space to a review of the industrial, financial, and educational condition of the twelve distinctively Southern States, omitting from that category the old slave States of Delaware, Maryland, and Missouri.

The races at Brighton Reach were largely attended yesterday, notwithstanding the intensely warm weather. The events were as follows:

CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--Capt. George Finney, owner of the schooner John Bigler, this morning received from Marquette, Mich., a dispatch that the vessel sprung a leak on Monday morning and sank Wednesday night, the crew being saved.
PARIS, Sept. 5.--The irritation of the French press against England is spreading to the public. A journal called the Anti-Anglais is selling in large numbers on the boulevards.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 5.--Lieut. Freeman H. Crosby, executive officer of the steamer Bear, of the Greely relief expedition, arrived at home to-day.
It was so cool in Newfoundland yesterday that gentlemen were comfortable in light overcoats, and on Cape Sabine a drop of hot coffee would freeze in falling to the ground.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--A special from Matamoros, Mexico, tells of a desperate battle between the ranchmen and a notorious band of cattle thieves at Las Vegas.

Frederick Linsley, of No. 520 Grand-, street; Benjamin Hymen, of No. 34 Ridge-street and Thomas J. Pitman, of No. 550 Grand-street, appeared before Justice Patterson yesterday, in the Essex Market Police Court, to answer to the charge of selling oleomargarine.

GENEVA, N.Y., Sept. 5.--Nearly every business place and residence in this village, which was the home of the late Secretary Folger for over 45 years, is draped in heavy mourning. It is safe to say that no death has occurred since Lincoln's assassination that has so moved the people of Geneva as Folger's.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 5.--State Treasurer Barksdale was here to-day to confer with Judge Hughes regarding the recent coupon decision, and it is understood that the Judge has consented to a rehearing at an early session of the court.

Chittenden, Townsend Chittenden, counsel for E.M. Knox and others; who obtained the injunction against the Board of Aldermen in the matter of the Broadway railroad franchise, yesterday went before Judge Donohue and presented certain amendments in their complaint.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 5.--The annual races of the Hampden Park Association closed to-day, the meeting having been one of the most successful ever held here.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 5.--The list of the victims of Frank Patterson, the alleged forger, who is under arrest at Philadelphia, grows larger daily. Henry Kroehl, a wealthy resident of the Park, cashed one of the forged notes for $800.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 5.--A scheme is on foot for constructing, at the expense of the Government, a canal connecting the St. Lawrence River at Longueuil with tue Richelieu River at Chambly; such canal to be about 11 miles long. It will reduce the waterway between Montreal and New-York abuut 80 miles for Hudson River boats.

Congressman Nicholas Ford, the Butler candidate for Governor in Missouri, writes to the New-York State Committee of that party that he is hopeful "that in the coming struggle Missouri may be in a position to announce eight of her Electoral votes for Butler and West."

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 5.--The sending of the regiment of Louisiana field artillery to install the Democratic candidate for Judge at New-Iberia, and keeping them there a week to prevent an imaginary outbreak, has already borne fruits.

Mr. Kelly had begun a suit in the Court of Common Pleas to recover $25,000 damages for an alleged breach of contract.

LONDON, Sept. 5.--A petition has been presented to the court for an order to wind up the Monarch Line Steamship Company. Shares of the nominal value of 9 are quoted at 10s.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 5.--Ten persons out of 17 who were confined in the County Jail made their escape last night by sawing off several bars of the iron grating of a ventilating register in the floor. None of them have been recaptured.

The origin of the circular letter, which, as was published in THE TIMES yesterday, has been sent by dealers in and manufacturers of plumbers' supplies in this city to architects in different parts of the country, was the result of a meeting held in the United States Hotel about two weeks ago.

The court room of Justice McMahon, at Gravesend, was filled on Thursday afternoon with citizens called together to protest against the grant to the Manhattan Beach Company of the 317 acres of land at Sheepshead Bay referred to in THE TIMES of Tuesday last.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 5.--Mrs. Robert A. Alston died in Decatur to-night at 6 o'clock. She was the widow of the late Col. Robert A. Alston, who was murdered some years ago in the executive office by Capt. Edward Cox.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5.--The English guests of the American Association for the Advancement of Science upon their arrival at Germantown Junction at 1:30 o'clock this morning were met by a delegation of 20 of their hosts, who, with Mayor Smith, had patiently awaited them for three hours.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 5.--The returns to the State Department of Agriculture Sept. 1 have just been compiled. The reports show that a drought of from four to six weeks has prevailed generally throughout the State, proving very injurious to growing crops.

Tickets good, going Saturday, Sept. 6, on any regular train except the fast limited express. To Utica and return, $6; to Syracuse and return, $8; to Rochester and return, $8; to Buffalo, Niagara Falls, or Suspension Bridge and return, $8.
ALBANY, Sept. 5.--Gov. Cleveland has spent the day in the transaction of official business, and has been less interrupted by visitors than on any previous day since his return from the woods.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 5.--At the Greenback State Convention to-day Gen. Benjamin F. Butler was indorsed as a Presidential candidate. George W. Carpenter, of Swansea, was nominated for Governor, and John F. Woodbury and J.E. Williams, of Lancaster, for Congressmen. The platform of the National Convention at Indianapolis was indorsed.

BINGHAMTON, Sept. 5.--About 11 o'clock last evening a fire broke out in Hazen Block, a three-story wooden structure in the village of Marathon, on the Syracuse and Binghamton Railroad, 31 miles from this city.
