ST. PETERSBURG, Sept. 5.--The railway line over which the Czar will travel to Warsaw has been specially inspected and will be furnished with military patrols along the entire way.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--James M. Gamble, of the firm of J. J.M. Gamble, wealthy realestate dealers here, jumped from the thirdstory window of the flat building No. 48 Congress-street into the alley below at 2 o'clock this morning.

FORTRESS MONROE, Va., Sept. 5.--Mrs. Harian, wife of ex-Senator and ex-Secretary of the Interior James Harlan, of Iowa, died at Hygeia Hotel last night at midnight. Her body was taken to Washington to-night, and was accompanied by Secretary and Mrs. Lincoln.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 5.--The assignment made by the Minnesota Elevator Company, of Redwing, was followed to-day by that of the Mazeppa Mill Company, of the same place, to W.H. Putnam. In fact, the latter failure, though somewhat delayed, was really the cause of the elevator company's troubles.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 5.--John Gick stabbed Mrs. Mary Hannon in the thigh this morning, inflicting a dangerous wound. Gick's wife and Mrs. Hannon became involved in a quarrel, and Mrs. Hannon had Mrs. Gick down and was beating her. The latter called to her husband, who rushed out of the house and stabbed Mrs. Hannon.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 5.--H. Prostof, a prominent citizen of New-Philadelphia, shot himself in Lake View Park about noon to-day and died instantly.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 5.--In a glove fight here to-night Dick Egan, "the Troy Terror," knocked out Hughes, "the Dangerous Blacksmith," in three rounds. Hughes being exhausted. The police prevented further fighting. A large amount of money changed hands.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 5.--The stove molders' strike, which has been maintained for nine months by the union at a cost in wages of $5,000 a day, was broken to-day by half of Redway Burton's men going back to work at the same rate of wages against which they struck.

NASHVILLE, Sept. 5.--Intelligenee comes from Guthrie, Ky., that considerable excitement and alarm exists near Elkton on account of the death of Mr. Bell, a prominent citizen of Todd County, from what Dr. McReynolds pronounced genuine cholera.

READING, Penn., Sept. 5.--John S. Holtzman, the Democratic candidate for County Treasurer, is charged with having put his mother in the County almshouse in 1869, where he left her to die and be buried in Potter's field.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 5.--Sharpers with O'Brien's Circus got $1,250 from Marshall Foote, a farmer, 78 years of age, of Lee, Mass., by the three card monte game.

In less than six months' time the Rev. Joseph Byron has erected a new church in East One Hundred and Nineteenth-street, and in it he celebrated mass for the first time yesterday morning. Services were held at 7 o'clock, with 600 people present, and at 9 o'clock 800 assisted at the mass.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 8.--When the 6:30 afternoon train from New-Haven, on the Derby Railroad, stopped at the West Haven station to-day, an exciting episode occurred which had a taste of the wild, untamed West about it.

Col. GEORGE BLISS returns to his task of defending Mr. BLAINE to say that he thinks we are mistaken in inferring that Mr. BLAINE had in mind the $25,000 worth of Northern Pacific stock which he had agreed to deliver to WARREN FISHER and ELISHA ATKINS when in his letter of April 22, 1872, he spoke of leaving to the chances of the future things that would benefit him.

For several nights in succession a man walked to and fro before Alderman Quintard's house, in Greene-avenue, Brooklyn, whistling repeatedly through his fingers and hammering on a board tree-covering with his cane. He sometimes kept it up until 2 o'clock in the morning to the great annoyance of the Alderman's family and their neighbors.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 8.--The fire area, as defined last night, was not broken, as it was surrounded by a cordon of engines, which left the material already on fire to burn, while plying all their strength to keep the flames from leaping across into new fields. GENEVA, N.Y., Sept. 8.--It is expected that 10,000 visitors will be in Geneva to-morrow in attendance on Secretary Folger's funeral. The railroad companies leading into Geneva will run extra trains in order to accommodate people wishing to attend the funeral, the final arrangements for which were completed this evening.
BERNE, Sept, 8.--The International Copyright Congress assembled here to-day. Delegates from 10 different countries were present.

MADRID, Sept. 8.--An American clergyman who was making a tour through the Peninsula, accompanied by his daughters, arrived a few days ago at San Sebastian, a watering place on the northern coast of Spain, not far from the French border, and put up at the Hotel Inglese. While there the gentleman died of heart disease.

The only topic of conversation at Bergen Point yesterday was the adventure of Miss Grace P. Furniss, a young lady well known in local society, with a burglar early on Sunday morning. Miss Furniss is the daughter of Mrs. L.E. Furniss, a wealthy widow, who resides in one of the handsomest residences on Sixteenth-street.

Two hundred and ninety-three very much disappointed young girls went away from the Normal College with heavy hearts yesterday. They had passed the 75 per cent. average on examination for admission, and confidently expected to at once begin studies fitting them to earn their livelihood as teachers. The "introductory" class numbered 791.

AUGUSTA, Sept. 8.--To-night the Republicans of Augusta held a great jubilee over the result of the election. The returns were received at Meonian Hall, and speeches were made by citizens and visitors. At 9 o'clock a procession was formed on Water-street and marched to the residence of Mr. Blaine, cheering all along the line.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 6.--The weather to-day, the second day of the racing here, was very warm, the track stiff and heavy in spots, and the attendance good.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 8.--The Australian steamer Zealandia, which arrived here this morning, brings particulars of the boat race between Edward Hanlan, of Toronto, and William Beach, of Sydney, which was rowed on the Paramatta River on Aug. 16. The Zealandia left Sydney on the day before the race occurred, but ...

LONDON, Sept. 8.--The Pall Mall Gazette says the Chinese Government has made a declaration of war in the form of a manifesto from the Emperor to the people. The Emperor declares that he regards the French action as constituting a state of war, and he calls upon his subjects to aid in repelling the foe.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8, 1884. Postmaster-General Gresham and Secretary Chandler have gone to New-York to attend the funeral of the late Secretary Folger. Secretary Teller is also expected to be present.

The examination in the case of Patrick Judge, who is charged with having thrown the beer glass which struck and killed Frederick Kopf, during the excursion of the Empire Steam Laundry Association on Sunday, Aug. 31, was resumed before Justice O'Reilly, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday. The only witness produced by the prosecution was a German lad named August Druse, about 13 years old, who lives at No. 82 King-street.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 8.--This has been a gala day for Elmira. It is estimated that there were 50,000 persons in the city and on the fair grounds, Gov. Cleveland, accompanied by Private Secretary Lamont and Adjt.-Gen. Farnsworth, arrived here at 5:40 o'clock this morning.

The right to occupy Forty-second-street between Lexington and Fourth avenues, has long been enjoyed by the Houston, West-Street, and Pavonia Ferry Railroad Company. By lease from it the Third-Avenue Railroad Company enjoys a similar right. Both companies claim, under the General Railroad act, the privilege to extend their lines from end to end of Forty-second-street.

AUGUSTA, Sept. 8.--It is impossible at this time to give exact figures as to the result of the election, but there is abundant evidence in the returns at hand of the realization of the hopes of the Republican Party managers. Robie's plurality will probably reach 13,000, possibly more. All the Republican Congressmen are re-elected.

SARATOGA, Sept. 8.--The National Prison Association is holding its sessions here, President Rutherford B. Hayes presiding. At the First Baptist Church yesterday morning the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott preached the annual sermon. Among those on the platform were ex-President Hayes, the Rev. Dr. Byers, Prof. Francis Wayland, and W.M.F. Round.

The returns up to the hour of writing from Maine indicate a Republican majority of some 17,000 to 18,000. The returns have been sent, compared with those of September, 1880--a silly mode of comparison which only requires a little more analysis to get at the probable result. The Blaine managers will claim a great victory.
The "Workingmen" of the First District of Oncida County have nominated Henry M. Steber, of Utica, for the Assembly.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 9.--The hot weather, which would have materially benefited the city in July or the early part of August, has evidently arrived in earnest, to-day being the hottest of the season. Mrs. J.V.L. Prayn. of Albany, gave a children's dancing party at her cottage this afternoon and evening.

The rumble of trains and the rattling of carts and trucks over the pavement, mingled with the shouts of the drivers, in the neighborhood of Forty-second-street and Madison-avenue contrasted strangely with the solemn funeral services that were being conducted at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity yesterday morning.
The firm of Dessar, Wise Co., clothing manufacturers, of No. 452 Broadway, this city, and St. Louis, confessed judgment in favor of creditors to the amount of $68,210.18 on Sept. 1.

David S. Hill, while despondent last night, shot himself in the head at his home, No. 318 Fourth-street, Jersey City. He was a milk dealer, 41 years old, and married.

A gentleman writes to THE TIMES that in nearly every ward in Bellevue Hospital there were two or more cases of typhoid fever, and asks why it is that all the typhoid cases are not confined to one ward, and contagion thus guarded against.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Sept. 9.--Oliver H. Bateman, a young man arrested for the double crime of murder and a previous outrage committed on the two little McLaughlin girls, near Flag Springs, on Aug. 31, last night made a confession to a reporter...

CALHOUN, Ga., Sept. 9.--Casey Williams, alias Hiram Nettles, alias George Nichols, a notorious Alabama murderer and desperado, has been discovered hiding out in this county and is new in jail awaiting transfer to Tuscaloosa, Ala., where the charge of murder exists against him.

BINGHAMTON, Sept. 9.--Gov. Cleveland will arrive in this city to-morrow at 11:38 A.M., via the Erie Railway. He will be received at the station by a committee of citizens composed of the following-named gentlemen: The Hon. B.N. Loomis, the Hon. J.S. wells, P.J. McTighe, C. S. Hall, Charles Davis. Congressman S.C. Millard, Judge Edwards, and others.
HONESDALE, Penn., Sept. 9.--In 1872 Maggie Burton, then 16 years of age, was living with her parents, well-to-do people, in Rathlayne, Maryborough, County Queens, Ireland.
PARIS, Sept.9.--The Comtesse de Paris. wife of the Comte de Paris, was to-day safely delivered of a daughter.

There was no quorum at the meeting of the Manhattan Railway Directors which was called for yesterday. The Executive Committee, however, declared a quarterly dividend of 1 per cent. on the consolidated stock of the company, payable Oct. 1.

Isaac M. Bull, one of the most prominent of the old-time China merchants, died at Cromwell, Conn., on Monday last. He was born at Milford, Conn., in August, 1808. At the age of 20 years he was sent to China as supercargo by his uncle, Gen. Edward Carrington, a wealthy China merchant of Providence.

LONDON, Sept. 9.--This was the first day of the Doncaster September meeting. The race for the Champagne Stakes for 2-year-olds was won by the Duke of Portland's b.c. Langwell. Mr. Childwick's b.c. Royal Hampton came in second and Mr. J.H. Houldsworth's b.c. Golden Ray third.

ALBANY, Sept. 9.--An application was made to Attorney-General O'Brien to-day to dissolve the Rochester and Pittsburg Railroad Company on the ground that the road, as at present constituted, being a consolidation of five or six roads, two of which are in Pennsylvania and...

CASSADAGA, N.Y., Sept. 9.--The National Liberal League closed its annual session to-day. A new board of officers was elected, consisting of Robert Ingersoll, President; Samuel P. Putnam, Secretary; Charles Watts. Ehzur Wright, James Parton, and S.B. Wakeman, Vice-Presidents; Courtlandt Palmer, Treasurer, and Charles B. Reynold, Chairman of the Executive Committee. Two thousand dollars were pledged to defray next year's expenses.

Mgr. Capel closed on Monday night in St. John's Cathedral, Milwaukee, the triduum commanded by his Holiness Pope Leo XIII. to be celebrated throughout the world. During the triduum the reverend prelate delivered a series of six conferences to crowded congregations,...

CHICAGO, Sept. 9.--Charles Downie, the Board of Trade man who recently shot and killed his brother William, was removed to the boys' department of the jail shortly after midnight last night. While being led thither he imagined he was being led to the scaffold by his enemies and called loudly for protection.

PARIS, Sept. 9.--It is officially stated that war will soon be declared against China. The scheme of occupying Formosa has been abandoned. A fresh expedition of a more important nature than the previous ones has already been prepared. The whole question will be discussed at Saturday's Cabinet council.
Mr. BLAINE has at last made a political speech, which he undoubtedly intended should have some significance and some effect on the minds of his fellow-citizens whose votes he is soliciting.

About 50 members of the New-York Society of Amateur Photographers assembled in a small room on the fifth floor of No. l,260 Broadway last evening and listened to some remarks by A.L. Henderson. He is a member of the London and Provincial Photographers' Association.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 9.--The Louisville and Metropolitan Ball Clubs battled for supremacy on the grounds here to-day before a large audience.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 9.--Henry W., Johnson, colored, the Attorney-General of Liberia, it has just been learned by his son here was murdered in Monravia, Liberia, by his wife on the 13th day of February last.

NAPLES, Sept. 9.--During the last 24 hours there have been 800 fresh cases of cholera and 300 deaths in this city. The town presents a gloomy aspect. Images of saints with acolytes bearing tapers have been borne at the head of processions of women through the principal streets, who invoked the help of the Virgin.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept.9.--Gen. Benjamin Butler arrived here this morning, and at 1 o'clock this afternoon delivered a speech at the fair grounds to 8,000 persons. He went to Lincoln by a special train the afternoon to address the State Anti-Monopoly Convention in session there.

The Board of Deacons of the WillisStreet Baptist Church, at Paterson, N.J., held a secret meeting in the church on Monday evening, at which Pastor Guirey preferred charges against Deacons Bustard and Worden for calling him a liar and hypocrite at the church meeting last Wednesday night.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 9.--The Democratic County Convention held at Mayville today, nominated Arthur A. Moore, of Fredonia, for Special Surrogate, and J.L. Thayer, of Sherman, for County Treasurer.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 9.--Now that peace has been restored to the parish of Iberia by the State troops of Gov. McEnery, and all the Republican officers have been dispossessed of the places to which they had been elected, the Demoeratic ring which thus obtained the upper hand are providing against the promulgation of the truth in the future.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 9.--This was the third day of the Fall meeting of the Kentucky Racing Association. The weather was very warm, the track in good condition, and the attendance large.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 9.--H.B. Price, colored, a Justice of the Peace of the Eighth Ward, has been arrested twice since yesterday noon on serious charges, and it is said that there are more warrants to be served on him to-morrow.

AUGUSTA, Sept. 9.--Mr. Blaine remained quietly at home to-day. Among his callers were Gov. Robie, ex-Secretary of the Navy Nathan Gotf, Jr., of West Virginia; the Hon. John S. Collier, President of the Maine Senate, and William H. Gunnerson, of the Post Office Department. Mr. Blaine received a large number of dispatches congratulating him on the result of the Maine election.

The inquest in the case of Charles Jaehnsen, who died a few minutes after receiving a blow from an unknown man at Sixty-fifth-street and Third-avenue, Brooklyn, on the night of Sunday, Aug. 31, was concluded last evening...

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 9.--The Polish inhabitants of Montana, a small mining town several miles from here, and the authorities had a general collision last night, during which a number of Polanders were seriously, if not fatally, injured.
In the Maine election of 1882 Gov. ROBIE'S plurality was 8,560. The vote cast on Monday has not yet been fully reported, but Gov. ROBIE'S plurality will not be far from 15,000.

The committee appointed by the Tammany Hall Committee on Organization to draft resolutions and an address to be presented to the General Committee at its meeting on Friday evening held a conference last evening. John Kelly presided.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 9.--A war is raging in the office of the Evening Journal, of this city. A few weeks ago C.M. Hubbard, the general managing editor, was discharged by Lloyd Breeze, the editor-in-chief. Hubbard claimed to be held by his contract until January, and refused to consider himself discharged.

BINGHAMTON, Sept. 9.--The thirty-third semi-annual meeting of the State Homeopathic Medical Society began in this city to-day. Many homeopathists from all parts of the State are present. Dr. Edward S. Coburn, of Troy, presided.

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 9.--The attendance at the Tri-State Fair to-day was all that was expected, fully 8,000 people being on the grounds. The heat was intense, the thermometer marking 100 in the shade. The first race of the day and the fair was the 2:50 trot...

The eighth annual meeting of the National Association of Trotting Horse Breeders began yesterday afternoon on the grounds of the New-York Driving Club at Morrisania. The track was in excellent condition, the weather was very favorable, and a fairly large assembly of horsemen gathered to witness the races.

PETERSBURG, Va., Sept. 9.--The Democratic Congressional Convention held here this evening to nominate candidates for Congress from the Fourth District of Virginia adjourned without making a nomination, to meet in this city on the first Tuesday in October, at 8 o'clock in the morning. A number of delegates opposed any nomination being made.

WARRENSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 9.--There was A lively fight between private citizens and a detachment of Washburn Bunting's Circus last week. W.J. Sheppard, accompanied by two companions, drove up to Baker's Hotel, near the Fair Grounds, to procure some refreshment.

ALEXANDRIA, Sept. 9.--Gen. Lord Wolseley, Commander of the British forces in Egypt, and Lord Northbrook, Special High Commissioner, arrived here at noon. The whole city turned out to see them Land. They will proceed immediately to Cairo.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9.--One of Mr. Blaine's active supporters in this city is a lawyer named F.H. Fall. He is President of a Blaine and Logan club which is at this time engaged in raising a banner in the northwest section of the city.

SOCIAL CIRCLE, Ga., Sept. 9.--Walnut Grove, in Walton County, is enjoying a remarkable sensation. Among the most respected residents of the place is Miss Laura Shelnut, who has passed the meridian of youth, but yet remains an active participant in Society events.

PORTLAND, Sept. 9.--Full returns from the First Congressional District give Reed 17,584; cleaves, 16,669; Reed's plurality, 915. In 1880 Reed's vote was 18,920 and Anderson's 16,803: Reed's plurality, 117. The entire Republican county ticket is elected by a big majority.

When the citizens had read THE TIMES there was a great deal of indignation expressed at what was called Mayor Strong's incorrect and false statements of the financial condition of the city, but what was in reality a revelation of the true state of its affairs.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9.--Mrs. Oscar Skinner, the wife of a West Madison-street grocer, left the city some time ago, and on her return this morning went directly to her home, No. 307 Washington Boulevard. A ring at the bell brought to the door a plump and pleasing little woman named Mrs. Alimena P. Allen.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept 9.--William Collison, the telegraph operator on duty at Snake Hollow, in the Hocking Valley, where the property of the coal operators is being guarded by troops, was shot and instantly killed by one of the guards, named Batton, last night, being mistaken for a striking miner who was supposed to be endeavoring to set fire to one of the hoppers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9.--The Chicago Live Stock Exchange decided yesterday to purchase 10 head of healthy cattle to be presented to the Live Stock Commission for the purpose of being placed in a herd or herds of cattle claimed to be afflicted with pleuro-pneumonia until such time as will prove whether the suspected disease does or does not exist.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9.--Officer John F. Fowier, of the Metropolitan Police Force, was fatally shot to-day by John Langster, a negro. Langster escaped from a chain gang and was pursued by Fowler. On overtaking him the negro defied arrest.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 9.--Victoria Morosini, daughter of G.P. Morosini, disappeared from her home this afternoon under circumstances which led her parents to think that she had eloped with Ernest J. Shelling, until lately the family coachman.

The Second Battery Artillery had its annual field-day yesterday. Heretofore the command has been accustomed to have a water excursion in commemoration of its anniversary. This year, however, it decided to have a picnic...
Forty years ago next month William Christ declared in the Superior Court that it was his bonafide intention to become a citizen of the United States and renounce" the King of the French."

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 9.--This has been a day of doubt and discomfort. The depositors and stockholders in the broken national bank have been unable to get any idea, either by hook or by crook, at which end of the born they are coming out.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Sept. 9.--William Hill, an old farmer, was assassinated last night in his house, in the Cherokee Nation, about a mile from Fort Smith, by his son-in-law, William Phillips. The murder resulted from an old family feud.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9.--The statement is made that at the Democratic Convention of the Fourth Congressional District to-morrow James H. McVicker, the theatrical manager, will be named as the candidate.

The funeral of Washington Q. Hutton, who for 48 years was connected with the National Guard, took place yesterday at the LexingtonAvenue Baptist Church. The coffin was borne into the church by members of the Twelfth Regiment, National Guard.
It was on a Coney Island boat yesterday. The crowd on the steamer would soon be lost amid the wild dissipations of West Brighton. The stately elephant was already visible.

In New-York there has been for the past few years only two public schools devoted exclusively to the education of colored children. Last May an act was passed by the Legislature providing that these colored schools be classed,...
GENEVA, N.Y., Sept. 9.--Secretary Folger's funeral occurred to-day at the First Presbyterian Church in this village. The event drew 12,000 people to Geneva from all parts of Central New-York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9.--It was not until late last night that word was received here that Mr. Blaine had dodged the prohibition question when he went to the polls yesterday, and it was not until the report was confirmed to-day that his warmest friends believed it.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES is the best paper for Chicagoans to read while in New-York, because it contains more Chicago news than all the other New-York papers combined. Its politics are temporarily abominable.
The Rev. William A.H. Garland, of No. 340 East Seventy-seventh-street, was at Coney Island on Monday in search of his missing daughter Amy, who left her home last February.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 9.--A special to the Post-Dispatch from Jefferson City says: "The Republican State Convention met at noon today and was called to order by William Warner, Chairman of the State Central Committee.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 9.--John D. Sleight, for many years an extensive furniture dealer and manufacturer of this city, made a general assignment to-day to Charles P. Ridenour, a former partner. The preferred creditors include employes, local banks, and residents.
"Constant Reader."--Write to the London Gazette. The advertisement was published some time in July.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9.--Two attachments were issued from the Superior Court yesterday against the Union Catholic Publishing Company, one in favor of Benzinger of New-York, for $827, and another in favor of D.O. Roundy Son for $611.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 9.--John McBurth, the conductor who was arrested yesterday at Asbury Park upon a charge of defrauding the New-York and Long Branch Railroad Company by stealing and selling tickets, was honorably acquitted to-day. Charles Brown, who made the charge against McBurth, after he had been arrested on a similar charge, was held for trial.

All streets, whether wide or narrow, were benefited by the introduction of railroads into them. So testitled Real Estate Agent W.E. Hawes before the Commissioners who are to decide whether or not a railway should be built on Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9.--Miss Sallie Pugh, the youngest daughter of Senator Pugh, of Ala bama, was married to-day to Albert D. Elliott, of Pennsylvania. Only a few friends and immediate family connections were present. The newly married couple left for a Northern tour. They Will reside at York, Penn.
John O'Brien, an 18-year-old member of the Border and Cat-alley gangs, went to his home at No. 654 Water-street, Monday night, under the influence of liquor and went to sleep on the roof.
Something ought to have been said about Prof. COPE'S address before the Association for the Advancement of Science the day after the address was delivered, but the weather was far too hot.

Among the various gentlemen who gain their living by that noble quadruped called the horse, is an individual known under the soubriquet of "Jack the Skinner." Contrary to the rules observed by the horsey fraternity.

About two years ago Burr entered into partnership with Capt. Cornell, a farmer at Port Washington, for the purpose of raising colts,...

A large, well-proportioned lady with closely-cropped brown hair, pleasant features, and a clear, well-modulated voice, was introduced to a fair-sized audience in the Temple, on Clermont-avenue, Brooklyn, last night, as Mrs. Laura G. Fixen, "Minnesota's Prohibition Queen."

Frederick Rufenacht arrived in this city from Albany on July 30. He was met at the boat landing by a runner for Louis Picus, keeper of an immigrant boarding house at No. 504 Canalstreet, who induced Rufenacht to go with him to the boarding house.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 9.--The Grand Circuit meeting was opened at Narragansett Park to-day. The weather and track were good, while the attendance was poor. The favorites won in both classes. The 2:25 pacing race was unfinished. Billie M. won the first heat and Cohannet the second. This goes over until to-morrow. The following are summaries:

Mr. Mitchel Donald McDonald, a lawyer and banker, and one of the most prominent citizens of Toronto, visits New-York with his family every year and is the guest of the Rev. A.B. Simpson, of No. 125 best Twenty-second-street, whose wife is Mr. McDonald's sister.

The taxpayers of New-Brunswick, who are wrought up to hot indignation over the negligence of the Directors of the local bank, might perhaps employ their emotions more usefully by overhauling their own conduct.

EUFAULA, Ala., Sept. 9.--A case coming close to starvation, in the person of "Aunt" Mandy Ingram, a colored woman about 85 years old, was discovered here 3 yesterday. She rated that she had been confined to her bed for four months, and that for several days and nights in succession she bad been lett alone and entirely deserted by people of her color.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept.9.--The members of the American Association for the Advancement of Science rose up to-day in a perspiration, palm leaf in hand, and declared that it was hot. Upon this fact the association set its seal and stamped it with the thermometer.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9.--William Lyle, a young man connected with the local staff of the Chicago Times, fatally stabbed Daniel Gregg, an engineer on the Chicago and Northwestern Road, about 6 o'clock last evening, at the Chicago Driving Park, where the Illinois State Fair is being held.
The offer of 100,000 marks made some time ago to the University of Heidelberg, on condition that women should be allowed to study there, has been declined by the Faculty.

BOSTON, Sept. 9.--This morning Eugene V.R. Thayer, of Boston, drove six-in-hand from Glen house to the summit of Mount Washington in one hour and ten minutes, beating the record made last year by W.H. Vanderbilt by seven minutes.

HARTFORD, Sept. 9.--Sam Pine, the notorious negro criminal who committed a number of dastardly outrages in the southwestern part of this State and in Westchester County, N.Y., iucluding a brutal assault on Miss Slocum, of North Salem, N.Y., has been identified in the...

NORWICH, Conn., Sept. 9.--A 5-year-old boy in short clothes entered Raphael's cigar store on Main-street, in this city, on Sunday morning, and bought a package of cigarettes, giving the dealer a five-dollar gold piece, which the child evidently supposed was a bright new one-cent piece.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 9.--The Chancery Court to-day confirmed the sale of Green's Bank back to its original owners under terms proposed by the committee appointed by the creditors. This gives the bank 6, 12, 18, and 24 months to pay its creditors. with 6 per cent. interest.

Closely buttoned up in their uniforms Gens. Rogers, Ward, and Christensen, as a court of inquiry, listened perspiringly, last evening, to testimony in reference to the manner in which Gen. Daniel D. Wylie has conducted the affairs of the Ordnance Department.

VALPARAISO, Sept. 9, via Galveston.--The English bark Campbell, laden with guano, has been wrecked. The crew were saved and were brought here by the bark Rosedale, which arrived to-day. The Campbell sailed from here on Aug. 1 for Falmouth, and was returning, having sprung a leak.
BOSTON, Sept. 9.--In the Fifth Congressional District to-day Francis B. Hayes was nominated by the Republicans, and in the Fourth Charles T. Gallager. Against Mr. Hayes there...

A portion of the crew of the Alexandre steamship City of Merida, which was burned in the harbor of Havana on Aug. 29, arrived here on the Ward steamship Niagara Monday evening, and were landed yesterday.

The New-Yorks won a game from the Detroit Club on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Detroit men have not defeated the team of this city this year, and with Weidman and Bennett as their "battery" they went into the contest yesterday with a determination to win at least one game from the New-Yorks.
NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 9.--In the Democratic Convention of the Third Congressional District, at Lafayette. to-day, Edward J. Gay, of Iberville, received the unanimous nomination for Congress.

The Maine election was the chief topic of conversation at the political headquarters of both parties yesterday. The Democrats did not think the Republican majority at all significant in view of the fact that they made comparatively no fight, and the additional fact that it was Mr. Blaine's own State.

August Rassiga, President of the Long Island City Board of Aldermen, was the proprietor of a lager beer saloon on Borden-avenue, Hunter's Point, up to about a month ago. He was dispossessed for nonpayment of rent, but...

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 9.--Several Cincinnati brewers were interviewed to-day as to the probable effect of the heavy Prohibition vote in Maine upon the German vote in Ohio. Mr. Christian Moerlein, of the Moerlein Brewery, said: "I believe that in Maine as many Democrats as Republicans votes for the prohibitory law.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 9.--Carl Schurz returned from La Crosse at 4 o'clock this afternoon. He was escorted to the residence of John P. McGregor. where he dined with a number of invited guests and then had a rest before the great independent demonstration this evening.
Coroner Martin held an inquest yesterday in regard to the death of Michael Hart, who was thought to have been stabbed on August 24, by his brother, Julius Hart, a fish peddler.

The crowd of persons at Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday interested in the examination of Patrick Judge, who is accused of the murder of Frederick Kopf on an excursion a week ago Sunday, waited patiently until 4:30 o'clock for the arrival of Assistant District Attorney Gove, and at that time, the official not appearing,...

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Sept. 9.--This city and its vicinity were yesterday visited by a terrific rain, wind, and hail storm. Several barns were unroofed and other outbuildings demolished. A special dispatch from Ullinet, O'Brien County, says several buildings were demolished there, but that no one was hurt.

LONDON, Sept. 9.--Mail advices from Warsaw state that arrests of Nihilists are of daily occurrence. Six persons were arrested Sunday morning. In one case the gendarmes entered the house of a Russian named Herring and seized him while he lay asleep. Seditious papers were found in his house.

Pending his suit to recover $25,000 damages from William J. Ferguson, the actor, for an alleged breach of contract, Manager William W. Kelly seeks an injuction to restrain Actor Ferguson from continuing to play in "Called Back."

A convention of Christian workers was begun last evening in the Twenty-third-Street Gospel Tabernacle, (the old Salmi Morse Temple,) and will continue for three days. The object of the convention is to get together Christian workers in order to "stir up their hearts to the neglected work and solemn opportunities of the age."

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9.--The announcement was made here this morning that John Scott, President of the Erlanger system of roads, has resigned and Frank S. Bond, a Director of the Texas Pacific, has been elected in his stead.

The sport at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday was excellent, and as the favorites captured the majority of the races there was a more equitable division of the spoils than on the preceding days, so that the betting ring was somewhat composed and, less excitement prevailed.

At about 10 o'clock on Monday evening, as Justice Warring was about to leave the Coney Island Police Headquarters, a pair of lovers entered. The Justice was somewhat surprised when the male lover informed him that it was the desire of both himself and his sweetheart to be married immediately and upon the spot. INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 9.--Ex-Gov. Hendricks and wife will leave here this evening for Toledo, Ohio, where the ex-Governor is to deliver an address at the State Fair. Before returning to this city Mr. Hendricks will make several speeches, political and otherwise.

The New-York Society of California Pioneers celebrated "Admission Day" yesterday by an informal banquet at Glen Island. About 40 members were present. Speeches were made by the Hon. Demas Strong, James A. Sperry, F. B. Clarke, Dr. James A. Reed, A.A. Greed, and E.C. Kemble. The old "Bear" flag of the society floated on Starin's boats during the afternoon.

OTTAWA, Sept. 9.--The Commissioner of Inland Revenue states that the abolition of canal tolls on grain will cause a loss of $30,000 in revenue to the country, while the total abolition on all cereals would amount to nearly half a million dollars.
The Acting Secretary of the Treasury, Mr. COON, has recently taken a stand in regard to plans for public buildings which certainly ought to be maintained.

CLEVELAND, Ohio,Sept. 9.--Lee Crandall, the Washington Greenback editor, reached Cleveland to-day in the interest of Butler. In an interview this evening he said: "I have been through Maryland effecting Butler organizations. and will strike into West Virginia next.

Last Friday was an unlucky day for farmer Jacob Rice, of Foster's Meadow, Queens' County, Long Island. When he went to his hennery in the morning he discovered that some time during the night all his chickens had been stolen.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 9.--A council of the Baptist Church has for some days had on trial the Rev. T.J. Powell, Pastor of a church in Orangeville, Trumbull County, on the charges of bad standing in the church, drunkenness, and lying.

The Germania Assembly Rooms in the Bowery were crowded last evening by the largest gathering since the opening of Koltes Post Fair. It was a good-natured crowd throughout, notwithstanding more time was necessarily devoted to removing perspiration than to anything else.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 9.--United States Senator Plumb, of Kansas, has come to Ohio to take part in the campaign, and was to-day registered at the Gibson House, in this city. In an interview he said: "There is much depending...

ROCHESTER, N.Y., sept. 9.--The indications point to a large attendance at the reunion of the Army of the Cumberland here next week. Major W.H. Lambert, of Philadelphia, will deliver the annual oration, and a poem will be read by Benjamin F. Taylor, of Chicago.

SELMA, Ala., Sept. 9.--The Fourth District Republican Congressional Convention met to-day at Marion, Perry County. A special dispatch to the Times reports that the convention was little more than a mob from beginning to end.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9.--Mr. Joseph Medill's denial that he made an appeal to the Republican National Committee for financial aid for the Republicans of Illinois has been read with a good deal of surprise by persons in this city who know something of the facts.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9.--The most important piece of news in theatrical circles to-day was the appointment of C.D. Hess to a managerical position in the Grand Opera House here. The presumption is that the press Opera Company will soon disband, and it is surmised that Manager Hamlin and Mr. Hess may in the future unity their interests in operatic enterprises.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9.--A Tribune special from Santa Fe, New-Mexico, states that the celebrated suit in which the United States is plaintiff against the San Pedro and Cano del Alqua Company came up to-day before Chief-Justice Axtell, in chancery, to set aside the patent and reduce the area claimed by the company...

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 6.--A political millennium seems to have come to the First Oneida Assembly District, formerly the battle ground of factions and third parties. Instead of factional differences in either party, both Republicans and Democrats are racing for one man.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9.--The stove molders' strike is growing more serious. The Chamberlain foundry, which has been at work, has now stopped and joined the other manufacturers. A few men who are at work at the other foundries are virtually imprisoned, it being dangerous for them to appear on the streets.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 9.--The village of Coxsackie, on the Hudson, has lately been the scene of several sensational affairs, the most recent of which is the following: In May last Susan, the plump young widow of Frank Dederick, was married to Joseph Sahl, a young man of steady habits and good character. Their friends joined them in celebrating the event.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9.--A good deal of suppressed excitement was caused among the friends of the Reading Railroad Company to-day by the appearance in the street of some of the Jersey Central stock formerly belonging to the Reading Railroad Company, a part of the 50,000...

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 10.--At the convention of workingmen to-night for the purpose of nominating a candidate for member of Assembly, Assemblyman Hooley was renominated. During the evening a dispute arose and an attempt was made to eject John Brophy. He refused to go out and drew a revolver. He wanted to speak, and keeping the crowd back he jumped on the stage, made a speech with revolver in hand, and then retired.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 10.--The Order of Cincinnatus has arrranged for a pageant on the night of Sept. 17. The members have information that both Blaine and Logan will be here that night and witness the parade. There is to be a Republican conference held here at that time.

KINSTON, N.Y., Sept. 10.--The Leader to-morrow morning will publish a long letter from Prof. Silas food, of this city,a poet and artist well known throughout the country and an old and steadfast Republican, stating his intention to support Cleveland.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 10.--The only wheat yet standing is in the extreme northern portions of Minnesota and Dakota. A few fields remain to be cut as harvest has been somewhat delayed on accouut of unfavorable weather.
SHANGHAI, Sept. 10.--The Chinese are blocking the Woosung Bar with junks filled with stones.
FORT EDWARD, N.Y., Sept. 10.--There is much excitement here regarding the suspension of the old State Bank. The Directors, in looking over the books, find an apparent deficiency of $65,000.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 10.--The scramble of the parties in the First Assembly District to be first in adopting the candidate for Assembly nominated by the workingmen resulted in victory for the Republicans.

ASHLAND, Penn., Sept. 10.--Great alarm is felt throughout the coal regions owing to the scarcity of water. Whole towns are entirely without drinking water, and many of the collieries, unless the mine water is purified for use in the boilers, will be forced into idleness.
"Constant Reader."--Maud S., 2:09 ; Jay-Eye-See, 2:10. Among the passengers who arrived yesterday on the French steamship Labrador were Capt. Berthaut and Lieut. de Villaret.
HELENA, Montana, Sept. 10.--There is great excitement at Benton over the confirmation of an important gold discovery in the Little Rocky Mountains, 100 miles northeast of that place.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 10.--Another tragedy in the terrible list marking the close of the National Bank of New-Jersey came near being enacted this morning, when the widow of Cashier Hill attempted to take her own life. A vigorous effort was made to suppress the facts in the case, and to-night James P. Bodine, a brother-in-law of Mrs. Hill, denied that she had attempted suicide.

At a meeting of the Young Men's Republican Club last evening the minutes of the previous meeting were corrected by expunging from the record a report of a speech made by George Hill, the Corresponding Secretary.
John H. Lyon made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors yesterday to David Welch, giving a preference for $5,253 87 to the Murray Hill Bank, and one for $5,172 62 to Letitia J. Reynolds.

Among the visitors to the Democratic headquarters yesterday were Congressmen Randall, W.M. Springer, Lewis Beach, O.B. Potter, and Perry Belmont. Mr. Randall said there was nothing discouraging in the Maine elections; a large Republican majority was to be looked for.

George H. Stuart, President of the Merchants' Bank of Philadelphia, has furnished to the Turf, Field, and Farm the following letter of Mr. Robert Bonner, which was written in answer to a request that he would allow Maud S. to be exhibited at the fair of the Pennsylvania State Agricultural Society:
AUGUSTA, Sept. 10.--Three hundred and fifth-eight towns give Robie 69,878; Redman, 51,217. These are not official figures. The complete official returns will not be in for several days.

The Hon. William C. Endicott, the Democratic nominee for Governor of Massachusetts, is a lineal descendant of Massachusett's first Governor and a grandson of Jacob Crowninshield, Secretary of the Navy in Thomas Jefferson's Administration.
FONDA, N.Y., Sept. 10.--The Republican County Convention, which was held here this afternoon, selected delegates to the Congressional Convention favoring the nomination of George West, of Ballston.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 10.--The dead body of Edward Breitenstein, Secretary of the Washington Mutual Fire Insurance Company, and of the German Mutual Life Insurance Company, of this city, was found at Benton Park, in the southern part of the city, at 10 o'clock last night ...

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 10.--The Democratic State Convention met here this morning, and was called to order by Chairman Stone. There was a large attendance of delegates and spectators. H.O. Kent, of Lancaster, was chosen President, and made a speech in which he outlined the issues which led to the nomination of Mr. Cleveland for the Presidency.

The eighteenth annual convention of the National Curling Club of the United States was held at Lyric Hall, Forty-first-street and Sixth-avenue, yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock.

The brig Anita Owen, Capt. Murphy, which arrived yesterday from St. Jago, was stopped at Lower Quarantine. During her voyage, which occupied 22 days, three of the sailors died from yellow fever and were buried at sea.

Among the passengers of the North German Lloyd steamship Fulda, which sailed yesterday for Bremen, were Rear-Admiral Earl English, Past Assistant Surgeon P.M. Rixey, Chief Engineer George R. Johnson, and Paymaster ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 10.--The Democrats have for some time been quietly intimating that a scheme was being formulated outside of the State Central Committee which would supplement the work of that committee and make Ohio Democratic in the October election beyond the shadow of a doubt.
LONDON, Sept. 10.--The Earl of Dufferin, at present British Ambassador at Constantinople, has been appointed Viceroy of India.
The work which the Hon. CARL SCHURZ is doing in the West is of a kind that no other public man in the country could do so well, if, indeed, any other public man could approach it.
There are people who seem to imagine that they can wipe out the distinctions between classes in American society by denying that it contains any classes.

Townsend Robins, 42 years old, of No. 356 West Fifty-second-street, who had charge of the elevator in the Park View flat house, No. 224 Fifty-ninth-street, went up in the elevator yesterday afternoon at 5 o'clock, and at the fifth floor was instantly killed by being crushed between the elevator and the walls of the shaft. How he got there is not known, as there was no one in the elevator at the time.

CHIPPEWA FALLLS, Wis., Sept. 10.--This town has been suffering from a flood worse than that of 1880. The Chippewa River is 23 feet above low water mark and Duncan Creek is higher than ever known before.

BOSTON, Sept. 10.--Regular Republican nominations were made to-day in the Sixth, Seventh, Eighth, and Tenth Congressional Districts. Henry Cabot Lodge in the Sixth, Charles H. Allen, of Lowell, in the Seventh, and W.W. Rice in the Tenth were all nominated unanimously ...

VICKSBURG, Miss., Sept. 10.--This (Warren) county is in the hands of a set of officials of very questionable morals and integrity. It has come to light that a system of falsifying bills has been practiced for some time by Supervisor W.S. Mills.
TORONTO, Sept. 10.--News has just reached this city of a murder which occurred on the 26th of last July at Jackfish Bay, on the north shore of Lake Superior.
The Railroad Committee of the Common Council met yesterday to hear the applications of a number of street railroad companies for permission to lay tracks in the streets and avenues of this city.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10.--The American Buttonhole and Sewing Machine Company, at Twentieth-street and Washington-avenue, issued a notice to their workmen today at a 11:50 that work would be suspended for two weeks.
William C. Rhinelander, who shot John Drake on June 19, was yesterday adjudged to be insane by two members of a commission of three, appointed by Recorder Smyth, of the Court of General Sessions.

Theatrical managers are at this moment in a condition of profound gloom. Their exceedingly sombre thoughts are occasioned by the extraordinary weather conditions which are giving joy exclusively to the proprietors of hotels on the seashore.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 10.--The racing was continued here to-day. The weather was very warm, the track fast, and the attendance good.
NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 10.--Considerable uneasiness is manifested in railroad circles in regard to the cheap freight rates on cotton existing between Texas and Southern points and the East via Cairo.
READING, Penn., Sept. 10.--A deliberate murder was committed at noon to-day near Hearper's store, South Annville Township. The victim was a young man named Bernhard Evans.

DELAVAN, Wis., Sept. 10.--A terribke railroad accident, which resulted in the death of Albert R. Topping, aged 19 years, son of Charles H. Topping, a dry goods merchant, and Winifred C. Dewey, aged 18, daughter of Prof. Elias Dewey, Principal of the Delavan High School, occurred at this place last evening.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10.--At the city election to-day Mayor Franklin was re-elected. The Blainites were bent upon slaughtering Lucius D. Davis, the editor of the Daily News, who believes that Blaine is unfit for the Presidency, and who is opposing his election in his paper.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 10.--The Hon. Evans D. Allnutt died last night at the Anchorage Lunatic Asylum, and with his death comes the story of a revolting crime. It is charged that Mr. Allnutt was brutally murdered by two attendants named McClanahan, and Ballard, who ...
ERIE, Penn., Sept. 10.--Richard Compton, an engineer at the Middlesex Furnace, made a rather novel and startling demand of a bank today. Compton had a deposit in the Veech Savings Bank.
To say that the members of the WillisStreet Baptist Church of Paterson expected a circus last night at the meeting to investigate the Guirey-Bradbury scandal would be to express things mildly.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 10.--The Louisville Club dropped a game to the "Mets" to-day through their inability to hit Lynch, who proved himself wonderfully effective, particularly with men on the bases. Hecker pitched again for the home nine, and did good work, though the visitors bunched their hits whenever they made ...

CLEAR LAKER, Wis., Sept. 10.--A cyclone struck this place late yesterday afternoon. Three lives were lost, and the greater portion of the town is in ruins. After the storm had passed men, women, and children ran about in a frenzy of excitement and fear.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 10.--Early in the campaign, so the story comes, and from authentic sources, the member of the National Republican Committee for Iowa pledged that this State would furnish $100,000 for Blaine's election.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10.--A bold highway robbery was committed here at 2 o'clock to-day. Mrs. Akers, a widow, residing at No. 127 St. Clairstreet, went to the savings bank a few minutes before 2 o'clock and drew out $90, which she placed in a small hand sachel with her passbook.

POTTSVILLE, Sept. 10.--A strange case of love and misplaced confidence, the particulars of which have just come to light, occurred in this city a month ago. A handsomely dressed German girl about 18 years of age, of prepossessing appearance, came to Pottsville and took up quarters at the Exchange Hotel.

WARSAW, Sept. 10.--The ball last night in honor of the royal party was a grand affair. As many as 700 persons were invited. The Czar and Czarina and the Grand Dukes arrived at the bail amid salutes and fireworks, and walked through the hall, bowing to the right and the left.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--A special from Leavenworth, Kan., states that to-day the plant of the Kansas Prohibitionist, the St. John organ of the State, was seized for debt. It is probable that the type and press will be sold under the hammer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--First Lieut. William B. Homer, Fifth Artillery, has been ordered to report to the Superintendent of the Military Academy, West Point, N.Y., for duty in the Department of Tactics. The following transfers in the Fourth Artillery have been announced:

Just as he turned the corner of Thirtyeighth-street into Broadway, at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning, Officer Waugh, of the Twentyninth Precinct, saw "Ed" Scott, a vagrant, spring on a passerby and bear him to the ground.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--The situation in the Cattle market was much the same as earlier in the week. Good shipping Beeves were again scarce, and for that class, notwithstanding the rather discouraging reports from New-York, the market held firm.

Between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon an explosion occurred in the japanning works of Aaron Cragin, on Sandford-street, between Willoughby and Myrtle avenues, Brooklyn, which resulted in the death of one man and the fatal injury, it is feared, of one other.

The New-Yorks again easily defeated the Detroit team on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The local players were forced to face the "German" battery, Getzlein and Gastfield, and they succeeded in bettering their batting averages, hitting the curves of Getzlein 14 times for a total of 21 bases.
Robert Kuntz, a young wood worker, who lived with his father at No. 335 East Fifthstreet, attempted to commit suicide yesterday afternoon by taking a dose of Paris green.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10.--As Mrs. Muchler was passing down Seneca-street this evening, her husband approached her and without saying a word threw the contents of a five-ounce bottle of vitriol in her face.

NAPLES, Sept. 10.--It is officially announced that during the 24 hours ending last night there were 721 fresh cases of cholera in the city of Naples and 250 deaths. Since the beginning of the cholera outbreak in Naples there have been 1,100 interments in the cholera section of the cemetery.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 10.--The Fifth District Democratic Convention met at Monroe at noon to-day. The friends of Gen. J. Floyd King, the present member, largely predominated, while the supporters of Boatner, the McEncry ring favorite, evidently came prepared with a plan for bulldozing their man through.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 10.--The Democrats of Griswold by club resolutions have "boycotted" D.H. Seott, the publisher of the Advocate, alleging that he was intoxicated and disorderly at their recent flag raising and torchlight parade, and that he has since ridiculed the meeting and its projectors in a highly offensive manner.

One of the first couples in France to take advantage of the new divorce law were named Granville. They were married 50 years ago. The lady's age was then 16, and 15 days after the wedding she obtained a separation from her husband.
The Directors of the Northern Pacific Railroad have recently been discussing the question of leasing the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company, but have arrived at no conclusion.

JAMESTOWN, Sept. 10.--Mrs. Jeannette Fenton Hegeman and Albert Gilbert, Jr., were quietly married to-day by the Rev. Charles D. Barrows, of the Presbyterian church. Mrs. Hegeman is the youngest daughter of ex-Gov. R.E. Fenton. The groom is a member of the firm of Gilbert Jones, owners of the Crown Roller Flouring Mills. Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert will reside in Jamestown.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10.--The Potters' Gazette, one of the strongest Republican papers published in Columbiana County has come out for Cleveland and Hendricks. This journal is the organ of the boss potters, and has wielded great influence politically in the district. It has always been radically Republican.

NYACK, Sept. 10.--Jessie Isherwood, a young lady of respectability, 23 years old, has disappeared strangely from her home in West Nyack, and fears are entertained that she has been abducted and perhaps murdered.

The Independent Scandinavian Cleveland and Hendricks Campaign Club will hold its first meeting at Germania Hall, No. 194 Third-avenue, on Thursday, Sept. 11, at 8 P.M. A committee will be appointed consisting of one from each Assembly district to form separate campaign clubs in all the Assembly districts.
Much surprise and not a little alarm has been caused among the friends of Francis F. Taylor, of this city, by the sudden disappearance of that gentleman from his accustomed haunts.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 10.--One of the most terrible accidents ever recorded in this city occurred this afternoon at the South Tredegar Iron and Nail Works.

FORT PLAIN, N.Y., Sept. 10.--Kate Smulsey still continues in the same condition, and her retaining life after a six months' fast is considered a miracle by the country people who live in this vicinty.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 10.--The General Passenger Agents of lines in the territory bounded by the lakes, the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers, and the Buffalo, Pittsburg and Western met here to-day for the purpose of taking steps to restore rates, but it proved a failure.
PEORIA, Ill., Sept. 10.--The cookers at the Enterprise Distillery at Pekin, owned by Messrs. Spellman Doheny, of this city, exploded today, making a total wreck of the building.

Principal George White, of Grammar School No. 70, was absent from school about an hour and a half, on a subpoena from the Grand Jury, last Spring. Much discussion was had by the Education Commissioners at their first meeting after the Summer vacation, yesterday, as to whether he should receive full pay for the time he was absent.

Liberty Hall, corner of Nostrand and Gates avenues, Brooklyn, was crowded to overflowing last evening by enthusiastic Democrats, who had assembled to participate in a grand Cleveland and Hendricks banner raising and ratification meeting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--That the result of the election in Maine is not going to cause any relaxation in the Republican Finance Committee's search for campaign funds is evident from its latest exploit.

One of the most remarkable of those curious orgies known as Rhode Island clam bakes which has ever been held on Manhattan Island was enjoyed by the Ivy Club at Sulzer's East River Park yesterday afternoon.

A party of 450 Mormon immigrants arrived yesterday on the Guion steamship Wyoming. Elder B. Bennett, who is in charge of the party, says that 200 of the immigrants are Scandinavians, 150 English, 50 Germans, and 56 Swiss.

LONDON, Sept. 10.--At the Doncaster September meeting to-day the race for the St. Leger Stakes for 3-year-olds was won by Mr. R. C. Vyner's b.c. The Lambkin. The Duke of Westminster's ch.f. Sandiway came in second, and Mr. R. Peck's b.f. Superba third.

BINGHAMTON, Sept. 10.--Gov. Cleveland stopped here this morning while en route from Geneva to Albany. In anticipation of his visit the Common Council of the city made arrangements for a public reception to the Governor.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10.--The sessions of the American Association for the Advancement of Science were continued to-day at the Academy of Music.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 10.--Advices from Liverpool, England, state that there is great dissatisfaction over the manner in which both the United States and Canada shippers of live stock are treated by the Inspectors of the British Government.

The Cragg family of acrobats have made a hit at the New Park Theatre, and their clever and amusing performance is decidedly the most interesting feature of "The Corsican Brothers" burlesque.

When Edward Murray, one of Contractor Otis's mail van drivers, drove across Broadway on his way to Jersey City shortly before 2 o'clock yesterday morning, he stopped and gave a low whistle. A man came rapidly out of the shadow of a building and climbed into the van, the door of which had been opened by Murray.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--The leading produce markets were more active to-day than the recent average, and somewhat stronger, Provisions being especially so.

The Convention of Christian Workers, now in session at the Twenty-third-Street Gospel Tabernacle, near Sixth-avenue, was opened yesterday by a prayer meeting, led by the Rev. Dr. Clift, of Washington.

Sheriff Cronan, of Hudson County, yesterday lodged Capt. John Dartt, commander of the Nova Scotian brigantine Carlston, in jail, in default of $4,000, to await the issue of a civil action brought by Charles Johnston to recover damages for the alienation of Mrs. Johnston's affections.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., Sept. 10.--The great Democratic mass meeting and torch-light procession here to-night proved, as was anticipated, to be the largest political demonstration ever held in this State.

Ever since the 1st of May last the fourthstory floor of the rear tenement house No. 284 Tenth-avenue has been the home of John Armstrong, an employe of the Manhattan Gaslight Company in West Eighteenth-street, his wife Mary, and his 16-year-old daughter Sarah.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 10.--An arrangement has been effected, it is understood, by which the bondsmen of John C.S. Harrison, as Receiver of the Indiana Banking Company, will pay into court, probably on Saturday next, the amount of his deficit as such Receiver, about $160,000.

The cholera in Naples spreads with frightful rapidity. On Tuesday 800 fresh cases and 300 deaths were reported, and the epidemic is yet far from having reached its worst. If it increases during the next four or five days as rapidly as it has increased since it first made its appearance in the city it will have surpassed ...

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 10.--John Boyle O'Reilly, of Boston, addressed a large audience in the Court House this evening in the interests of Cleveland and Hendricks. The building was crowded, and the speaker was frequently applauded.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--The Enterprise Distillery at Pekin was totally wrecked at 7 o'clock this morning by the explosion of a patent cooker.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Sept 10.--The last spike on the Louisville, New-Orleans and Texas Railroad was driven to-day, at a point about 125 miles north of Vicksburg and 95 miles south of Memphis, completing the road from New-Orleans ...

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 10.--S.T.K. Prime, of Dwight, Ill., who is by general consent admitted to be the highest individual authority in the United States on matters connected with the condition and outlook of the grain crops, was a visitor on Change to-day.
At the second day of the Fall meeting of the National Rifle Association at Creedmoor yesterday the first match shot was the Shorkley, at 800, 900, and 1,000 yards--seven shots at each distance.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--The Fire Engineers of the United States at their session to-day listened to several papers on "Spontaneous Combustion," in which the writers held to the view that granite was one of the worst possible building materials, because it contained recesses which, filled with water and heat, superinduced explosions. Other papers of a technical nature were also read.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--James Norval, one of the wealthiest farmers of Shelbyville, Ind., was picked up on the fair grounds in this city Saturday evening by his son. The old man was unconscious when found, and was taken home. It was thought he was suffering from a sunstroke, but to-day it was uncertained that he had been drugged and robbed of $1,000 in cash. He is now insane, and at the point of death.

There was a change in the weather yesterday. As it was not the right sort of change no special comment was given it, and to the minds of people who like things laid on with a trowel the weather was no different from the weather of the past four days.

A great programme is offered for to-day by the Coney Island Jockey Club. There is a bewildering array of entries for the six races, and for the Bridge Handicap for 3-year-olds, the principal event, 18 starters are announced, with Louisette carrying the top weight of 118 pounds. The parade ground at Prospect Park presented a very neat appearance yesterday when the first eleven of the Manhattan Cricket Club opened a game with the I Zingari eleven visiting cricketers from Canada.
The Directors of the Western Union Telegraph Company yesterday received the report of the company's business for the quarter ending June 30, 1884.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--The Department of Agriculture reports that the condition of cotton on Sept. 1 was lower than on Aug. 1 by reason of drought, which has been the severest in Texas, yet felt in every State east and north to North Carolina.
In a financial way, last evening was the most successful for the Koltes Post Fair, now in progress at the Germania Assembly Rooms.

BOSTON, MASS., Sept. 10.--The Prohibitionists, at their State Convention held here to-day, nominated President Seelye, of Amherst College, for Governor, and Henry H. Faxon, of Quincy, for Lieutenant-Governor.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 10.--Exhaustive reports on the tobacco crop from 500 correspondents of the New-England Homestead, covering all the seed leaf tobacco-growing sections of the United States, indicate that the crop, now nearly harvested, is the best in growth and quality that has been raised for years.

President Arthur spent a quiet day yesterday, like everybody else, feeling the effect of the hot weather. In the afternoon he went out for a drive in Central Park and attended to some private business. Last evening Gen. George H. Sharpe spent a short time with him, after which he denied himself to callers.
The Freeholders of Essex County, N.J., were surprised at their meeting yesterday by the presentation of the resignation of Warden Leonard, of the County Lunatic Asylum.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 11.--The industrial outlook in this city in view of the approaching Winter is discouraging. Nearly all the river miners are on strike, and the railroad miners threaten to join them unless their wages are raised.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 11.--Lord Cavanaugh, a tall man with a military carriage stepped up to the railing before Magistrate Mulholland to-day and denied that he was a vagrant, as Detective Becker, who arrested him last evening, charged.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11.--An attachment was issued from the Superior Court to-day against Levy Brothers, of New-York, in favor of Joseph Frank for $15,794. Later a writ of garnishment was served upon L. Silverman, a banker who had on deposit $2,500 of the firm's money.
UTICA, Sept. 11.--The Fall term of Hamilton College opened to-day, with 44 Freshmen and nearly all of the old students in attendance.

It is possible that young Thomas F. Grady will receive a "friendly trip," which will materially interfere with his patriotic efforts to disclose Gov. Cleveland's monopolistic tendencies, at the meeting of the Tammany Hall General Committee this evening.

READING, Penn., Sept. 11.--The drunken and desperate fight which took place near Carper's store, in Lebanon County, yesterday noon, between two tramps, Peter Reisderf and John Miller, and which terminated in the death of the former, wears now the appearance of wanton and deliberate murder.
There have been four victims of the explosion in the japanning works in Sanford-street, Brooklyn, Wednesday afternoon. James Hodgkins was killed outright.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 11.--The committee in charge of the Monmouth Battle Monument met at Freehold to-day. It was decided to postpone the dedication of the monument, which is nearly completed, until Thursday, Nov. 13.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 11.--William Stevens, aged about 50 years, was driving down Clove Mountain, one of the steepest of the Shawangunk range, near Alligerville, yesterday, with five tons of millstone on his wagon. One of the wheels caught in a rut in the road and the wagon was overturned. The stone fell on top of Stevens, crushing him almost to a jelly and breaking every bone in his body. He leaves a wife and family.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 11.--Ex-Gov. Foster has come out of his retirement and will take hold and give the Republicans hereafter all the material and moral aid in his power.

There was nothing new under the sun yesterday. There were the same scorched pavements, parched roads, sweltering men, complaining women, and perspiring horses that have been noticed since the beginning of the unusual hot spell.
It is a significant fact that when a Rhode Islander spoke of Henry B. Anthony, he called him "the Governor." It is a long time since Mr. Anthony was Governor.

Within a few days the number of BLAINE'S followers has been increased by the addition of two notable persons. Some years ago there lived in Boston a Methodist minister named E.D. WINSLOW.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 11.--The races were continued here to-day. The weather was very warm, the track fast, and the attendance very good.
Vito Lingobardo, an Italian bootblack, living at No.89 Bleecker-street, was called into a barroom in Mercer-street to black a gentleman's boots.

READING, Penn., Sept. 11.--The molders in the employ of the Manhattan Hardware Works, in this city, left their work to-day, owing to a reduction in their wages. They claim that they cannot support their families by earning from $1.25 to $1.75 per day and averaging only two or three days per week. They will not go to work unless they receive the same wages that they were paid prior to the reduction.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11.--Messrs. M.P Handy, William L. Elkins, P.A.B. Wildener, L. N. Megargee, and C.R. Deacon will begin the publication in this city of a new daily penny paper, with morning and evening editions, on or about the 22d inst.

MONTREAL, Sept. 11.--Alfred Isaacson was until recently the junior partner in the firm of J.H. A.G. Isaacson, notaries public of this city.
PARIS, Sept. 11.--The Government denies that China has declared war. The Chambers will not be summoned to meet before Oct. 15. Prime Minister Ferry has returned to Paris.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11.--Mary Josephine Anderson, alias Hanson, a single woman, 36 years old, was arraigned before Judge Prendergast in the County Court among the insane cases to-day.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 8.--Hanging in the headquarters of the Republican State Central Committee, on Kansas-avenue, is a lithographic copy of a photograph of the Kansas Republican banner which was so conspicuously paraded at the Chicago Convention.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 11.--Mrs. Muchler, the unfortunate victim of last evening's vitriol throwing, is recovering rapidly from the shock. It is now thought that one of her eyes will be saved, but she is terribly disfigured, there being three large places on the cheek and lips seared and scarred in that horrible manner peculiar to vitriol. Her arms are also badly burned.

A cool breeze from the south fanned the brows of the members of the National Association of Trotting Horse Breeders as they sipped beverages of various colors on the balcony of the clubhouse in Fleetwood Park, Morrisania, yesterday.

It was rumored here to-day that the President had decided to appoint Gen. George H. Sharpe Secretary of the Treasury. Gen. Sharpe was recently appointed a member of the commission to visit South America.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11.--Mr. C.C. Cole stated at the 'Republiean Congressional Committee Headquarters to-day that he was about to go to West Virginia to help "stir the boys up" for Blaine and Logan.

The Boston Saturday Evening Gazette divulges the fact that Harvard College has lately been sadly disappointed in the contents of the wills of two gentlemen of whom the institution had cherished great expectations.

Giovanni P. Morosini did not know yesterday where his daughter Victoria was. That she had been married, as was stated in the morning papers, to her father's former coachman, John Ernest Hulskamp, with whom she eloped on Tuesday afternoon, there could be no question.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 11.--Gen. John A. Loan was present this afternoon on the grounds of the State Fair Association, and made a speech to an audience numbering 7,000 or 8,000 persons.

Gunekle resigned." A special from Marysville, Ky., says: "The Democratic Congressional Convention of this district yesterday nominated William H. Wadsworth."

CHICAGO, Sept. 11.--The mystery that surrounded the life of Private Henry previous to the arctic expedition has been cleared up by a search of the military records at Leavenworth, Kan., and an interview with Lieut. Wallace, of Troop G. Seventh Cavalry.
Hubbard P. Fanning, the driver of an ash cart, made an attempt yesterday to end his life by shooting himself twice in the head with a revolver.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11.--With the small blade of a common pocket knife, J.H. Squier, for many years one of the best known private bankers in Washington, deliberately cut his throat from ear to ear this morning, and a few minutes later died without uttering a word.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11.--A peculiar trick came to light to-day. It seems that the Independent Club secured a small ticket, on one side of which is the sentence, "Blaine and Logan check, 5 cents," and on the opposite side was the name of a well-known liquor dealer. The card was published, and created a decided sensation. It is believed that the cards have been supplied to all the liquor dealers. Blaine's adherents are dumfounded.

ALBANY, Sept. 11.--A large Democratic ratification meeting was held to-night, over which Judge Amasa J. Parker presided. The principal speech was made by ex-Senator Francis Kernan, who discussed at length the public records of Mr. Blaine and Gov. Cleveland.

CLEAR LAKE, Wis., Sept. 11.--The damage done by Wednesday's cyclone in Clear Lake and vicinity will reach fully $250,000. Hardly a house remains unscathed. The three persons who lost their lives in the storm were Mrs. Peleg Burdick, wife of the Postmaster, and two young men in W.R. Ingalls's store named William Cavanagh and A.V. Sanderson.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 11.--William B. Ogden, President of the Trades Assembly, stated yesterday in an interview that there are 24,000 members of the trades unions of Cincinnati, of whom nearly 8,000 are idle.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11.--Col. John E. Nunez, who sailed from this port in December, 1883, and was arrested as a rebel by Spanish soldiery at Sagua La Grande, Cuba, on Jan. 14, imprisoned, court martialed, and finally released, returned to this city to-day.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 11.--About two months ago Mrs. Jennie Rose was shot and killed by a burglar. The family consisted of Charlie Rose, his wife Jennie, who was an invalid, and Miss Nancy Frazier, a cousin of Mrs. Rose, who was in the house as help.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 11.--The opening game between the Columbus and Brooklyn teams this afternoon was a comedy of errors, in which the latter club played the most important part.

The Independent Scandinavian Cleveland and Hendricks Campaign Club of the City of New-York was organized last night at No. 194 Third-avenue.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 11.--The nomination of Foran, for Congress, by the Democrats of this district has made the Republican leaders wary about accepting a nomination against him. Ex-Mayor Rose was generally agreed upon, but when he positively refused to run, an attempt was made to get ex-Congressman Amos Townsend on the track.

The brig Anita Owen, on which there were several deaths from yellow fever during the voyage from St. Jago, came from Lower to Upper Quarantine yesterday. She will go today as far as Robbin's Reef, where she will discharge her cargo.
DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 11.--W. Millar, wholesale grocers of this city, to-day made an assignment to Samuel T. Douglass. The firm has been in business 30 years.

SCHENECTADY, Sept. 11.--Yesterday was Engineer Edward Crane's unlucky day. He took the 10 o'clock Saratoga train on the Delaware and Hudson Road from this city, and having until 4 o'clock to wait for his return trip, he was detailed to engineer a wild-cat train sent out to pick up iron scraps.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 11.--Eugene Clark, the 13-year-old son of Peter Clark, living at Ashley, met with a horrible death this morning. He was assisting in the helting of cars at Ashley, when the train upon which he stood parted and he fell between the rails and about 300 cars passed over him. His head was cut it two and his body crushed to a shapeless mass.

The feature of the third day of the National Rifle Association meeting at Creedmoor yesterday was the President's match for the military championship of the United States, open to all members of the army and navy and Marine Corps or the National Guard of any State; position standing and distances 200 and 500 yards.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 11.--The Democratic State Committee met here to-day and appointed an Executive Committee of one from each county to meet at least once in 10 days to consider campaign matters. This committee was authorized to appoint prominent supporters...

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Sept. 11.--The most terrible flood ever known here is now sweeping everything before it. Last night at 11 o'clock no serious damage had been done, but by 4 o'clock this morning six of the largest bridges across the Chippewa River had been swept away.

A large number of persons connected with the New-York Athletic Club assembled on their grounds yesterday afternoon to witness a trial of speed by H.M. Johnson, the professional sprinter, who is to-day, it is thought, the fastest man in this country at 100 and 150 yards.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 11.--The Supreme Court yesterday affirmed the death sentences of two Cherokee County murderers. The first one is a colored man named Hills, who chopped a ballroom rival to death. The second is Jerry Marshal, who beat a 3-year-old child to death.

Andrews Careso, a Hungarian immigrant, settled in Pennsylvania some years ago, and, obtaining employment, he saved money. Recently he decided to visit his native land, and on Tuesday he arrived in New-York.

CAIRO, Sept. 11.--Lord Wolseley, after a conference with the military authorities of Egypt, in consequence of the falling of the Nile, has ordered preparations to be made, so that, if necessary, the expedition can proceed from Debbeh to Khartoum by the desert route.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 11.--The excitement over the disappearance of Jessie Isherwod from this place Monday night increases. A slight clue has been obtained which may result in the discovery of her whereabouts.

PORTLAND, Sept. 11.--A special to the Press from Augusta says: "The total vote of the State will reach 142,410, and Robie's majority over Redman 20,615. This is the largest majority ever given a candidate for Governor in this State in a Presidential year."

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 11.--The Academy of Music was crowded to suffocation to-night, where a mass meeting was held under the auspices of the Young Men's Democratic Association. Speeches were made by G.F. Rosche, of NewYork, and W.H. Hensel, Chairman of the Pennsylvania State Democratic Committee. The greatest enthusiasm prevailed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11.--With a charming exhibition of impartiality and industry the Republican Finance Committee, having called for "voluntary contributions" for Mr. Blaine's help from the Government clerks, the business men of the District, and the members of the Fire Department, have now turned their attention to the members of the police force.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 11.--Mr. Blaine arrived here this noon.
