CHICAGO, Sept. 11.--John E. Norton Co., dealers in cigars and tobacco at No. 139 Madison-street, filed a voluntary assignment in the County Court to-day in favor of Edward B. Mantz.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 11.--The 100 striking bootmakers in the L. Candee rubber shop went back to work this morning, the company consenting to open every window six inches to give them fresh air. Then the 400 female operatives struck for open windows and went out. The company will probably capitulate to-morrow.
BERLIN, Sept. 11.--Prince Bismarck has arrived here. M. Courcel, the French Ambassador, postponed taking his furlough in order that he might hold a conference with Bismarck.
SANDUSKY, Ohio, Sept. 11--Henry Mooney, 22 years old, residing at Point Au Pelle, was killed this afternoon by being struck on the head by a pile driver with which he was working.

BOSTON, Sept. 10.--"At sixes and sevens" aptly describes the condition of political affairs in Massachusetts at the present time. The People's Party is not yet organized, nor will it be fully until Butler returns from the West and infuses some of his own personality into the movement.

UTICA, Sept. 11.--The Democratic County Convention to-day indorsed the nomination of Cleveland and Hendricks, and nominated for County Treasurer Pierre Becker, of Rome; for Special Surrogate, C.C. Snyder, of Utica; for Coroners, A.G. Spencer, C.B. Watkins, and H. G. Dubois. Charles Ballou, of Utica, was chosen Chairman of the County Committee.
ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 11.--Gov. Cleveland was engaged this morning in transacting routine work as usual and receiving callers.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 11.--The annual rush between the Freshmen and Sophomore classes came off to-night on the college campus. The struggle was a hard one, and the '87 Class was far outnumbered. They held their own and drove the Freshmen from the cannon which they were striving to take possession of. The rush was witnessed by all the undergraduates.
PARIS, Sept. 11.--M. Dumas has written a new drama for the Comedie Francaise, to be produced this Winter.

GRIFFIN, Ga., Sept. 11.--Allen Andrews, an aged colored man, who lives on the plantation of the Rev. C.W. Thomas, about three miles from this place, had a dispute last Saturday night with a colored woman about some flour that she borrowed of him some time since and has not returned.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 11.--Henry Davis, fire boss at the Pine Brook Colliery of the Lackawanna Iron and Steel Company, was startled this morning, shortly before 5 o'clock, by the gong at the Dickson Works sounding an alarm of fire.
The Society of Medical Jurisprudence held its first Fall meeting last evening at the rooms of the Academy of Medicine. Dr. C.S. Wood presided.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 11.--Gov. Thomas A. Hendricks, the Democratic candidate for VicePresident, arrived in this city yesterday morning as the guest of the Tri-State Fair Association. DENVER, Col., Sept. 12.--After a stormy debate which lasted nearly all the morning the Republican State Convention adopted the majority report of the Committee on Credentials, seating the anti-Hill delegations, and adjourned at 10 A.M. On reassembling, the convention proceeded to ballot for Governor.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 12.--John O'Brien, an attorney at Phoenix, N.Y., was arrested today by Deputy Sheriff Fred Schug, charged with forging the name of Alma Wood to pension drafts and defrauding the United States out of $1,924.

Charles Stevens, alias James Abbott, 38 years old, a painter, was sentenced yesterday, in the Court of General Sessions, to two years in State prison by Recorder Smyth for bigamy.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 12.--Reports received from several places in the interior and from the river counties state that yesterday's storm was unusually severe.

BOONTON, N.J., Sept. 12.--It was a few minutes before 8 o'clock this morning when venerable William W. Messer came into the dining room of the Briggs cottage, in Boonton Park--a pleasant, three-story house, which he had rented for the season, and in which he lived with his wife and daughter Mary, a woman 20 years of age, but with hair gray since she was 15.

Col. Mapleson has at last conveyed something like a definite idea of his plans for the coming season to certain persons in this city, and this gives promise, after all, of an exceptionally fine season of Italian opera at the Academy.
WARSAW, Sept. 12.--Before departing for Wilna the Czar and Czarina gave a state dinner at the Lazienki Palace. One hundred guests were present, including only five Polish ladies.
NAPLES, Sept. 12.--King Humbert announces that he shall not leave Naples until the epidemic wanes.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 12.--Ever since the Buffalo Bill combination exhibited in this city the boys have been practically throwing the lasso, and some of them have become very expert.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 12.--Oscar Johnson, 6 years old, was frolicking with companions on logs in a millpond this afternoon when he mysteriously disappeared. A crowd gathered, and after two hours the body was recovered from the water. The boy's parents are Swedes, and recently came to America.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Sept. 12.--Reports received to-day for THE TIMES from the leading grape-growing sections along both sides of the Hudson River show that the Concord growers in the southern part of the valley--nine-tenths of the entire yield is composed of Concords--will commence shipping grapes on Monday.

It was ascertained yesterday that the Francis F. Taylor who committed suicide on Monday evening last at Niagara Falls was the missing stationer of No. 51 Exchange-place, this city. Causeless worriment about business is said by his friends to have been the cause.

Mr. Van Weel, of Amsterdam, one of the committee of foreign shareholders of the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad Company, is expected to arrive in this city to-day. The entire committee will make an inspection trip over the road at once.

Nourished in a malarious domestic atmosphere, the youthful Percy W. Barton is of rank but vigorous growth. He is now about 12 years old. Since he was about 10 years old his parents, Susan W. and Horace W. Barton, have been on unpleasant terms.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 12.--James R. Shipherd, the son of an Oberlin Congregational minister, and for years the leading milliner of Cleveland, hanged himself this morning in the attic in his residence, on Prospect-street, rather than face the disgrace of 10 days in the workhouse and meet the coldness and criticism of those who had once been his intimates and friends.

A report was current in Wall-street yesterday that Messrs. Powell and Westlake, the English committee appointed to investigate the affairs of the Erie Railway, had published their report in London and that the report made an unexpectedly bad showing.

A large and distinguished assemblage witnessed last evening at the great hall of the Tammany Society the first performance of Mr. John Kelly's entertaining comedy of "Coming Around." Several rehearsals of Mr. Kelly's composition has been held, and its first production has been awaited with much interest.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 12.--Two NewHaven policemen arrested a corpse this morning. When the chambermaid of the United States Hotel went at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon to the door of room No. 113 to make the bed she found the door locked. She knocked, and received no answer. At 2 o'clock she repeated her visit and obtained a similar result. The door was at last forced open.
Two letters of a matrimonial nature were received yesterday at Castle Garden. One was written by J.L. Thomas, of Detroit, who inclosed a postage stamp for the answer which he expected.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 12.--Yesterday the Hon. Silas B. Dutcher, Republican, of Brooklyn, had a political discussion at the Sinclairville fair with the Hon. Darius O.O. Ogden, of Penn Yan, Democrat.

The I Zingari eleven, from Canada, and the Staten Island team played a game of cricket on Staten Island yesterday afternoon, and it proved to be one of the best exhibitions of batting seen here this season. The change in the weather made the game enjoyable to both players and spectators.

CORK, Sept. 12.--At a meeting of the corporation of the city of Cork to-day the Nationalist members demanded to know of the Mayor why he had dared to invite the Duke of Edinburgh to visit the city. The Mayor gave them no answer.
CAIRO, Sept. 12.--Later dispatches confirm the report of the substantial victory of the Mudir of Dongola at Ambukol over the rebels from Kordofan.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 12.--Benjamin Johnson, colored, was hanged this afternoon for complicity with Allen Ingalls in the murder of Beverly Taylor, his wife, and little girl near Avondale last February.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 12.--On the south side of Front-street, almost opposite North-lane, is a desolate mound of earth.
The Rapid Transit Athletic Club, composed of employes or the elevated roads, held its annual picnic and games in Sulzer's Harlem River Park yesterday.

TORONTO, Sept. 12.--A fire started some where in the rear of Slaven's drug store, on Kingstreet, Midland, about 7 o'clock this morning and rapidly spread to the adjoining premises, occupied by Mr. Stafford, butcher.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 12.--The Prohibitionists of the Thirteenth District have nominated James Baker for Congress.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 12.--J.Q. Haltmann, manufacturer of engines and machinery, made an assignment yesterday. His assets are $75,000. Charles Steinberg, a hatter, made an assignment to-day. His assets are $6,000.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 12.--The shell of the body of Luther Knight, the machinist, who, it is supposed, was poisoned by his wife, was taken to Arlington, Vt., to-night. His death is as much a mystery as ever. Knight's father is here, but claims to be afraid of his son's wife, and will not go near the house.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 12.--There is a deadlock which promises to last for some time in the Democratic conference of the Twelfth District.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Sept. 12.--The decision or Judges Pratt and Dykman, at the General Term held in Brooklyn this week, in the case of James Roache against B.B. Odell, Sheriff, attracts considerable attention along the Hudson. The case was originally tried before Judge Barnard, whose decision has just been reversed.

MANCHESTER, Sept. 12.--The Guardian, in its commercial article, says: "Business is meagre, owing to the dullness of the cotton market. Prices have not improved. Buyers are indisposed to anticipate future wants, but postpone the execution of orders in the belief that they will gain by waiting."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12.--Somebody started a report this afternoon that President Arthur had appointed Gen. George H. Sharpe, of Kingston, N.Y., Secretary of the Treasury to fill out the late Judge Folger's term. This report spread rapidly, and for a time it was believed in the Treasury Department to be true.

BUFFALO, Sept. 12.--For some time past unusual activity has been noticed at the Union Iron Works in the southern part of the city, but the reason was not known until to-day, when it leaked out that the Packer estate, E.P. Wilber, George Beals, and the other owners had transferred their title to the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company for a nominal consideration.
CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 12.--Gen. B.F. Butler arrived from the West this afternoon, accompanied by his side partner, Col. Plympton.

OMAHA, Sept. 12.--The Democrats and their Anti-Monopolist allies, having combined upon a State ticket in the convention which finished its work at 6 o'clock this morning, the Democrats to-night celebrated the nomination of J. Sterling Morton for Governor by a torchlight procession.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 12.--Many citizens of Rochester heard with concern to-day that Gen. Isaac F. Quimby had been compelled to retire from the position of Professor in the University of Rochester. Ill-health has been the leading cause. His resignation was handed in Sept. 4, to take effect at the beginning of the present term.

ALBANY, Sept. 12.--It is not Gov. Cleveland's intention, as announced in some of the Western papers, to make a trip to Chicago next month and speak at several points on the way. He has now no expectation of going outside of the State before the election.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 12.--D.J. Rocks, a prominent builder and contractor, eloped to-day with Mrs. Thomas Quinn, the beautiful wife of his neighbor and friend. Rocks has been married for 19 years and has a wife and four children. He is 40 and Mrs. Quinn is 22.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12.--The Secretary of War has made a ruling that in carrying out the recent act of Congress providing that medical officers of the army shall be borne on the army register, in accordance with dates of commissions, credit must be given for volunteer service.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12, 1884. Minister Foote informs the Department of State that an American line of steamers has been placed on the coast and rivers of Corea.
EAST SAGINAW, Mich., Sept. 12.--Gen. Logan left Toledo by a special train this morning for Bay City, accompanied by a committee, consisting of the Republican nominees of this State and others.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Sept. 12.--The terrible floods reached a climax last night, and the waters of the mad Chippewa River are slowly receding. There has been a fall of three and one-half feet since 10 o'clock last night. The entire Chippewa Valley presents a scene of devastation.

CAIRO, Sept. 13.--Gen. Lord Wolseley will start for Assioot next Monday. Orders have been issued in Cairo which point toward an intention to use the desert route from Debbeh to Khartoum in case the Nile route fails. Agents are scouring Upper Egypt buying camels. Over 30,000 of these animals will accompany the expedition. Gen. Sir Evelyn Wood has been appointed Inspector of Communications with the Nile.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 13.--The schooner J.T. Mott, of Oswego, N.Y., was struck by an unknown craft on Lake Erie, four miles southeast of Colchester, and sunk in 42 feet of water. The crew reached Colchester this morning in a yawl. No assistence was given by the colliding craft.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 13.--Annie Guisler, a young German girl, about 20 years of age, has been having fits of melancholia for about two weeks. The cause is not fully known, as she had been reticent in regard to it with her landlady, Mrs. Bolander, on Court-street.

The two days' cricket match between the I Zingari team, of Canada, and the Staten Island team was brought to a close yesterday afternoon and resulted in a bad defeat for the Canadians. The Staten Island men won in one inning, scoring 282 runs to 94 in two innings by the I Zingari eleven.

BERLIN, Sept. 13.--Prince Dolgorouky, of the Russian Legation, will accompany Emperor William to Skierniwice. The Czar will go to Alexandrovo Monday to meet Emperor William. The Czarewitch and Gen. Gourko will go to Granica to meet Emperor Francis Joseph.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept.13.--Gen. Thomas Taylor, Chief of Police, and his son, Blanton Taylor, were tried in the City Court to-day for provoking an assault on Joseph Eakins, city edtor of the Times. They were found guilty and fined to the full extent of the law. The son was also sentenced to 10 days in jail.

LONDON, Sept. 13.--The conversion scheme of the Right Hon. Hugh C. Childers, Chancellor of the Exchequer, is not meeting with brilliant success. The banks and insurance companies maintain a stubborn resistance toward it, while the general public and investors ignore the opportunities it offers.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Sept. 10.--It is 23 years since the rebel guerrilla Quantrell, with his cutthroat gang of land pirates, made his raid into this town and shot down a line of 180 of its people, who were ranged before the rebels, elbow to elbow.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 14.--.The saloon of Asa Dolph, the champion bicycle rider, was taken in charge by the Sheriff last night. There is much excitement in New-Brighton, Staten Island, over the finding of a number of bones and a silver watch at the bottom of a well that has been for some time unused. The well is on a piece of property in Jersey-street, and was recently purchased by the Irving Manufacturing Company.

Deputy Coroner Messemer yesterday made an autopsy on the body of Dr. Adolph J. Nockin, the druggist, who was shot and killed in his store at One Hundred and Sixteenth-street and Third-avenue by a former employe named Theodore Bung. A number of physicians were present at the autopsy.

NEWPORT, Sept. 14.--A cool wave has arrived and struck terror to the hearts of the hotel keepers, livery stablemen, boatmen, and others catering to the Summer traffic. The Aquidneck House, the Ocean House, and all the other hotels are open and have many substantial guests.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14.--Postmaster-General Gresham has successfully parried numerous attempts which have been made to-day to get from him a positive statement concerning the report that he is to be named as Judge Folger's successor in the Treasury Department.

The Countess de Giverville, whose husband has been confined in the insane pavilion at Bellevue Hospital for some days, having been taken there from the Metropolitan Hotel, arrived in this city Saturday morning with her brother.

The Chinese inhabitants of this city yesterday celebrated their. Tezingming or "Feastof the Dead." This commemoration is held annually, and consists of placing upon the graves of departed relatives or friends food and drink and a fac simile paper figure of the dead person, with appropriate ceremonies.

James Quinlan, a tramp, 34 years old, went into the lumber yard of Duryee Co., at First-avenue and Thirty-fifth-street, yesterday afternoon, and, picking out a soft plank, prepared himself for a comfortable nap.

KINGSTON, Sept. 14.--Mrs. Elizabeth A. Weeks, a widow about 50 years old, has been committed to jail, in Catskill, Greene County, charged with murdering her son, Charles, 23 years old, on Sunday, May 18, last.

Sitting Bull and some of the braves of his tribe will be at the Eden Musee throughout the present week. They will give representations each day of wild life on the plains.

MERIDEN, Conn., Sept. 14.--Crowds of people from this city have visited the scene of the mysterious shooting of Wallie H. Perkins, near Wallingford Centre, at 2 o'clock yefterday morning. The mystery deepens, and the case now appears bad for Perkins and young Talcott, who was with him.

The fair of Koltes Post, No. 32, G.A.R., which has been open at the Germania Assembly Rooms during the last week, was successfully closed last night with a sacred concert and ball. The attendance was large, and the cool evening made the entertainment very enjoyable.
The Guion steamship Arizona, with Augustin Daly and company on board, was sighted yesterday afternoon at 5:25 off Fire Island, and reached Quarantine at 8 o'clock, anchoring there for the night.

ROME, Ga., Sept. 14.--The village of Coosaville is in a state bordering upon warfare, owing to a feud which exists between Hig Vann, of that place, and the Johnson family, of Chattooga. Several days ago the belligerents met, and more than a dozen shots were exchanged, but without fatal results.

The cold weather has brought Coney Island up with a short turn, and the days of the season are limited. It was generally admitted yesterday that, unless the mercury was forced up several degrees within a fews days, there would be no more Coney Island Sundays in the year of grace, 1884.
ST. PAUL, Sept. 14.--The boat in which Ole Sunderland, Ole Strand, and Ole Ness were fishing in Lake Minnetonka yesterday was capsized and the former two were drowned.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 14.--A most shocking affair occurred on board of a north-bound passenger train from New-Orleans, a few miles south of Jackson, last night. Two young men named Marlow and Smith got aboard of the train at Crystal Springs.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 15.--A strange double divorce suit has just been decided here. James Forsyth was united in wedlock with Miss Lydia Davis, of the quiet, sleepy little hamlet of Port Ewen, just across Rondout Creek, on Sept. 24, 1877, in this city.

CONYERS, Ga., Sept. 15.--Last Saturday night the Methodist Church here was burned to the ground. The fire was discovered at about 9 o'clock, and had made but little headway. It originated in the vestibule.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15.--The Hon. John V. Farwell writes to the Tribune emphatically denying the printed reports that contagious pieuropneumonia had appeared in his herd of Jersey and Guernsey cattle on his Lake View farm. The bull that died, he says, was afflicted with a common disease, and was kept apart from the herd. The sick cows are not ailing from pleuro-pneumonia.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 15.--Mr. Bair, who is training Maud S. at Charter Oak Park for her effort to break her 2:09 record, to-day drove her an easy mile in 2:13 , without urging. She is in prime condition, and will be ready in another week for her great effort.

The eyes of agricultural New-Jersey are upon Waverly Park, where they will remain until late Friday evening, for there proceed the festivities of the Twenty-ninth annual fair of the New-Jersey State Agricultural Society.
Mme. Fursch-Madi, the distinguished prima donna, arrived here yesterday by the Austral to fulfill engagements to sing in concert and oratorio during the Autumn and Winter in various cities.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 15.--The neighbors of Mrs. Johanna H. Whittaker, in East Fayettestreet, were aroused at about 6 o'clock this morning by her little son, 9 years old, who, with tears streaming down his cheeks, announced that his mother was dead.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 15.--It is reported that five inches of snow fell at Spring Hill, Cumberland County, yesterday. There was also two inches of snow at Truro.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15.--A special dispatch to the Times from Huntingdon, Penn. says: "The Bedford County Bank, at Everett, has been obliged to suspend because of losses sustained in the failure of the Kemble Coal and Iron Company of Riddlesburg. The officers of the bank say that depositors will be paid in full. No statement has been made of assets and liabilities."

BALTIMORE, Sept. 15.--There is some excitement at Millington, Kent County, Md., over the poisoning of 19 persons by eating ice cream. William Bratcher keeps a confectionery store in the town.

When Mr. Morosini's discharged coachman climbed over the back fence of the broker's residence in Yonkers, last Tuesday afternoon, and waited under an apple tree for his lady love to come out to him, he claims to have had no more idea of an elopement than he had of a voyage to the moon.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 15.--The trading schooner Sir John A. took fire off Discousse, Cape Breton, on Thursday night, and was burned to the water's edge, the crew having barely time to escape in a boat without saving any of their effects. The vessel was owned by John Echler, of Guysborough, and is insured.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 15.--Ferdinand Lefleur, a middle-aged man, who has been employed for some time as sexton of St. Jean Baptiste Church, Ottawa, was arrested to-day on a charge of stealing various large sums of money belonging to the church and its priests.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 15.--The Connellsville Coke Producers' Association is meeting with some new opposition from the pig iron men of the East.

This is, in many respects, the pleasantest season for European travel. The magnificent fleet of ocean steamers now in the transatlantic service is crowded with returning Americans and foreigners coming to visit this country.

Among the passengers by the steamship Arizona, which arrived from Europe Sunday evening too late to pass Quarantine and therefore did not come up to the city until yesterday morning, were Augustin Daly and his comedy company, which sailed from New-York on July 5 last to fill a short engagement at Toole's Theatre, in London.

WASH'TN, D.C., 16th April, 1876. MY DEAR MR. FISHER: You can do me a very great favor, and I know it will give you pleasure to do so--just as I would do for you under similar circumstances. Certain persons and papers are trying to throw mud at me to injure my candidacy before the Cincinnati Convention, and you may observe they are trying it in connection with the Little Rock and Fort Smith matter.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 15.--William Monahan, the driver of a Blue Island-avenue car, late last night struck Matthew P. Sullivan, a passenger, with a car hook, and the latter will probably die. Sullivan and a companion were intoxicated and attacked the car conductor, and Monahan, mistaking it for an attempt at robbery, struck Sullivan.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15.--The Evening Bulletin, the oldest afternoon paper in Philadelphia, reduced its price to-day from 3 to 2 cents.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 15.--In the trial of Dr. James D. Pitts, at Hamilton, for the murder of Dr. Thomas Walter, on Tangier Island last May, the jury to-night returned a verdict of guilty of murder in the second degree, and fixed the term of imprisonment at 18 years in the penitentiary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15.--Lieut.-Col. Orlando Moore, Seventeenth Infantry, was retired to-day, having been found incapacitated for active service by a retiring Board. Major Hough is promoted to the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel.

PANAMA, Sept. 6.--But few cases of yellow fever have been reported, although an occasional death from that disease is noted. Mr. A. C. Waibel, a young New-Yorker, is the latest victim. He died on Sunday evening after an illness of only 60 hours. He had resided here for two years. His employment caused him to frequently visit the line of the canal, where, it is supposed, he contracted the disease.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15.--The thirteenth cricket match of the regular series between the United States and Canada was begun at Nicetown to-day before a good-sized attendance.
ALBANY, Ga., Sept. 15.--On Dr. Jones's plantation two negroes--Henry Dickinson and Washington Hooper--were suitors for the hand of the same dusky maiden.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 15.--De Wolfe the bigamist, from New-York, who is still in jail here for debt, has been served with a writ by a New-York attorney in a divorce suit brought by his first wife. The prisoner seems to be at ease, and dresses every day as carefully as if he were going out for a promenade on Broadway.

The Gold and Stock Telegraph Company threatened some time ago to remove a "ticker" from the office of Ellis Morris, No. 47 Montgomery-street, Jersey City. Morris obtained in the Supreme Court here a preliminary injunction restraining its removal.

GLEN HOUSE, N.H., Sept. 15.--C.R. Milliken, proprietor of the Glen House, this noon arrested F.E. Smith, of Belgrade, who arrived here to-day, for stealing over $2,000 worth of diamonds and jewelry from the room of Miss Abbie Knight, of Washington, who has been spending the season here. The valuables were found on his person.
LONDON, Sept. 15.--Advices from China state that the Chinese have no intention of blocking the Woo-Sung River, on which Shanghai is situated, unless the French make an attack.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 15.--The estate of W. R. McGill, the deceased President of the Cincinnati and Eastern Railroad, who was suspected of committing suicide by leaping from a train several months ago, was to-day appraised at $20,000, Mr. McGill was in debt to various individuals to the extent of many thousands of dollars, which gave rise to reports after his death of his having been a defaulter to the railroad company.

SARATOGA, Sept. 16.--The Summer residence of ex-Sheriff James O'Brien, of New-York, in this place, was entered by burglars a few days ago.

PHILADELPHIA Sept. 16.--The international cricket match between the United States and Canadian teams, which was begun on the grounds of the Germantown Club at Nicetown yesterday, terminated this afternoon in a victory for the visiting team by 100 runs.

Oscar Strasburger, surviving partner of the firm of Oscar Strasburger Co., wholesale dealers in toys, fancy goods, c., at Nos. 443 and 445 Broadway, has been put in an asylum at Coburg, Germany. For a long time he had been mentally distressed by fear of business reverses.

The preliminary injunction obtained by Ralph Anderton, Jr., a stockholder of the NewYork Concert Company, restraining Rudolph Aronson and others from voting on 446 shares of the company's stock at the approaching election of Directors, was dissolved by Judge Donohue, in Supreme Court Chambers yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16.--The sixth annual session of the National Telephone Association was opened in Parlor C. Continental Hotel, this morning. Nearly 100 active and honorary members, representing 34 distinct telephone companies, were present.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 16.--There has been a most remarkable change in political affairs during the past ten days, and the dullness at the headquarters of the Republican Party no longer exists. New life has been infused, and to-day great energy prevails.
Peter Sheahan, alias Timothy, of No. 133 Baxter-street, was arrested on Sunday night, for disorderly conduct and for liberating a prisoner, by Officer McManus, of the Sixth Precint.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16.--The General Managers of the railroads west of Chicago to-day adopted the recommendation of a special committee, unanimously decided upon yesterday, to form four pools--two for business east and two for business west of the Missouri River.

BINGHAMTON, Sept. 16.--This city has 42 cigar and tobacco factories and dealers. Twothirds of this number comprise small shops, employing only a few hands each, but several are among the largest in the State outside of NewYork City.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 16.--The cornerstone of the new Methodist Episcopal church was laid to-day with appropriate ceremonies, the Rev. T.L. Flood, D.D., editor of the Chautauquan, making the address to a large assemblage, including many clergymen. The church is to cost $50,000. The one it will replace was begun in 1814. The money for the new edifice is nearly all subscribed.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 16.--A large crowd gathered in the County Court room this forenoon to listen to the arguments of counsel in the case of Elizabeth D. Phillips against Ernst Meincke, a suit to recover $5,000 damages for breach of promise of marriage.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 16.--The sloop yacht Wanda, of New-York, failed to come in stays off the Old Light in the gal last night and went ashore, when the sea began combing over her. Her house was washed away, her cabin flooded, and her sails torn into ribbons.

The September entries for the great Long Island Stakes, two mile heats, to be run on Saturday next, are Rataplan, Modesty, Checkmate, and Miss Woodford. These are in addition to the 14 entries made in January.

The sudden decline of the mercury has led to the beginning of what are technically known as "Fall openings," and the hearts of those who like to examine handsome goods as well as purchase of the same are made happy.

AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 16.--Mr. Blaine will leave here on his Western trip on the 4 o'clock train to-morrow afternoon. Senator Frye will accompany him as far as New-York.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 16.--The stock belonging to the Henry Hall Sons Company, of Highland Mills, comprising manufactured and partly manufactured fishing tackle, was sold this morning by the Sheriff of Orange County...

NAPLES, Sept. 16.--The excesses of Sunday caused a slight increase in the number of cases of cholera yesterday. King Humbert, in his journey to the North, was enthusiastically greeted along the route.

Elijah Alliger was arrested yesterday on a charge of advertising himself as the owner of an altered United States bond. On Sept. 6 Alliger borrowed $100 from the Fidelity and Casualty Company, and left the bond as security.
READING, Penn., Sept. 16.--A very sad misfortune overtook the wife of Daniel Yoh, repairman on the Schuylkill Canal, residing at Shoemakerville.

FORT DODGE, Iowa, Sept. 16.--A masked man about 2 o'clock yesterday entered the house of William Jennison, the School Treasurer of Washington Township, and demanded of Mrs. Jennison the school money. She replied that it was in the bank, whereupon the intruder drew his revolver and shot her dead.
The sculptor Jules Lebrethon, who has a contract with L. Marcotte Co. and lives with his famous pupil, A.S. Gaudens, at No. 148 West Thirty-sixth-street, had an adventure early yesterday morning.

Four men who were doing business in the Mercantile National Bank, at No. 191 Broadway, about 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, made a rapid rush for the door.
FOO-CHOO, Sept. 16.--The British Lieutenant who was wounded when the British war ship Zephyr was fired upon through mistake by the Chinese at the Kinpai forts has died from the effects of his wounds.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Sept. 16.--Bedford County Bank, doing business at Everett, Penn., has closed its doors and notified the depositors that it cannot settle.

A farewell reception was given last evening to the Rev. Dennis Osborn, of India, at the Sixty-first-Street Methodist Episcopal Church. Mr. Osborn's complexion and features are those of a Hindoo of the better class.

MADRID, Sept. 16.--The negotiations in regard to the Spanish-American treaty of commerce promise to reach a speedy termination.
The funeral of the late Robert Hoe took place yesterday at his Summer residence at Tarrytown. The coffin, which was placed in the parlor, bore a few flowers on its lid.
The Republican County Committee last night granted further time in which to prepare the reports of the Committee on Constitution and Bylaws and the Committee on an Address to Republican Voters.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 16.--The Brooklyns and Cincinnatis played a dull, uninteresting game to-day, the score being 11 to 0 in favor of the home team. The Cincinnatis batted fairly well, making 18 based out of 13 hits.

All uncertainty has at last been cleared away, and German opera, or opera sung in German, at the Metropolitan Opera House, is a settled matter. Cable messages arranging the final details in the engagement of a company were interchanged yesterday between the Metropolitan Directors and Dr. Damrosch.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16.--Much sharp criticism of the authorities has been heard recently because of the long delay in bringing the suits against Capt. Howgate's bondsmen, which have just been ordered by the Solicitor of the Treasury.

ONEONTA, N.Y., Sept. 16.--President Arthur has accepted an invitation to be present at the Union Fair, to be held here Sept. 25 and 26. His Cabinet are also invited. Several excursion trains are expected here on that day, and there will undoubtedly be the largest crowd ever seen in the Susquehanna Valley.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16.--The Controller of the Currency has been notified that the Directors of the National Bank of New-Jersey at New-Brunswick will visit Washington on Thursday or Friday of this week for the purpose of conferring with him in regard to the proposed resumption of that bank.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 16.--The reason for the mysterious absence from the city of Ernest de Morella, Consul of Italy and Turkey, doing business at No. 33 South Gay-street, this city, came more clearly to light this morning, when attachments against his wines and other effects amounting to over $6,000 were laid in the hands of Sheriff Airey.

The racing yesterday at the Sheepshead Bay track was probably the most sensational of the year, and those who made the journey to the track were amply rewarded by witnessing some great flights of speed.

A merry crowd of young people, all going off for an afternoon in the woods, was waiting for a train on the platform of the NewRochelle Station yesterday. Suddenly they all clustered around a girl, breathless with excitement, who had rushed down the steps leading from the street above to the track as though she were mad.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 16.--The Hon. Lyman W. Coe, of Torrington, was nominated for Congressman from the Fourth District by the Republicans by acclamation to-day. No other name was mentioned.

RIVER FALLS, Wis., Sept. 16.--About 9 o'clock this morning the boiler of the engine of a thrashing machine, owned and operated by Charles and Theodore Ecker, exploded while at work upon the farm of Alaric Chapin, six miles east of this village, killing the engineer, Charles Ecker,...

AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 16.--In Cato, 10 miles north of this city, Mr. Bergh's agent, Moulvey, acting for the American Humane Society, has found a woman named Angeline Hoyt, aged 60 years, who for over half a century has been confined in a filthy pen, on the ground of being insane. She sits in the pen--8 by 12 feet and 8 feet high--in the corner of a woodshed.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 16.--The Directors of the Norfolk Knitting and Manufacturing Company have informed their employes that owing to dullness in the demand for cotton goods it is probable that operations will be suspended for a few months till the old stock has been worked off. The factory employs 150 hands, who will be thrown out of employment.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 16.--An exceedingly cold wave is now passing over the maritime Provinces. In certain parts of Cumberland County several inches of snow have fallen, and on Sunday it is reported that a five inch fall of snow took place at Moncton, NewBrunswick. It is thought that the crops will suffer from the unseasonable change.

Higbie Carpenter, age 62, of No. 109 East One hundred and Twenty-sixth-street, was knocked down and run over last evening by a Third-avenue surface car at One Hundred and Twenty-third-street, and had his right leg cut off. He was taken to the Ninety-ninth-Street Hospital, and the driver of the car was arrested.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 16.--The September meeting at Mystic Park was inaugurated to-day with two fairly interesting races. The attendance was light. In both races the favorites were winners.

ALBANY, Sept. 16.--Chairman William H. Barnum made a short stop here to-day, and informed Gov. Cleveland of the result of his Western trip. His investigations were directed chiefly toward Wisconsin and Illinois, but incidentally took in Ohio, Michigan, and Indiana.

SKIERNIWICE, Sept. 17.--The Grand Dukes Vladimir and Nicholas of Russia, the Prince of Saxe-Altenburg, and the Ambassadors of Austria and Germany at St. Petersburg, with their attaches, attended the Emperors yesterday afternoon on their hunting excursion.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17.--At the State Fair this afternoon the bee tent was the scene of a remarkable entertainment. Prof. Arthur ...

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 17.--John Helm, brother of the late Gen. Helm; his nephew, Helm Bruce, and Thomas G. Hayes, his brother-inlaw, went to Oak Hill Cemetery this morning accompanied by friends to have the General's remains exhumed.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 17.--A high wind prevailed to-day, making ball playing difficult and disagreeable work. But nearly 600 people were out to see the game between the Metropolitan and Indianapolis Clubs.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 17.--The sixteenth annual reunion of the Army of the Cumberland began to-day. Large numbers of members have arrived from all over the country. The hotels are all crowded, and Power's Hotel, the headquarters of the society, presents a busy scene. Many distinguished members are present.

Miss Emma Juch, the popular prima donna, who returned from a vacation tour in Europe, was smiling radiantly upon the capers of the expressive Lotta last evening. She had never seen the little comedienne, and good nature and perfect health beamed in her countenance as she applauded with her dainty hands.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 17.--The new Democratic Convention to nominate a candidate in the Second Congressional District of Maryland assembled at Towsontown to-day. On the ninth ballot Dr. Frank T. Shaw, of Carroll County, was nominated to succeed the Hon. J. Frederick C. Talbot.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 17.--There were many callers at the Executive Chamber to-day, including a number of excursion parties. Among the prominent visitors were James Valentine, of London, England; Henry Hall, ...

BORDENTOWN, N.J., Sept. 17.--A man who is believed to be Frederick Burgner, of No. 820 North Third-street, Philadelphia, was found dead in a lane near here this morning, with a bullet hole through his brain. He was about 42 years old, of fair complexion, and wore dark whiskers. He was well dressed. An inquest will be held by Coroner Keller this afternoon. It is supposed to be a case of suicide.

"Nobody can read in a judicial spirit the Mulligan letters and say that BLAINE is a proper person to be President of these United States," wrote Congressman LYMAN, an independent Republican, a few days ago, in an excellent letter addressed to prominent voters of the Ninth Massachusetts District who had asked him to be a candidate for re-election.
The police of the Fourth Precinct raided a low house in Chatham-street last night and locked up nine dissolute women for examination in the Tombs Police Court this morning.
A few weeks ago the William B. Hanson Association organized a Blaine and Logan club. The club unfurled a handsome banner at its headquarters, No. 213 Bowery, last evening.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 17.--A long litigation of interest to many New-Yorkers is drawing to a close. The action commenced by Jesse Peck against David Cady Smith, as Executor of Eliza Peck, deceased, has been pending nearly six years.

EASTON, Penn., Sept. 17.--The annual session of the Evangelical Lutheran Synod of East Pennsylvania will be held here to-morrow morning, and will continue one week. To-night the Rev. Mr. Billheimer of Reading, preached the annual sermon. About 130 ministers and lay delegates will attend. The syond represents over 13,000 communicants.

The annual Fall regatta of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club will be sailed to-morrow morning, when prizes will be awarded to the winner in each of eight classes, in which the yachts will be classed on time allowance.

Friends of the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company frankly admitted yesterday that a Receivership was inevitable for that corporation. The Executive Committee of the company was in session yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17.--Several members of the Association for the Advancement of Science attended the second day's session of the National Telephone Association, at the Continental Hotel, to-day.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 17.--Jacob Schaefer, the champion billiardist, now in this city, challenges George F. Slosson to play an 8 or 10 inch balk-line game for from $500 to $2,500 a side. He will play two games--one in Chicago and the other in New-York--800 points up, the games to be played in December.

Eleven weary looking people, with hopeless faces, and travel-stained garments, stood yesterday morning in front of Pettit's Hotel, at Jamaica, Long Island, and gazed upon the protean landscape before them.

When Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Hulskamp got off the train which arrived at the Mount St. Vincent station yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock they started direct for the Morosini mansion through the convent grounds.

James F. Roach, a fireman of Hook and Ladder Company No. 6, in Canal-street, went on on excursion to Mauch Chunk, Penn., yesterday with Dover Post. The train left there about 6 o'clock last evening to return.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 17.--Philip V. R. Harrington, a farmer, of Knowersville, last night called at the police station and reported that his 17-year-old daughter was missing since last Wednesday night.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 17.--The racing was continued here to-day. The weather was fine, the track stiff, owing to the rain of last night, and the attendance fair.

The Sinking Fund Commissioners had under consideration yesterday the applications for new armories for the Ninth and Twelfth Regiments, both of which were referred to committees for report at the next meeting.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 18.--Gen. John A. Logan and J.C. Torrence will leave Rochester on Friday morning by a special train for Youngstown, Ohio, passing through Erie, Sharpstown, Sharon, and New Castle, Penn. They will reach Erie at 9 o'clock Friday morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18.--The bronze equestrian statue of Major-Gen. John Fulton Reynolds, killed at Gettysburg July 1, 1863, while in command of the left wing of Meade's army, was unveiled this afternoon.
"La Jolie Parfumeuse" will be sung for the last time at Wallack's on Saturday afternoon, with Mme. Theo as Rose Michon and Mlle. Lefort as Bavolet.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 18.--A Trustee was appointed over the insolvent estate of George H. Broune, of the Branford Point House, to-day by Judge Stedman. This is the result of a chilly season at the seaside this Summer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18.--Col. Matthew M. Blunt, Sixteenth infantry, has been detailed as a member of the General Court Martial appointed to meet at San Antonio, Texas, by special orders of Sept. 12, vice Lieut.-Col. Thomas M. Vincent, Assistant AdjutantGeneral, relieved.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18.--President Miller, of the Western whisky pool, who was at the Grand Pacific Hotel yesterday, said that he had fixed up, with the aid of Dr. Rush, the troubles of the Buffalo distillers, and he said that since that was settled the pool was again in a good condition.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 18.--Platt Saeger, of Washington County, was driven from his bed this morning by an attack of acute asthma. He bathed his breast with turpentine and then approached the kitchen stove to heat his breast. The fluid took fire, and he called his father, who wrapped him in a blanket and hurried to get some water. When he returned the young man was dead.

LONDON, Sept. 18.--Nothing definite is known in London with reference to the reports current in New-York that Col. Mapleson had made propositions looking toward giving a season of Italian opera at the New-York Academy of Music. It is believed, however, that he in-` tends to do so, and that Mme. Patti will appear. Col. Mapleson is at present on the Continent.

Superintendent Walling was riding up town in a Third-avenue surface car last evening, in the Bowery, near Houston-street, when a halfdrunken ruffian named Jeremiah Sullivan, of No. 76 Prince-street, got on board. When the conductor asked him for his fare he refused to pay, and became noisy and abusive.

LONDON, Sept. 18.--An exciting rowing match occurred yesterday at Southampton between the crew of the cutter Uncle Sam, of the United States flagship Lancaster, and a local crew. The Uncle Sam has 14 oars; the rival boat has 18.

The gossips of South Oyster Bay and Smithville South, Long Island, are busy discussing the alleged marriage of Conklin Vandewater and Miss Cornelia Mann. Mr. Vandewater, who is 19 years of age, is the son of the late Conklin Vandewater, and when he attains his majority will become the possessor of a moderate fortune.

CAIRO, Sept. 18.--The Khedive, Nubar Pasha, the Egyptian Prime Minister, and Sir Evelyn Baring, the British representative in Egypt, have received an identical cipher dispatch from Gen. Gordon. The dispatch left Khartoum Aug. 26, and reads as follows:

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 18.--A cable dispatch was received here to-day from London stating that Sir John Macdonald is to be elevated to the peerage. Sir John is already a member of the British Privy Council. On being congratulated this evening Sir John stated that the announcement was rather premature, as he had received no information of an official character that would lead him to believe that the report was correct.

John Carpenter, who killed his wife, Mary, at Third-avenue and Twenty-sixth-street, and who was sentenced last month to be hanged, was yesterday granted a stay of 20 days by Recorder Smyth to complete his appeal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18, 1884. The President has appointed Harry Kisling bury, son of Lieut. Kislingbury, who lost his life in the Greely expedition, as cadet at large to the Naval Academy at Annapolis, in place of one of the cadets recently appointed, who failed to pass a physical examination.
Mrs. William Astor sat in a window of her Fifth-avenue mansion on Friday last watching a gang of men who were excavating a ditch in which to lay the pipes of the New-York Steam Heating Company.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 18.--Besides the select and distinguished gentlemen who journeyed along with Mr. Blaine to-night there were certain individuals who carefully concealed their identity and availed themselves of moments when enthusiasm ran high to ply their vocation and coolly rifle fat Republican pockets.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 18.--Cyrus W. Kellogg had his bicycle smashed by Louis Sommers's team on Olive-street, in this city, last Spring. The latter refused to pay damages and suit was brought. The case came up in the civil side of the City Court to-day and is yet pending.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 18.--A most precocious and depraved gang of juvenile sneak thieves has been broken up in this city to-day by the police. There are about 20 of them. None of the members are over 12 years of age.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 18.--A trial which has been in progress in Renshaw County during the present term of the court has brought out the details of one of the most deliberate murders known to the criminal annals of Alabama.

The Republican State Committee's headquarters were favored yesterday with visits from a number of Republicans from the interior, all of whom made favorable reports of the campaign's progress in their several localities.

Edward Sorlin, son of Dr. E. Sorlin, of No. 33 Passage Verododat, Paris, was arrested yesterday, as he was about to sail for France in the steamer Labrador, on a charge of stealing certain sums of money from John Schmidle, a restaurant cook in Park-place, who had befriended him.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 18.--The Hon. Michael Solomon, member of the Legislative Council of Jamaica, was here yesterday, in connection with the proposed union of that colony with the Canadian Dominion.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 18.--Mrs. Mary Essex, an 84 years' resident of Waterbury, was thrown down with great force upon her lawn to-day by a violent gust of wind, receiving internal injuries and dislocating her hip. The doctors think she will die.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 18.--John McCullough opened his season in this city to-night, appearing at the Opera House before a moderately large audience. He was warmly received. "Virginius" was presented.

LONDON, Sept. 18.--Henry M. Stanley, the African explorer, delivered an address to-day before a large meeting of influential citizens at the Cannon-Street Hotel upon the Congo country, its past history, its present developments, and its future commercial prospects. The address was received with prolonged applause.

The representation of "La Mascotte" given at Wallack's Theatre last evening was the best the opera bouffe company now in posssession of that house have supplied since they commenced operations for the season, 10 days since. The male characters were personated with unusual felicity, ...

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 18.--The Fall session of Rutgers College began this morning. Fifty applications for admission to the Freshman Class have been received, besides additions to the upper classes. There are few changes in the Faculty. Prof. Reilly, who for 25 years has been with the college, goes as United States Consul to Athens.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 18.--Members of the Connecticut National Guard are agitated over the report that there is a likelihood of a deficiency in the State military fund, and that the most rigid economy will have to be practiced in the future.

BLOOMINGTON, Sept. 18.--The Hon. Thomas A. Hendricks, who was bruised in the railroad accident near Farmer City yesterday, was unable to reach Saybrook on time to-day to address the Democratic meeting, but he arrived this afternoon, and spoke briefly. He then returned here and departed for Indianapolis. The crowd at Saybrook numbered between 5,000 and 6,000 persons.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 18.--About the 1st of June last some person placed a cross tie on the track of the North Carolina Railroad, about a mile east of Durham. The freight train from Greensborough to Raleigh, with a passenger car attached, and running in the night, came along and was wrecked.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 18.--At a dance in Riverton, a village near Winsted, late last night, Russell Rose and James Ramsbottom, rival beaus, quarrelled and fought. Ramsbottom was struck in the stomach and killed. Rose is in jail to await the action of the Grand Jury.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 18.--The Rev. Selden Gilbert, formerly of Little Falls, N.Y., was installed Pastor of the Church of the Messiah tonight. Prayer was offered by the Rev. W.H. Dearborn, of Hartford; the Rev. E.C. Bolles, of Salem, Mass., preached the installation sermon; ...

Mrs. Lucy D. Scheiffelin has begun an action in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, to annul her marriage with Bradhurst Schieffelin, of this city, on the ground that the ceremony was performed under a misapprehension.

LIVERPOOL, Sept. 18.--Mr. Henry Irving and Miss Ellen Terry sailed for Montreal to-day in the Allan Line steamship Parisian. The general public and the theatrical profession assembled in force upon the dock to see them off. Among the stage notables who were present were Miss Terry's sister, Mrs. Saker, John L. WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 18.--Deputy Sheriff Seaton, who was in charge of the County Jail here, went down this evening into the prisoners' quarters, locking the door after him. As he turned to unlock the door the prisoners made a rush upon him and struck him so severe a blow on his head with a club muffled by a blanket that he was knocked down.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18.--Distressing stories of a lack of peace and harmony in the Republican Finance Committee are in circulation here. It is said that the members of that committee have been so encouraged by the yield of their squeezing operations upon the Government ...
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 18.--Quaint old Worcester opened its gates to-day and bade the Hon. James G. Blaine tarry here for a few hours on his way from Augusta to New-York.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 18.--The great event of the day at Hampden Park was the victory of Sellers over Hendee in the one-mile amateur race. From 12,000 to 15,000 people were present. The day was unfavorable for fast time, the breezes being quite strong.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 18.--For several days Mr. Thomas M. Jackson, proprietor of the Atlanta Box Factory, has imagined that he could detect a handkerchief flirtation between his wife and Mr. Will McDonald, a saloonkeeper across the street.
MADRID, Sept. 18.--Heavy floods are destroying the crops in many parts of Spain.

Pliny White was arrested by Deputy Sheriff Brown yesterday on an order granted by Judge Donohue, in the Supreme Court. The order was based on affidavits made by John Y. Brokaw, the proprietor of the Allman House, No. 67 East Tenth-street, and Mrs. Sarah C. Brown, his housekeeper.

Two small children, a girl of 5 years and a boy of 4 year, belonging to Emanuel Foerster, were playing in front of their home, No. 2,216 First-avenue, from 3 to 5 o'clock on Wednesday afternoon. The girl walked up four flights of stairs and complained of feeling sick, ...
Probably one of the largest crowds that was ever seen on a race track in this country gathered on the grounds of the Coney Island Jockey Club at Sheepshead Bay yesterday.

A few days ago Officer Frank N. Evanhoe, of the Twenty-ninth Precienct, while down town and at leisure, saw Peter Lake, alias Grand Central Pete, the bunko steerer, talking to a man whose demeanor and attire were provincial near the Astor House.

LONDON, Sept. 18.--The Pall Mall Gazette says the report of the fighting near the Kinpai forts, below Foo-Choo, yesterday, was greatly exaggerated. Only 200 French troops landed and defeated a few villagers.

What looked like a shark with a hole in its back lay in the water off the Delamater Iron Works, at the foot of West Thirteenth-street, yesterday afternoon. It was the Peacemaker, the submarine torpedo boat designed by Prof. J.H.L. Tuck.

NAPLES, Sept. 18.--Excessive heat prevails, but the general condition of the city is improving. The gloom and depression which have overhung the city since the epidemic became serious are beginning to disappear, and the streets are regaining their customary activity.

Coroner Levy has decided to go ahead to-day with an inquest in the case of Frederick Kopf, who was killed, as alleged, by Patrick Judge. He has sent subpoenas to the police of the Ninth Precinct to produce the witnesses in the case.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 18.--Coroner Bollman is steadily but secretly working up the case of John F. Crowley, the inebriate who is supposed to have been murdered in W.D. McCarthy's saloon last week. The examination of witnesses so far has brought out, it is said, ...

The family of Thomas Mack, living on the third floor of the tenement house No. 279 Third-avenue, were sickened yesterday by eating canned salmon purchased at a neighboring grocery. Mack drives a black-and-tan cab for the New-York Cab Company.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 18.--In the United States Court this evening the attorneys for the Sentinel Company filed a bill of discovery in the Blaine libel suit, upon which no action was taken. The bill sets out at length a history of the case to date, including the filing of the complaint, ...

CHICAGO, Sept. 18.--Another day has passed and the Western railroads managers, though they have struggled hard to get out of it, are still in the mire. At the morning session numerous resolutions were presented and discussed.

Some unknown miscreants made an attempt yesterday morning to set fire to the two four-story frame tenements Nos. 222 and 224 East One Hundred and Twenty-first-street. These buildings are occupied by 16 families and had the attempt to fire them succeeded, a loss of life would doubtless have resulted.

In the generally very accurate obituary notice of my father-in-law, which appeared in the Times last Monday, it is said, in reference to his "Guinea Catalogue" of 1841, that it had since been "outstripped by the leviathan catalogues of Mr. Quaritch."
In the heat of the national canvass the character of the next Legislature of this State should not be overlooked. The Senate holds over, but the entire Assembly is to be elected as usual.

ATHENS, Ga., Sept. 18.--A few weeks ago a negro named Nick Wooten was arrested, convicted, and sentenced to 20 years in the penitentiary for entering the bedroom of the Misses Barnett, in Madison County. During the trial of Wooten, at Danielsville, a white man, married and respectably connected, named John Williams, rendered himself very conspicuous in his ...

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 18.--Ella Gilrov, aged 8 years, met with a horrible death by suffocation on a sand bank near Moosic to-day She had gone on the bank to play, when the treacherous sand sank beneath her feet, and she was carried down a distance of nine or ten feet. When dug out life was extinct.

Military Park, in Newark, was decorated with bunting last evening and between 8,000 and 10,000 people gathered to listen to an address by Gen. Butler. With a brief introduction he plunged into his subject:

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18.--The demonstration in honor of the Hon. Carl Schurz at the Armory this evening was one of the largest political receptions tendered a speaker in many years. The occasion was one of striking significance.

Edward Bibby, a professional wrestler, who keeps a saloon in Jersey City, was arraigned befor Judge Stilsing yesterday morning on a charge of having beaten his wife. He admitted the charge. He said that his wife was a habitual drunkard, that she spends from $20 to $25 a week in the gratification of her tastes, and that her habit had provoked him until he struck her. He gave bail to appear for trial.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 18.--The Fal meeting of the Louisville Jockey Club was continued here to-day. The weather was good, the track stiff, and the attendance fair.

On the 16th of April, 1876, Mr. BLAINE sent to Mr. FISHER a letter which he prayed Mr. FISHER to sign and send to him. It was a letter of exculpation to be used in his explanation of the disgraceful Little Rock and Fort Smith Railroad transactions.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 18.--The second business session of the Army of the Cumberland was called to order at 11 A.M. to-day by Gen. Sheridan, who asked for Gen. Barnett's report of the Garfield monument.

Mr. and Mrs. Hulskamp now occupy a prettily furnished little flat on the top floor of the flat house No. 78 West Twelfth-street. Both of them yesterday were decidedly under the weather, and Mrs. Hillskamp was suffering very much from nervousness, and was inclined to be hysterical.

PARIS, Sept. 18.--A portion of the Paris press are making violent attacks upon the American press for their comments on the bombardment of Foo-Choo. Le Paris, in an article entitled "Our Good Friends, the Yankees," says: "All that hateful malice can dictate to scribblers in delirium has found its way into their colums.

SKIERNIWICE, Sept. 18.--The Emperor Francis Joseph took his departure yesterday. His farewell to the Czar and Czarina, to the Grand Duchess Maria Paulovna, and to the Grand Dukes Vladimir and Nicholas was of the most cordial character.
PORTLAND, Sept. 18.--The following has been received direct from the Secretary of State:

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 17.--That the Democrats believe Connecticut is a doubtful enough State to attempt to carry for Cleveland a pretty evident from the talk of their managers. They have not fairly got their machinery in operation yet.
PORT HURON, Mich., Sept. 18.--The forest fires were checked to-day by a north wind, which blew the flames back over the burned district, where, finding nothing to consume, they died out.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18.--The members of the American Fish Culture Association visited League Island to-day for the purpose of inspecting the carp which were place in a pond there in January, 1883. When placed in the pond the carp were about four inches in length, they having been hatched the Summer before.

At the Brooklyn Rink last night Mrs. Mary T. Lathrop, President of the Women's Christian Temperance Union, of Michigan, delivered an address on prohibition. The Rev. Mr. Fitzwilliams, of Damascus, Penn., opened the meeting with prayer. Mr. G.S. Weeks then sang "We Mean to Vote as we Talk and Pray."
J.W. Jones, a retired merchant, lives in a handsome two-story frame cottage at No. 1,707 Washington-avenue. Tremont. The cottage stands back from the road and is surrounded by a pretty garden.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18.--At the State Department it is said that there need be no fear if any trouble growing out of the decision of the Mexican boundary line Commissioners, which places the line 660 yards north of where it was supposed to run.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 18.--The First Assembly District Democratic Convention for Jefferson County met in this city to-day and nominated A.W. Ingraham for the Assembly by acclamation.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 18.--Peter Clarke, Marshal of the City Court, was killed this afternoon in the discharge of his official duty by Mrs. Margaret Ahearn. The Ahearns, who live in the lower part of the city, have been in arrears for rent, and the landlord to-day obtained a precept ...

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 18.--The Ulster County Republican Convention this afternoon nominated Capt. James H. Everett for County Treasurer; Charles T. Coutant, of Esopus, for Coroner, and Alexander C. Hasbrouck, of Lloyd, for Justice of Sessions.

The second day's tournament of the New-Jersey State Sportsman's Association attracted a number of well-known shots to the grounds of the Jersey City Heights Club, in Marion, N.J., yesterday. Each train brought passengers with shotguns on their shoulders, ...

The Republican Association of the Tenth Assembly District held a meeting last evening in Concordia Hall to ratify the Blaine and Logan ticket. There was a goodly number in the hall, and the head of the ticket received much applause when his name was mentioned. The chief speech was made by Police Justice Patterson.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Sept. 18.--This morning the 20 striking miners arrested at Coal Centre for conspiring to keep J.S. Neel's men from working, and who had been released on bail, were on hand for the hearing to be given them before Judge Hart.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 18.--The Governor has pardoned John Cody, convicted in Westchester County of assaulting a woman, and sentenced Oct. 4, 1882, to seven years' imprisonment in Sing Sing Prison. The following reasons have been filed:

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 18.--Capt. W.L. Ellsworth has accepted the nomination for President of the United States tendered by the American Political Alliance, and will personally stump the States of Louisiana, Tennessee, Maryland, and Virginia. The headquarters of the Alliance are to be removed from Boston to Philadelphia, where they will be established at the old American Club House.
"Lady Reader."--Yes; at almost any bookstore. The Jewish festival of Rosh Hashana, or the New Year, begins this evening.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 18.--Morgan Swartz, a prominent citizen of Minersville and a hotel proprietor at that place for 25 years, is lying dangerously ill. His mother-in-law, Mrs. Stitzer, who has been constantly at his bedside, came down stairs this morning and notified the members of the family that he was dying. She then dropped dead. She was 70 years of age.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 18.--The veterans of the Fourteenth Regiment, New-York Heavy Artilery, held their annual reunion here to-day. About 50 members were present during the day, and more are in attendance at the banquet this evening.

Jerry McAuley lies dead in his rooms over the Cremorne Mission, in West Thirtysecond-street. He took his wife to Central Park on Wednesday afternoon for a walk.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18.--About 50 persons, most of whom were women, attended a meeting to-night at Wilson's Station, 15 miles from this city, to ratify the nomination of Mrs. Belva A. Lockwood for President of the United States.

The members of the Aztec Club had their annual dinner in commemoration of the attack made upon the City of Mexico during the Mexican war, at Pinard's last night. Gen. The fifth annual report of the St. Paul, Minneapolis and Manitoba Railway Company has just been issued. It shows a decrease in the gross earnings for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1884, of not quite $1,000,000, as compared with the business of the previous year.
Suits are now pending against the city in which persons who claim to have been injured through defects in the street pavements seek to recover over $1,500,000 as damages.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 18.--The Convention of the Connecticut Universalists closed this afternoon. The following officers were elected: President--The Rev. Dr. Chapin, of Meriden; Vice-President--E.M. Brown, of Hartford; Secretary--The Rev. John Lyon, of Bridgeport; ...

CHENEY, Washington Territory, Sept. 18. --E.J.S. Danford Co., bankers, closed their doors to-day. Danford and his wife have absconded with all the assets of the bank, including the deposits. D. Ainsworth, Cashier, is under arrest. Danford telegraphs from Victoria, British Columbia, that he is in fine health.

A young Englishman, who is at present staying at the Brunswick Hotel, was yesterday torn with conflicting emotions by a numerous and varied collection of visiting cards, the owners of which were supposed to have called in person on the gentleman.

BOSTON, Sept. 18.--John D. Long was renominated to-day in the Second Congressional District by the Republicans, and A.A. Ranney in the Third. Mr. Long was renominated by acclamation and unanimously, and the convention was without incident.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Northern Pacific Railway was held in the office of the company's Secretary, in the Mills Building, yesterday at noon. A very large proportion of the stock was represented.

FORT PLAIN, N.Y., Sept. 18.--It is claimed now that the Smulsey family are aggrieved because people won't believe that their daughter has been 196 days without food. If people will pay for the services of two nurses to watch her constantly they magnanimously offer to let them watch, and see whether their assertions as to her continued abstinence are true.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 18.--Gov. Cleveland was busy to-day transacting routine work and receiving callers. Among the visitors were the Hon. John R. Fellows and Dennis A. Spelissy, of New-York; T.W. and G.T. Barr, of ...

A seedy-looking man stepped into the boudoir-like office of a Broad-street banking and brokerage house on Wednesday afternoon. He wore no collar and no cuffs, and such of his linen as was visible was of a very dark hue. His coat was ragged and dirty, and the open-work ...

CHICAGO, Sept. 18.--Frank Belmont, a prisoner in the County Jail, was with Isaac Jacobson last night. Jacobson, who is under sentence of death, was cheerful and is so to-day. He said to Belmont in substance: "I am satisfied that my sentence is just. I killed George Bedell, and I know that I am guilty.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 18.--New-Haven will be represented at the New-Orleans Exposition by some fine woodwork. Master Carbuilder Denver, of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, a few weeks ago decided to send specimens of New-England wood, and since then ...

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 18.--An accident occurred yesterday afternoon in the lumber mill of J.H. Waite, 16 miles from this city, near the village of Windsor. Thomas Stanly, a well-known lumberman in this county, was clearing away sawdust near the shaft, when his clothing caught in the shaft and he was literally torn to fragments by the machinery. Mr. Stanly was 55 years old and leaves a large number of children.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 18.--The poker player is in hard luck in Waterbury, where Edward U. Lathrop, a grain and feed dealer; William Smith, a jeweler, and E.S. Smith, a manufacturer, have been arrested for indulgence in the game. The two Smiths are fashionable young men. They insist that there can be no case will be contested hotly in the courts.

The first regatta for catamarans ever sailed in the waters of this neighborhood took place yesterday. There have been match races between catamarans, and horses have tried their speed against these remarkable vessels.

The effort to put the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company into the hands of a Receiver culminated yesterday in an application to Judge Donohue, in Supreme Court, Chambers, for the appointment of its President, Garrett S. Mott, ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18.--Having settled it to their own satisfaction that neither Postmaster-General Gresham, Secretary Chandler, Minister Norton, ex-Secretary Windom, Assistant Secretary French, Jesse Seligman, Gen. Sharpe, nor any other gentleman ...

CHICAGO, Sept. 18.--The new whisky pool is said, by the Chicago distillers, to be working well in limiting the production, all the signers of the Cincinnati agreement upholding its terms. While they are not getting rich, the pool is keeping them off the road to the poorhouse. The rise in prices they expect to be gradual and in a year to be sufficiently great to place the business again on a good paying basis.
E.J. Baldwin, of San Francisco, is at the Hoffman House. Gen. S.V. Benet, United States Army, is at the Grand Hotel.
No river in the world absorbs at this moment more of the attention of Kings and Cabinets than the one which the intrepidity of STANLEY discovered to be among the mightiest streams of the globe.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 18.--Justice George Smith held to-day, in deciding a lawsuit in Meriden, that the filling of Mrs. Mary Crowley's teeth on Sunday was a work of necessity, and Dentist Roberts will recover the money for which he sued.

HARTFORD, Sept. 18.--A ripple of excitement was occasioned on Wednesday in South Manchester by the announcement of the MeadSickles escapade. William H. Mead, the hero of the affair, has for a number of years been in the employ of W.H. Cheney as a delivery clerk, and ...

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 18.--Maud S. was given three practice miles at Charter Oak Park this afternoon in the presence of Robert Bonner, her owner, and other well-known horse admirers. She was sent the first mile in 2:21, the second in 2:16 , and the third in 2:11 . The conditions were not the best for fast work, and the mare was not urged.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18.--The Record tomorrow will say: "It was announced yesterday upon the best authority that all the interests engaged in the production of anthracite coal had agreed that the only hope for its proper protection next year was a combination.
The Butler party held its State Convention in the Academy of Music, at Newark, yesterday. The call was issued in the name of the Greenbackers.

Joseph Fettretch, a lawyer, living at No. 775 Lexington-avenue, went to Police Headquarters yesterday in search of an eight-hundred-dollar horse and phaeton which his coachman had either lost or had stolen from him.

At Worcester Mr. Blaine was joined by a delegation from Springfield, which had gone up to act as an escort to him to this city. Among the gentlemen were ex-Mayor W.H. Haile, the Hon. Henry S. Hyde, J.L. Shipley, Col. S.C. Warriner, and J.S. Carr.
George Jura and Maria Gessen were married yesterday at Castle Garden by Pastor Berkemeier. The bridal pair came from Hungary, and arrived at Castle Garden by the steamship Frisia on Wednesday.

A great crowd blockaded the streets about the Academy of Music last night waiting for the doors to open for admission to the anti-Cleveland meeting. A force of 50 or more policemen were placed at intervals through the banner-decorated Academy, and twice as many more guarded the doors.
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 18.--R.C. Marshall, of Portsmouth, was to-day nominated for Congress by the Second District Democratic Convention.

In the Supreme Court, at White Plains, yesterday, a suit was begun by Josiah Rich, late of Yonkers, against the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company for $150,000 damages, occasioned to him by reason of the action of the defendant company in changing the location of their station.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18.--The wheat men at La Crosse, Wis., and vicinity reluctantly admit that the damage to wheat by rust is not half understood, and say that it was not only serious, but widespread.

It was decided by Judge Van Brunt, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, that telegraph companies never had a valid right to erect poles in the streets unless they had compensated the owners of the premises in front of which the poles were raised.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 18.--The sleeping cars of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad are being repaired and remodeled. The seats which heretofore have been lengthwise with the car will be set as in the passenger coaches.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 18.--The Trades Journal, of Akron, Ohio, hitherto an influential Republican journal, has come out for Butler and West.

In a little blue and white striped tent, on the brow of a hill in Waverly Park, New-Jersey, most of the agricultural and some of the political talent of that State sat or stood in deep expectancy from noon of yesterday until the afternoon was well-nigh passed.
