WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 19.--Judge Barker, of the Superior Court, has disallowed the exceptions in the famous twenty-thousand-dollar libel suit of Sheriff Sprague against H.H. Bigelow.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 19.--This evening there was an imposing demonstration of strikers, the first ever seen in this city, who, to the number of several hundred, with two bands ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19, 1884. A rumor was in circulation to-day that a theft of $15,000 had been discovered at the Treasury Department, but all the Treasury officials most emphatically declared that there was no truth in the story.
LIMA, Sept. 19, via Galveston.--Advices from Tacna say that the fugitive Peruvians who arrived there were compelled to leave within an hour, under penalty of imprisonment.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 19.--Howard Douglass, an attorney, has just returned from Deer Park, where he spent several weeks with John R. McLean, of the Cincinnati Enquirer.

When the inscription "Twice Prime Minister of England" was devised for the Lord Beaconsfield statue in Westminster Abbey, it was suggested by an eminent Tory Peer that the inscription would be better had it been made to read: "Once a lawyer's clerk. Twice Prime Minister of England."

The dissolution of the firm of Hatch, Brooks Hamlin, brokers in Exchange-place, was announced in the Stock Exchange yesterday. The firm was composed of John R. Hatch, Walter Brooks, and Walter A. Hamlin, all young men. Mr. Hatch, who was the Stock Exchange member, retired, and his partners formed a new firm under the title of Brooks Hamlin.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19.--The City Guard and the National Blues have formally voted to go to Washington to take part in the inauguration parade next March, and the other eight companies of the Second Regiment will take similar action at their next meetings.

BOSTON, Sept. 19.--Mr. Charles H. Waterman, of New-York, the nominee for Vice-President of the United States by the American Political Alliance, has accepted the nomination and will make an extended personal canvass.

The season is almost here when o' nights the air reaches a temperature which causes congelation. Even before the air reaches this bracing point and thermometers begin their downward race in dead earnest it gives a few premonitory twinges of coolness.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 19.--A private reception was tendered Gen. Sheridan this morning at Charlotte, on Lake Ontario.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 19.--In the outlying districts of the Schuylkill, Luzerne, Northumberland, Carbon, Lehigh, Wyoming, and Lackawanna regions the coal and iron police, as well as the members of the detective corps, have discovered unmistakable evidence of the existence of lodges of the notorious brotherhood of Mollie Maguires.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 19.--Mr. G.A. Rogers, of Boston, made a perilous balloon ascension from North Adams, Mass., to-day.

While Contractor Hoxsey's men were at work yesterday morning near Fulton-street, Paterson, one of the horses suddenly fell into a deep excavation, the existence of which had been entirely unsuspected by the men.

The County Committee of the County Democracy, at a special meeting last evening to arrange the preliminaries for putting local and Congressional candidates in nomination, decided that the County Convention should be held in Chickering Hall on Wednesday, Oct 15, at 3 P. M.
PARIS, Sept. 19.--The Mayor of Marseilles has resumed the issue of daily bulletins showing the progress of the cholera in that city and the surrounding country.
A party of New-Yorkers, including Mr. and Mrs. George Peabody Wetmore, Mr. and Mrs. William B. Wetmore, and J. Hooker Hamersley, had a very unpleasant experience with the sea last Monday night.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19.--The wrecked sloop yacht Wanda, of New-York, was towed up from outside the harbor this morning and beached at the New-Haven Yacht Club's house by her new owner, C.R. Waterhouse, Jr., of this city.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 19.--A reception was held on board of the flagship Tennessee, of the North Atlantic squadron, this afternoon, and was given by Admiral Luce, who will be succeeded to-morrow by Commodore Jouett.
The horses attached to a coach driven by William Low were frightened by a passing car on the Brooklyn bridge yesterday afternoon and dashed down the roadway toward the New-York exit.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 19.--The little village of Pine Hill, 30 miles from here, was startled this morning by the report that Ida Alton, a young woman of 26, daughter of Alfred Alton, a respected farmer, was found dead in her bed at the hotel of George Cole.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 19.--The most marvelous array of campaign uniforms ever seen in the peaceful valley of the Hudson was shown in the parade and public meeting of the Tarrytown Blaine and Logan Club this evening.

Coroner Ferdinand Levy wore a look of determination and a blue coat, yesterday, as he prepared to carry out his intention of holding an inquest in the case of Frederick Kopf, who, it has been alleged, was killed by Patrick Judge on an excursion barge, Aug. 31 last.

Lynde Harrison, of New-Haven, is at the Windsor Hotel. Daniel S. Lamont, of Albany, is at the Hoffman House.

Commissioner Thompson addressed to the Mayor yesterday a communication stating that the works for the additional water supply from the Bronx River are so far completed that the city is now receiving about 10,000,000 gallons of water per day from that source.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 19.--At Talladega, Ala., yesterday Leroy Huey and John Davis, both prominent young men in the place, had a quarrel, when Huey drew a large knife and plunged it into the breast of Davis, inflicting fatal wounds. Huey escaped.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19.--The temperance people have been very much agitated here lately. It has not been many months since the authorities broke up the Florence House, New-Haven's all-night resort of fragrant notoriety.

A suit in equity has been begun in the Supreme Court by Levi Parsons against Isidor and Simon Wormser, bankers and brokers. In his complaint he says that for many months prior to Oct. 23, 1883, the defendants, as brokers, carried for him, on margins, $350,000 of Missouri, ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19.--Uncle Horace Barns, the rich old man of West Haven who wandered from his home on Thursday, was found this afternoon on Centre-street, walking aimlessly about. He was sent home. He had eaten nothing during his absence, and it is feared that the result may be fatal.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 19.--F.S. Winkley, an experienced gold prospector from New-Mexico and Idaho, brought to this city today specimens of gold and silver ore taken from gold mines recently discovered in Murray County, Ga., inside of Fort Mountains, about 50 miles from this city.
PRINCETON, Sept. 19.--The students of Princeton College have taken steps toward organizing the campaign club of the college.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19.--Dispatches received from points in Indiana, Michigan, and Ohio indicate that the Western attempt at an earthquake was but a weak imitation of the recent shakeup in the East.

The Right Rev. H.D. Whipple, Bishop of Minnesota, and family; the Rev. J.O. Bevan, Dr. W.H. Heath, the Rev. W.J. Seeber, and Joseph Millbank are among the passengers of the White Star steamship Celtic, which sails for Liverpool to-day.

The offer made by Mr. AUSTIN CORBIN has again directed attention to the mismanagement of the Brooklyn Bridge, and public criticism of that mismanagement seems to have caused Trustee STRANAHAN to make another plaintive appeal in behalf of that poverty-stricken and oppressed corporation, the Union Ferry Company.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 19.--A. special to the American from Denton, Carolina County, Md., says: "Ezekiel Eaton nearly 40 years ago married a wife in the lower part of this county and resided near Smithville, a village not far from the memorable Concord, until about 10 years ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19.--First Lieut. George L. Converse, Third Cavalry, hag been relieved from duty as a member, and First Lieut. James M. Burns, Seventeenth Infantry, as Judge-Advocate of the general court-martial convened at Columbus Barracks, ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19.--An application of the North Church, situated on NewHaven's public Green, to build an extension in the rear of their building for chancel purposes, has been met by strong opposition in the shape of a petition to the Mayor, Aldermen, and City Council, signed by over 500 prominent citizens.
WEST POINT, Ga., Sept. 19.--A romantic marriage occurred this afternoon, when Mr. John M. Harrington and Miss Loula Zachry, of this place, were married two miles from town.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19.--The ironclad monitors Nantucket and Passaic and the torpedo boat Alarm, which arrived at New-London to-day, will remain till Monday or Tuesday and then proceed to New-York.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 19.--Augusta furnishes a new invention in the shape of fireproof cotton bagging, which promises to revolutionize the packing of the Southern staple, the banishment of the old jute bagging, and a reduction of cotton insurance rates from the highest to minimum figures.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 19.--A shrewd attempt to defraud the Government out of $2,000 or $3,000 pension money has been frustrated, and this morning the accused persons were brought before Commissioner Hallett and held in $1,000 bonds each for appearance to-morrow.
A ruffian and drunkard, James Kittle, who is 26 years old, and works now and then, on June 24 was drunk at No. 140 West Nineteenthstreet, where he lived with his mother Teresa, ...

The Amalgamated Stonecutters' and Bricklayers' Unions filled Irving Hall last night. The bricklayers struck for a reduction to nine hours a day. The stonecutters would not cut stone for non-union men to lay, and went out on strike to avoid being locked out.

MONTREAL, Sept. 19.--The gay young Harold De Wolfe, whose escapade in Montreal recently gained for him so much notoriety, has been pronounced insane and a warrant of commitment to the asylum has been obtained. De Wolfe will be consigned to his new quarters at once.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 19.--The chief race of the day at Hampden Park was the threemile open race, which Hendee won in 9:25 3-5, with Brooks and Gaskell as his chief rivals, Sellers refusing to race because he was weakened by the three days' racing.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19.--Not long ago a letter was published in the Cork Examiner, in which E.P. Brooks, of Peoria, Ill., the writer, sought to show that Blaine had befriended Irish suspects, not only in securing their release but in securing them employment and assistance upon their arrival in this country.
NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 19.--Col. S.L. James, lessee of the Louisiana Penitentiary, has failed for a large amount, much to the surprise of the public, who supposed he was working a bonanza.

The Democratic convention for the nomination of a candidate for Congress in the Third New-Jersey District, was to have been held at Elizabeth on Monday next, but as the primaries are to be held to-night and the intervening time is deemed too short, it has been decided to defer the holding of the convention until Wednesday.
Mr. BLAINE has pretty well lost the reputation for audacity with which he went into the campaign. There was not very much of it left before the publication of the last lot of his letters.

A meeting of the Directors of the Academy of Music was held in the offices of the Adams Express Company yesterday afternoon. The proceedings were conducted with great secrecy, but their nature is sufficiently well known to furnish material for a news paragraph.

PARIS, Sept. 19.--The Telegraphe announces that Prime Minister Ferry, in behalf of the French Government, is willing to forego pressing the indemnity claims upon China provided the latter Government shall cede to France for 99 years the port of Ke-Lung, the present treaty port of the island of Formosa.

On a charge of contracting an unlawful marriage with Nathan L. Hawes, knowing him to be a married man, Anne E. Wetmore, who rejoices in several aliases, was on trial yesterday in the Court of General Sessions before Recorder Smyth.
The letters written by BLAINE to WARREN FISHER, Jr., and JOSIAH CALDWELL reveal the real character of the man who wrote them.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19.--The Hillyer Guards, of Hartford, have voted to go to Mobile, Ala., next Spring, where a competition drill between Northern and Southern companies will take place. The Hartford company has a good record, and is working hard to improve by constant drill.
Bright and early yesterday morning a stream of political pilgrims set in toward the Fifth-Avenue Hotel and never stayed its course until it broke upon the Hon. James G. Blaine.

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 19.--A committee of the Erie Republicans met Gen. Logan at Dunkirk this morning, and upon reaching this city at 9 o'clock he was welcomed by the "Plumed Knights" and other Republicans clubs and escorted to the Reed House, where the party breakfasted.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19.--Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bradly, of No. 502 Chapel-street, who were married in September, 1834, celebrated their golden wedding this evening.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19.--The wholesale cloak establishment of Albert Harzfeld Co., No. 240 Monroe-street, was closed by the Sheriff to-day to satisfy a number of confessions of judgment entered against the firm in the Superior Court.

SCRANATON, Penn., Sept. 19.--The contest for the Democratic Congressional nomination of the Eleventh District, which has been waged here with considerable spirit for several days, culminated this afternoon in the choice of the Hon. John B. Storm, of Monroe County, on the one hundred and twenty-third ballot.

HINTON, West Va., Sept. 19.--The village of Leesburg, just across the Virginia line, is greatly excited over the inhuman conduct of a man and wife in abandoning their two-monthold child and leaving it to die of hunger and exposure.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 19.--William McCormick, aged 68, has for a number of years past made his home with the family of John H. Roberts, near Johnsons, Orange County.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19.--Isaac Jacobson, the Finlander, who murdered George Bedell, a north side carpet cleaner, in April last, died on the gallows here at noon to-day.

BOONTON, N.J., Sept. 19.--Mrs. Maria Messer, wife of William W. Messer, who shot her and her daughter a few days ago, died early this morning. The body of Mr. Messer was taken to Woodlawn to-day for interment. Mrs. Messer's will follow. Mary, the daughter, is failing rapidly and can survive but a short time.

After Mrs. Morosini became ill from grief at her daughter's elopement with Ernest Hulskamp, the coachman, a constant watch was kept upon her by her friends and relatives, who feared that, in her anguish, she might do herself harm.

There was a large representation of wing shots on the grounds of the Jersey City Heights Gun Club at Marion, N.J., yesterday, when the three days' tournament of the New-Jersey Sportsman's Association was brought to a close.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19.--The squeeze in September corn which, during the course of two weeks, has caused the chief interest, on 'Change to centre in the corn pit, seems drawing to a close.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19.--The annual meeting of the New-York Synod of the United Presbyterian Church was held to-day in the Fifth United Presbyterian Church, of this city.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19.--The following is a copy of a letter written by the Hon. John M. Gregory, of the Civil Service Commission, on the employment of women in the public service:

The Chinese in New-York held their annual primaries last evening for selecting candidates for local offices. They have a miniature government whose capital is at No. 16 Mottstreet and whose executive is Mr. Ah Chow, magistrate.

The basis on which the three contending factions of the Democratic Party in this city will be represented in the selection and appointment of inspectors of election for the approaching election was determined by the Police Commissioners yesterday.

CAIRO, Sept. 19.--Two more telegrams have been received from Gen. Gordon. He complains of the slowness of the authorities in sending the relief expedition and states that the number of rebels besetting Khartoum is increasing.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 19.--A murder is likely to be the outcome of the mission of the Salvation Army in this city. They have been operating here for about six weeks, and have conducted their work without creating any disorder.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 19.--Rumors that Peters Colt, dealers in dry goods, were in an embarrassed condition have been afloat for some time. Members of the firm met all inquiries with denials of the rumors.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 19.--The systematic manner in which the country is being defrauded out of revenue by the use of false invoices has become so notorious that the Dominion Government are taking active measures to capture the guilty persons.
OSWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 19.--The Republicans of the First Assembly District of Oswego County to-day nominated Henry C. How for Assembly.
Three men entered the saloon of George A. Higgins, at No. 204 Van Dyke-street, Brooklyn, last evening, and were furnished with drinks by John Ferguson, the bartender.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 19.--Senator George H. Pendleton, who has been confined to his home for the past ten days by serious illness, is now recovering. His physicians say that with care he ought to be out within a week.

The case of Assistant State Dairy Commissioner B.F. Van Valkenburgh against Frederick Linsley, a grocer, of No. 520 Grand-street, who is accused of selling oleomargarine for butter, was up on examination at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday.

Six large, noisy apes, genuine lion slayers, brought half the people in Roosevelt-street outdoors in a crowd yesterday. The biggest of them was as tall as a man, and about as ugly as anything on legs could be.

MANCHESTER, Sept. 19.--The Guardian in its commercial article says: "While slightly more active in some directions the tone of the market has not improved. Prices are unchanged. Sales generally have been small."

SYRACUSE, Sept. 19.--Huntinton Beard, grocers, of Fayetteville, have had in their employ for several months a boy named George May, the son of a farm hand living near Manlius Centre, in this county.

A meeting of property owners on Lexington-avenue was held at No. 165 East Seventysecond-street on Thursday evening to take measures to oppose the construction and operation of a railroad on the avenue by the NewYork Cable or other railroad company.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 19.--At a late hour last night, while the miners at Lawrence Merkel's colliery, at Mahoney Plane, were being hoisted out of the slope, a heavy piece of timber fell from the top of the pit, striking the upwardround cage, which contained five or six miners.

A meeting of the Directors of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad was to have been held yesterday, but no quorum attended. The meeting was adjourned until next Tuesday, by which time it is expected some news will have been received from Director Smithers, now in England, regarding the disposition and wishes of the foreign stockholders.

LA CROSSE, Wis., Sept. 19.--The damage to wheat by rust is regarded by wheat men to be very serious, and most stringent orders have been issued to buyers to be especially careful in the examination of all grain offered for sale.

A fire broke out at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning in the rag shop of Antonio Dia, No. 189 South Fifth-avenue, a frame shed occupying the alleyway between two old dilapidated three-story buildings, which are crowded with a miscellaneous colony of Italians, Irish, and negroes.

ALBANY, Sept. 19.--Gov. Cleveland was kept busy at his desk all day, but found time to receive a number of visitors, among them being B.F. Angel, Geneseo; M.F. Stone, of the Chicago News; A.M. Patterson, ex-Assemblyman, ...

ALBANY, Sept. 19.--While John Hunt was engaged in laying a sewer on North Swan-street late this afternoon the embankment caved in, burying him under several feet of dirt.
NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 19.--The Republicans and independents of the Sixth Congressional District have about determined to support the Hon. John Yost, of Pointe Coupee, for Congress, against Judge Irion.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19.--Alva Chase, a well-to-do farmer of East Killingly, was buried to-day with a funeral ceremony wholly free from religious observance. He left a will in which he declared his abhorrence of all parsons, and his heirs were to forfeit the property if his wishes were not carried out.

Dittenhoefer, met last night at No. 385 Bowery and resolved to hold a grand ratification meeting under its own management, at Irving Hall, between Oct. 15 and 25, and announced that at this meeting distinguished German speakers, now engaged at the West, will be present.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 19.--There was quite a stir at the Corn and Flour Exchange to-day over a fight on the floor of the Exchange, in which both combatants were pretty badly used up.

MERIDEN, Conn., Sept. 19.--Three male insane patients escaped from the Middletown Asylum last night. One of them was captured near Durham this morning. No traces of the others have been found.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 19.--A few weeks after the decease of the late Rev. C.T. Brooks, the eminent scholar, poet, and divine of this city, a committee was formed from among his friends to raise a fund and procure a suitable memorial of his literary and ministerial labors.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19.--The Evening News was sold at auction to-day, and was bought for $25,000. The sale included the presses, type, and fixtures of the office. The last issue of the paper under the old management appears to-day.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 19.--The most notable event of the day at the Mystic Park races today was the sudden death of John Shepard's bay stallion Young Rolfe, just as he was completing the first heat in the 2:25 class. Death was caused by a ruptured bloodvessel. The horse was valued at $15,000.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 20.--At 4:30 this morning a collision between a freight and a passenger train, 11 milessouth of Albuquerque, New-Mexico, on the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, resulted in the death of Passenger Engineer W.K. Fisher, Fireman Robert Baxter, and a brakeman. The passengers were thoroughly shaken up, but otherwise escaped uninjured.

Great enthusiasm prevailed.

There is a curious series of trees on the farm of Mrs. P. Mariner, of Penn Yan. The original tree, an elm, was blown down over 80 years ago. The trunk, which remains, is 58 feet long, and from this trunk a row of 26 young trees have sprung, many of which are fully 50 feet high. The young trees seem like branches from the old trunk, but they are well-grown perfect trees.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 19.--The elopement mania appears to have struck Canada in earnest. This time the subjects, who belong to Glencoe, are barely in their teens, their ages ranging from 13 to 16.
The jib and mainsail boats, the Hoodoo, of the Jersey City Yacht Club, and the Daisy, of the Harlem Yacht Club, engaged in a twentymile race on the Sound yesterday for $100 a side.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 21.--There was a brutal attempt at wife murder in this city this morning early, that would have been a success had not the woman's screams summoned aid and resulted in the calling in of the police.
Wild cries and the sound of glass breaking attracted the attention of Policeman Finnegan, who was patrolling his post in Manhattanville at 3 A.M. yesterday.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 21.--The apple crop of 1884 will be the smallest that has been gathered for years. Throughout Western Connecticut orchards that usually yield hundreds of barrels will scarcely produce a bushel, and frequently not a single apple.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21.--On the night of Sept. 17 an extensive robbery was committed at the business house of Julius Zehtner Co., at Madison, Wis., the property stolen consisting of 15 bolts of silk and two bolts of velvet.

Mr. BLAINE has announced that the only issue of this canvass is the maintenance of a high tariff. Did it ever occur to him that protection to American manufactures and American labor could be got better by reducing extravagant duties than by keeping them up? We invite his attention to a brief chapter from the testimony before the Tariff Commission.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 13.--"Nebraska is a safe Republican State, and will give a majority for Blaine and Logan." These are the words of a Democrat, spoken to-day, and in reply to the question whether there is really any possibility that, through the disaffection of the Republicans, especially the Germans, and by a ...

Grace Church was reopened yesterday and the Rev. Dr. Huntington officiated within its walls for the first time as its Rector. A very large congregation greeted him. He officiated at the communion service in the morning and preached in the afternoon. Dr. Huntington was very much pleased with the consgregation. He is greatly improved in health after a Summer vacation.
The Irish-American Blaine and Logan independent movement had a decided boom yesterday afternoon, not less than 30 local statesmen removing their hats when Chairman Rowe called the meeting to order.
CUTHBERT, Ga., Sept. 21.--In Randolph County, Joseph Phelps, while passing the house of Henry Daniel, got into a quarrel and shot Daniel dead. He is now in jail.
All the barkeepers of White Plains were given a holiday yesterday, a thing they have not enjoyed in time immemorial. Not a saloon or other place of business was open, and ...

TROY, Sept. 21.--Congressman Burleigh, of Whitehall, will be renominated by the Republicans in this district, which comprises Rensselaer and Washington Counties, and will be elected without difficulty.

BOSTON, Sept. 21.--The Rev. Dr. Newman Hall, of London, preached at the Mount Vernon Church, on Ashburton-place, this morning to a crowded congregation. He took for his text Romans, viii., 28: "And we know that all ...
The annual fair of the American Institute will be opened at Third-avenue and Sixtythird-street, Wednesday afternoon.

BOSTON, Sept. 21.--A cable message received this noon at Harvard College Observatory from the European Association of Astronomy announces the discovery of a bright comet by Dr. Wolf, of Zurich, on the 7th inst.
--The woodcut illustrations for Lady Brassey's new volume, "In the Trades, the Tropics, and the Roaring Forties," will number about 250.

In accordance with the recent decision of Justice Donohue, of the Supreme Court, the annual meeting of the stockholders of the NewYork Concert Company, for the election of Directors for the ensuing year, will be held in the Casino this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21.--Commissioner of Pensions Dudley was not asked to resign, but that his resignation was received with anything more than polite regrets by the Secretary of the Interior is not believed by those who know something of the recent attitude of the Interior Department toward the Pension Office.

There will be a very few yellow cling peaches and a few Saiways from the Delaware peninsula this week, but scarcely enough to be worth mentioning. There will be a steady supply, however, from New-Jersey for the next two weeks, but the quantity to come from there is small and there will be no more cheap peaches this year.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 21.--A strange fatality seems to overshadow this city, for another great fire broke out this morning in the lumber district, and this evening sees 20 acres burned over and thousands of feet of lumber destroyed.

Officer M. Regan, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, heard a pistol shot and a scuffie at Thirty-first-street and Broadway early yesterday morning, and near "Tommy" Gould's saloon found William A. Roberts, a chorister of the Rice Opera Company, now playing at the Bijou Opera House, clinched with a man who escaped.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 21.--S.H. Byington, editor of the Norwalk Gazette, has recovered the pocketbook and $300 which he lost on a Consolidated Road train Thursday, and which was reported to have been numbered among the spoils of the Blaine party pickpockets.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 21.--During the past few days this city and the surrounding towns have been flooded with counterfeit silver dollars of good execution and deceiving the most wary and experienced.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 21.--Harry Clay, a well-known lawyer and politician, was shot and perhaps fatally wounded here this morning by Andrew Wepler, a Councilman of the Eleventh Ward.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21.--John W. Keely, the inventor of the Keely motor, sat in his dressing gown this evening in the second story of his residence on Oxford-street reading the newspaper accounts of the experiments with his new motor gun on Saturday in the presence of a party of Government officials at Sandy Hook.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 16.--Iowa, "the banner" Republican State, is not on fire yet for James G. Blaine. On the contrary, strange as it may appear, the State which in 1880 gave Garfield a plurality of more than 78,000, and a clear majority of more than 45,000, is in danger of ...

The Rev. Henry J. Vandyke, Jr., Pastor of the Brick Church, in Fifth-avenue, numbered among his hearers yesterday morning the Hon. James G. Blaine, Walker Blaine, William Walter Phelps, and John A. Stewart, who is one of his parishoners.

AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 21.--In the Spring of 1871 there appeared in Johnson County a newcomer named Berry Williams. He was joined soon afterward by his wife and two children, the latter infants. The man seemed to avoid refer-...

From the time that good people got out of church yesterday until long after nightfall the block in Twelfth-street, between Fifth and Sixth-avenues, in which live Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Hulskamp, was crowded with promenaders, ...

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 20.--The situation in Minnesota and Dakota is getting to be decidedly mixed as regards the wheat crop, and both farmers and grain buyers are beginning to have much uneasy curiosity concerning the final outcome.

WHELLING, West Va., Sept. 21.--The extended drought is causing very serious loss to the farmers in this portion of West Virginia and neighboring counties in Pennsylvania and Ohio. With the exception of a few unimportant local showers no rain has fallen for five weeks, and all the small streams have either dried up or been transformed into a succession of stagnant ...

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 21.--New-London has been treated to a circus performance on top of a church spire. J.F. and W.S. Gilbert, two amateur trapezo performers, went through a series of foolhardy antics yesterday, standing on their heads and hanging by their toes from the top of the capstone of the Broadway church.

The young men of Harlem were given some pulpit advice on the exercise and control of will power last night, in the Church of the Holy Trinity, at One Hundred and Twenty-fifthstreet and Fifth-avenue, by the Right Rev. Anthony Wilson Thorold, D.D., Bishop of Rochester, England.
Some time ago we directed attention to the honesty of JOHN QUINCY ADAMS, as shown by a little transaction in bank stock.

An air of expectancy pervaded the interior of the Abyssinian Colored Baptist Church, at No.166 Waverley-place, within which an unusually large congregation had gathered yesterday afternoon. All the seats down stairs were taken, and there were many heads peeping over the gallery rails. The Pastor, the Rev. William Spelman, prayed fervently that the light of reconciliation might shine into the hearts of the congregation. More persons came in during the singing.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 21.--The Pequot House and other Summer hotels on the Sound will formally close their season next Saturday.

The Atlantic is about the best number that has appeared these six months. Articles of really vital human interest are printed, and there are several of them. WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 21.--At Brady's tunnel, 32 miles east of this city, a terrible affray was started last night between the Italians and negroes employed in the work of excavation.
Edwin Booth is at the Albermarle Hotel. Lieut. Frederick Schwatka, United States Army, is at the Sturtevant House.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 21.--The roof of a passenger car of the Derby train which arrives in this city at 8:22 caught fire in Derby, and much excitement was caused among the passengers, but the fire was extinguished by cutting a hole through the roof, and no one suffered except a few women who fainted.

Philip Loewenthal, the detective who has been advertising for the girl who left home one week ago to-day, because she was ashamed to face her parents after failing to pass an examination, was made happy yesterday by the ...

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 21.--Will Skidmore was digging in the former site of a smokehouse in Spencer, Roan County, on Friday, when he struck something hard, and, prosecuting his search further, he unearthed a shoe box containing the skeletons of two children, apparently 5 or 6 years old. They had evidently been buried a great while. Intense excitement was occasioned by the discovery, as about three years ago two children disappeared from the town.
PORTLAND, Oregon, Sept. 21.--G.W. Buchanan, an old pioneer of Washington Territory, living at Chehalis, died yesterday, at the age of 90 years. He came to the Pacific coast over 30 years ago.

Angie Morrison, 40 years old, was taken to the Chambers-Street Hospital yesterday to be treated for narcotic poison. The woman endeavored to destroy herself by taking laudanum at No. 316 Greenwich-street, and it is expected that she will recover.

Among the passengers of the Cunard steamship Servia, which arrived from Liverpool yesterday, were the Rev. Philip Schaff, D.D.; Gen. J.B. Brown, Surgeon J.S. Billings, United States Navy, and Dr. James M. Brown, United States Navy.

The fickle populace who deserted Coney Island yesterday repaired to New-York's central breathing place in thousands. The music in the mall attracted nearly 80,000 people, according to the estimate of the police officers, who ought to know.

There is no doubt that the object of Mr. BLAINE in making a circuit of the Northeastern and Middle States at this time is to awaken interest in his lagging canvass and, if possible, to arouse enthusiasm.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 21.--Great preparations are going forward here for the annual races of the New-Haven Bicycle Club, at Hamilton Park, next Tuesday and Wednesday. Many of the wheelmen have already arrived. The town is full of them.

As the participant in a quarrel cannot look upon it from the attitude of a disinterested observer, the anger of sundry Paris newspapers against American comment upon the war in China need cause no surprise.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Sept. 21.--A letter from Oceana, the county seat of Wyoming County, this State, says the stirring times of the civil war have been recalled there by the finding, in a secluded hollow in the woods about a mile and a quarter from the Court House, of the remains of a complete soldier's outfit.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 14.--Ben Butler did not get a very cordial reception in Nebraska. He came here, perhaps, with the belief that the Anti-Monopolists of the State were his sort of men, principally Greenbackers and Communistic ...

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 20.--The 100hour walk closed at midnight, and was won by O'Leary, who made 380 miles and 1 lap. Miller, of St. Louis, and Waters, of Denver, walking alternately, made 369 miles. O'Leary was matched to walk 400 miles as well as to beat his opponents.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Sept. 21.--The mystery surrounding the strange disappearance of James Wainwright, hunter, guide, and laborer, who was murdered last Monday morning within 300 yards of his little forest home as he was coming to this village to work, seems in a fair way to be solved.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 21.--The Phillips well, in the Butler division of the lower field, still largely controls the oil market, and whenever the drill is set in motion prices decline amid a whirl of excitement.
A novel and interesting bench show will be opened in the Madison-Square Garden Tuesday, Oct. 21, and will be continued until the ensuing Friday.
The Guion steamship Alaska, Capt. Murray, arrived yesterday from Liverpool, after an unusually quick passage. Her corrected time from Queenstown was 6 days 22 hours and 7 minutes.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Sept. 21.--The Democrats in Warren County voted yesterday for their favorites for State Senator, Surrogate, and Sheriff, and the result shows that James E. Moon, of Phillipsburg, is nominated for Senator by a large majority. William M. O'Neill, of Belvidere, is the candidate for Surrogate, and George Van Campon for Sheriff. The contest between O'Neill and G.M. Davis for Surrogate was very close.

The concert given at the Casino last evening, although very numerously attended, was of slight interest in a musical sense. Little fault was to be found with the instrumental selections, although these were by no means novel, but the vocal performances were scarcely entitled to the name.

The Republicans of Ohio ought not to sacrifice their candidates for State offices to be voted for Oct. 14 merely because an unworthy man has been nominated for President, and must be beaten on Nov. 4.

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 21.--Boyd Hannan, a Pocahontas County squatter, went to hunt for his cows, and on the top of Ganly Mountain he encountered a gaunt she bear with two cubs. She attacked him ferociously.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 21.--The race for Congress in this Fourth Georgia District is one of great warmth. The Hon. Henry R. Harris is the regular Democratic nominee, and he is antagonized by ex-Congressman Henry Persons. Many white Democrats support Persons. The character of the campaign may be judged from the fact that last week, while Mr. Harris was visiting Carrollton, he awoke next morning to find his effigy hanging from a telegraph pole.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 21.--Thomas Alexander, 19 years of age, and entitled to $50,000 in cash on his twenty-first birthday, inflicted a mortal wound upon himself last night, all on account of a poor young lady who did not see fit to accept him and his purse.
Philadelphia's tax rate this year is $1.85 on $100. Senator Wade Hampton is to make 18 or 20 speeches in South Carolina during the campaign.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 21.--The Prohibitionists have begun an active canvass in the river and interior counties of this part of the State.

Philip Ferris, who was arrested in the Grand Central Station Friday on the charge of truancy as he was about to take a train for Chicago, was taken before Justice Patterson, in the Jefferson Market Police Court, by Detective Price, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, yesterday.

A crowd gathered on the lower side of Union-square last night to watch a fine-looking, swarthy man, dressed like a prosperous mechanic, who was gazing upward and talking wildly. He was removed to the insane pavilion at Bellevue Hospital.

BOONEVILLE, Ind., Sept. 21.--As John W. Garrison and 12 companions were returning to their homes last night from Tennyson, a quarrel arose, during which three revolvers were discharged and Garrison was instantly killed. The entire party were riding in one wagon, and, it being dark, it is not known who fired the fatal shot. Each one denied having done the shooting.

The Central Council of the United Father Mathew Societies held a meeting yesterday afternoon at Seventh-avenue and Twenty-secondstreet to receive the report of the Committee of Arrangements for celebrating the birthday of the Very Rev. Theobald Mathew, the great apostle of temperance.

In the Summer garden in the rear of Charles Krumm's saloon, No. 167 Chrystie-street, yesterday afternoon there was a sacred" concert, given by three plaster of Paris damsels before a beer-drinking audience of burly Germans.

The distinguished members of the legal profession who daily haunt the Tombs are in a state of great indignation at the conduct of their brethren who guide the course of justice at the Essex Market Police Court.

George Rayles, who lives at Fortiethstreet and Sixth-avenue, is a Greek sailor, with bronzed features and a rolling gait. He has a pretty young wife whom he is compelled to leave at home with his mother six months of the year, while he is off on a voyage.
The date of the coming private Consistory at Rome, for the creation of several Cardinals, is officially announced as fixed for Sept. 29, and the public Consistory for Oct. 2.
A German named Myerberg, who lives on Barren Island, was expecting his wife and six children on the steamship Hammonia, which arrived here last Friday.

BRAINERD, Minn., Sept. 21.--The saw mills here and at other Mississippi points above and below are still running, and do not propose to close until cold weather sets in, and yet the whole season's cut, in the face of the up-hill business done as to sales, will be comparatively small.

The Fall meeting of the American Jockey Club will begin on Saturday next, Sept. 27, and continue on alternate days until Saturday, Oct. 11. This will make seven days' racing, and the programme is much more interesting than any of the previous meetings held at Jerome Park within the last four years. The entries for the stakes are very numerous and will afford excellent sport.
WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 21.--Upon investigation it appears that the Riverton murder, near Winsted, last week, in which young James Ramsbottom was killed by Russell Rose, was provoked.
NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 21.--Among the many visitors who came to New-Haven on Thursday to get a glimpse of Mr. Blaine were some business men and substantial farmers from up Naugatuck way.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 21.--The Record will to-morrow authoritatively deny the report telegraphed all over the country that the coal combination has been reorganized on the percentage basis.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 19.--Connecticut Democrats are not over-confident of their ability to re-elect Gov. Waller. Many things tending to strengthen the Democratic Electoral ticket in this State are by no means to be counted to the advantage of the party in its fight for State officers.
NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 21.--Frank V. Conant, the murderer, will be placed on the stand at New-London to-morrow to testify in his own defense. The trial will probably be concluded the coming week.

There is, if the diagnosis of Dr. Ramon L. Miranda, of No. 54 West Thirty-seventh-street, is correct, another case of yellow fever in this city. The victim is Domingo Morales. He is a laboring man, native of the Canary Islands.
The audience at Koster Bial's last evening was very large and decidedly enthusiastic. As usual on Sundays, considerable changes were made in the programme.

The old buildings on the south side of Bleecker-street, from Broadway to Mercer-street, were recently torn down and a temporary two-story structure was erected, to stand for four years, when the leases of adjoining property will expire. On the southeast...

The race for the championship of the baseball League is drawing to a close, and each day's play brightens the prospects of the Providence club. Unless something unforeseen happens, the pennant emblematic of the championship will flutter to the breeze in Providence next year.

ATCHISON, Kan., Sept. 21.--A serious fight occurred between citizens of Burr Oak, Jewell County, Kan., and showmen belonging to Miles Orton's circus Friday night, in which one man was killed and several were wounded.

LEESPORT, Penn., Sept. 21.--The citizens of this place turned out last night for the twelfth time to serenade John Reeser and Mrs. Emanuel Kershner, who have been living as man and wife for some time.

Funeral services over the body of Jerry McAuley, the river thief, convict, and missionary, who was so well known to the Christian people of this city for the good work of his later years in the Cremorne Mission, were held yesterday afternoon in the Broadway Tabernacle.

The wind blew straight in from the ocean on Coney Island yesterday, The breeze was steady and strong, and was like a draught from the polar seas.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 21.--A determined war has begun here against the gamblers. Several gambling hells are in full blast in the city, and so shameless have their proprietors become that they make no secret of their business. Some time ago a raid was made on these concerns, but they were soon running again.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 21.--A shocking accident occurred at the Market-street crossing of the Pennsylvania Road at 10:20 o'clock to-night. A train for New-York had just passed, when J. McLaughlin, the driver of car No. 9 of the East ...

The steamship Cienfuegos, Capt. Faircloth, of the ward Line, which arrived yesterday from Cienfuegos and St. Jago, brought the survivors of the three-masted schooner John J. Taylor, which was abandoned in a waterlogged and dismasted condition on Sept. 18, in latitude 30 11 and longitude 75 46 .

DUBLIN, Sept. 21.--The National League held a meeting yesterday at Ballinsloe. Joseph M. Kenny, member of the House of Commons for Ennis, declared that Ireland would never be contented until she was free.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 22.--The annual cane rush between the Freshman and Sophomore classes of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute occurred this afternoon. The Freshmen appeared on the ground from their dressing room stripped to the waist, their bodies marked with black crosses on their backs and breasts.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 22.--The Commissioners to appraise lands for a State Park at Niagara Falls, Messrs. Paschal P. Pratt, Luther R. Marsh, and Matthew Hale, to-day made their awards. The land owners asked altogether over $3,000,000. The awards give them an aggregate of $1,433,429.50.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 22.--Caldwell H. Colt, the Hartford millionaire, has purchased uniforms for a naval brigade to parade with the Cleveland and Hendricks battalion of this city, and he has sent a dozen Gatling guns here for the use of the brigade.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22.--Lord Claude Hamilton, his brother, Lord George Hamilton, the Earl of Mount Edgecombe, and the latter's son, the Viscount Vallatort, all of England, arrived at the Grand Pacific Hotel last evening, with Manager W.J. Spicer, of the Chicago and Grand Trunk Railway, and Chief Engineer A. B. Atwater, and Chief Mechanic H. Roberts, ...
DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 17.--While the outlook in Iowa is giving the friends of Cleveland a great deal of satisfaction, it is plain that the hope of carrying it against Blaine will not ...
BUFFALO, Sept. 22.--What was termed an independent Republican meeting, to ratify the nominations of Blaine and Logan, was held in this city this evening.

ALBANY, Sept. 22.--It is reported that Mr. George O. Jones resigned from the Chairmanship of the State Committee of the Greenback-Labor Party at its meeting held in this city last Saturday because he is convinced that the pretense to build up a permanent "People's ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22.--Lieut.-Commander Hitchcock, commanding the Nina. reports that the sixth chain has been placed under the Tallapoosa. The work of raising the wreck will soon be begun, the pontons having arrived to-day.
Mr. Isidor Cohnfeld, the owner of Maxey Cobb, has made public the following card, in answer to the challenge published yesterday from Mr. Case:
There was serious trouble last night at the "hole in the wall," as an aperture between Mundorff Moench's beer garden, in Broadway, and the Theatre Comique is called.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 22.--NewHaven's military young men at agitated. Several small, though important, items were overlooked in the plans of the Commissioners who superintended the building of the new Union Armory.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 22.--Harry Clay, the brilliant young lawyer, grandson of the great commoner and the last of his distinguished line, who was shot in a saloon by Councilman Andrew Wepler at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning, died at 7 o'clock this morning from the effects of his wound, and an entire city is in mourning.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Sept. 22.--For several months past the State Board of Health has been urging Supervisors and Justices of the Peace in townships in the Hudson River and inland counties to organize Town Boards of Health where none already exist.

Those persons who visited the United States Circuit Court room yesterday expecting to see a mild form of legal circus, with a side show thrown in by way of variety, went away again very much out of countenance when they found that all that could be heard was the history of the telephone in a never-ending series of explanations, and that all they could possibly ...

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 22.--Latest information from certain districts in Sullivan County state that the prevalence pf dysentery is more alarming. The number of cases is multiplying instead of decreasing. In one neighborhood alone there are 17 cases.

About 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the house at Temple and High streets, Paterson, owned by Mrs. George Van Riper and occupied by Josiah Dobbs and family. Mr. Dobbs was alone in the house at the time, and was barely able to escape with his clothing in his hands, so rapidly did the flames spread.

The Grand Opera House, which in many respects is the most comfortable playhouse in this town, as well as the most spacious, with one exception, has of late years occupied a position distinctly its own.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 22.--Democrats are working hard to carry this (Allegheny) county for Cleveland, and they process to believe they can do so. They base their hopes upon fusion with the Greenbackers and the apathy of stalwart leaders.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22.--A long list of confessions of judgment, all against S. Friedman Co., wholesale jewelers, at No. 182 Madisonstreet, were filed in the Superior Court to-day.

Mrs. Thomas J. Loughlin, who was mangled in the collision between an East Newark horse car and a Pennsylvania, Railroad train at the Market-street station in Newark Sunday night, died of her injuries yesterday morning.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 22.--E.K. Richmond, the carriage manufacturer, who was thrown from his carriage on Saturday, died this morning from the effects of his injuries.

The formation of Cleveland clubs in the down-town business Exchanges is being bushed industriously. The New-York Produce and Maritime Exchange Cleveland and Hendricks Club now numbers more than 700 persons, of whom about 40 per cent. are said to be Republicans.

Samuel Jones, an ex-Deputy Sheriff of Queens County, recently accused Rowland Seaman, a wealthy builder and prominent politician of Queens County, of holding improper relations with his wife. Mr. Seaman denied the charge and denounced Jones as a loafer. Seaman being the bigger man.

James McGrath is known in the Fourth Ward as " Brute" McGrath on account of his cruelty to his mother. He was a prisoner in the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning for cutting her with a table knife. He has been arrested for assaulting her at least a dozen times. She is feeble, 60 years of age, and earns a living by cleaning offices.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 22.--James Gordon Bennett, accompanied by Charles Nordhoff, arrived here this afternoon. He was met by John W. Mackay, who later in the day pointed out to him prominent features of the city. The train on which Mr. Bennett arrived narrowly escaped a serious disaster. As it pulled out of the Port Costa station it ran into a train of wheat cars.
LONDON, Sept. 22.--Robert Towle, proprietor of a lace factory at Nottingham, has failed. His liabilities are heavy.

A cloudy day, with a brisk wind, made the annual Fall regatta of the Harlem Yacht Club a complete success yesterday. A goodly number of guests, among whom were many ladies in bright costumes, enjoyed themselves on ...

When the doors of the Court of Sessions, in Yonkers, were thrown open yesterday morning the throng of people who had been slowly gathering outside for a half hour before that pressed tumultously into the room.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ga., Sept. 22.--Robert D. Allen for a year or so paid attentions to a Mrs. Freeman, a young widow, of this county, who seemed to smile with favor upon his suit. Last Fall Allen went on a visit to Alabama, and when he returned the air was thick with rumors to the effect that Mrs. Freeman had given her heart to Andrew Lively, and would soon plight her hand in marriage to him.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 22.--The GreenbackLabor and Anti-Monopoly Party have completed their Congressional ticket as follows: First District--Henry Weber; Second District-- Dr. W.H. Hire: Third District--A.E. Osborn; Fourth District--R.P. Webb: Fifth District-- George L. Walton; also, for Presidential Electors--A.B. Booth, E.R. Blake, George S. Wells, ...

Two brokers while at lunch at Delmonico's Broad-street restaurant, yesterday, started a discussion regarding the merits of Presidential candidates. The men have for some time been good friends. One is a member of the Mining Stock and National Petroleum Exchange and the other is a well-known privilege broker.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 22.--The delegates to the Republican State Convention, which convenes in the State House at 12 M. to-morrow, have been arriving in the city to-day on each train.

The action of the Executive and Advisory Committees of the Brooklyn Young Republican Club to-night, whatever it may be, can do Mr. BLAINE no good, and if the decision is favorable to an active participation in the national canvass it will inevitably do the club much harm in that municipal field in which it has hitherto labored with such profit to the city and credit to itself.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 17.--Boastful predictions in Iowa are usually made by people who have no time or inclination to look at the record of past elections in the State. It was amazing to hear a prominent gentleman connected ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 22.--Proposals for five jobs of Government river and harbor work were opened in United States Engineer McFarland's office to-day, and awarded as follows: Dredging the mouth of the Connecticut River, 40,000 cubic yards, A.J. Beardsley, Bridgeport, 15 cents per yard.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22.--William Beach Hazelton, a well-known journalist of this city, formerly of Baltimore, was taken to the station house early yesterday morning by a hack driver and locked up on the charge of refusing to pay his hack fare. At the instance of his wife and some friends he was visited to-day by Drs. Hamilton and Kleinschmidt, who, after an examination, declared him insane, ...

A shot was heard yesterday afternoon on the fourth floor of No. 10 Reade-street, where Louis Heikump and his son, George L., book and paper edge gilders, of No. 255 Clermont-avenue, Brooklyn, have an office. The son was found at his desk with a small pistol in his hand, and he was slightly wounded in the right temple.
Mr. Edwin Booth will begin an engagement at the Boston Museum Nov. 17.

OLEAN, N.Y., Sept. 22.--The large Newfoundland dog Heck, belonging to the St. Elmo Hotel, in the neighboring oil town of Eldred, Penn., was known throughout the northern oil field for its great strength and almost human intelligence. The porter of the hotel, a kindhearted but intemperate person, was an especial favorite with the dog.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22.--The term of Mr. C. E. Coon as acting Secretary of the Treasury, under special delegation of the President, will expire on Wednesday. No warrants for the payment of money from the Treasury can be issued after that day unless the existing vacancy in the office of Secretary shall have been filled before that date. It is expected, however, that an ap-...

The stockholders of the Casino held their annual meeting yesterday afternoon. When Mr. Aronson, as President of the company, called the meeting to order, at 1:30 P.M., there were about 30 stockholders distributed among ...
The failure of one of the clerks of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company to report for duty yesterday gave rise to widely circulated rumors that some irregularities had been disclosed in that office.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 22.--Two children of Patrick Chambers--a boy and a girl --residing at Pleasant Valley, were viewing a picnic train going down the Lehigh Valley Road this morning from the Pennsylvania Railroad bridge, which passes over the Lehigh Valley Road, when they were struck by a Pennsylvania train which they did not see coming. The boy was instantly killed and the girl fatally injured.

John D. Franks, of West Point, Miss.; L.L. Jackson, of Baltimore; C.E. Bennett, of Detroit, and J.D. Rickey, of Fulton, were among the visitors at the headquarters of the Democratic National Committee yesterday. In a letter to the committee from a prominent citizen ...

CAIRO, Sept. 22.--A dispatch from the French Consul at Khartoum has been received confirming the previous reports that the siege of that city had been raised. The dispatch further states that the country in the neighborhood of Khartoum is freed from rebels, and that the obtaining of food supplies is comparatively easy. The French Consul was on the point of starting for Dongola with Cols. Stewart and Power.

The Swedish Blaine and Logan Club, No. 192 Third-avenue, numbers nearly 400 members. Last evening was set apart for a banner raising, and at 8 o'clock the club assembled in Twentysecond-street, near Third-avenue, and, after music by a band, the banner inscribed with the names of Blaine and Logan was stretched across the street.

Postmaster Manley, of Augusta, sat writing in Mr. Blaine's reception room about 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when the card of the Rev. Dr. James King was brought to him. Dr. King followed the card and told Mr. Manley that a delegation of Methodist ministers representing the New-York East, the New-York, Newark, New-Jersey, and East German Conferences was waiting to see Mr. Blaine.

"Mme. I'Archidue" is an opera bouffe that has scarcely enjoyed the popularity of Offenbach's earliest works, although it bas been sung many hundred times in France and many dozen times in the United States.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 22.--Assignments were placed on record this morning from the great whisky corporation of the Newcomb-Buchanan Company, the largest concern of the kind in the South, and one of the largest in the Union. At the same time other assignments, also for the benefit of creditors, were filed by George C. Buchanan and Andrew Buchanan, the members of the firm.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 22.--A disastrous fire occurred in the Grand Trunk Railway car shops at London East yesterday. The fire broke out in a box car which was standing in the repair shop. No fire had been used near the car, and the origin of the conflagration is a mystery.

The oil market was unsettled yesterday, and the weakness in the price made trouble for some of the operators on the "bull" side. There was a decline in the forenoon from 74 to 70 5/8, and several lots of certificates were closed out under the rule in the Mining Stock and National Petroleum Exchange for the account of embarrassed speculators.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 22.--Prof. J. H. Niemeyer, of the Yale Art School and teacher of drawing and painting, has been engaged to reorganize the art departmeut of Smith College, Northampton, Mass., which will be put in the line of accomplishing more and effectual work in the immediate future.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 22.--The number of visitors at the Executive Chamber averages about 300 a day. Some doubtless come to examine the artistic beauty of the rooms, but nearly all are moved by a desire to see the Democratic candidate for President. When Gov. Cleveland is at leisure he cordially receives any one who may desire to speak with him.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 22.--It is stated that the losses of the National Bank of New-Jersey will amount to about $250,000. Cashier Hill's defalcation will probably reach $200,000, while the balance represents the overdraft of the President. Controller Cannon has authorized the reopening of the bank, which event will occur on Wednesday or Thursday next. Lewis T. Howell has been elected President and E.S. Campbell Cashier.
The English press is somewhat perturbed over intimations that at the coming Autumn session of Parliament the Parnellites will join the Tories in opposition to the Franchise bill.

The steps of the clubhouse on the grounds of the Gentlemen's Driving Club were thronged yesterday with well-known local horsemen to witness two races. Dr. Ward's b.g. Ripton and Nathan Straus's b.g. Joe Ripley trotted to wagon for $250 a side. The race was best two out of three heats, the owners driving the horses.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 22.--The Rev. Thomas R. Bacon, of Dwight-Place Congregational Church, one of the Bacon sons, and who presided over the richest church in the city, said to-day with reference to the report that his church was being disrupted by his denunciation of Blaine and his outspoken support of Cleveland that, although one or two families were not ...

Thomas McGuire, a lame man, of No. 26 Oak-street, went out on Sunday night to look for his dissipated wife, who had left home. He found her in a dive at No. 35 Mulberry-street, in company with a woman called Mary Kelly. He tried to persuade her to come home with him, and failing he laid his hand on her shoulder as if to take her by force.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22.--Mr. Blaine and party arrived at the Broad-street station at 11:50 to-night, where a great crowd had assembled. Mr. Blaine was met by George H. Boker, President of the Union League; Mayor Smith, and other prominent citizens, and after cordially greeting them, was hurried to a private carriage amid the booming of cannon and the hurrahs of the multitude. He was driven to the Continental Hotel and went ...

PORTLAND, Oregon, Sept. 22.--A fire here last night destroyed a whole block, including the Esmond House, the leading hotel of the city. The conflagration started in a hay yard and spread with such rapidity that all efforts to save the hotel were unavailing.

LAFAYETTE, Ga., Sept. 22.--A tragedy with all dime novel attachments has just culminated here. One of the most attractive young ladies of this county had among her admirers Mr. Edward Stoner. He paid assiduous court to her, but the advent of a rival blasted all his hopes.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 22.--Judge Given to-day affirmed the constitutionality of that feature of the new liquor law which allows a saloon to be closed by injunction after its proprietor has been convicted of illegal sales. The defense had demurred that the injunction superadded an excessive penalty and also came between the defendant and his right to a jury trial, but these points, the Judge holds, are not, well taken.

John Nile, of No. 385 Water-street, and James Mitchell, of No. 230 West Houston-street, two blacksmiths, went into Alloys Dinkelman's restaurant, at No. 221 Bowery, yesterday afternoon, to get something to eat. They objected to the texture of the beefsteak, one playfully designating it as cowskin. The waiter insisted that it was tenderloin, fresh from the rump.

Those plausible and well-dressed gentlemen who hire halls or theatres and invite people to see them perform acts of a character generally considered impossible of achievement, except to the evil one himself, are invariably well received in this wicked and frivolous city.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Sept. 22.--W.J. Purdy, of Williamsport, Penn., who has been freight agent of the New-York Central Railroad Company at Batavia since January, 1883, was removed on Saturday by order of President Rutter. The reason given for his removal is that he neglected his duties and treated patrons of the road unfairly.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 22.--The three Italians arrested for passing counterfeit money were taken in charge this afternoon by Agent A.L. Drummond, chief detective of the united States Secret Service. The first act of the detective was to take the prisoners to a photograph gallery, where each wars compelled to sit for his picture. They bore the ordeal quietly.

The Young Men's Republican Club of Kings County met last evening at Music Hall, Henry W. Knight in the chair, and transacted some routine business. Mr. Knight said that Mr. Blaine would come to Brooklyn to address a meeting to be held under the auspices of the club at a date to be fixed at an early day. The Chairman also announced that the club had 1,400 names on its roll of membership.

LONDON, Ontario, Sept. 22.--Thomas Fawcett, a banker of this city, who is also at the head of several agencies in Western Ontario, is in difficulties. It is known that his checks were refused by the Bank of Montreal. His liabilities are estimated at $800,000 to $1,000,000. It is stated that his several agencies carried discounts representing about $60,000 each.
Who will be the Republican Party's candidate for President four years from now? It is hardly time to think seriously about that yet, but it is a matter to be determined this Fall.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 22.--The weather was fair to-day, but rain last night rendered the track stiff. The attendance was fair.

BOSTON, Sept. 22.--Inspectors who were detailed a few days ago to hunt for a thief who had stolen a valise stuffed with bank notes, bonds, and diamonds, had a surprising story to tell today of the result of their efforts. On Friday last a messenger from the town of South Framingham, on the Boston and Albany Road, hurried into the Police Headquarters here ...

TALLADEGA, Ala., Sept. 22.--Last night at 11 o'clock Abe and Chalmer Boswell escorted home a young woman whom they had accompanied to church. A dispute arose as to which she favored, when Abe Boswell drew his revolver and shot Chalmer Boswell dead. The murderer escaped.

SCHENECTADY, Sept. 22.--Edwin S. Hopkins and his wife and two other members of the King Hopkins company of Bohemian Glass Blowers went out on the Mohawk River in a light Adirondack boat yesterday afternoon.

THE TIMES seems to be the booming paper just now, and, notwithstanding the Tribune's statements to the contrary, its circulation is more than double what it was before, and a great deal more than double that of the Tribune.

When Carleton H. Betts, a young sporting man, living at No.132 East Fify-seventhstreet, called at the general Post Office for his letters yesterday afternoon he was met by Detective George W. Blank, who arrested him on a warrant issued by Police Justice Calkins, of Coxsackie, Greene County, N.Y., in which Betts is charged with grand larceny.

After three hours' parliamentary pettifogging and scattering oratorical warfare the temporarily ruffled members of the Abyssinian Colored Baptist Church clasped hands over a breach-healing resolution last night and went home overflowing with good will and choral praises to God.

The New-York City Mission and Tract Society, of No. 50 Bible House, reminds its friends of the approaching close of the fiftyeighth year of its beneficent operations. The Executive Committee, headed by the Rev. Dr. John Hall and composed of ministers and laymen of the several religious denominations, is quietly yet vigorously pushing forward the work of city evangelization.
LONDON, Sept. 22.--A dispatch to the Times from Foo-Choo says that the cholera has decimated a village near that city.

Nathan L. Hawes listened coolly to the reading of his ardent love letters to Mrs. Annie E. Wetmore, yesterday, in the Court of General Sessions, before Recorder Smyth. UTICA, Sept. 22.--The Republicans of the Second District have nominated George P. Nock, of Rome, for Assembly. He is a lawyer and is the son of Thomas G. Nock, President of the New-York Locomotive Works. He is young and popular, and there is fair prospect of his election.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22.--Having had his resignation accepted, to take effect on Nov. 10. Commissioner of Pensions Dudley has already started on his journey to the West, to do what he can for the success of the man who failed to vote on the Prohibition question in Maine. Col. Dudley will devote his attention to the State of Ohio until Oct. 14.

The funeral services of the dead millionaire, Seabury Brewster, were held yesterday morning in one of the parlors of the New-York Hotel. The body lay in a cloth-draped coffin in the adjoining room, the lid entirely covered with a cross of Japanese lilies and a sheaf of ripened wheat.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 22.--Saturday afternoon Librarian Hoadly, at the Capitol, after he had shown some visitors the original grant of 500 to Gov. Winthrop when he went to England to obtain our charter, noticed that a collection of coins that had hung just above it was gone.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 22.--The terms of imprisonment of Edward Noble and Albert Prince, the youthful sheep stealers of Ulster and Dutchess Counties, expired to-day. They were rearrested on the charges of burglary at Ulster Park, and they were held to await the action of the Grand Jury.

LONDON, Sept. 22.--A dispatch from Shanghai to the Times says: "A new complication has arisen in the Franco-Chinese difficulty. The blocking of the bar at the mouth of the Woosung River has been ordered by the Chinese authorities, although a passage for the ships of neutrals is to be left.

Application was made to Judge Cullen, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, for an order permitting the service by publication of the summons in a suit brought by Mrs. Ione Dobson against Mrs. Cornelia V. Hogan to recover $50,000 damages.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 22.--Commodore Luce, it is understood, will proceed to Washington in a few days to consult with the authorities there in regard to the War College established here as well as to dispose of the report of the Coal Board, of which he is President.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 22.--There is every reason for saying that Phillips's well in Butler Field attained its highest production today, and henceforth the question with the oil trade will be its decline. The owner of the well telegraphed this afternoon that its production will never again be increased by drilling. The well has done its best, and stands without any doubt the largest well ever opened.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 22.--A farmer named Foreman admitted to-day before Judge Given, in divorce proceedings, that he had set up spurious allegations in order that his wife could secure a bill on cross-plea. Mrs. Foreman was then examined, and the perjury was made so glaring by her admission that the Judge ordered Foreman arrested on the spot and directed an attorney to file an information against him forthwith.
LONDON, Sept. 22.--The announcement of the sailing of Mme. Nilsson for New-York is incorrect. Before her departure for America she will sing in Albert Hall on the 8th of October.
LANCASTER, Penn., Sept. 22.--The Prohibitionists of the Ninth District to-day nominated Barr Spangler for Congress.

The Republican State Committee has completed a schedule for Mr. Blaine's trip through this State on his way to Ohio. A special train, consisting of a locomotive and two parlor cars, has been assigned to Mr. Blaine's party.

OTTOWA, Ontario, Sept. 22.--The hostility shown by Indians in Montana toward Canadian ranchmen in extorting money from them is likely to be the subject of correspondence between the United States and the Canadian Government.
GLOVERVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 22.--D.C. Farthing, a glove manufacturer, has made an assignment to J.O. Parsons. Liabilities, $10,000. The creditors expect to get only 5 per cent. of what is due them.

When Victoria Morosini eloped with her father's coachman Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ramsgate, who were stopping at the Clarendon Hotel, were very indignant at being mistaken by a detective for the missing lovers.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 22.--A special train bearing Gen. Logan, C.H. Andrews, William D. Kelley, Gen. Noyes, Major McKinley, and the escort committee left Youngstown for Alliance at 9 o'clock this morning.

Charles Herrman, a young man of 27 years, ran up to the top floor of a tenement block in Liberty-street, about 8 o'clock yesterday morning, and found the women of the house at the washtub in the kitchen.

The elaborate gold cup, won by James R. Keene's horse Foxhall at the Ascot races in England, in 1882, has been in the hands of United States customs officers for about 18 months. The Collector at this port held that the cup was dutiable, but Mr. Keene refused to pay duty upon it on the ground that it was a trophy and a work of art and ought to be admitted free.

The residents of Tenafly, N.J., were startled by an explosion at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, and in an instant the rubber factory of the Pond Manufacturing Company was wrapped in flames. The explosion originated with the bursting of a naphtha tank, large quantities of that fluid being used in the business of the company.

LONDON, Sept. 22.--The Duke of Cambridge, Commander-in-Chief of the British Army, will pay a visit to Ireland, leaving here Oct. 1. While in Ireland the Duke will inspect the troops at Kurragh, Cork, and Belfast. Unusual precautions are to be taken to protect Earl Spencer, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland.

The New-York Cab Association, having adopted the cheap rates of fare, has added 25 new cabs to its stock and is prepared to offer the public quick and comfortable transit and guarantee it against extortion.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23.--A special meeting of the Republican State Committee was held to-day at the headquarters, for the purpose of filling the vacancy on the Republican Electoral ticket caused by the death of Judge John Leisenring.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23.--Lieut. G.B. Harber has been ordered to ordnance duty on Oct. 1 at the Washington Navy Yard. The orders of Lieut. F.E. Beatty to the Ranger have been revoked, and he has been ordered to remain on the Nina. Capt. Bancroft Gherardi has been appointed a member of the Naval Examining Board.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 23.--The score or more Canningham families in this city are excited over a rumor to the effect that $500,000 awaits the nearest of kin to a certain Kate Cunningham who recently died in Australia.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23.--At a meeting of the Illinois Methodist Conference at Carlinville, yesterday, a resolution was presented to the effect that the body give its support to ex-Gov. St. John in the coming Presidential election. A motion was made to table the resolution, but it was lost, and the resolution was adopted with but few dissenting votes.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 23.--A Mohawk Indian named Alexander Brant, aged 16, has been convicted at Belleville for attempting to wreck the Grand Trunk Railway fast express between Montreal and Toronto. He pleaded guilty, but urged in extenuation that he placed the obstacles--two ties and a boulder weighing about 150 pounds--upon the track because he wanted to see how they would fly when the express came along.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 23.--The present Grand Jury of this county convened yesterday. It is said that several bigamy cases are under investigation, and quite a number of clergymen of this city and adjacent towns are summoned to appear as witnesses. Some of these ministers were examined to-day, and more are subpoenaed to give testimony to-morrow. The report created considerable excitement here, as many of the parties directly interested occupy high social positions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23.--John W. Harbourne, of the firm of Billings, Harbourne Co., stationers, of this city, has disappeared. The Anglo-California Bank has levied an attachment of $6,000 on the firm's establishment. All the creditors of the firm are in the East.

TOWANDA, Penn., Sept. 24.--Bartholomew Lane and E. Decker, partners in the livery business here, had an altercation yesterday. Decker knocked Lane down. This contraction of circulation is regarded with much interest in Wall-street.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 24.--The State Exposition opens in this city on the first day of October. The main building contains 125,000 feet of space. Sixty counties have appropriated from $500 to $2,000 each to display their exhibits.

WALLINGFORD. Conn., Sept. 24.--The Rev. H.M. Tenney, of the Wallingford Congregational Church, shot William McGarry, a builder, in the arm with a rifle this afternoon while he was firing at a mark. McGarry will recover unless blood poisoning sets in.

QUEENSTOWN, Sept. 24.--The Cunard Line steamship Aurania, Capt. Hains, from New-York Sept.17, arr. here at 2:30 A.M. to-day on her way to Liverpool.

PEEKSKILL, Sept. 24.--The Workingmen's Cleveland and HendricKs Club, of Peekskill, flung a fine banner to the breeze this evening and had a Housing out-door meeting.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 24.--A mysterious murder came to light at London to-day. At an early hour this morning a youth named James Currell, aged 16, employed as a bellboy at the Grigg House, was found dead in his bed.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24.--The special train bearing the tattooed candidate for President arrived very nearly on time in Syracuse, but there was a good deal of delay in putting him on exhibition, which was exceedingly vexatious to the men, women, and children who had assembled to see the show.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 24.--The State Convention of the new Butler party met in the Skating Rink to-day. There were nearly 1,500 delegates present, mostly young Irishmen, and there was enthusiasm enough to run a national convention. Gen. Butler, accompanied by ...

NEWARK, Sept. 24.--The Grand Opera House was packed to-night on the occasion of a Cleveland and Hendricks mass meeting, under the auspices of the Jefferson Club. Senator John A. McPherson presided, and addresses were made by Congressman Perry Belmout, of NewYork, and A.S. Sullivan and ex-Senator Eaton, of Connecticut. The large audience was very enthusiastic and listened with the closest attention to the remarks of the speakers.

CHATTANOOGA, Sept. 24.--A special from Lincoln, Ala., says that the boiler of a steam saw mill owned by Willis Hall, near Lincoln, exploded to-day, killing Mr .Hall and fatally injuring a young man named John Crump. Loss to mill by explosion about $1,000.

ROME, Sept. 24.--The reports from different parts of Italy for the past 24 hours give a total of 441 fresh cases of cholera and 203 deaths. Of these 264 cases and 75 deaths occurred in the city of Naples. This shows a slight increase in...
The attendance was large at the Brighton Beach races yesterday and the track was in good condition.
"Gov. Cleveland," remarks the Kansas City (Mo.) Times, "will not come West. The West will go to Cleveland."

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 24.--Sealed proposals were opened at the general offices of the Milwaukee, Lake Shore and Western Railway Company, in this city, this afternoon, for the construction of the company's ore docks at Ashland.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 25.--Yale's athletic team loses a strong man in Walter C. Camp, who for the past five years has been the moving spirit at Yale in these matters.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 25.--Special dispatches were received on 'Change and by the afternoon papers here to-day stating that Alexander Mitchell, President of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul, had tendered his resignation, and that Frank Bond, of the Reading Road, has been decided upon as his successor.
