WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 25.--R.C. James, a miner, got into a dispute with a traveling umbrella mender at the General Grant Hotel at Alden this afternoon. He procured an old army musket standing in the corner of the barroom and dealt the umbrella man a fatal blow on the head. James resides at Alden, and a warrant has been issued for his arrest. Both men were intoxicated at the time.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 25.--A special dispatch from Brookhaven, Miss., says that on last Saturday night a mob of 40 men visited the Franklin County Jail, overpowered the jailer, and took out four negro prisoners and lynched them to trees in the Court House yard.

A procession of Italians, the women in gay costumes and most of the men dressed like laborers, trooped across City Hall Park yesterday afternoon and entered the hall by the rear door. BALTIMORE, Sept. 25.--John W. Garrett, President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, is slowly passing away. Dispatches from Deer Park at midnight state that he will hardly live through the night. Those present at his bedside are his children, Many Garrett, Robert Garrett, T. Harrison Garrett, and Lizzie Garrett.

So many bald-headed men nightly populate the orchestra chairs at Niblo's Garden to observe the evolutions of the ballet in the "Seven Ravens" that that portion of the audience, viewed from above, resembles a section of a cobble-stone pavement. But the spectators are not all bald-headed, and among the illustrious exceptions is Commissioner of Charities and Correction Hess.

For twenty-two days past Mary Collins, aged 40 years, of No. 57 Summit-street, Brooklyn, has been suffering from smallpox. The house in which she lived is a big tenement and has 40 other occupants, 12 of whom are children attending the public schools.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 25.--The game today was a walkover for the New-Yorks. Serad showed the need of more practice than he has been allowed to have, and was given most wretched support, the fielding of the Bisons being, if possible, more miserable than that of the New-Yorks on Tuesday.

The Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen heard arguments yesterday in favor of and against the proposition to build a street railroad through Thirty-fourth-street from the East River to Tenth-avenue and thence to the Forty-second-Street Ferry.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 25.--Elbridge T. Gerry's steam yacht Electra arrived here from New-York last night and went to Bristol this morning to take a steam launch just completed for her by Mr. Herreshoff. She will go to Gardiner's Bay, fishing, the first favorable opportunity.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 25.--Prof. Lewis R. Packard, Professor of Greek at Yale, arrived in this city this afternoon on a special car from Nashau, N.H., where he had been for the benefit of his health. He was taken to his home on Church-street on a stretcher in the police ambulance, under the care of Dr. Chapman. Prof. Packard has been a confirmed invalid since his last visit to Greece, were he overworked himself in making investigations.

An action was recently begun in the Supreme Court by Louis H. Meyer, as Trustee, against the Mexican National Construction Company and 101 other defendants, these defendants including many of the well-known brokers and bankers of the city who, in June, 1883, subscribed to a loan of $2,000,000 to the company, which is building the Mexican National Railway.

Fire was discovered at 11 o'clock last night in the lumber yard in the rear of Decker's piano works, No. 321 West Twenty-fourth-street. It was caused by the explosion of a bottle of phosphorus, which had been thrown over the fence. The police think that some one had intended to set the place on fire.

PLYMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 25.--The feature of the third day of the Grafton County Fair was the presence of Gen. Butler. He was accompanied by the Hon. Moody Merrill, of Boston, a large stockholder in the association, who, in the absence of the President, introduced the distinguished guest to the large gathering.

Six houses have been entered by burglars in Yonkers this week. J.C. Campbell, of No. 200 Washington-avenue, reported at the Police Headquarters yesterday morning that his house had been entered during the preceding night.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 25.--A dispatch received this morning says Mr. Blaine will visit Indianapolis on Thursday, Oct. 2, coming from Cincinnati. Messrs. Butler and St. John have already arranged to come here that day, and will speak at night from the same platform.

LONDON, Sept. 25.--Lord Salisbury has written an exhaustive article in the National Review, in which he undertakes to prove that the Conservatives in reality desire the franchise to be coupled with redistribution. This, he says, will give the Conservatives more seats than they now hold. The article is exciting much attention.
Secretary Whipple, of the Massacusetts Republican State Committee, estimates Blaine's probable majority in that State at 40,000 votes.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 25.--There is little doubt that most of the important railroad work in Minnesota to-day is tending toward Winnipeg and covering territory that has hitherto fed the Manitoba Line.

Commissioner of Pensions Dudley left his office early in August to put his shoulder to the lagging Blaine wheel. Ex-Sheriff Thomas Desmond, of San Francisco, a stout, squarely-built man, has been staying at Sweeny's Hotel during a visit to NewYork. Early yesterday morning he had an opportunity of putting his muscle to good use.

COLUMBUS, Sept. 25.--The long expected celebration of the Cleveland and Hendricks clubs of this State came off in this city to-day and tonight. Columbus is fairly ablaze with enthusiasm, and the most lavish display of fireworks lends a brilliant hue to the whole demonstration.

A little boy and girl, aged 10 and 6 respectively, were guests at the Gault House Sunday night. They were alone and had come from Fort Collins, Colorado, their destination being Delta, Keokuk Country.

Richard Oliver, who has been a member of the Executive Committee of the Brooklyn Young Republican Club since the club was organized, takes exceptions to the statements made by W.H. Knight concerning the meeting of the club on Tuesday evening. Mr. Knight says that there were 1,500 members present at the meeting, and of that number not more than 100 were opposed to the indorsement of Mr. Blaine.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 25.--Ten years ago a white man named Osborne was riding by the house of Mr. Compton, a farmer in Oconee County, when the dog in the yard barked at him. He drew his pistol and fired at the dog, but the ball struck Mrs. Compton, killing her instantly.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 25.--A stiff breeze added zest to-day to the Fall regatta of the New-Haven Yacht Club. The first gun, at 11:45 o'clock, started off classes G,F, and E, comprising the cat-rigged and small boats of the fleet--the Alice, owned by E.W. Smith; Gracie, ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 25.--The conference of delegates from Psalm-singing churches, called for the purpose of consulting with reference to closer union, and to devise means whereby the custom of Psalm singing in churches may be preserved, met here this morning.

John Scholl, a homeless German, 30 years of age, was arrested yesterday morning by an officer of the Seventeenth Precinct, who found him parading through Third-avenue half naked and followed by a crowd.

ARGUSVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 25.--Charlie Vanderveer is a long, lank, country lad residing here. He is termed a genius, and for many years he has worked upon a balloon. At last it is finished, 23 feet in diameter and 35 feet in height. It is regarded as an extraordinary piece of work for a country boy. Flaming bills cover the fences and dead walls in this section, announcing an assension of the home-made balloon on Oct.8.

LONDON, Sept. 25.--The Times's special from Shanghai says the German Government has instructed its Consuls and naval commanders to maintain an independent attitude toward the Franco-Chinese difficulties. It is feared, however, that complications may arise which may prevent German neutrality.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25.--"The sudden marriage of Henry Friedman to Miss Sarah Scheiier coming so soon after the Morosini elopement has led the newspapers to treat the affair in a way that places my friend in a false light," said David Longsdorf, of No. 424 Marketstreet, to a Philadelphia Times reporter to-day.

At a meeting last evening of the Seventeenth Assembly District Republican Association at No. 341 West Forty-seventh-street, exAlderman McClave in the chair, a dozen members were elected and committees were appointed to further the interests of the campaign.
LONDON, Sept. 25. --This was the third day of the Newmarket first October meeting. The race for the Newmarket October Handicap was won by Mr. Leopold de Rothschild's 4-yearold b.c. Hamako.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 25.--The Republican Convention for the Third Assembly District of Ulster County was held this afternoon at Phoenicia. Cornelius A.J. Hardenburgh, of Shawangunk, was nominated. The contest was close between him and ex-Assemblyman Johnson. Four candidates were in the field.

Several bachelor members of the Century Club have apartments in the four-story brick building at Union-square and Fifteenth-street, only four doors from the clubhouse. Isaac Newton, Chief Engineer of the Department of Public Works and a prominent member of the club, occupied two rear rooms on the third floor, facing on Fifteenth-street.

As counsel for ex-Judge Levi Parsons, Lawyer Coles Morris moved before Judge Donohue, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, for the continuance of the injunction restraining I. Wormser, the bankers and brokers, from disposing of $579,000, par value, of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railroad Company's bonds and of stock representing several hundred thousand dollars par value.

NAPLES, Sept. 25.--A tragic incident has resulted from the cholera plague here. A girl, 17 years of age, was seized with the disease, and her lover, anxious to be by her side, attempted to enter the room where she lay.

Rosario Fertilla, an Italian fruit peddler, who lives at No. 77 James-street, ran up the stairs to the street from the basement of his house at 7 o'clock yesterday morning. His wife, Josephine, staggered up the steps behind him exclaiming "I am short!" and fell fainting on the sidewalk.
LONDON, Sept. 25.--Advices from Burmah state that a sanguinary outbreak had occurred in the jail at Mandalay. Several hundred convicts were killed.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25.--It was rumored on the streets to-day that H. Wien Co., lace dealers, at No. 179 Madison-street, had failed. A call at the above number disclosed the fact that Wien had sold his stock to Charles Block, formerly in the dry goods commission business.

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 25.--The Hon. W.D. Kelley, of Philadelphia, addressed a large audience on the tariff in this city to-night. He was repeatedly annoyed by the brass bands in the passing procession and twice left the stage ...

George Welhefer, a German employed in the watch factory at Sag Harbor, committed suicide Wednesday night by jumping into the bay. Before he drowned himself he wrote a letter in which he said: " I have lived too long. God has punished me severely. My body will rise in the sea. God have pity on my poor soul. I go to where none have returned."

Bridge Trustees Van Schaick and Wittie recently signed a call for a special meeting of the Board of Trustees "to hear expert evidence on the matter of increasing the present facilities and reducing the cost of transportation over the Brooklyn bridge."

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 25.--Judge Levi N. Blydenburgh and E.P. Arvine, of this city, addressed an enthusiastic Cleveland and Hendricks ratification meeting at Ansonia tonight. Mr. Arvine is an anti-Blaine Republican. He is the first independent in this State to go upon the stump.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 25.--Herbert C. Mason, 44 years of age, a prominent Boston business man, committed suicide on Wednesday at Stockbridge Mass., where he and his family were summering.

Miss Sarah C. Carpenter, aged 38 years, has been missing from her home, at No. 72 Hancock-street, Brooklyn, since Wednesday morning. Miss Carpenter had not come to breakfast, but no particular attention was paid to that fact.

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Sept. 25.--The Indian Conference has devoted much time to the discussion of the capacity of the Indian for citizenship, the best way to secure his claim as a citizen, the subject of compulsory education, and the abolition of the reservation plan.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Sept. 25.--The townspeople await the inquest in the Wainwright murder mystery with growing impatience. The State officers say that they have a clear case, but against whom they do not say. It is presumably, however, against Rockwell, the imprisoned candidate for Sheriff. While Policeman McMahon, of the mounted squad, was riding along the King's Bridge road, near Jerome-avenue, about 10 A.M. yesterday, he discovered the body of a man a short distance from the street in the bushes.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 25, via Galveston. --The Mexican Congress this afternoon issued a formal proclamation announcing that Porfirio Diaz has been elected President of Mexico for four years, his term of office beginning Dec. 1, 1884.
MINEOLA, Long Island, Sept. 25.--There was great excitement on the Queens County Fair Grounds this afternoon, caused by a series of accidents to horses and riders in a 3-year-old running race.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 26.--A mortgage was filed in the Recorder's office to-day, given by the Wyoming Valley Coal Company to George S. Bennet and John M. Crane to secure the payment of bonds to the amount of $150,000.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 25.--The Blaine caravan set out on the road pretty early this morning, having been advertised to exhibit at 10 A.M. in Fulton, 25 miles north, where the Oswego County Fair is being held. ALBANY, Sept. 25.--Patterson Freeman, a well-to-do farmer of Crescent, was lately worried over the failure of his crops. This morning his wife arose at 5 o'clock, leaving him asleep in bed.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 25.--The Yale Law School opened to-day. The incoming class is much larger than last year's Junior Class, and includes many members of the Class of '84, academic department.

ALBANY, Sept. 25.--Gov. Cleveland expects to go to Buffalo next week, Wednesday or Thursday, to attend to some pressing private business.
HAMILTON, Ontario, Sept. 25.--A great labor demonstration and mass meeting will be held here on Oct. 1. Workingmen from all parts of the province will take part.
POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 25.--Samuel Spotts, aged 50, of St. Clair, has been committed to jail on a charge of feloniously assaulting his stepdaughter, a child of 6 years. Lynching is threatened.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25.--The leading Produce markets were generally more active to-day and averaged stronger. This applied chiefly to Grain and October Lard and did not apply at all to Barley, which was swamped for the nonce by larger offerings. The weather was fine, but a cold wave was said to be approaching, and this furnished an excuse ...

CHICAGO, Sept. 25.--Chief Veterinarian D.E. Salmon returned to Chicago to-day from Kentucky and Ohio, where he went to trace pleuro-pheumonia cases which were understood to have been carried from this State. His visit resulted in the discovery of the disease in both of those States.
BOSTON, Sept. 25.--The will of Francis B. Hays, the Republican candidate for Congress in the Fifth District, who died last Saturday morning, was filed in the County Probate office today.

Assistant Bishop Henry C. Potter, President of the Protestant Episcopal Convention, yesterday read a report of his work for the past year, showing increased prosperity in the affairs of the diocese.

The death of the Rev. John Allen Giles, D.C.L., is announced in a dispatch from London. He was born at Mark, Somersetshire, in 1808, and was educated at the Charterhouse and Corpus Christi College, Oxford. He obtained the degree of B.A. in 1828.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 25.--The Republican State Convention met at 9 A.M. yesterday to receive the report of the committee on credentials, and by recesses managed to kill time until 4 P.M., when the committee reported. The contesting delegations were allowed to present their cases before the convention.

Two hundred delegates from the northern counties attended the Sacramento Valley Immigration Convention, which is sufficient proof that that end of the State is awake to the fact that many of its matchless resources have been allowed to slumber undisturbed too long.
Georgia is full of relatives of distinguished people. Mr. Blaine, who superintended the Government work in the Oconee River, is a first cousin of James G. Blaine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25.--For the second time within a few days citizens of Pennsylvania who are in Government employ here have received a letter from the Pennsylvania Republican ...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 25.--After many months of earnest work on the part of C.P. Huntington, his lieutenants, and the people of Nashville, the Chesapeake and Nashville Railway is at last an assured fact.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 25.--For several years attempts have been made to induce the people of this county to raise tobacco instead of cotton. The experiment has been tried this year and has succeeded beyond expectation.

About three weeks ago Mr. John M. Allen, a wholesale produce commission merchant of New-York, well known in this community, being at the station here in Milford attending to the shipment of fruit, some of which was consigned to him on commission, was arrested on the complaint of Mr. J.O. Truitt and Capt. Harris for buying fruit without a license. While Mr. Allen was at the station a farmer drove up ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25.--Secretary Chandler is credited with having urged the President to appoint a Secretary of the Treasury who would make the most of his position to advance the Republican ticket. It is said the President did not receive this advice kindly.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 25.--An unostentatious wedding took place in Trinity Church at 1 o'clock this afternoon, when Grace, daughter of the late Charles H. Russell, of New-York, was married to W. Strother Jones, of New-York.

The disappearance of Frank Munn, the Assistant Secretary of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company, is still an unsolved mystery. Whether he sailed last Saturday in the White Star Line steamship Celtic, accompanied by a woman not his wife, also remains a question.

The report printed yesterday that Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Hulskamp had been remarried on Tuesday by the Rev. Father Gallagher according to the rites of the Roman Catholic Church seems to be without foundation.

TALLADEGA, Ala., Sept. 25.--While Isaac Terry was engaged this evening in digging a well he was overcome by gas, and asked to be pulled out immediately. When about 30 feet from the top of the well, he fell to the bottom, expiring in 10 minutes. Henry Tomlinson attempted to rescue him, when he also fell to the bottom, and died before he could be rescued.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 25.--Gen. Alfred M. Scales, the Democratic candidate for Governor, who was badly hurt a week ago by being thrown over a precipice in the western part of the State, is still unable to meet his appointments, and his friends fear that he is more seriously hurt than was at first supposed. He cannot stand up, and internal injuries of a serious character are feared. He is at home in Greensborough.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 25.--The striking cigarmakers, aided by members of other trades, had another parade this evening. After the parade J.J. Junio delivered a fiery speech denouncing capitalists. The strike is expected to be a long and a bitter one.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 25.--The Government has directed the municipal authorities strictly to enforce the rules relating to foreigners. This injunction is made in view of the participation of foreigners in the recent political disorders.

BOSTON, Sept. 25.--The Democrats in the Sixth Congressional District to-day renominated Henry B. Lovering, of Lynn, and in the Seventh District placed Richard S. Spofford, of Newburyport, in nomination. The Republicans in the First District renominated Robert T. Davis, of Fall River.

The steamer Lord of the Isles, of the Union Line, which cleared from Shanghai July 18, arrived at Quarantine Wednesday night, and yesterday was moored at Pier No. 47 North River. She had an eventful passage. Clearing from Amoy on July 27 she sailed right into a strong typhoon, which continued two days with a very high sea, and inflicted injuries of which she still shows the effects.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 25.--At a late hour last night, near Shelbyville, D.P. Brown and W.F. Pigg rode up to a tollgate on the Lewisburg turnpike kept by an old man named Wade and his wife. They demanded passage through on a family ticket.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 25.--Lawyer James S. Thompson, of East Haven Centre, recently built a new house next to his late residence. On the night of Aug. 31 he heard his dog barking in the yard, and, going out, found his barn door open and his horses loose.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25.--The Chicago creditors of the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company to-day took possession of the company's property in this city, disconnected its wires and stopped business.

Mr. Irving's season on this continent will begin at Montreal next Wednesday evening, Oct.1.
Judge Maguire has granted the motion to dissolve the injunction in the case of N.C. Goodwin, the actor, against Edmund Morris, charged in the complaint to be a professional gambler.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 25.--The principal soloists in to-day's concerts of the Musical Festival were Mlle. Emma Juch and Mme. Isabella Fassett.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 25.--The Wyoming Valley Coal Company gave a mortgage this afternoon to George S. Bennett and John M. Crane to secure the payment of bonds to the amount of $150,000. The mortgage has been filed in the office of the Recorder of Deeds.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 25.--Another chapter was written to-day in the life of Nellie Hubbard, she who a half dozen years ago set the fashion for fashionable young women by eloping with the coachman, Gov. Hubbard was at the height of his popularity and political success when Nellie deserted the parental mansion in Hartford to become the wife of the family groom, Fred Shepard.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Sept. 25.--The Democratic Congressional Conference of the Seventh District met here to-day and nominated George Ross, an attorney, of Doylestown. Mr. Ross is a brother of the late Judge Ross.

At the meeting yesterday of the Executive Committee of the trunk lines, passenger department, no action was taken looking to a revision or modification of the rates now existing between Chicago and the seaboard. The matter will probably be the subject of the meeting to be held on Tuesday next.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25.--A special to the Times from York, Penn., says that great interest and no little excitement has been caused in that city by the miraculous and instantaneous cure of persons supposed to be beyond the reach of ordinary remedies. In some cases the patients have been snatched almost from the jaws of death by the mere touch of a human hand.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25.--John H. McBride, one of the oldest and most widely known teachers in Philadelphia, died to-day. For almost a quarter of a century he had been connected with the public schools.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25.--Within the hour preceding midnight last night the Hon. Walter Q. That is because the defense it put forth, though as strong as Mr. ROGERS'S ingeniuty and experience as a lawyer and his zeal as a party man could make it, was rendered feeble by the facts.

Miss Nellie Cole is a dashing brunette, well known, but not in polite society.

The ship John T. Berry, Capt. Watts, which arrived at this port from Antwerp, yesterday, after a voyage of 40 days had some unpleasant experiences. Up to Sept. 11 the ship had light westerly winds and calms, when a heavy gale struck her. Sept. 14 she experienced a hurricane which lasted six hours, during which she lost two of her sails.
The Directors of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad declared a quarterly dividend of 2 per cent. yesterday, payable Oct. 20. The stock transfer books will close Oct. 2.

PAUL, Minn., Sept. 26.--A gentleman prominent in local railroad circles said yesterday "It is pretty generally conceded that in their designs on North and Northwest territory the Chicago and Northwestern Road, the Rock Island and its children, the Wisconsin, Minnesota and Pacific, the Burlington, Cedar Rapids and Northern, and others, are one at heart.

A special meeting of the Seawanhaka Yacht Club was held last evening at Delmonico's to arrange a Fall regatta. It was decided to have to have two races--one over the regular club course, on Oct. 18, and one of 20 miles to windward and return on the open ocean, on Oct. 15. The outside race will be open only to sloops and cutters of the first, second, and third classes.

Carlo Gallia, an Italian, living at No. 11 Watts-street, made a complaint to Justice O'Reilly, at the Jefferson market Police Court yesterday, against Alexander Grant, who calls himself a lawyer and interpreter, and has an office at No. 102 Bayard-street.

It is unfortunate that the first municipal election under the law which gives the Mayor of this cite power to make appointments without confirmation by the Board of Aldermen should occur on the same day with the Presidential election.

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 26.--There is great excitement in the Seventh Ward of this city over the scandalous developments growing out of an attempt to burn the recently completed residence of William Chambers. A requisition signed by the Governor of New-Jersey calling for the surrender of the bigamist Ramsgate was handed to Justice Duffy, in the Yorkville Court, yesterday, by Mr. Murphy, Chief of the Jersey City Police. A telegram was also given to the Justice stating that there was in the Register's office in Boston ...

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 26.--The St. Louis Malleable Iron Company made an assignment this morning to John T. Davis. H. M. Filley is President of the company and B. G. Farrar Secretary. The schedule of the assets shows $11,000. No statement of the liabilities has yet been made.

Early yesterday morning Christian Sommers, a sailor on Mr. Astor's yacht Nourmahal, hired a boat at May Brothers' float, at the foot of West Thirty-fifth-street, to go on board his vessel. He was rowed by an experienced boatman.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 26.--Mr. John W. Garrett, President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, died at his private cottage, at Deer Park, at 5:25 o'clock this morning.

GALESBURG, Ill., Sept. 26.--Pleasants Henderson, of this city, has commenced suit in the Circuit Court against Justice Craig, of the Supreme Court, placing damages at $15,000. The case grows out of the Henderson against Hendorson divorce suit, in which Justice Craig was made a central figure. It was claimed that he had been criminally intimate with Mrs. Henderson. The case never came to trial.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 26.--The star of empire in the stock business has passed away from Colorado, Nebraska, and Wyoming and has moved northwest into the fertile grazing valleys of Dakota and Montana.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Sept. 26.--The body of Frank B. Skillman was found on the beach near the foot of Cottage Place to-day. Mr. Skillman fell overboard from the yacht Modesty, near Sandy Hook, Saturday evening, while fishing with the owner of the yacht, John C. Cracknell, of Bayonne City, and a party of friends.

ILION, N. Y., Sept. 26.--George W. Weaver, the publisher of the Ilion Citizen, is tonight printing the first newspaper in the world the type of which was entirely composed by a type-setting machine. The edition of 5,000 copies is being printed by the aid of an electric motor. Hundreds of visitors have been to see the operation.

READING, Penn., Sept. 26.--Among the many victims of thieves who have been plying their vocation during the last few days at the annual county fair here was John S. Holtzman, who was robbed of $200 and a number of notes. Holtzman is the Democratic nominee for County Treasurer. He put his 80-year-old mother in the almshouse where she died and was buried in potter's field, although he was a comparatively rich man at the time.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 26.--Gov. Cleveland has not definitely decided on what day he will leave the capital for Buffalo, but it will probably be on Wednesday or Thursday of next week. There will be no demonstrations along the line if the Governor's wishes are consulted.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 26.--During the Blaine demonstration to-night fire broke out in the dry goods store of Strauss Brothers Miller, on Superior-street, where the crowds were the thickest. NEW-HAVENS, Sept. 26.--As the workmen at Winchester's repeating arms factory returned from dinner to-day an explosion occurred which narrowly escaped proving fatal. In mixing fulminate large stone retorts are used, whose capacity is from 10 to 15 gallons.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Sept. 26.--J. L. Dan ford, the defaulting President of the bank at Cheney, Wyoming, who absconded some days ago to British Columbia, has fled from Victoria in consequence of American detectives being there to capture him.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Sept. 26.--The Fifth Ward of this city is largely Democratic, fourfifths of the inhabitants being Irish. Among the residents are ex-Assemblyman Flynn. Alderman Burke, and other prominent influential Irishmen. About a month ago, after strong...

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 26.--Frank L. Kernochan, a prominent manufacturer of Pittsfield, Mass., accidentally shot himself fatally on Friday morning about 3 o'clock. He thought there were burglars in the house, and took a revolver down cellar. He fell near the bottom of...

WASHINGTON, D. C., Sept. 26.--William McMahon, a printer, who came to this city from New-York two weeks ago, was fatally cut to-night by George Hough, also a printer. The men, with another companion, had been drinking together during the day, and had had a dispute as to which was the better man at wrestling.

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 26.--A serious riot occurred early this morning on Water street, near the Pennsylvania Railroad's passenger station, the participants being members of the Republican marching clubs from Pittsburg and Steubenville and local clubs.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 26.--For the third time within a week the Newport express was run off the track this afternoon at the Fair Haven station. The train due in New-Haven at 4:57 was derailed, and it took an hour to put the car upon the track again. The place where the car left the track is about 100 yards from the high Quinnpiac bridge. The drawing-room coach Niantic was again the car derailed.
The annual cricket match between the selected teams of New-York and Philadelphia was commenced on the grounds of the Staten Island Club, at Tompkinsville, yesterday.
NEWPORT, R. I, Sept. 26.--The, Casino will be closed for the season Oct. 4, three week earlier than last year.

The Commissioners of Charities and Correction have been forced to abandon for the present much-needed improvements at the Tombs. At a meeting of the board yesterday the only bid made for the construction of the proposed two prison buildings in the Tombs courtyard was one by Mahoney Brothers, who asked $98,000 for the work.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 26.--Miss C. I. Welton, a wealthy young lady from New-York City, perished in a snowstorm last Tuesday night while descending Long's Peak. Miss Welton had been spending the season at Colorado Springs and visiting Pike's Peak and other points of interest.
Tammany's Committee on Organization, contrary to general expectation, did not even refer to the subject of a straight ticket at its meeting last night.

Nahum Sullivan, one of the oldest and best-known merchants of this city, died at his home, near Montclair, N. J., yesterday morning. He was a special partner in the firm of Sullivan, Vail Co., dealers in woolens at 329 Broadway.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 26.--Early this morning as freight train No. 17 was passing Greenwood, on the Cincinnati Southern Railroad, a man named Samuel Hays, who was intoxicated, stumbled on the track, and before the train could be stopped was crushed to death.

The Sons of the Revolution are taking in hand the subscription list for the pedestal to the statue of " Liberty." They have asked President Arthur to head a one-dollar subscription list, and every man, woman, and child in America is invited to send in $l or more.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26.--The acting Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon issued the one hundred and thirty-first call for the redemption of bonds. The call is for $10,000,000 of the 3 per cent. loan of 1882, and notice is given that the principal and accrued interest will be paid at the Treasury on the 1st day of November, and that interest will cease on that day.

John Work Garrett was born in Baltimore on July 31, 1820. Though one of the most prominent men in the financial circles of the country he did not begin life in the orthodox manner as a poor man's son.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 26.--Dell Houck. who was formerly employed at the station here as yard master of the Albany and Susquehanna Railroad, and who eloped with his sister-in-law, the wife of Charles Neer, was arrested in Rochester yesterday and brought to this city last night by Sheriff Black.

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 26.--At the balloon ascension at the fair to-day Samuel Pherrin was killed by a timber, used in balancing the balloon, falling and crushing his skull. Several other persons were injured. William Hallahan was killed near here on the railroad last night.

BOSTON, Sept, 26.--It is reported in one of the evening papers that a bet of $3,000 a side was put up to-day in this city on the general result of the November election. The money was deposited in the Shawmut National Bank.

The demand for coachmen as husbands by their employers' daughters is becoming so general that gentlemen in and about this city who have eligible drivers are in daily fear of losing them and being obliged to intrust their horses to inexperienced hands.

BERLIN, Sept. 26.--The German Government has forbidden the new corvettes, Ting Yuen and Chen-Yuen, which were built for China, to leave Kiel under the German flag.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Sept. 26.--At the opening of the Methodist Conference this morning the verdict of the committee appointed for the trial of the case of the Rev. R. M. Smith, who is charged with adultery, was given. Both charges were unanimously sustained, and the erring brother was expelled from the Conference.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 26.--James Egan, famous the country over as a left-handed pitcher, died at the New-Haven County Jail to-day of brain fever. To many this will recall the bright, manly presence of a young athlete who stepped into the baseball arena some four years ago with bright prospects.

MANCHESTER, Sept. 26.--Tne Guardian in its commercial article says: "The market was quiet throughout the week except during yesterday, when there was more business in shirtings at a decline in prices of d, to 1d. There has been more inquiry for export yarns but no increase is buying."

Twenty-five guests sat down to a dinner tendered to Capt. A. L. Boivie, of Brooklyn, last evening, at the Metropolitan Hotel, in acknowledgment of his untiring energy in assisting and encouraging his Scandinavian countrymen who have come to this country.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26.--The demand to-day for tickets to the Democratic mass meeting at Horticultural Hall to-morrow night was very great. Abbett, of New-Jersey, will be the most prominent speakers from other States and Congressman Randall and Chairman Hensel of this State.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 26.--Gov. Waller goes West next week to stump Ohio for Cleveland and Hendricks. After the October election in Ohio the Governor will make a personal canvass of Connecticut.

DUBLIN, Sept. 26.--The corporation of Limerick to-day rejected, by a vote of 18 to 2, he proposition to provide for the payment of the special police tax as reduced by Earl Spencer, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland. The Mayor announced that Mr. Patrick Egan, President of the Irish National League in America, had telegraphed his approval of their action.

A middle-aged woman giving her name as Helena Hulser, who said she was a native of Germany, arrived in Paterson, N. J., a day or two ago. Yesterday she called at the police station and told a remarkable story.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 26.--Henry Byrd, a well-known portrait painter, died here this morning, aged 79 years. He has been married several times, and leaves several families. His last wife bore him two children, who are still infants.

PANAMA, Sept.17.--The great question at present in Chill is the definition of the relations between Church and State. There has been a good deal of discussion on the subject in Congress, but liberalideas seem to prevail. A complete separation of Government and the church seems probable.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26.--Mr. Cannon, Controller of the Currency, has returned to Washington from an official visit to New-York. He says that the affairs of the Marine National Bank of New-York were in good condition, and he proposed a dividend of 10 per cent. in favor of its creditors about Oct. 1. He also said there was every prospect of a speedy and satisfactory settlement of the disputed questions connected with the Clearing House.

The above is accompanied by a large cut of a Portland sleigh of the latest fashion.

LONDON, Sept. 27.--Mme. Christine Nilsson met with an accident while riding in a cab in Pall Mall to-day. The horse slipped and the carriage was badly smashed. Mme. Nilsson was thrown violently to the pavement. Her left hand was slightly injured, the wound bleeding badly. Her right arm and left leg were also hurt.

A merry frolic was engaged in by several members of the Stock Exchange between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. A bright-looking colored boy, known as the "little black piper," was taken into the board room while business was in progress and induced to play popular tunes on his fife. The lad is but 14 years of age, of small stature, and remarkably black skin.

CASTLETON, N.Y., Sept. 27.--Among the passengers on the steamer Saratoga from Troy on Tuesday evening was John Kelly, a young man who was employed during the Summer months as a waiter in the Putnam House, Manchester, N.H.

LONDON, Sept. 27.--This week's Economist says: "The rate of discount for bank bills, 60 days to 3 months, is 1 5/8 per cent., and for trade bills, 60 days to 3 months, 2 per cent. Money is much firmer, owing to the increasing demand.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27.--Among the securities of the New-Jersey Central Railroad, the care of which Reading assumed under the lease, is the loan of the Central New-Jersey Car Trust Association.
NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 27.--The Law School opened on Thursday with 22 registered in the entering Junior Class. The majority of them are Yale graduates.

ALBANY, Sept. 27.--Gov. Cleveland expects to leave for Buffalo on the limited express on the Central Road at noon next Thursday. This train makes only a few short stops. There will be no opportunity for demonstrations at the stations. This will be as the Governor desires. He says that he does not want to take "a triumphal trip." He will arrive in Buffalo early in the evening, and will be given a grand reception.

The Colossus and the Java, two unfinfinished men-of-war, are being broken up in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. They are both rotten, and the dismantling is by order of Congress. Fifty piles of wood from the vessels were sold yesterday at from 25 cents to $3 a pile. The vessels were begun in 1863, and work on them was stopped on account of the ending of the war.

A majority of the members of the American Yacht Club have decided to postpone their proposed Full regatta from Sept. 30 to Tuesday, Oct. 14, and the course will be laid on the Hudson River instead of Long Island Sound.

The people in Egypt who have obtained awards for property destroyed during the Alexandria fire are exceedingly indignant at not being paid. Three-quarters of these "victims" are swindlers, who have managed to get an award for a sum far in excess of the value of what they have lost.

LONDON, Sept. 27.--Up to midnight on Thursday the total number of deaths in Europe from the cholera since the outbreak in Toulon, according to a minute system of tables that I have been keeping, was 14,132.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 27.--Dar Gardner, who shot his wife and then sent a bullet into his own brain, died this morning. He never regained consciousness. His wife is still alive, but very low. The ball fractured her jaw, making an ugly wound.

It is announced that the Hon. J. Randolph Tucker, Democratic nominee for Congress in the Tenth District of Virginia, has returned a check for $1,000, sent by a political admirer in Philadelphia to assist him in prosecuting his canvass. Mr. Tucker's election by a large majority is assured, but a check for $1,000 would be of material assistance to the Democratic National Committee, which is now appealing for funds for legitimate campaign purposes.

The ladies' fair for the benefit of the Hoboken Hospital will open to-morrow evening with a music festival. The hospital received over a thousand patients last year, and gets no support from State or city, being maintained entirely by contributions.

More documents were sent from the Republican National headquarters yesterday than on any day since the campaign opened. The aggregate of the documents sent out during the week is over 2,000,000. As the freight propeller Pequet, of the Providence Line, was slowly steaming up the East River eastward bound last evening at 7 o'clock, a tugboat, with two canal boats in tow, was observed to be heading across her bow when she was opposite Catharine-Street Ferry. The Pequot immediately blew a whistle as a warning to the tugboat to stop.
The Fall meeting of the American Jockey Club began yesterday at Jerome Park under favorable auspices, for the weather was pleasant, the track in good order, and a large crowd was present.

--Purkess is one of the numerous corrupt forms of the diminutive of Peter, as thus, Peterkin, Perkin, Perkins, Perkis, Purkis. The rusticulus mentioned by Matthew Paris might as likely as not be named Purkiss, though we have not a title of evidence to that effect. This is a personal baptismal name, and has nothing to do with a family or successors.

The American Institute Exhibition is now in full swing, and the building in which it is held is crowded in every part. The machinery department attracts considerable attention. LONDON, Sept. 27.--An epidemic of embezzlement, with sensational sequels, is prevalent in Hungary. The institutions plundered have been in all cases orphan asylums, supported wholly or in part by the State.

ROME, Sept. 28.--One fresh case of cholera has been reported to-day in Rome, the patient being a soldier. In the Kingdom of Italy during the last 24 hours there have been reported 408 new cases and 222 deaths, including 116 cases and 74 deaths at Naples and 39 cases and 25 deaths at Genoa. Since the outbreak of the disease in Italy 13,220 persons have been attacked and 9,480 have died.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 25.--Three full State tickets are in the field in Wisconsin--the Republican, Democratic, and Prohibition--and upon these, as well as upon the Electors and members of Congress, a lively fight is progressing.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 28.--Henry Meyer and Robert Schlanker, two young men from Buffalo, came to this city on the excursion from that place on Saturday night, to attend the Democratic demonstration here.

PETERSBURG, Va., Sept. 28.--Prayers were offered in the churches here to-day for rain, which is badly needed in this section on account of the damaging effect the protracted drought has had on the crops.

SANTIAGO DE CHILI, Sept. 28, via Galveston.--In accordance with the law of Parliamentary incompatibilities 22 Deputies were to-day excluded from the Chambers. NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 29.--To-night the regiment of Louisiana Field Artillery, Col. Gustave Legardeur, was mustered out of the State militia, and this famous command has ceased to exist.

READING, Penn., Sept. 29.--An old man named Adam Deas wandered away from his home, in this city, last Thursday, and all search at the time was fruitless. To-day his body was brought to Henninger's morgue and identified.

Forty-one hundred persons paid admission to witness the Metropolitan Club defeat the Louisville nine on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The contest, although well played on the part of the local club, failed to prove interesting on account of the large lead gained by the Mets at an early stage.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 29.--In the face of the watchfulness of the police and the vigi lance of the citizens' patrol, incendiary fires continue to be started in different portions of the city, and the alarmed and frightened citizens expect momentarily to near of the commencement of another conflagration. The English version of "Der Bibliothekar," which was presented at the New-York Comedy Theatre last evening, was entitled "Digby's Secretary." The adaptation is the work of Mr. William Gillette, who seems to have sufficient confidence in the merit of his work, as may readily be inferred from the fact that he appeared in the title role.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 29.--The employes of the Cornell Steamboat Company's machine and boiler shops have been notified that their wages will be reduced this week. They will not know the exact amount of the reduction until they receive their pay on Saturday.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 29.--There has been another break in freight rates eastward, which are now 2 cents per 100 pounds lower all around than they were on Saturday night, and 10 cents lower than a week ago. All rail rates per 100 pounds on flour and grain are now 13 cents from Milwaukee to Philadelphia,...

ROCHESTER, Sept. 28.--THE TIMES'S correspondent was assured by the Blaine politicians in Syracuse, Auburn, Seneca Falls, and Canandaigua that when he reached Rochester he would find things "red hot;" there was a perfect stampede in Monroe County for the tattooed candidate, and the majority was going to be at least 8,000.
Interest to the amount of $140,000 is due to-day on bonds of the Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia Railroad.
A number of gentlemen interested in the improvement of the telephone system met at No. 67 Greene-street yesterday afternoon to witness experiments with a new telephone.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 30.--The Committee of Catholic Theologians, who have been holding their sessions for the past four weeks at St. Charles's College, in Howard County, and at St. Mary's Seminary, this city, expect to finish the work assigned them in a few weeks and submit the result of their labors to Archbishop Gibbons, the presiding officer of the Plenary Council.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--The Secretary of the National Prohibition Party furnishes the following letter of acceptance from Gov. St. John, the candidate of that party for President of the United States:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 30.--The little town of Dansville is in a state of great excitement. Early this morning it was learned that a terrible homicide had occurred there. About 11:30 o'clock last night Pomfret Allen shot Michael Torney twice, killing him almost instantly. Torney and Allen were both residents of Dansville. Allen is a man of family whose matrimonial relations have been more or less unpleasant.

The baseball craze has reached the colored population of Brooklyn, and in order to decide the colored championship two clubs, the Remsens and the Alpmes, crossed bats at Washington Park, Brooklyn, yesterday.

BOSTON, Sept. 30.--The annual meeting of the Harvard University Boat Club was held this evening in Holden Chapel, Cambridge. Officers for the ensuing year were chosen as follows: President--A.T. French, '85; VicePresident--G.L. Winthrop, '86; Secretary--F. S. Parker, '86; Treasurer--W.R. Wilson, '86.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--Gen. P.H. Sheridan arrived at the Palmer House this morning, en route to Fort Leavenworth, Kansas, to witness the biennial target practice of a picked army team of 12 rifle-shooters.

Neither Senator Edmunds nor ex-Senator Conkling was in the United States Circuit Court yesterday when argument was resumed for the plaintiff in the case of the Bell Telephone Company against the People's Telephone Company, and for the first time two or three spectators in the voiceless space of the back seats slept peacefully during most of the drowsy afternoon.

Mrs. Dr. De Forest Brown, of Chicago, who has just returned from a Summer tour of Europe, and is at present in this city, visited the French cities in which the cholera has been raging, and studied the conditions under which the disease was spreading, as well as its treatment. She was in Italy previous to its outbreak there, and hence was unable to say anything about the sufferings in Naples.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 30.--"Nunky" was again in court to-day on the petition of A. M. Palmer, of New-York, for an injunction restraining Manager Field, of the Museum, from further performing the play in this country.

LONDON, Sept. 30.--M. Maurel has instituted a suit against Mme. Patti, claiming $10,000 damages as compensation for breaking an engagement at the Paris Italiens. M. Maurel alleges that the Marquis Caux has promised not to interfere in the matter.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 30.--Intelligence has just reached this city of the heroic death of a young lady who was murdered by burglars. Early this morning Katic Richards, daughter of the Postmaster at Minneville, Ohio heard burglars in the Post Office.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 30.--The Republicans of this county were considerably surprised this afternoon by the nominations made by the Democratic County Convention held here.
WADY HALFA, Sept. 30.--The steamer Nassifkheir, employed in the Gordon relief expedition, has passed the Semneh cataract. She was badly damaged in making the passage.

It has been decided by Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, that the Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn bridge have a right to extend its terminus across Printing House-square on a line parallel, with Tryonrow to Centre-street.

TOLEDO, Sept. 30.--At about 9 o'clock this morning Mr. Blaine was driven to the station. Ex-Senator B.K. Bruce, Emery A. Storrs, ex-Gov. Foster, Judge West, and Senator Plumb were added to the party of yesterday. At the station there was some delay, and it was nearly 10 o'clock when the special train started for Tiffin and other points south.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30.--Early this morning fire broke out in the stables of Commodore Kittson, at Erdenheim, the famous stock farm formerly owned by Aristides Welch. Two buildings took fire and burned so furiously that aid was telegraphed for to this city and to Norristown, but as no assistance came the farm hands were compelled to stand idle and view the destruction of the buildings.

The father and brothers of Miss Carpenter, the Brooklyn lady who has been missing from her home, No. 72 Hancock-street, since last Wednesday morning, followed up several clues yesterday without any success.
Mme. Ristori will sail from Havre for New-York on the steamer St. Germain on Oct. 18. Her American tour will last four months.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 30.--The National Convention of the Irish-American Republican League assembles here this afternoon. Over 300 delegates have already registered, of whom 100 are from Ohio, 15 from Virginia, 40 from Indiana, 40 from Illinois, 50 from Kentucky, 30 from Iowa, 18 from Texas, 4 from Alabama, 6 from New-York, and 7 from Pennsylvania.
John Condon, 17 years old, attempted to commit suicide late on Monday night by hanging himself in his bedroom at his parents' residence, No. 586 East One Hundred and Fortiethstreet.
UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 30.--The fifty-fiffth annual meeting of the New-York State Temperance Society was held here to-day, the Rev. H.M. King, D.D., of Albany, Senior Vice-President, in the chair.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30.--A special to the Times from Trenton says that the theory is gaining ground very rapidly, in the Grant case, that Eddie Grant, the 12-year-old brother, accidentally shot George in the barn.

The Republicans of Suffolk County held their convention at the Court House in Riverhead yesterday afternoon. Prominent among the delegates were Senator Otis, ex-Judge Hodges, ex-Assemblyman Nichols, and ex-Senator Birdsall, of Queens County.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 30.--Reports from the rural districts of the State show the drought to be doing terrible damage. In Mercer, Somerset, and Hunterdon Counties the ground is parched and cracking.

CENTRALIA, Penn., Sept. 30.--"Hell's Kitchen" is the local name of a tract of land lying north of Locust Mountain, several miles from Centralia, the inhabitants of which are for the most part farmers. Among those who had amassed a fortune was Samuel Heinreith, one of the oldest citizens in the place. He is 62 years of age, and has a wife and six children--three boys and three girls.
The supporters of Blaine and Logan in the Stock Exchange have secured more than 200 names of members who are in favor of organizing a Blaine campaign club.

The New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad has just published a map of its line and its connections throughout the United States.

BUFFALO, Sept. 30.--Politics have been uncommonly active here to-day. In the afternoon the Republican County Convention was held and John Easer nominated for County Treasurer after a spirited contest. He is a reputable man, which is more than can be said of all the candidates.
The Fall combination sale of Jersey cattle was begun yesterday at the Horse Exchange, at Broadway and Fiftieth-street.

LONDON, Sept. 30.--The Times this morning Says: "It is likely that the Republicans are still in a numerical majority in America, though it appears that a Democratic Government is impending through the action of Republicans who are dissatisfied with the Administration withdrawing from politics or temporarily joining the Democrats. A reform in the Republican Party would reclaim the dissatisfied element."

ROME, Sept. 30.--A soldier in this city has died from the cholera, and another, who is suffering from the disease, has been taken to the lazaretto. King Humbert has decided to bestow decorations upon those who have taken a prominent part in combating the epidemic. Signor Grimaldi, Minister of Agriculture and Commerce, has gone to Genoa to inquire into the condition of the cholera patients there.

The German vote is perhaps the least uncertain quantity in the present canvass. A large part of it has in the past been attached to the Republican Party, and this has especially been the case in the West. Doubtless many Germans will vote for the Republican candidates this year, but there is certainly a very general migration across the political line. JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 30.--Frank Bentley, a young man, while tending a thrashing machine near his home in Ellington, N.Y., yesterday afternoon, caught his left leg in the cylinder of the machine. It was terribly mangled, and the physicians amputated it early this morning. Later in the day Bentley died from the effects of the accident.

Every bird in North America with any sort of reputation to maintain will be glad to learn that 15 gentlemen interested in their welfare met in the library of the New-York Academy of Science, in the American Museum of Natural History, yesterday, to discuss birds in a number of different lights.
Detectives Foley and Stanton, of District Attorney Winfield's office, lodged Arthur Le Fon, a French cook, in jail at Jersey City yesterday on a charge of bigamy.

The El Paso, a new iron steamship of the Morgan Line, is now loading at this port and will start on her first voyage to New-Orleans in a few days. She was built expressly for the New-Orleans trade by William Cramp, of Philadelphia.

The Tammany ticket was a topic of conversation among Democrats and Republicans yesterday. CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--The Rounds Type and Press Company, of No. 175 Monroe-street, yesterday filed with the Recorder of Deeds their voluntary assignment to Samuel D. Ward.
Dr. J. Williston Wright delivered last evening the introductory lecture of the course in the medical department of the University of the City of New-York.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 30.--J.Q. Robinson, 64 years old, of North Adams, Mass., the oldest Deputy Sheriff in Berkshire County, committed suicide to-day by shooting himself through the head. He had been out of health for some time and despondent. This is the only cause known, as he had means enough. He leaves a widow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--There was a large surplus of common Cattle in the market to-day. Such grades as come in competition with range Cattle were almost wholly neglected, and holders of that class found it utterly impossible to effect sales except at a big shave.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 30.--The racing was continued here to-day A heavy rain prevailed all the morning, which made the track very bad. The attendance was poor.

The Hudson County Butler Convention broke up in a row late Monday evening. The delegates met at McPherson Hall and indorsed Congressman William McAdoo, the Democratic nominee, and John R. Wiggins, the Republican candidate for Sheriff.

The second day of the meeting of the American Jockey Club was well attended despite the threatening condition of the weather, as there was no racing at any other point east of the Alleghanies to attract the attention of the sporting community.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 30.--A massmeeting of the students was held this evening for the purpose of electing the officers of the Baseball Association for the ensuing year. The following men were chosen: President--C.R. Wylie, '85; Treasurer--T.H. Harris, '86. An auditing committee was elected to supervise all expenditures and to aid the Treasurer in collecting funds for the association.

Robinson, of New-York, discuss the issues of the campaign. LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 30.--Though it has rained all day extensive preparations were made for the reception of the Hon. Thomas A. Hendricks, who comes as the guest of the Southern Exposition.

BATAVIA, Sept. 30.--Sixteen delegates and one candidate from each of the four counties constituting the Thirty-first Congressional District--Genesee, Livingston, Orleans, and Wyoming--met in Batavia to-day to attend the Republican Congressional Convention. This is the first convention since the apportionment placing these counties in the same district, and each county presents a candidate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30, 1884. It is estimated that the reduction of the public debt for September is a little over $13,000,000.

"Yes, my audiences were apparently with me in sentiment wherever I spoke," said the Hon. Carl Schurz last evening in reply to a question regarding the remarkable succession of political speeches made by him in Wisconsin, Illinois, Michigan, Indiana, and Ohio during the past three weeks.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 30.--A special conference of the independent Republicans of Iowa, who have been denied an existence so far, will be held in Des Moines on Friday next, and attendance is pledged from numerous towns, including Cedar Rapids, Marshalltown, and Ottumwa.
VIENNA, Sept. 30.--The attempt of the sugar firm of Weinrich to arrange their financial difficulties privately was a failure, and the firm has been formally announced as bankrupt.

TIEN-TSIN, Sept. 30.--An imperial edict has been issued to the Viceroy of Canton orderhim to issue a proclamation urging and encouraging the Chinese people to resist the French.

The annual Fall trade sale of books was commenced yesterday morning by George A. Leavitt Co., auctioneers, at Clinton Hall. There was a good attendance of dealers present, and spirited bidding was occasionally indulged in.

Political circles in Long Island City are again agitated over charges of bribery preferred against Health Officer Edward Carroll, of Blissville.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--The friends of John McCullough have stood by him nobly. They have made every endeavor to cry down the reports of his failing health, and have even said that his queer actions have been caused by an overindulgence. To some extent their protestations have been heeded, but they can no longer conceal the truth.

PARIS, Sept. 30.--The Journal des Debats says: "If England persists in embittering our relations with China, and in violating our rights in Egypt, we will be compelled to accept dependence on Germany."

NEWARK, Sept. 30.--About 300 citizens held a meeting in the Common Council chamber to-night to consider the plans for a new sewer system, proposed to relieve the meadows in the southern portion of the city and carry off the sewage that has collected there and made that section of the city almost uninhabitable.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 30.--Pittsburg is to have another Eastern outlet, in the shape of a direct connection with one of the strongest trunk lines in the country.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Sept. 30.--At a meetof the cotton-seed crushers of the Mississippi Valley all of the mills in the valley producing cotton-seed oil being represented, all agreed to pay only $8 per ton for cotton seed from the planters.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--The leading produce markets were very irregular to-day, both in tone and price, as was only natural the last business day of a month, when a good many arrangements have usually to be made to protect the deliveries of the morrow.

ELMIRA, Sept. 30.--Rush C. Wakeman, once traveling partner of a large New-York grocery firm, but subsequently know along the Erie and other railways of this and adjoining States under several aliases as a most daring and skillful confidence operator, swindler, and gambler, died a paralytic in an obscure part of Toronto on Friday last.

BOSTON, Sept. 30.--In the Fifth Congressional District to-day Edward D. Hayden, of Woburn, was nominated in place of the late Francis B. Hayes, whose death occurred soon after his nomination and before he was formally informed of the action of the convention. Mr. Hayden received 78 out of the 84 votes cast on the informal ballot and was declared nominated by acclamation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--J.O. Harvey, a prominent young business man of Wilton, Iowa, was arrested at the Briggs House yesterday by Detectives Granger and Myers on a charge of attempted blackmail, and he was taken to Rockford, Ill., to-day to answer to that charge. Harvey is the son of the Rev. Mr. Harvey, a wellknown Iowa clergyman.

Robert Carman, who was shot by David Degnan in the saloon at No. 209 Seventh-avenue, Monday night, died at St. Vincent's Hospital at 6 o'clock yesterday morning. He spoke only once after he was taken there, and then only to complain of intense pain. The autopsy, by Dr. Kelly, removed the mystery attaching to the supposed third shot and the two wounds.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 30.--The German steamer Martha, from Stettin and Copenhagen, bound for New-York, with 150 passengers, is reported to-night to be off Liscomb in a disabled condition.

FONDA, N.Y., Sept. 30.--J.F.W. Ruttenber, formerly editor and proprietor of the Mohawk Valley Democrat, was to-day indicted by the Grand Jury for arson in the third degree in firing the Democrat office. He pleaded not guilty and was released on $5,000 bail. Ruttenber was formerly of Newburg, and was proprietor of the Evenina News in Gloversville.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 30.--Lloyd's agent here last evening stated that the steamer Finchley struck and sunk off Isaacs Harbor on Sunday morning in seven fathoms of water.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--The September corn deal came to an end to-day amid a scene of excitement unparalleled in the history of the Board of Trade. A number of doctors of divinity and laymen stood upon the bricks and boards and stones which marked the site of the embryo New-York Presbyterian Church, at One Hundred and Twenty-eighth-street and Seventh-avenue, yesterday.

A meeting of the Executive Committee of the Ichthyophagous Club was held yesterday at the office of the State Fish Commissioner, Mr. E. G. Blackford, in Fulton Market to arrange for the coming dinner of the club. Between the period of the last dinner and the present date the gentlemen who were at this meeting congratulated themselves on the fact that none were yet dead.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 30.--R.T. Ball, LL. D., F.R.S., Royal Astronomer of Ireland, visited Prof. Young to-day, and in the afternoon delivered to the Senior Class an entertaining lecture on his work in Dublin.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 30.--Among all the curious stories that the candidacy of James G. Blaine has brought out is that of his war substitute, living near the suburbs of this city. It seems that near the close of the late war, there was a call for six substitutes from men living in Maine who did not desire personally to enter the conflict, and the men were secured.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 30.--Last night Henry Van Patten, a young man of this city, came to his mother's house, in an intoxicated condition, with a dissolute woman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--Junius B. Wheeler, Professor of Civil and Military Engineering at the United States Military Academy, has been placed on the retired list of the army, and Capt. James Mercur, Corps of Engineers, appointed to the office thus vacated.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 30.--The October meeting of the Narragansett Driving Park Association was held at Narragansett Park to-day.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 30.--The great business house of Henry McCallum, carpet dealer, on Fifth-avenue, failed to-day for a large amount.
The Suffolk County Democrats held their County Convention at the Court House, Riverhead, yesterday afternoon. The Hon. Charles R. Street, of Huntingdon, presided.

PARIS, Oct. 1.--M. Herrison having resigned his portfolio as Minister of Commerce, Deputy Rouvier has been appointed to that office.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1.--One of the handsomest ladies in the "Adamless Eden Company," which played at the New-Haven House this week, was Miss E. Gertrude Gardiner, who played the role of Lady Demioner.

MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 1.--The meeting of Alabama lumbermen at Birmingham yesterday took steps to call a general convention of the millmen in Alabama, Georgia, and Mississippi, who ship to Northwestern markets. MOUNT WASHINGTON, N.H., Oct. 1.--The Glen House and all its outbuildings were totally destroyed by fire at 8 o'clock this evening. From all appearances nothing is saved. ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 1.--The election today passed off quietly. A light vote was polled. Henry G. McDaniels was elected Governor, W. A. fright Controller, Gen. R.V. Hardeman Treasurer, Clifford Anderson Attorney-General, and N.C. Barnett Secretary of State--all Democrats. Out of 7,000 votes not more than 800 were polled in this (Richmond) county. Logan had agreed to be in Worcester on Oct. 11, and great preparations were making for a Republican demonstration on that occasion, but a dispatch received to-night from Secretary Fessenden, announces that the National Committee has canceled Logan's appointments in the East. Mr. Blaine's stumping tour has at least proved how little even Americans know about their country. When he began it with that glowing eulogy on Worcester, Mass., the people outside of that favored spot learned for the first time now unfortunate they are, and how near Paradise really is to them. Before that few knew of Worcester at all, the general impression being that it was a dictionary instead of an elysium.

Mr. Mackaye told the young ladies and gentlemen that the actor's art was the greatest of all arts, and that they would succeed in their profession just in proportion to the general culture they strove to obtain.

LONDON, Oct. 3.--The Mincing-lane markets are quiet. Sugars are dull. The prices of Demerara sugar are low. Beet root sugar is steadier, and there are but few sellers. Prices for refined have further declined. Coffee is quiet but steady. Tea is quiet. At the public sales of new season's the previous prices prevailed. The sales of rice are slow.

A dispatch has been received in this city announcing the death of the Rev. George C. Athole, Rector of the Church of the Holy Innocents, at Rotherham, England, on Thursday. Mr. Athole left this city in April last, to visit his former home in Scotland, and was in hopes of regaining his health. He grew worse, however, and died Thursday from a complication of diseases.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 4.--An order in Council has been passed allowing steel for shovels and spades of not less tlian 11 or more than 18 wire gauge, and costing not less than $75 per ton of 2,240 pounds, to be imported free of duty by manufacturers of shovels and shades for the purpose of manufacture until the next session of Parliament begins.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct 4.--Mr. Richards, the Postmaster of Irish Creek, Ontario, identifies one of the men captured at Morristown yesterday as the man who shot him on Monday morning, after robbing his store, to avoid capture. The men give their names as William Hogan, Charles Lawrence, and Crawford. Two of them are from the United States and the other is from Canada.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 4.--Daniel Hollenbeck, a well known and prosperous farmer, left home yesterday, ostensibly to get medical relief from an ailment. To-day his body was found in the woods, he having hanged himself with his handkerchief. His mind became unsettled several years ago at a religious revival.

The independent Republicans have completed an organization in Brooklyn, composed of 100 gentlemen who have expressed their willingness to devote themselves to campaign work from the present time until election day.

The question as to the status of a mule in the animal kingdom is a much-mooted one here. An ordinance was passed by the Council some months since prohibiting certain animals, among them horses, from running at large within the city limits. Mules were omitted--accidentally, it is supposed.

Visitors at the Republican State National Headquarters who had been led by newspaper reports to believe that the demonstration in honor of Gov. Cleveland at Buffalo Thursday evening was in any way remarkable were yesterday invited to disabuse their minds of that impression.

BATH, Me., Oct. 4.--The three-masted schooner R.D. Bibber was launched to-day from the yard of George W. Johnson. Her dimensions are: Length, 162 feet; breadth, 35; depth, 13; tonnage, 767. She is owned by Mr. Johnson and others, of Batin, and will be commanded by Capt. B.E. Pinkhaus, of Booth Bay.
The sun was sinking behind the fertile slopes of Rumson Neck. The broad, shallow waters of the South Shrewsbury were hardly ruffled by the gentle breathing of a southwest wind.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 4.--The general assignment of George S. Hanes, a leading merchant of Niagara Falls in the hardware trade, was filed in the County Clerk's office here to-day. The Assignee is Henry C. Howard, President of the Bank of Niagara.

--As touching the antiquity of the lake dwellings of Proto-Helvetia, there is very little to be said. No medals, coins, or other relics whereby the date of their erection can even be approximately determined have been found.

Miss Jennie Blackman, of Mill Plain, (Danbury,) arose from her bed while asleep Monday night and wandered some distance from the house to a brook, in which she was found asleep in two feet of water, with her head resting on the bank. After being awakened she expressed herself ignorant of what had happened. Miss Blackman is 18 years of age, and has had attacks of somnambulism before.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 4.--The action of the Common Council at its regular meeting last night over the claims of several leading livery men for carriage hire for city officials during the visit of President Arthur to this city in August last, while en route to the Catskills, caused much comment to-day.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 4.--A large audience assembled in the Wieting Opera House last night to hear the New-York Opera, Company in "Prince Methusalem."

Hart, who left her residence No. 204 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, at 9 o'clock in the morning and had not returned at a late hour last night. Mrs. Hart is about 32 years old and has been a sufferer from hysteria for a long time.

The Union Pacific Railway Company, the Kansas Pacific Railway Company, and the Denver Pacific Railway and Telegraph Company were consolidated on Jan. 24, 1880, and formed into the present Union Pacific Railway Company.

CHESTER, Conn., Oct. 4.--A domestic tragedy of the saddest kind is being slowly enacted here. It is the dying from consumption of the 10 children of Frank Bushneil and wife, one of the best families in the place.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 4.--Advices have been received here by the Indian Department from British Columbia of rather an alarming nature. The Kitax Indians some time since handed Ahtah, one of their tribe, over to the authorities for the murder of J. Youmans, a trader.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4.--"I hope and believe that Cleveland will be elected President," said Passmore Williamson to a Philadelphia Times reporter, as he slowly walked along Chestnut-street, confessing the ravages of rheumatism.
COVINGTON, Oct. 4.--The racing was continued here to-day. The weather was warm, the track in better condition, and the attendance good.

Nellie Hastings, little daughter of Mr. Will and Carrie Hastings, of this place, lays claim to six living grandmothers--four great grandmothers and two grandmothers. The great grandmothers are Mrs. Mary Hastings, of Westchester, and Mrs. Susan Dougherty, of Londonderry; Mrs. Eliza Steadman and Mrs. Elizabeth Steel, of Freeport. The grandmothers are Mrs. Joseph Hastings and Mrs. George Steadman, of Freeport.

LONDON, Oct. 4.--It is given out that the membership of the proposed association for the protection of holders of American railway securities will not be limited to members of the Stock Exchange, but that bankers and merchants will be invited to join it.

LONDON, Oct. 4.--The total eclipse of the moon which occurred to-night was successfully observed throughout Europe, and proved a most interesting spectacle. It began at 9:33 P.M. and ended at 1:16 A.M.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Oct. 4.--At Noank last evening occurred an unusual event in the double golden weddings of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel B. Latham and Mr. and Mrs. Silas B. Latham. The two couples were married together 50 years ago. The Rev. Samuel R. Kuapp D.D., of NewYork, performed the second ceremony before 15 witnesses. The presents were numerous.

ALBANY, Oct. 4.--The Executive Committee of the American Canoe Association met here to-day and decided to hold the annual meet of 1885 at Grindstone island, in the St. Lawrence River, to begin Juily 24, and continue to Aug. 8. Various changes and modifications were made in the sailing regulations and in the association's by-laws. The visitors were given a banquet tonight by the Mohican Canoe Club, of this city.

WHEELING, West Va., Oct 4.--A special train on the Pan Handle Road, carrying Thomas A. Hendricks, collided with a hand car this morning at daylight, and John Feutz, a boy of 12 years, and Thomas Waldon, a trackman, were killed. Plumed Knights from this city were also on the train. No one on the train was injured. A heavy fog prevailing at the time caused the accident.

The annual Fall regatta of the Pioneer Boat Club took place yesterday from the boathouse, at the foot of Thirty-fourth-street, Brooklyn. The regatta was looked upon as a little matter of business to be disposed of before the elaborate festivities in the upper rooms of the boathouse, in which 50 men were to have a good time, could reasonably be enjoyed.

The Central Iowa Railway Company having made a default in the payment of interest due on its bonds on Oct. 1, John W. Weed, as the holder of five bonds, has begun a suit against the company for $150, and has procured, in Supreme Court, Chambers, an attachment against its property in this State.

The new iron steamship Portia, of the Newfoundland and New-York Steamship Company, left this port on her first outward trip on Friday. She is bound for Halifax and St. John's with a full cargo of general merchandise. She is the sister ship of the Miranda, which came out here a month ago.

Thomas W, Conoklin, aged 22, of No. 23 Wakeman-avenue, Newark, was reported to the police of this city last night as missing. On Thursday last he purchased a canoe in Williamsburg aud started to paddle to Newark.

Dr. John R. Cypert, of No. 656 Lexington-avenue, reported to the Health Department yesterday the death of John Gilmartin, a lad, which occurred on Friday morning at his parents' residence, No. 1,761 Avenue A, from hydrophobia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4.--A good many persons imagine that if they can pass a civil service examination they will step at once into a place in some one of the departments of the Government. The auction sale of a portion, of the Fox estate last June will be remembered as having been satisfactory to both sellers and buyers. PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 4.--The case of the United States against Sergt. Dennis Kelly was resumed this morning in the Circuit Court before Judges Webb and Colt. Judge Colt stated that the court had decided to take jurisdiction, the decision being based on the act of the Maine Legislature of 1871.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 2.--"The Republican Party found an empty Treasury, and now it has a surplus of $400,000,000." This is the boast made by Major Calkins, in a campaign speech in this State, and it has been the keynote of many a Democratic speech since.

The new Church of the Holy Rosary of the Blessed Virgin Mary, on One Hundred and Nineteenth-street, near Pleasant-avenue, was completely filled by the people of the parish at the dedication services at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning. Archbishop Corrigan officiated, attended by a large number of priests.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 5.--The Collector of the Port has been informed that under recent regulations of the department at Washington the importation of neat cattle into the United States is now confined to four ports on the Atlantic seaboard--Portland, Boston, New-York, and Baltimore--a discrimination against the entire South Atlantic and Gulf coast and all the Southern ports of the country.
