CLEVELAND, Oct. 5.--If any man in Ohio cares to hear about polities during the coming week he need not stir away from his own front gate. The Blaine procession will move continually, according to programme, while Senator Logan, accompanied by his wife, will also fill his manifold engagements.

Michael L. Flynn, proprietor of a hotel at No. 58 Whitehall-street, hung his waistcoat recently on the gaspipe in his bedroom and sat down in an easy chair to take a nap. He had dozed about five minutes when ha saw two young men vanishing through the door.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 5.--Sir John Macdonald has suddenly been called to England, and leaves here early this week, by way of NewYork, probably Tuesday, for London. Although the object of his visit is only known to a few of his intimate friends, it is believed that before his return to Canada he will be raised to the peerage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5.--Several weeks ago the Federation of Labor Unions of the District of Columbia passed a resolution denouncing Gov. Cleveland, and the Blaine organs spread the news broadcast with great glee as an evidence that the workingmen were for Blaine.

The Rev. Mr. Shilan preached in the Madison-Avenue Congregational Church (Dr. Newman's) yesterday morning. The Rev. Dr. Burchard, who was to have supplied the pulpit during Dr. Newman's Western trip, was unable to take charge of the services owing to sickness in his family. There was no evening service. One hundred and twenty persons were present yesterday morning. It is expected that Dr. Burchard will preach next Sunday.

The First Baptist Church, at Park-avenue and Thirty-ninth-street, was fairly well filled yesterday morning, when the new Pastor, the Rev. Isaac M. Haldeman, stepped before his congregation for the first time.

Early yesterday morning Thomas F. Huggard, of No. 83 Mercer-street, sat down upon a stoop to sleep off the effects of the numerous drinks he had taken. He says he awoke in time to see John Kenny, of No. 4 King-street, making off with his gold watch and chain and $19 in money. Officer Link, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, arrested Kenny and took him to the Jefferson Market Court.

The safe return of Lieut. Mason A. SHUFELDT, of the United States Navy, from his adventurous journey through hitherto unexplored regions of Madagascar is a subject of congratulation all the more hearty from the perils and narrow escapes which seem to have marked his undertaking.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 5.--The Republicans of Herkimer County yesterday nominated John M. Budlong, of Schuyler, for member of Assembly, Speaker Sheard declining to be a candidate for re-election. Caleb P. Miller was nominated for County Treasurer.
The growing tendency of American girls to marry coachmen is inexplicable to shallow observers. Such people are at a loss to know wherein consists the attraction of the coachman.

WADY HALFA, Oct. 5.--A remount depot of camels and horses is being formed here. Sir Charles Wilson has started for Dongola by camel. A messenger reports that Gen. Gordon has returned to Khartoum. The Robatat tribe dispersed on hearing of the death of their leader in the battle of Korti. Gen. Wolseley is at Wady Halfa, and is expected to remain for some time.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 5.--William J. Dowd, owner of the Derby House, on Templestreet, came near sacrificing the lives of eight human beings there early Saturday morning by means of coal gas escaping from an old and defective furnace in the cellar.

"I thank God," said the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher yesterday morning, "that when I grew up I chose to labor among the lowly. When I came here men said to me 'There's no necessity for your settling in Brooklyn. You ought to come over to New-York, where you can make more of a show.'
LONG BRANCH, Oct. 5.--A funeral long to be remembered in this place was that of Frank S. Chanfrau, the actor, which took place to-day at 1 o'clock at his late home in Cedar-avenue.

It was commission Sunday at the Rev. R. Heber Newton's church yesterday, and the Pastor preached in the morning on the life, character, teachings, and example of the man Jesus, and His place in the history of the world.

"I will have the pleasure of listening with you, this morning, to the Rev. Dr. Newman Hall, of London," said the Rev. Dr. Charles S. Robinson to his congregation at the Presbyterian Memorial Church, Madison-avenue and Fiftythird-street, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5.--The Board of Visitors to the Naval Academy for 1884 has made a report to Secretary Chandler. It is accompanied by a special report upon the conditions of admission to the Academy, prepared at the suggestion of the board by Mr. Eaton.
WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 5.--At Bellaire, Ohio, late Saturday night, after the procession, and after others had spoken, Mr. Blaine made the following speech:

NEWARK, Oct. 5.--It is now believed that the fate of Thomas W. Conkling, the clerk of Holmes Adams, of New-York, who started from Williamsburg to make a canoe trip to this city on Friday, is settled. His canoe was found floating bottom up in Newark Bay this afternoon. He lived with his parents at No. 27 Wakeman-avenue.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 5.--The last speaker at the Cleveland and Hendricks meeting Saturday night--Archibald M. Howe, of the Executive Committee of the Massachusetts independents-- made an address that amply repaid the independent Republicans present for waiting so long.

The supply of cranberries for the NewYork market will be much lighter this season than last, and that crop was much less than usual. The yield of cranberries this year in New-Jersey is fully as great as last season, although the quality of the berries is not so good.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 5.--The proposed biennial sessions amendment in Connecticut excites more interest in Hartford than anywhere else in the State, for the reason that its people want to have the Legislature in session here as long and frequently as possible on account of the money it brings.
The friends of Mrs. Henry I. Hart, of No. 204 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, who disappeared from her home at 9 o'clock Saturday morning, are convinced that she has committed suicide.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5.--Between 4 and 5 o'clock this morning a fire swept through Heacock's storage warehouse, Nos. 1,317 and 1,319 Brown-street, and nine adjacent houses were also destroyed by falling walls.
The report made by a majority of the Springer committee with reference to frauds committed by United States Marshals, Commissioners, Supervisors, and other Federal officers connected with the ...

Contrary to their intention, the Blaine party have been driven from one defensive position to another, and the one in which they find themselves quite as uncomfortable as in any other is that last chosen by them, namely, the maintenance of high taxation.

A notorious gang of roughs knonw as the Bridge gang, the scene of whose operations is the bride that spans the Morris Canal at the foot of Henderson-street, Jersey City, are responsible for a murder committed on Saturday night.
Jesse Collins, of No. 182 Ninth-avenue, had been drinking heavily for the past few weeks, and as a cansequence he was in the incipient stages of delirium tremens.

DULUTH, Minn., Oct. 5.--Another heavy rain last night injured the tracks of the St. Paul and Duluth and Northern Pacific near Fond du Lac, 16 miles from Duluth, so that a most serious accident occurred this morning.

A cloud of smoke and fire shot out of the windows on the third floor of the building at No. 46 West Fourteenth-street at about 7:30 o'clock last night, and in a moment the whole block between Fifth and Sixth avenues was as light as it ordinarily is in broad daylight.

ROME, Oct. 5.--There were 207 fresh cases of cholera and 126 deaths from that disease reported in Italy during the past 24 hours. Fortynine of the cases and 33 of the deaths were at Naples, and 20 cases and 20 deaths at Genoa.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5.--Herman Shaffer, of No. 332 Cherry-street, Camden, was arrested this afternoon by Lieut. Kelly and Officer Matlack, of that city, on a charge of passing counterfeit Bland dollars at Trenton. He was locked up and will be taken to Trenton to-morrow morning by Deputy United States Marshal A. Baird, ...
No census-taker will ever be able to determine how many Italians are packed in the four-story tenement house opposite the gas works at the foot of East One Hundred and Eleventh-street.

After the Ohio election the Republicans propose to "whoop it up" in great style in the State of New-York. All those gentlemen who have been dispensing campaign oratory for the benefit of the Ohioans will be impressed into service, and detailed for duty in the cities and towns of the State.

"How is the betting on the election?" was asked last night of a sporting man at one of the up-town resorts. "Well," was the reply, "there is no betting just now, and there won't be any more until after the Ohio election.

An old man sitting alone on a rock at the foot of East Eighty-ninth-street, just after 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, saw Jay Gould's big yacht the Atalanta heading toward him in the quiet stretch of water half a mile beyond Hell Gate.
PARIS, Oct. 5.--At the Longchamps races to-day a mob, dissatisfied with the riding of an English jockey named Sharpe, pulled him off his horse, and while on the ground brutally kicked and beat him.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6.--Gen. William T. Sherman arrived to-day at the Grand Pacific, with Miss Sherman, and left in the afternoon for Milwaukee to attend the wedding of Gen. Alexander McCook, who will be married on Wednesday to Miss Cole, a sister-in-law of Dr. Burns, United States Army, and a stepdaughter of ...

HOUGHTON, Mich., Oct. 6.--A serious fire is raging in the Calumet and Hecla mine at Calumet. The fire was started Saturday night. At this time the bodies of two persons, suffocated in the mine, have been recovered, and rumors are afloat that others are missing.

The Aldermen determined yesterday to take a fresh start in the matter of letting out Broadway for a horse railroad. Alderman Waite, almost immediately after President Kirk had rapped the board to order, presented a petition from the Broadway Surface Railroad Company for per mission to build a horse railroad from the Battery up Broadway to Fourteenthstreet.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 6.-- The town elections to-day throughout the State have resulted in Republican gains, and, on the whole, the party has reason to gather much encouragement from them, but in some localities the Democrats have made unexpected gains.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. , 6.--Some months ago Dr. Lockwood and wife, of Poughkeepsie, came to this city, stopping here and in several of the larger towns of Broome County, selling medicines.
NORWICK, Conn., Oct. 6.--F.W. Fenner, a large wholesaler and retailer of general merchandise and produce at Versailles, made an assignment to-day. The assets are said to be small.

BIRMINGHAM, Oct. 6.--The Hon. James Russell Lowell, American Minister to England, delivered the opening address at the Town Hall to-day, as President of the Midland Institute, upon the subject of "Democracy."
JACKSON, Miss., Oct 6.--The Republican Executive Committee met here to-day. I.T. Montgomery was appointed Elector in place of J.L. Alcorn, who refused to serve, and E.T. Jackson, vice J.N. Carpenter.

The Grand Jury for the October term was sworn in yesterday by Chief Clerk Sparks of the Court of General Sessions. Judge Cowing, in charging that body, said that the people should be congratulated on the fact that there was so little business just now to be prosecuted.

The Metropolitans are having a rough road to travel in order to win first honors in the American Association. They encountered the Toledo players on the Polo Grounds yesterday, in the presence of 2,000 persons, and it was generally conceded that the Mets would have an easy victory.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 6.--The failure of Emil Dahlheimer Co., jewelers, of Cincinnati, has caused much excitement among manufacturing jewelers of this city and Attleborough, who appear to have become involved to the extent of from $20,000 to $30,000.
MILWAUKEE, Wis, Oct. 6.--Daniel Wells, Jr., the plaintiff in the great suit of Wells against McGeoch, was examined before Court Commissioner Bicodgood to-day.
The finest programme of the meeting is offered for to-day by the American Jockey Club, as the six races have filed with a remarkbly fine lot of horses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6.--Mr. John R. McLean, editor and proprietor of the Cincinnati Enquirer, will be married to-morrow morning to Miss Emily T. Beale, daughter of Gen. E.F. Beale, of this city. The ceremony will be private and in the presence of only the immediate relatives of the two families at the residence of the bride's father, on Lafayette-square. The Rev. William A. Leonard, Rector of St. John's Episcopal Church, will officiate.

The announcement that the great master, John L. Sullivan, would " wind up" with Mr. Steve Taylor, of Jersey City, at that gentleman's benefit in Turn Hall last evening, brought out all the sporting characters of the city and agitated pugilistic circles as they have not been agitated since the recent fiasco at Madison-Square Garden.
TRENTOW, N.J., Oct. 6.--A general parade of the Cleveland and Hendricks clubs of this city, Chambersburg, Millham, Bordentown, and Burlington took place to-night.

The Ladies' Club for Out-Door Sports, of New-Brighton, Staten Island, held another field day yesterday. Two very close and well-played matches occurred during the day in the first and second rounds of the ladies' doubles.

When Charles F. Murphy, of No. 143 East Thirty-first-street, a driver in the employ of the Fourth-avenue railroad, went to the depot at Fourth-avenue and Thirty-second-street to take out his car, at 7 o'clock yesterday morning, he was so drunk that the starter would not permit him to go to work.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6.--"May Blossom," with the best part of the original Madison-Square cast, began its traveling season to-night at the Chestnut-Street Theatre, in the presence of a very large house, in spite of the exceedingly hot night.

There could be no better evidence of an utter lack of ammunition on the part of the opponents of Gov. CLEVELAND than is afforded by the so-called report of the Subcommittee of the Executive Committee of the Young Men's Republican Club of this city.
Dr. Cyrus Edson, of the Health Department, yesterday received a letter in which the writer said he had "a weakness for roasted chestnuts."
CHICAGO, Oct. 6.--Minnie Brooks, the notorious woman who was stabbed late Saturday night by the colored rough, Joe Williams, died from her wounds at 4 o'clock this morning.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6.--The Republicans are graciously furnishing railroad passes gratuitously to Ohio voters in Chicago and the West generally who desire to return to the Buckeye State and cast their ballots on Oct. 14.
It is asserted that Mr. John F. Plummer, who was conspicuous in the citizens' movement which nominated Allan Campbell for Mayor two years ago, will be nominated for Mayor by the Republicans.

HONG KONG, Oct. 6.--The French forces under Admiral Lespes, which began an attack upon Tamsui on Thursday, have captured and occupied that town, and Admiral Lespes has sent three battalions to effect a junction with Admiral Courbet at Kee-Lung.

NASHVILLE, Oct. 6.--James Stollings, a baker and confectioner, aged 28, and Hattie Allmond, aged 14 years, who eloped from Constitution, Ga., six miles north of Atlanta, were arrested here last night by direction of the Atlanta Chief of Police.
The following letter has been given out for publication by the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher: BROOKLYN, N.Y., Oct. 6 1884.

Mr. George Bliss, of Morton, Bliss Co., tucked his arm through that of a tall, cleanshaven, well-built gentleman yesterday afternoon in the Barge Office and the two walked around the big shed, threading their way between heaps of baggage, groups of excited Frenchmen and Frenchwomen, and blue-coated officials.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 6.--J.W. Rosenthal Co., the heaviest clothing dealers of Rochester, made a general assignment this morning.

The various departments of Columbia College opened yesterday, and the lectures will be commenced in a day or two. Sixty-three Freshmen have entered the academic department, and there are others yet to pass their examinations.

OLEAN, N.Y., Oct. 6.--The great Phillips oil well, in Butler County, which has demoralized the trade for weeks past by its constant and enormous yield of oil from sand where no such deposit was believed to exist, is ...
The report of the Board of Visitors to the Naval Academy calls attention to the unsatisfactory status of the naval cadet. In former days the students of the Academy were midshipmen.
ROME, Oct. 6.--During the past 24 hours there were 36 fresh cases of cholera and 12 deaths in Naples. In Genoa there were 27 fresh cases and 22 deaths during the same time.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 6.--A big Democratic demonstration took place at Holly Springs to-day, the chief feature of which was the speech of Senator L.Q.C. Lamar. He said he believed there existed a profound sentiment of discontent with the manner in which the National Government had been administered.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6.--Albert Hague, chief of the expedition sent out by the Geological Survey Department of the National Government to examine the geysers in the Yellowstone Park, survey the national preserve and make a report to the Government on its condition, arrived here from the West this morning.

The Veterans of the Seventh Regiment made arrangements to accommodate 200 of their members at their annual dinner last evening. There were, however, over 300 present when President Locke W. Winchester led the invited guests into the grand dining room of the Metropolitan Opera House.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Oct. 6.--The bituminous coal region about Bigler ana Wallacetown, Clearfield County, is excited about the disappearance of W.P. Norton and James Welsh, two sub-contractors employed by the constructors of the main line of the Beech Creek Clearfleid, and Southwestern Railroad.

Adolph Lablarth, a gentleman from France, who for some time has earned a living as au itinerant dentist, and who last lived at No. 217 Spring-street, has lately been possessed with the belief that he is heir to an enormous fortune, which he thought his father was trying to keep from him.

LONDON, Oct. 6.--Mr. Gladstone has issued a circular urging his supporters to attend the opening of Parliament, as he proposes at the earliest moment to submit important and pressing business for the consideration of that body.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 6.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruggles, Chief-Justice, and associates present, the following business was transacted:

William Dempsey was just in the act of stealing a horse and wagon yesterday from in front of No. 76 North Sixth-street, Brooklyn, when he was arrested by Policeman Riley. Dempsey made a desperate resistance, and the policeman was obliged to use his club.
Miss Libble Kirk, the serio-comic actress who disappeared from Trenton a few days ago, denies most emphatically that she eloped with a commercial traveler.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6.--If any proof were needed that the Blaine men dread the effect of the declaration for Cleveland made on Saturday night by President Oyster, of the Federation of Labor Unions, it could be found in the treatment he receives at the hands of the Blaine organs here.

The Tammany Hall Congressional Convertions were held throughout the city last night, and the programme arranged by the machine was carried out without any friction, the proceedings at all the meetings being concluded within a few minutes after the roll call was completed.

I. S. Wormser, the bankers, have been asking proxies in London and New-York to be used at the forthcoming election of the NewYork, Lake Erie and Western Railway. Simon Wormser said yesterday that the purpose was to vote the stock for John King, the prospective President, and other good men.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 6.--Hanford N. Hayes, one of the foremost of the contractors and builders of Bridgeport, dropped dead to-day in a store on Main-street, in that city. The doctors attribute the cause to heart disease brought on by overwork.

WELLSVILLE, Oct. 5.--The hurricane that passed through this part of Allegany County a week ago, the Democrats of Wellsville say, was only a forerunner of the great Cleveland cyclone that is to sweep down upon the Blaine Republicans of this region on the 4th of November.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 6.--The Thirtieth District Congressional Republican Convention will meet here to-morrow. Senator Charles S. Baker will receive the nomination without a doubt, as he has a clear majority of the delegates.

ALBANY, Oct. 6.--Richard T. Cook, of Paterson, N.J., a wealthy merchant, was seen here to-day acting in a strange manner. He approached the house of C.S. Lockwood, a friend, at if intending to enter, and then hastened away. Mr. Lockwood hurried out to greet him, but was ...
At the Fourteenth-Street Theatre last evening Miss Minnie Palmer restored to the American public those charms which have recently been captivating the hearts of the English.
The steam yacht Atalanta, after her return to Irvington on Sunday evening, was carefully examined and her injuries were found to be very slight.
BOSTON, Oct. 6.--The earnings of the Union Pacific Railway Company's entire system for August is $2,430,155.46, a decrease from August of last year of $47,246.74; the expenses ...

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 6.--A special dispatch to the News from Mount Carmel says that a desperate contest between two lovers of a young girl named Rosie Andrigo, daughter of a well-to-do coal operator, took place to-day in her parlor.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6.--A.T. Andreas, a map and directory publisher at No. 42 Montauk Block, had a confession of judgment against him entered in the Superior Court to-day in favor of Daniel B. Tolman for $6,784.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6.--The General Passenger Agents of the roads running east from Chicago met here to-day to consider the notice of the Grand Trunk that it had reduced its rates to Buffalo to $11 first class and $8 second class, because the Michigan Central had been cutting rates. It was finally decided that all the roads should adopt these rates.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 6.--"I think they are getting ready for a game on this wheat. There's a hen on somewhere," remarked a commission man, speaking to THE TIMES'S correspondent on Change to-day.

The Executive Committee of the Academy of Music Directors met yesterday afternoon at the office of Clarence A. Seward and ratified the motion adopted at the stockholders' meeting on Thursday evening last to assess the stockholders in aid of Col. Mapleson.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 6.--Samuel Roberts, the defaulting paymaster, was put on trial before the Presbytery of Lackawanna County to-day.

At a regular meeting of the Brooklyn Common Council, yesterday, a report was presented by the Committee on Railroads in reference to the application of tho Nassau Cable Railway for permission to build its road on certain streets of the city.
Adam Flach attempted to commit suicide by hanging himself to a clothes hook in his room, at No. 369 First-avenue, yesterday. He was arrested and was arraigned in the Yorkville Court.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 3.--This busy city of about 30,000 inhabitants, and with a vote of about 6,000 when it is all brought out, was repeatedly referred to by Republicans in Indianapolis as one in which would be found a large number of instances to illustrate the remarkable change said to be going on in the Democratic Party.

The danger of rambling through Central Park during the late hours was forcibly impressed upon the police authorities by the experience of Alvin L. Smith, a visitor from Nebraska, who was shot and robbed by a highwayman in the Park on Sunday night.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 6.--A frightful collision occurred on the Rock Island Road a quarter of a mile east of Commerce Mills, and seven miles west of this city, this afternoon.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 6.--John McCullough's friend, Dr. James M. Keller, of Hot Springs, arrived here this morning and immediately sought the presence of the tragedian.

Mr. Stanton, the Secretary of the Metropolitan Opera, House Company, received a letter from Dr. Damrosch yesterday, giving the full list of soloists included in the company he has engaged for the Metrepolitan.
ALBANY, Oct. 6.--Vreeland H. Youngman was nominated for member of Assembly in the Second District to-day by the Burlingame or anti-Draper Republican Committee.
PARKERSBURG, West. Va., Oct. 6.--Blaine's party left wheeling this morning. After making several shert speeches at small towns he arrived at Grafton, where he spoke as follows:

There is little doubt that the score of fires that occurred in Edgewater, Staten Island, between Friday and Sunday were caused by an organized gang of incendiaries.

ALBANY, Oct. 6.--Before he started for the North Woods, Gov. Cleveland stated that the charges preferred by the Roosevelt Committee against Sheriff Alexander V. Davidson, of NewYork, would receive careful attention from him as soon as they were reached in the regular order of business in the office.

"Boccaccio" is one of the prettiest of the light operas of the period, and its representation by Mme. Geistinger and her associates at the Thalia Theatre is to be remembered as a performance of uncommon artistic excellence as well as vivacity and brilliancy.

Two wild steers created the wildest commotion in the north section of lower Jersey City yesterday. It is not an unusual thins for droves of cattle to be driven through crowded thoroughfares in Jersey City to and from the Central Stock Yards. It was from such a drove, headed for Newark, that the two steers broke yesterday afternoon.

The Etruria, another new steamship for the Cunard Line, was recently launched at the yard of John Elder Co., on the Clyde. She is a sister ship of the Umbria, which was launched last June, bnt which has not yet made her maiden voyage.
HONESDALE, Penn,, Oct. 6.--George Dolling, a miner in the employ of the Delaware and Lackawanna Company, caught a young rat in the mine some weeks ago. He took it home and made a pet of it.

At midnight on Oct. 2 John Devine was alone, behind the bar of his saloon, at No. 1,090 Third-avenue, when a broad-shouldered goodlooking young fellow entered and called for a glass of beer. He drank the liquor, threw a nickle on the counter, and walked to another part of the room.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6.--Information was received this afternoon to the effect that the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company had been given notice by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company that it would on and after Oct. 12 be deprived ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 6.--The Board of Aldermen received the report of their Finance Committee to-night and rejected the scheme which the Derby Railroad Directors offered for a readjustment and scaling down of the debt which the railroad owes the city.

William Johnson, alias " Henry Peckham," alias " T.R. Moore," was charged yesterday, in the Court of General Sessions, with entering the room of Thomas Desmond, in Sweeny's Hotel, on Sept. 25, and attempting to steal $170 from the pocket of his trousers.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., Oct. 6.--Andrew Starin, of Stone Ridge, this county, was showing his companions a dynamite cartridge on Sunday when it exploded, ruining both his hands and injuring his body. He did not know it was loaded.

The first night of the new season at the Union-Square Theatre was a pleasant occasion. There were warm greetings for old friends as the faces of Miss Jewett, Mrs. Phillips, and Miss Harrison, Mr. Parselle,Mr. Stoddart, Mr. Whiting, and Mr. Fawcett were disclosed in the progress of the play, and a cordial welcome was tendered to the newcomers--Mr. John H. Barnes, from London, and Mr. John B. Mason, from Boston.

MONTREAL, Oct. 6.--Sir John Macdonald, Premier of Canada, left last night for New-York, and will sail for England bY the Cunard steamship Oregon on Wednesday. Sir John states that he is suffering from gastric catarrh, and ...

CAIRO, Oct. 6.--Major Kitchener telegraphs that the whole of Col. Stewart's party has been murdered, Col. Stewart, with his party, were stranded on the rocks in the cataract at Wady Garna, and had requested the Mudir of Dongola to send him assistance a few days ago.
LONDON, Oct. 6.--The Mackay-Bennett cable, which was recently laid between Europe and America, is broken. It is supposed that the breakage was caused by icebergs.

The charge of official prostitution against Mr. BLAINE rests on strong evidence from various quarters. Unfortunately there is too much in the career and character of the man that sustains it to allow of its being lightly dismissed.
The Hon. R.P. Flower will preside at the Cleveland and Hendricks demonstration on the Sub-Treasury steps Thursday afternoon. Ex-Lieut.-Gov. Dorsheimer, ex-Gov. Salomon, and A.S. Sullivan will speak.

A firebrand was thrown into the Republican County Committee, at its meeting last night, in the shape of the following resolution, which was presented, at the direction of the Executive Committee, by Chairman William H. Townley:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6.--Mr. Blaine's followers here have been and heard a good many discouraging things since their leader opened his "aggressive" campaign, but to-day they are a little more downhearted than usual.
There were many statements in Wallstreet yesterday as to the terms at which the new Louisville and Nashville Railroad securities would be offered.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7.--The leave of absence granted First Lieut. John Bigelow, Jr., Tenth Cavalry, in special orders of July 21, has been extended to Nov. 15. Leave of absence for two months, on Surgeon's certificate of disability, has been granted First Lieut. Adolphus W. Greely, Fifth Cavalry, Acting Signal Officer.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 7.--The heavy rains of the past few days seemed to have put a stop to the work of the incendiaries, and the citizens were lulled into the belief that the scare was over.

Two tie games of baseball were played in this vicinity yesterday. The Metropolitan and St. Louis nines struggled for nine innings on the Polo Grounds without either gaining a run. At Washington Park, in Brooklyn, the Brooklyn and Toledo players scored 4 runs each, when darkness put a stop to the game in the eighth inning.
The difficulty with which honest Republicans accept Mr. BLAINE for the sake of the party increases. We predicted that it would be so when he was nominated.
John Kelly received some threatening letters soon after the Chicago Convention, a particularly insolent one coming from Baltimore.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct.7.--The NewYork Universalist Convention assembled here to-day. A large number of clergymen were present, and were welcomed in an address by the Rev. T.H. Squire, of this place.

The Produce and Maritime Exchange Cleveland and Hendricks Club has engaged the Academy of Music for next Wednesday evening, when, with other organizations, it will receive Gov. Cleveland, who has arranged to be present.
BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 7.--The opening this afternoon of the October meeting at Beacon Park was well attended. Two races comprised the programme.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 7.--The officers of the Hampden Mutual Fire Assurance Company, of this city, have decided that it is best to close up the company's business, and General Agent S.C. Warriner has issued a circular calling in the policies, which now number 700 or 800. The losses by the fire at the Newton Paper Mill, at Holyoke, are the immediate cause of this step. The policy holders will all receive their return premiums.

Adolph Dessar, Joseph B. Dessar, David Dessar, and Edward Wise, composing the firm of Dessar, Wise Co., clothing merchants, at No. 557 Broadway, who recently failed, were arrested yesterday by the Sheriff on an order of arrest ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7.--The wife of William S. Watkins, of East Main-street, Bridgeport, eloped with a Boston drummer yesterday. Her husband had no suspicion of her design, and did not investigate till she had been gone for several hours. It is not known where the eloping couple went, but it is thought they are in New-York.

A hearty welcome was tendered to each member of Mr. Daly's company last evening, and in receiving Miss Rehan, Mrs. Gilbert, Mr. Lewis, and Mr. Drew the audience forgot the conventionalities and broke into cheers.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 7.--A little son of a German farmer named Kohlman was killed in a very peculiar way yesterday. The boy's sister, 10 years old, playfully threw a pumpkin, which struck him in the stomach. He became very sick and died in a few hours.

The annual meeting of the Clearing House Association took place yesterday. The transactions for the year ending Sept. 30 were as follows: Exchanges, $34,092,037,337 78; balances, $1,524,930,993 93: total, $35,616,968,331 71; average ...

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., Oct. 7.--A fire broke out this morning under the stage of the Grand Opera House. When the alarm was given the flames had gained much headway, and it was at once seen that it was impossible to save the building or its contents.
PARIS, Oct. 7.--It is evident that the cholera epidemic in France is rapidly subsiding, the number of deaths from the disease in the whole country to-day only reaching eight.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7.--The Hon. E.M. Chapin, of New-Hartford, for long years a Republican, was last week renominated by the Republicans for town Treasurer.
BATAVIA, N.Y., Oct. 7.--The Democrats of the Thirty-first District met in convention here to-day and unanimously renominated Col. R.S. Stevens, of Attica, for Congress.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 7.--Gov. Thomas M. Waller spoke at the Cleveland and Hendricks rally in Carll's Opera House to-night. He was at his best, and was literally showered with applause from a great audience.

CAIRO, Oct. 7.--M. Barrere, the French Diplomatic Agent, has received a telegram stating that M. Herbin, the French Consul at Khartoum, was killed at the same time Col. Stewart and his party were massacred by Arabs.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7.--Ex-Speaker Randall, who camp to the city on private business this morning, attended the Farmers' Club dinner, at A.J. Cassatt's residence, and came in this evening to take the night train on the Shenandoah Valley Railroad for Roanoke, Va., where he will speak to-morrow.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 7.--George Turner, the youth who on Saturday last killed Ernest Gibson and fatally injured James Livingstone, has been vindicated by the Coroner's jury.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7.--A dispatch from Harrisburg announces that the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania has affirmed the finding of the Court of Quarter Sessions of this city that Dr. Albert G.F. Goerson is guilty of murder in the first degree.

MERIDEN, Conn., Oct. 7.--It was announced recently in the New-York Staats Zeitung that six human bodies or skeletons had been discovered in a cellar of a tavern in Turzig, a Prussian town, by the recent purchaser of the place, while he was making some improvements.

EPHRATA, Penn., Oct. 7.--Joe Buzzard, Willam Weidner, and Diller Clark, all notorious characters, and members of the famous Buzzard gang, of the Welsh Mountains, who are now confined in the Lancaster County Jail for crimes committed some years ago near this village, will all be released next Saturday, having served their time.
LONDON, Oct. 7.--Earl Granville, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, has issued a circular to the Liberal peers urging their attendance at the opening of Parliament.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 7.--John Lidle, aged 18, in the employ of J.B. Simon, a grocer, went to the stable of his employer yesterday to take care of a horse.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 7.--Ex-Assemblyman David Healy, chief clerk of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, was removed from office this afternoon by Commissioner Peck for malfeasance.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 7.--Before Judge Colburn, in the Equity Session of the Supreme Court, to-day, Richard S. Greenough and James G. Smith, of New-York, who have been appointed Receivers of the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company in New-York, Ohio, Illinois ...

DETROIT, Oct. 7.--No contrast could be stronger to indicate the degree of enthusiasm felt by two parties than the Blaine meeting in this city last night and the St. John meeting held this evening. Both were held in the same building, the Detroit Opera House.
ALBANY, Oct. 7.--The decision of the Court of Appeals to-day in the case of John Baird against the Mayor, c., of the City of NewYork, involves a judgment against the city of about $1,500,000.

Three little 15-year-old robbers stood up defiantly before Justice Duffy, at the Tombs Police Court, yesterday. One had a turned-up nose, another crafty eyes, and the third a face which was the personification of budding wickedness.
The Society for Psychical Research has published a series of reports which are of no little interest. They are occupied chiefly with accounts of experiments in "thought transference."

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 7.--The Hudson River Baptist Association North opened its thirty-fourth annual meeting in the First Baptist Church this morning. Lewis E. Gurley, of Troy, was chosen Moderator. The opening sermon was by the Rev. J.M. Bruce, of Hudson, on "The Relation of Baptists to Freedom of Thought." Over 300 clergymen and lay delegates were present.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7.--From interviews had to-day with delegates to the International Prime Meridian Conference and American scientists who have taken an active interest in the subject it is believed that the conference will fail to arrive at any agreement with regard to a common prime meridian.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 7.--One of the largest political meetings of the campaign on the Western Reserve was held here last night ...

In explaining his reasons yesterday for resigning from the Republican Electoral ticket, Dr. William E. Forest said that after a careful examination of Mr. Blaine's record as a public man he could not make up his mind to vote for him.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 7.--This morning while a number of mountaineers were standing about the United States court room, waiting to be called as witnesses in the moonshining distillery cases, an officer stepped up and laying his hand upon the shoulder of a roughly dressed young fellow said, "You are wanted for murder."
CHICAGO, Oct. 7.--George A. Cramer, for two years in the employ of C. Hoffman, No. 187 Madison-street, as cashier, bookkeeper, and confidential clerk, is wanted by his late employer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7.--Much talk has been heard here about the importation into Ohio of men from Washington who will be expected to cast fraudulent votes at next week's election.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 7.--A convention of the Republicans of the Sixteenth Congressional District was held at the Court House in this city to-day for the nomination of a candidate for Congress.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 7.--Although the accounts of the Cornell "rush" of last Saturday have been exaggerated, nobody having been seriously injured, the authorities have thought best, in view of the danger attending such affairs, to take a decided stand in the matter. President White has summoned the officers of ...
CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 7.--The visible supply of grain, Oct. 4, as compiled by the Secretary of the Chicago Board of Trade, is as follows:
SANDUSKY, Ohio, Oct. 7.--John Conley, of Huron Township, this county, committed suicide to-day by shooting.

The Committee of One Hundred, organized by the independent Republicans of Brooklyn to carry on the campaign in that city against Blaine and Logan, has selected R.S. Bussing, Jr., as Chairman of the Campaign Committee, and W. J.D. Campbell as Secretary.

The brig F.J. Merryman arrived here yesterday with only three of her original crew. The vessel, however, fell in with a distressed German bark, whose crew abandoned her and took refuge on the brig, which they brought into port.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 7.--The first of a series of four joint discussions upon the political issues of the day, between the Hon. W.H. Calkins, Republican candidate for Governor of Indiana, and Col. Isaac P. Gray, Democratic candidate for the same office, was held here this afternoon. A great crowd assembled in and around the Court House yard, to listen to the debate, which was held from a stand erected upon the Court House steps.
COLUMBUS, Ga., Oct. 7.--The crop report to the end of September shows that cotton was greatly injured by the drought that prevailed over nearly the entire State during the month of September.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 7.--The United States steamer Standish is achieving a reputation for bursting great guns. This afternoon, at 5:15 o'clock, the second one within a year was burst to pieces.

The opponents of the scheme to build a railroad through Thirty-eighth and Thirtyninth streets from river to river descended upon the Railroad Committee of the Aldermen yesterday and entered their protest.

ST. MARY'S, West Va., Oct. 7.--After reviewing the procession at Parkersburg last evening, Mr. Blaine went to Marietta, Ohio, to attend a meeting there. He remained all night at Marietta, and was ferried across the Ohio River to Williamstown, where he met his special train at 8:30 this morning.

LONDON, Oct. 7.--This was the second day of the Newmarket second October meeting. The race for the Cesarewitch Stakes was won by Mr. J. Hammond's 3-year-old b.c. St. Gatien, who ran a dead heat with Harvester for the Derby.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 7.--Mrs. Georgiana Heustis, about 35 years of age, was arrested today on a requisition from the Governor of NewYork on a charge of fraudulently obtaining diamonds to the value of $20,000 from Theresa Lynch, a diamond broker on Broadway.
Some months ago John J. Clancy, a member of the Brooklyn Board of Education, wrote a letter to the local papers in which he denounced as scandalously excessive a charge of ...

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 7.--A large St. John meeting was held in the opera house this evening. It was addressed by A.A. Hopkins, editor of the American Reformer and Rural Home. About 1,500 persons were present. B.N. Payne, an ironmaster, presided. Prayer was offered by the Rev. Thomas Stacy, of Canton, Penn. Mr. Hopkins arraigned the Republican Party for insincerity to the temperance cause and denounced the Republican candidates. There was much enthusiasm.

Mrs. McElrath, of No. 120 Navy-street, Brooklyn, who has for two years been living quietly with a juvenile family of three children, has just doubled her family and presented a not very willing liege lord with three bouncing sons.

When FRANK A. FLOWER, of Madison, Wis., dishonorably ignored the request made by Senator EDMUNDS, that a letter which he had sent to him should be regarded as "private," and attempted to deceive the people of the United States by ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 7.--The difficulty among the 800 laborers on the Exposition buildings was adjusted to-day by Manager William B. Schmidt. The hour of nooning was allowed the men, and work was resumed. No further trouble is apprehended.

The arrangements for the grand Cleveland and Hendricks parade and mass meeting in Union-square to-morrow evening have been practically completed. According to the reports already received by Gen. Martin T. McMahon, the Grand Marshal, over 20,000 men will be in line and several Assembly districts yet to be heard from will probably swell the total to 25,000.
The Cambiaggio-Sieni Italian opera troupe will begin a season of three weeks at the Star Theatre Oct. 21.
DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 7.--In the game played here to-day between the New-Yorkers and the Detroit nine the former were defeated by a score of 1 to 5.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 7.--The Senior Class at meeting this noon elected T. Pershing, of Pottsville, Penn., class President for this year. They also elected W.J. Greene, W.W. Connor, and R.S. Lawrence as a committee to attend to the class photographs.

Mrs. Cornelia Dick, wife of Capt. Phil Dick, pilot of the tugboat Millard, living at No. 225 West Houston-street, was charged in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday with being a habitual drunkard.

Articles incorporating the Mutual News Company have been filed in the office of the Secretary of State, with a capital of $500,000. The company proposes to transact a general business throughout the United States, the Dominion of Canada, and Mexico.

LONDON, Oct. 7.--Advices received here state that the steamship Miramar, while on a voyage from Yokohama for Honk Kong, foundered at sea. All hands on board were lost, with the exception of two Chinamen.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7.--The rigors of the arctic climate are exemplified in the condition of Lieut. Henry I. Hunt, of the United States Navy. Lieut. Hunt was one of the officers who accompanied the expedition under Commander Schley to the north pole in search of Greely.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 7.--George Franck, of Orange, who figured conspicuously in the Phoebe Paulin murder case, was locked up in the Essex County Jail to-day on a charge of attempting to outrageously assault Mrs. Hettinger, of Orange.

The suit for absolute divorce brought by Domingo M. Mongo, Vice-President of the Toledo, Ann Arbor and Michigan Railroad Company against his wife, Kate Mongo, was called for trial yesterday before Justice Bartlett in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn.

The following are the entries for the cup race at the track of the New-York Driving Club to-day at 3 P.M., members to drive to top road wagons: B.g. Brarius, b.g. Hawthorne, b.m. Nellie King, b.m. Jessie Walter, br.h. Lantern, blk.g. Mark Twain, b.g. Lonsdale, br.m. Miss Leland, s.m. Mountain Maid, and ch.g. Crosby. The grand stand is free to the public.

Miciella Darreta, of No. 423 East One Hundred and Eleventh-street, was held in the Harlem Court Yesterday to await the action of the Coroner in the case of Francisco Camsomie, who died on Monday from wounds received in a quarrel among a number of Italians on Sunday night.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 7.--A snake story, with the necessary affidavits, comes in from the farm of John Yard, eight miles from this city on the Brunswick pike.

ALBANY, Oct. 7.--Gov. Cleveland will go to New-York on private business on Wednesday of next week and will remain until Thursday afternoon, when he has promised to be present at a demonstration to be held in Brooklyn.
Mr. Tilden has sent the following letter to the special committee of the Democratic Natonal Convention, which presented that body's complimentary resolutions to him:
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 7.--The annual cane spree between the Sophomore and Freshman classes took place last evening.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7.--An antiBlaine club has been organized among the Amherst College students, with 75 names on the roll. It is known that 50 more will be added. The college has formerly been almost solidly Republican.
COVINGTON, Ky., Oct. 7.--The fourth day of the Latonia Jockey Club's Fall meeting attracted a good attendance. The weather was warm and pleasant and the track a trifle deep.

The attempt of JOHN J. O'BRIEN, through the Republican County Committee, of which he is Chairman, to open the way for packing the primaries of the party in this city makes perfectly plain his designs in the local contest.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 7.--Returns from all but 18 towns give a total vote of 42,593 on the biennial sessions amendment, with a majority for the amendment of 15,701. Returns from 144 towns show that the Republicans control the Boards of Registration in 72, the Democrats in 49, and 23 are equally divided. This is no material change from last year.
After two unsuccessful attempts on account of rainy weather, the military authorities of this city succeeded in formally opening the new military parade ground in Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 7.--The Republican Convention for the Thirtieth Congressional District met this morning with James Harris, of Penfield, as Chairman, and 174 delegates present.

MACON, Mo., Oct. 7.--The Republican State Convention, in opposition to the Fusionists, met here to-day and organized. John Jeffery, of Boone County, was elected Chairman, and William P. Beech, of Macon County, Secretary. The following State ticket was nominated:

BOSTON, Oct. 7.--A well attended meeting of the stockholders of the New-York and New-England Railroad Company was held today for the purpose of taking such action as might be deemed expedient in relation to extricating it from its embarrassments.

Robert H. Ramsgate, the diamond polisher, who was arrested in New-York for bigamy, was taken into Judge McGill's court, on Jersey City Heights, yesterday for trial. He had on his first arraignment pleaded not guilty to the charge of having unlawfully married Mary J. Bogue before Justice of the Peace ...

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7.--The grand three days' cricket match between the Gentlemen of Philadelphia and the United States team, which was begun at Nicetown on Saturday, terminated to-day in a victory for the former, after a hard struggle, by three wickets.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 7.--Hendford Hayes, an old resident, dropped dead here yesterday from apoplexy, aged 65.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7.--A line of cheap herdic cabs was put on here yesterday by a Boston company. They are four-wheelers, and will carry four passengers.

It was night--night before last, Midnight had just pealed from a hundred city towers. An electric light, burned dimly in a wretched cabaret on the corner of Universityplace and Eighth-street. At a narrow table two men were seated engaged in eager conversation.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 7.--John McCullough left here this morning for New-York. At Columbus he will meet Capt. William Conner, his former manager, who is en route to that city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7.--When the late Secretary Folger was at the head of the Treasury Department one of his closest and most confidential friends was Mr. J.B. Butler, who occupied the position of chief of the appointment division in the department during nearly the whole of Secretary Folger's incumbency.

William P. McDonald, a member of the County Democracy, was crowding men in the Superior Court yesterday to be naturalized when Officer Simmons, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, ordered them to keep back.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 7.--At the City Hospital last night, in the presence of but two or three friends, Matt O'Reardon, one of the most popular song writers of recent years, died.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 7.--The village of Horseheads, a suburb of Elmira, is much disturbed over a movement which is on foot to have its name changed to North Elmira.

The Court of Appeals has sustained the decision of Chief-Justice McAdam, of the City Court, that the persons hurt in the panic on the Brooklyn bridge on Decoration Day, 1883, and the Administrators of the persons then killed cannot recover damages against the bridge Trustees.

At the instance of Andrew Ruehl, one of the proprietors of the Windsor Market, kept by Ruehl Merkel, at Nos. 646 and 648 Sixth-avenue, Patrolman Jagles, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, on Monday evening arrested Raimon Carrio, a Cuban, who claims to live at No. 262 West Forty-seventh-street.

Two strangers rang the bell at Busch's Hotel, in Hoboken, at 3 o'clock yesterday morning. The porter admitted them, and they went from room to room in so daring a manner that the porter thought they must be robbers and had them arrested.

LONDON, Oct. 7.--Louisa Devey, the Executrix of Lady Lytton, publishes her private correspondence with the late Lord Lytton to vindicate the character of the dowager from the inaccuracies that occur in the recent biography.
The following table shows the registration in this city yesterday and comparisons of that of previous years:

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 7.--The ninth Episcopal Congress of the United States met this morning in this city. The first service was a communion at St. John's Church, after which the regular session began at Whitney's Opera House. Bishop Harris presided and delivered the welcome address.

The rooms of the Detective Bureau presented the appearance last night of a small jewelry establishment. On the desk were scattered a number of gold and silver watches, gold chains, breastpins, scarf pins, and a miscellaneous assortment.
Yesterday was a glorious day for racing, and Jerome Park benefited by it, for the sporting community turned out in great numbers and flocked to the beautiful course at Fordham.

PORT JERVIS, Oct. 6.--A wealthy middleaged widower named Dominick Mines, owns a farm on the border of Wayne and Luzerne Counties, Penn. It is occupied by a farmer named Obert, and Mines boarded there with his family. Obert's daughter Lena is a pretty girl of 18 years.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 8.--Quite a sensation was created to-day by the fact becoming known that a number of the members of the Board of Education were organized to make a fight on the book publishing house of Van Antwerp, Bragg Co., whose representatives have ...

When the Metropolitan Elevated Railroad Company began, in 1882, its suit against the Manhattan and New-York Companies to have the merger agreement set aside, S.H. Kneeland, who was then its President, joined it as a plaintiff.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8.--Dr. Walter H. Zinc was assaulted last night at his own home in Branford, where he now lies at the point of death. Dr. Zinc, who is a trial Justice, returned home about 11 o'clock, and, as is his custom, went to the dining room. Afterward he picked up a paper and while reading fell asleep, his head dropping upon the table.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8.--Gen. John A. Logan left Washington at 8:20 this morning for this city accompanied by a delegation from the Philadelphia Young Republican Club. Although the train stopped for some time at the Baltimore Union Station there was no crowd present to receive the Senator and his escort.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 8.--"The most colossal liar of the nineteenth century," was the name applied to-night to Blaine by ex-Mayor William G. Thompson, of Detroit, in his speech at the Opera House, before the independents and Democrats of Ann Arbor.

PARIS, Oct. 8.--An official dispatch from Hanoi to-day states that Col. Donnier, with two battalions of the Foreign Legion, two companies of infantry, and a section of mountain artillery, had an engagement with Chinese troops in the Valley of the Loo Chuan River which lasted six hours.

Mrs. Georgiana Heustis, who is under arrest in Boston for obtaining diamonds to the value of nearly $20,000 from Theresa Lynch, a diamond broker of No. 925 Broadway, this city, by fraudulent representation, will probably not be brought here for several days, if at all.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 8.--A special from Warsaw, Wyoming County, says: "The coal office of Nobles Son, at Perry, was broken into last night and the safe blown open. Twentyone thousand dollars in Arkansas Levee bonds, $25,000 in bonds and mortgages, and $75 in cash were taken. The safe in Tomlinson's mill was blown open and $150 in cash taken. At Sweet's meat market, which they also broke open, the burglars got $150."

Reports sent to Congress last Spring by the Commissioner of the General Land Office proved that millions of acres of public land had been stolen by a fraudulent use of the Homestead, Pre-emption, and Timber Culture acts.

BOSTON, Oct. 8.--Private advices from the Superintendent of the Calumet and Hecla mine say that no damage has been done to the mine, that there were no gas explosions, and that the mill continues in operation as usual.

CAIRO, Oct. 8.--Advices from Dongola state that the Mudir of the place is sending out spies to assist the Nile expedition. The Sheiks from the Khartoum and Shendy district, with 500 of their followers, have submitted to the Mudir.

ELROY, Wis., Oct. 8.--At the Wisconsin annual Conference of the Church of the United Brethren in Christ, representing a membership of about 2,000, which has just been held at Monroe, Greene County, the following resolutions were passed:

Among other decisions handed down by the General Term of the Supreme Court was one that interests the well-known actor Dion Boucicault, and grew out of his connection with the theatre formerly known as the Park Theatre, in this city.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 8.--The regular monthly meeting of the Board of Directors of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company was held at its central building this morning, Mr. William F. Burns in the chair. The usual semi-annual dividends of 5 per cent. on the main stem and 5 per cent. on the Washington branch were declared, payable Nov. 1, at the office of the Treasurer in Baltimore.
BUFFALO, Oct. 8.--The Republican Convention of the Second Assembly District of Erie County was held to-day, and Frank Sipp was nominated for re-election. He made a speech accepting the nomination.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8.--Sarah Coyle, who was a laundress in the Morosini household at Yonkers, and who was Miss Victoria Morosini's confidante in her love affair with the coachman, Schelling, has been in Chicago, but has recently left for the more remote West.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 8.--At a meeting of the Straightout Republican State Committee held here to-day Gen. W.C. Wickham, the Hon. J.F. Dezendorf, and A.B. Cock tendered their resignations as Electors on the State Electoral ticket.

The Canadian Minister of Justice, addressing the Montreal Board of Trade on Tuesday, said there was only one obstacle to the conclusion of a new Anglo-American treaty of extradition--the American unwillingness to concede that an extradited person can be prosecuted only for the offense for which he is pursued and surrendered.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8.--When Pension Commissioner Dudley returned to Ohio and Indiana, after his two days' visit to his office here, it was stated that among his forces in the West was a brigade of special Pension Examiners and
An official statement has been issued showing that 96,688,992 passengers were carried by all the elevated railway lines of this city during the year ending Sept. 30, 1884.

Henry Odell, a diminutive and married grocery clerk living on Corbin-street, Jersey City Heights, has disappeared. So has Mrs. Hall, the tall, robust, and shapely wife of the chief engineer of the Galveston steamer Lampasos.

A largely attended meeting, held under the auspices of the Cleveland and Hendricks War Veterans' Association of Kings County, took place last evening in Music Hall, at Flatbush and Fulton avenues, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8.--Within the last 48 hours the news received here from Ohio through private sources has been so cheering to the Democrats that they are beginning to offer wagers that the Republicans will lose the State.
COVINGTON, Ky., Oct. 8.--A heavy rain fell before the first race, which made the track stiff. The weather was warm and the attendance good.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8.--Richard Trenke, the dissolute German printer who shot and instantly killed Mrs. Augusta Zimm, at the corner of Fourth and Willow streets, last night, was given a hearing at the Seventh District station house this morning.

BUFFALO, Oct. 8.--The State Convention of the Woman Suffrage Party began its session in this city to-day. Several counties were represented, but the attendance was not large. The convention was organized by the election of Albert O. Wilcox, of Richmond County, President, ...

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 8.--The arrangements for the reinterment of the remains of Red Jacket and other noted Indian chiefs here tomorrow are completed. The remains of Red Jacket, Little Billy, Destroy Town, Tall Peter, Young King, and Capt. Pollard have been placed in cherry caskets, and now lie in state in the rooms of the Historical Society.

There have been a number of changes in the cast of "Called Back," necessitated by the sending of some of the actors to other combinations under the control of the Madison-Square managers. Mr. Forrest Robinson has gone for the balance of the season to the "May Blossom" company, and the actress who played the landlady with the atrocious Cockney accent has gone somewhere else.
The steamship Assyrian Monarch, of the Monarch Line, which arrived from London by way of Havre yesterday, brought 70 Norman horses, 5 English stallions, 1 pony, and 2 St. Bernard dogs.
NYACK, Oct. 8.--The annual parade of the Nyack Fire Department took place this afternoon, and proved in every respect the largest and most attractive one ever witnessed in the county.

CENTRALIA, Penn., Oct. 8.--As two farmers named James Casson and Henry Boyer were driving, about 1 o'clock this morning, from Roaring Creek to Orangeville, this county, they were fired upon by a party concealed in the bushes bordering on the road.
PARIS, Oct. 8.--President Gr vy has issued a decree granting 50,000f. for the relief of the unemployed workmen of Lyons.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8.--Valentine Glitz, a gunmaker, working in the factory of Parker Brothers, at Meriden. attempted to commit suicide, late last night, after threatening to kill his wife.

LONDON, Oct. 8.--This was the third day of the Newmarket second October meeting. The race for the Middle Park Plate, for 2-yearolds, was won by Lord Hastings's b.c. Melton. M.A. Lupin's ch. c. Xaintrailles was second. Capt. C. Bowling's bay colt, by Sterling, out of Casuistry, and Mr. Childwick's b.c. Royal Hampton ran a dead heat for third place.
LONDON, Oct. 8.--The last session of the English Cabinet Council, before the assemblage of Parliament, was held to-day. The Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, President of the ...
NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 8.--A large and enthusiastic meeting indorsing Cleveland and Hendricks was held in the Grand Opera House here to-night.

CORNING, Oct. 6.--Corning has the reputation of harboring more statesmen to the square rod than any town in the Commonwealth. What the Hon. Charles Walker, Capt. Cole, Gen. Lathrop, E.P. Graves, Charles D. Baker, F.B. Brown, ex-Senator Bradley, F.N. Decker, and their associates don't know about the politics not merely of Steuben County but of the outside world is hardly worth inquiring into.

PHLADELPHIA, Oct. 8.--The paper trade is in a ruinous condition, caused by the Government embargo on the importation of foreign rags issued on Sept. 1 by Acting Secretary of the Treasury Coon. The Eastern book paper manufacturers' have called a convention at Cleveland for the 15th inst. to consider the condition of the market.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 8.--At noon today the citizens residing on Independence-street, in proximity to the immense icehouse of the Forest City Ice Company, were startled by a terrible crash.

The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange adopted a new by-law yesterday as follows: "No bets or offers to bet in regard to prices or future dividends of securities shall be made on the floor of the Exchange."

An interesting letter from the Hon. Neal Dow was yesterday made public by a gentleman who called at the Democratic National Headquarters. The letter was dated at Portland, Aug. 2, and says: "Your note of the 1st is received.

A barbecue, under the auspices of the Tammany Hall organization of the Eighth Assembly District, was held in Sulzer's Harlem River Park yesterday. Early in the day Caterer Morris arrived on the ground and prepared the ox for the hungry Tammany braves.
MASSILLON, Ohio, Oct. 8.--Mr. Blaine, accompanied by the Hon. William McKinley and by a long line of private carriages, drove this morning from Canton to this city, a distance of eight miles.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8.--James Timlin and James Cowles, roommates, of No. 17 Greenwood-street, have several times quarreled over a mutual sweetheart. In a fight which followed Cowles was dangerously stabbed over his heart.

QUINCY, Mass., Oct. 8.--John Quincy Adams has declined the nomination of the Democrats for Congress from the Second District. The independents, who were preparing to cast their strength for Mr. Adams, will hold a meeting at which they will tender the Congressional nomination to Dr. William Everett. It is expected that the Democrats will ratify the nomination.

All the members of the special committee appointed to consider reduced tolls and in creased facilities of travel on the Brooklyn bridge were present at the first meeting yesterday except John T. Agnew, of this city.

Wherever Mr. BLAINE goes he absolutely ignores in his addresses the grave charges made against him and resting on his own letters, but he pauses now and again to concoct and send off an explanation of one of the least harmful of them, and every explanation adds to the overwhelming proof of his incurable untruthfulness.

It was 8 o'clock last night, and the loungers at the St. James Hotel were rather more numerous than usual. A little group of gentlemen stood at the desk attentively studying a railroad time table and referring to the gorgeous hotel clerk for information, which that worthy seemed to be either unwilling or unable to give.

Patrick Hayes, of No. 30 Bowery, who when arrested, gave his occupation as that of a painter, but who is known to the police as a professional gambler, made a desperate attempt last evening to murder his wife at the corner of Grand and Second streets, Brooklyn.

President Smith, of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company, issued a voluminous circular yesterday formally offering to the stockholders of that company $5,000,000 6 per cent. 10-40 adjustment mortgage bonds and $5,000,000 of treasury stock.

The performance of "La Fille de Mme. Angot" at Wallack's Theatre, last evening, was not of very even merit. Works of this order have heretofore been sung as well as acted in New-York, and so far as Mme. Th o is concerned--and Mme. Th o is now the head and front of the troupe--singing is out of the question.

The Metropolitan Lacrosse Club, of Ottawa, played a game with the New-York team at New-Brighton, Staten Island, yesterday. The New-Yorkers were reinforced with three members of the Williamsburg Athletic Club, but they showed lack of practice and were easily beaten by 4 goals to 2.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 8.--A horse dealer named J.F. Hite, one of the most prominent in this section, has been missing for over a week, and it is generally supposed he has decamped.

Another good programme is put forth to-day by the American Jockey Club, and as the meeting draws to a close the racing appears to be more interesting. There are a splendid lot of entries, which are as follows:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8.--The family of James McIntosh, near Hallville, was rescued with difficulty from their burning home last night. It is believed that the house was set on fire by a neighbor, a member of the church in which McIntosh is a Deacon.
NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 8.--Albert Bowen, coachman to Postmaster Sperry and janitor of the New-Haven Post Office, was arraigned before United States Commissioner Platt to-day on ...
Mr. Edwin Booth, according to a cable dispatch, is expected to act in Berlin next February.
At the annual meeting of the shareholders of the Western Union Telegraph Company yesterday noon ex-Gov. Cornell presided. The number of shares of stock represented was 630,285.
The following sales of securities were made at public auction in the Exchange Salesroom, No. 111 Broadway, yesterday, by Adrian H. Muller Son:

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 8.--The games of the Intercollegiate Tennis Tournament were resumed this morning and continued through the day. The suprise of the day was the defeat of Sears by Knapp, of Yale, in the afternoon.

READING, Penn., Oct. 8.--The Reading cotton factory which, after six weeks of idleness, started operations last Monday week will close again next Saturday. The stoppage is made in accordance with an agreement with Eastern mills, a month's cessation having been determined upon on account of over production. The Reading mill employs 250 hands.

ALBANY, Oct. 8.--The Hon. Willis S. Paine, Superintendent of the Banking Department, recently requested the Attorney-General to give official construction to the savings bank laws in reference to the right of savings banks to invest 60 per cent. of their accumulated surplus in bonds and mortgages.
BATAVIA, N.Y., Oct, 8.--This was the fifth day and evening that the Republican Congressional Convention for the Thirty-first District spent its time for nothing.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8.--Last Summer. C.W. Story of Chillicothe, Ohio, won the Ashland Trotting Stakes, for 3-year-olds, with his b. g. Reference, at the Chicago Driving Park. The stake amounted to $1,875.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 8.--The Episcopal Congress was called to order this morning by Bishop Harris. "The Cathedral System in America" was the subject announced for discussion. The first writer was the Rev. H.H. Hart, M.A., of Denver, Col., who held that the cathedral is necessary to the Bishop, for without it he is like an Admiral without a fleet.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8.--A terrible accident occurred at the temporary crib of the new Hyde Park Water Works at 7 o'clock this morning, resulting in the loss of nine lives. For some time past a gang of 14 men have been working at the mouth of the lake end of the tunnel, about a mile off Cheltenham Beach.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 8.--John E. Russell, of Leicester, Secretary of the State Board of Agriculture, and Congressman P.A. Collins, of Boston, addressed the first Democratic rally of the campaign in Mechanics' Hall this evening.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 8.--John L. Sullivan, in an interview with a Bulletin reporter, said he intends to train down to 200 pounds or less for his set-to with Laflin.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Oct. 8.--It is reported that the death of Cadet Strang, of Oregon, who died at the Annapolis Academy last Friday, was the result of injuries received during a hazing when he entered the Academy two weeks before. This was told to THE TIMES'S correspondent by a relative of Strang.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 8.--Further advices received from Newfoundland to-day state that the fisheries have not proved such failures since 1868 as this year. On the northern coast of Labrador, which belongs to Newfoundland, the catch has only been one-third of the average of the past 10 years.
At Charter Oak Park, Hartford, on Tuesday, Maud S. was sent the last half of a slow mile in 1:03 , the final quarter being covered in 30 seconds, a 2:01 gait. Her owner was among her timers.

After the Court of Appeals had declared unconstitutional the act of 1883 forbidding the manufacture of cigars in tenement houses in this city, the Legislature passed a new law to the same effect. Ex-Judge A.J. Dittenhoefer, who had procured the annulment of the original act, maintained that the second one was likewise unconstitutional.

President Arthur spent the greater part of the day yesterday in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel. Secretary Chandler called in the morning and was closeted with the President for several hours. Among the other callers were Gen.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8.--Wallace A. Benson is an enterprising New-Yorker who has been victimizing rural Connecticut. Over in New-London County he has made a good many people sad.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 8.--Considerable excitement prevails over the recent discovery of silver mines in Murray County, Ga., at the base of Fort Mountain. Information received to-day states that a stock company has been organized and has procured ore at a depth of 11 feet that assays $1 to the pound. People are flocking there from every direction. They are undoubtedly the richest silver mines ever discovered in the South.

ERIE, Penn., Oct. 8.--To-day the State Commission appointed to investigate the whitefish fishing arrived here and held a joint meeting with the Board of Trade. The result of the visit will be the establishment of a State hatchery here capable of turning into the lake half a million fish every year.

There is mourning among the occupants of the house at No. 12 Stanton-street, from which "Doctor" Andrew Werner was taken on Tuesday charged with being a receiver of stolen property to a large extent. He had lived in the house for six years--ever since it was opened-- entertaining rather cordial relations with the members of the family from whom he rented his apartments.

WARSAW, N.Y., Oct. 8.--A full convention and some 500 spectators congregated at Irving Hall yesterday to nominate the Republican County ticket. The Hon. John E. Lowing, of Silver Springs, was nominated for member of Assembly.

Few political economists have as yet turned their attention to the probable effect upon back hair of a war between China and France. Women who, as a rule, are profoundly ignorant of the origin of their back hair, do not dream that it would be in any way affected by a blockade of the Chinese ports.

It was Fall opening day at the large establishment of E. Ridley Sons, at Grand, Allen, and Orchard streets, yesterday, and the place was thronged from morning until evening. The reputation which this firm has acquired for selling excellent goods at the lowest of prices is well established, and prudent buyers from all over the city make it a point to visit the store regularly in search of novelties and necessaries.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8.--The new Japanese Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to the United States, R. Ku Ki, arrived here from San Francisco to-day. He was accompanied by Mme. Ku Ki, Miss Ku Ki, and his secretary' K. Meia Ki.

The General Term of the Supreme Court, in an opinion written by Presiding Judge Noah Davis, and concurred in by Judge Charles Daniels, has affirmed the decision of Judge Donohue, rendered at Special Term, that the Commissioners of Estimate and Apportionment cannot lawfully transfer unexpended balances from one department or bureau of the City Government to another department or bureau.
LONDON, Oct. 8.--Edward Augustus Freeman, D.C.L., LL. D., the celebrated historian, has been appointed Professor of Modern History at Oxford University.

WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 8.--Adam Forepaugh brought his circus here to-day. Richard Clark, of Caledonia, Canada, started to open the ventilators, and stepped on the trap of the tigers' cage, when it gave way and precipitated him up to his waist in the den.

After an illness of more than two months Police Captain Edward Tynan, of the Fourth Precinct, died yesterday morning at 1:45 o'clock, at his residence, No. 140 East Nineteenth-street, of typhoid malaria.

In the criminal branch of the United States Circuit Court the United States Grand Jury yesterday presented indictments against the following named persons: Henry Gomez, for assisting in running away with the schooner Julia Baker and disposing of part of her cargo; Elljah Alliger, for claiming ownership in a stolen bond; Charles H. Campbell, for obstructing

The Metropolitans played off their tie game on the Polo Grounds yesterday with the Toledo Club. At the outset things looked gloomy for the Mets, but they began to bat as the game wore on, and, assisted by errors in the fifth inning, they gained a winning lead.

CANTON, Miss., Oct. S.-A singular case of spontanious combustion occurred here to-day at noon. A barrel of whisky exploded in the saloon of William O. Hargon and ignited. The room was enveloped in flames, but no serious damage was done. There was no light or fire in the room prior to the explosion.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 8.--Walter N. Thayer, of Troy, President of the Workingmen's Assembly, has declined the position, offered by Commissioner Peck, of chief clerk in the Bureau of Labor Statistics, made vacant by the removal of David Healy.

It is really astonishing that in a country where the people are to some extent humane and intelligent the firing of the guns belonging to our navy should be permitted. No less than three 100-pound rifled Parrott guns have recently been fired on board of American men-of-war.
ROME, Oct. 8.--The reports from the cholera-infected districts in Italy for the past 24 hours give a total of 197 fresh cases and 97 deaths.

The respective officers of the several down-town Cleveland and Hendricks clubs were busy yesterday afternoon completing the arrangements for the business men's meeting in front of the Sub-Treasury this afternoon. The meeting will be called to order at 3:30 o'clock by Charles M. Stead, President of the Stock Exchange Cleveland and Hendricks Club.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 8.--At Meriden to-day Charles L. Mitchell, of this city, was renominated by acclamation for Congress by the Democrats of this district. The convention adopted spirited resolutions, declaring "that the platform of principles adopted by the Democratic rational Convention at Chicago and by the State Convention at Hartford, and also the candidates placed in nomination by these

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 8.--Martin Dormer, a prominent citizen and brewer, of St. Clair, this county, received a telegram this morning from Tueson, Arizona Territory, stating that his daughter and her husband, Mr. ...
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 8.--The drought in this section is distressing. Cisterns are dry and city water is scarce. There has been no rain of consequence since Aug. 5. Everything green is parched.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 8.--In the Superior Court at Evansville suit has been filed to com pel the appointment of a Receiver for the Louisville, Evansville and St. Louis Air Line Railroad. The plaintiff says the road has been badly managed, and at present trains cannot run on full time, and the rolling stock is in such condition that the cars cannot carry full weight of freight.

MADISON, Ind., Oct. 9.--Prof. George Hubbard, Principal of a seminary here, to-day administered a slight punishment to Emma Stanley, aged 14, for persisting in whispering in class, and gent her home temporarily suspended. The girl's father. Harry Stanley, went to the school, knocked Hubbard down with his fist, and horsewhipped him. Papers are out for Stanley's arrest.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9.--The lake was calm and placid this morning after the disastrous storm of the past two days. As yet none of the bodies of the nine men drowned in the Hyde Park accident have been washed ashore, and in the meantime no inquest can be held.

SORANTON, Peun., Oct. 9.--John Savings the poet, and late Clerk of the Marine Court in New-York, is lying dangerously ill at his Summer residence, near Sprangueville, Penn., and it is feared that he cannot live many hours. He received the rites of the church this afternoon, and it is thought he cannot last until morning.

COLUMBUS, Oct. 9.--The Blaine managers have begun to cry "Stop thief!" and are raising such a dust about Democratic frauds, repeaters, colonized voters, and the use of money that their own movements are likely to be somewhat obscured.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct.9.--Under date of the 6th inst. the Hon. William Daniel, of this city, has forwarded to Prof. Dickie, of Michigan, his letter of acceptance of the Prohibition nomination for Vice-President.
