CAIRO, Oct. 9.--Advices from Dongola state that the Mudir of that place has received confirmation of a report that a steamer from Khartoum was wrecked after leaving Abu Hamed.

Mme. Etelka Gerster and Signor Italo Campanini have announced their intention of undertaking a concert tour through the United States, commencing late next month. These distinguished singers are to have the assistance of a complete concert company, and the material success of their enterprise mat be anticipated as confidently as its artistic interest.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9, 1884. Another session of the Prime Meridian Confer ence will be held on Saturday. American delegates express the opinion that if the French representatives continue their opposition to the proposed prime meridian of Greenwich the conference will adopt a majority resolution recommending that meridian and leave the French delegates to do what they please.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct.9.--The Democratic County Convention met to-day and without much opposition nominated William Keith for Sheriff, August M.Koeth for County Treasurer, A.P.Butts for Special County Judge, and J.C.Baird for Justice of Sessions. There were three contesting delegations, but their difficulties were amicably adjusted.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 9.--The Republicans made the following Congressional nominations to-day: First District, Henry J.Spooner, of Providence: Second District, William A. Pierce, of Johnston.

The pneumatic tubes between the main office of the Western Union Telegraph Company and the office at Fifth-avenue and Twenty-thirdstreet will be put in operation for the public service next Tuesday night.

Counsel for an insurance company gave to Judge Truax, in the Superior Court, yesterday, his reasons for asserting that the insured person whose representatives were suing the company had committed suicide.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 9.--Charles S. Riggs, of Nantucket, died at the State prison to-day. He was sentenced for life two years ago for murdering his son-in-law.

Some of the most eminent physicians of Montreal say that a great many ladies and children have been attacked after their return from their Summer rests, whether at the seaside or inland, with typhoid and malarial fevers and diphtheria.

Mr.Billy Birch was well received at the New Park Theatre last evening. It was a chestnut night. Mr.Birch told the story about the educated bass and warbled "And he's never done anything since."

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 9.--At a special election last Spring the village of Clinton voted-- 184 to 109--in favor of water works. This action was vigorously opposed by Theodore W. Dwight, of New-York, who is a large property owner in Clinton.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9.--Several days ago revenue officers seized 15,000 domestic cigars bearing import stamps, in the store of Leo D. Mayer. The proprietor was ill in Philadelphia, where he still is.
Col. John Hay, of Cleveland, is at the Brevoort House. Attorney-General Brewster is at the Buckingham Hotel.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9.--Miss Julia Robbins, a cousin of the wife of State Senator L.D. Condee, of Hyde Park, and Samuel E. Thrall, son of the General Ticket Agent of the Northwestern Railroad, ran away on Sept. 16 to Niles, Mich., and were married.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 9.--A young man fashionably dressed stepped off a New-York train at Princeton Junction at 2 o'clock last Sunday morning, and soon afterward made inquiry at the University Hotel for two students, who he said were his brothers.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 9.--D.J. Whiteside Son, dry goods and furnishing Goods, assigned to-day. Their labilities are about $6,000, mostly to New-York parties; assets, a stock of goods which will nearly cover the liabilities. R.R. Woodward is the Assignee.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9.--The meeting of the general Railway Time Convention was held to-day at the Continental Hotel. The principal transactions were the arrangement of a through schedule with New-York on the east, with Cincinnati, Chicago, and St.Louis on the west,...

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Oct. 9.--Owing to the burning of the Grand Opera House on Tuesday morning, the exercises of Founder's Day at the Lehigh University were held in the university chapel this morning, beginning at 10 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9.--The Adjutant-General of the Army has received a telegram announcing that First Lieut. James S. Marsteller, Twenty-fourth Infantry, was accidentally killed a few days ago while hunting in the Indian Territory.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 9.--Joseph Squires was killed by his brother Andrew at the house of another brother named George, in West Ashford, last night. He was stabbed in the neck and bled to death. Liquor was the cause of the murder.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 9.--About a year ago, in the personal column of a Cincinnati paper appeared an advertisement from Sarah Orton, a widow, of Parker's Landing, Penn., soliciting correspondence. It was answered by Thomas Weich, a very light-colored barber, of this city, and a correspondence ensued lasting until July.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Oct. 9.--Postmaster W.C. Wiley, of this place, left his home on Wednesday, Oct.1, without saying a word today of his family of his going, and has not since been heard of. It was rumored this afternoon that he had defaulted but his books do not confirm such a, report. Mr.Speese, a speical agent of the Post Office Department, of Pittsburg, wlll investigate the matter.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 9.--The Republicans of the First District of Dutchess County have nominated Joseph H. Storm, of Beekman, for the Assembly.

The Metropolitans defeated the Cincin nati Club on the Polo Grounds yesterday after a rather one-sided contest. The feature of the game was the battery work of Lynch and Reipschlager.

DETROIT, Oct. 9.--What it was difficult for the New-York Club to do on Tuesday was very easy to-day, namely, to hit Getzein. In spite of Dorgan's giving six men bases on balls, he pitched so well, or else the Detroit players batted so ill, that but four hits were made.

Henry Hopper, an English stationer and toy dealer, at No. 253 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street, shot himself in the head yesterday morning and died before medical assistance arrived. About two months ago his wife died, and coupled with the fact that he could not sleep well this made him very despondent. Hopper leaves three small children.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 9.--The games of the intercollegiate tennis tournament opened this morning with the competition for second place in the doubles. Trinity and Princeton were eligible, and two cleverly played games...

Morris Rose is the owner of a hardware store at No. 742 Third-avenue. He lives, with his wife and family, in rooms over the store. Mr. Rose says that no less than four times within a year burglars have tried to gain entrance to his store.

LONDON, Oct. 9.--At the South African conference held here to consider the violation of the treaty by the Boers, a firm and decisive policy was advocated. A resolution was adopted demanding that the Government enforce the Transvaal treaty.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct.9.--Gen. Butler arrived here from Port Huron at 9 o'clock this morning. After taking some much needed rest he left for Toledo at 3:10. He was intending to speak there this afternoon, but missed the connections.

Mrs.Margaret Mulvey, living at No. 7 East Ninety-first-street, during a quarrel with her husband,-Martin, at their residence last night, was beaten by her husband and seriously injured. She was taken to the Ninety-ninth-Street Hospital, where she died. Her husband was arrested.

Justice Patterson, at the Jefferson Mar ket Police Court, yesterday dismissed the case of assault brought by Julius A. Grunzig, of the German weekly Figaro, against John Appel, a doorkeeper of the Thalia Theatre.
The change in the weather was severely felt yesterday at Jerome Park. The racing, however, was of excellent quality, and caused much enthusiasm.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct. 9.--A.S. Ruggles, agent of the Dominion Savings Bank at Annapolis, and Gideon Burrell left there 10 days ago for the woods, taking with them from Maitland a guide named Cornelius Handley.

PARIS, Oct. 9.--Abbe le Mesle, of Havre, has withdrawn from the priesthood and married the daughter of a banker named Louisee, of this city.

ALBANY, Oct. 9.--Judge Charles A. Rapallo has not yet been able to resume his seat on the Court of Appeals bench. After his chill on Monday he was taken to the City Hospital, where he has since been under treatment. It is rumored that his illness is more serious than his friends care to admit. His physician says he is suffering from jaundice and kidney troubles.
ALBANY, Oct. 9.--At the Democratic Convention in the Third Judicial District, to-day, Judge William L.Learned, of this city, was renominated for Supreme Court Judge on the first ballot.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9.--The Supreme Court of the United States will meet on Monday next for the October term of 1884. Six of the Justices are already in the city and all are expected to take their seats when the Court assembles.
The annual Fall regatta of the Knicker bocker Yacht Club, which had been postponed on account of lack of wind, was sailed yesterday.

A portion of the crew of the whaling bark Seine, of New-Bedford, which was lost on the western coast of Africa last June, arrived yesterday on the steamship Wisconsin, of the Guion Line, from Liverpool.

BOSTON, Oct. 9.--The earnings of the Mexican Central Railway for September (approximate) were $249,953, as against $240,138 actual earnings for August, showing a gain over the previous month of $9,815. Tha subsidy received to Oct. 1 was $2,838,586.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9.--"I received a contract yesterday from the Western Union Telegraph Company, signed by John Van Horne, the Vice-President, and countersigned by the Secretary, to run their main wires under ground," said David Brooks, the electrican, to-day.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 9.--Judge Brooke, of the Corporation Court, to-day dissolved an injunction granted by the Supreme Court restraining Mayor Lamb from interfering with the Dismal Swamp Lottery Company.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 9.--Dr. T.C. Car son, of New-York City, has been appointed Superintendent of the State Idiot Asylum.

AUGUSTA, Me., Oct. 9.--Thomas Malloy, an inmate of the National Soldiers' Home at Togus, and a Sergeant at that institution. was fatally shot at 3 o'clock this afternoon by Charles Morgan Wallace, about a mile away from the Home, on the road leading to Hallowell Ferry.

BOSTON, Oct. 9.--The police of this city are now satisfied that the woman who attempted to secure a loan on painted African diamonds, representing them as pure brilliants, several months since, is none other than Helen Peck, lately arrested in New-York. There is a warrant in the hands of the police here for her arrest.

Charles B.Hammond, a clerk in the Post Office at Patchogue, Long Island, and son of Postmaster Hammond, who disappeared from Patchogue two weeks ago, was arrested by Inspector Newcomb late yesterday afternoon on a charge of robbing the mails.
COVINGTON, Ky., Oct. 9.--This was the sixth day of the Fall meeting of the Latonia Jockey Club. The weather was fair, the track in good condition, and the attendance large.

The melancholy accident by which a young canoeist lost his life in Newark Bay last week may produce the impression that canoeing is a particularly dangerous sport, instead of being, as it is, the safest of all aquatic sports.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9.--During the performance of "A Parlor Match" at Ford's Opera House, to-night a calcium light began hissing and finally went out with a loud report. The boys in the gallery, hearing the noise, began to run for the exits.

Remington, who for nearly five years past had occupied a room at the NewEngland Hotel, at the Bowery and Bayardstreet, was found dead in his room on the second floor of the hotel last evening, having committed suicide by hanging himself to a gas bracket. He was a man about 52 years of age and had no known business.

Maggie Ferrier, a precocious-girl, 11 years old, was reported to the police last night as having run away from her home. Her father told Capt. Copeland, who was in charge at Police Headquarters, that Maggie was stage struck, and had probably gone off with some theatrical company. She had run off with theatrical companies once or twice before. A general alarm was sent out, but the girl could not be found.

PARIS, Oct. 9.--Gen. Briere de l'Isle has telegraphed to the Government, confirming the report announced in a dispatch from Hanoi yesterday of an engagement between the French and Chinese in the valley of the Loochuan River, in Tonquin.

ROME, Oct. 9.--The reports from the cholera, infected districts of Italy-for the past 24 hours give a total of 145 fresh cases and 77 deaths, against 197 cases and 97 deaths for the preceding 24 hours.

There lives in Forsyth an old gentleman who is now in his seventy-ninth year. He was converted in 1833, licensed to preach in 1840, and has been preaching ever since.
One of the men in Maine to whom JAMES G. BLAINE sold Little Rock and Fort Smith stock and bonds in 1869 was JOSEPH A. SANBORN.

ALBANY, Oct. 10.--All work on the New Capitol was suspended this afternoon. The appropriation has been exhausted, and no more money will be available until the meeting of the next Legislature. Over 800 men are thrown out of employment.

MANCHESTER, Oct. 10.--The Guardian, in its commercial article, says: "There is a moderate business at low rates. Export yarns are generally firm."
Bark Lillian M. Vigus (of Halifax, N.S.,) Morine, Rotterdam 33ds., with empty barrels and iron to order --vessel to J.F. Whitney Co.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 10.--Leo Brigal, 13 years old, was arrested at Allegheny City this morning for maliciously destroying the sight of both eyes of Bertie Black, 4 years old, by throwing mortar into her face. He also seriously burned two other children by the same means. No cause is assigned for the fiendish acts.
The Metropolitan and St. Louis Clubs played the ninth of their series of games on the Polo Grounds yesterday, and it resulted in a defeat for the local players.

Primaries were held last evening for the election of delegates by the Republicans to the County, Congressional, Assembly, and Aldermanic Conventions, and to a Judicial Convention in the Twenty-first District. In few of the districts was there any lack of harmony or any contests. Of the total enrollment of nearly 24,000 only a little over one-third voted.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10.--The Third Presbyterian Church, corner of Ashland and Ogden avenues, of which the Rev, Abbott E. Kettredge is Pastor, was destroyed by fire this morning. The beautiful stone structure, with its high gables, and occupying a space of about 50 by 100 feet, was thoroughly gutted, and a crowd of about 5,000 persons witnessed the fire ...

Whatever may be its advantages, marriage by telegraph is not always safe. The truth of this has just been learned by sad experience by a widow lady who married by telegraph a man whom she had never seen, but whom she believed, on the faith of his letters, to be a leading citizen of his particular town.

"Hooray, I'm old John Dwper, an' I live in Brooklyn," shouted an intoxicated man near the Roosevelt-Street Ferry last evening. Policeman, Baker of the Oak-street station threatened to arrest the man if he did not keep quiet, and the latter ceased shouting.

BOSTON, Oct. 10.--Mr. Blaine having declared the statement that he offered a sum of money in 1880 for the Mulligan letters to be utterly untrue--a "mere malicious invention"-- Warren Fisher rises to explain.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 10.--Circuit Judge H.M. Finley, of a mountain district, was indicted in the United States Circuit Court to-day. The cause of his indictment was the arrest of John V.L. Brown, a United States Deputy Marshal, some months ago.

Patent medicine manufacturers who are endeavoring to freeze out low-priced druggists on the Campion system sent out a new black list yesterday with several new firms added in this city and in Brooklyn.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 10.--The Hon. Thomas A. Hendricks, Senator Bayard, Judge Thurman, and Gen. Rosencrans arrived in this city this morning to address the great mass meeting here to-night. During the day Senator Bayard visited the Chamber of Commerce and made a brief address.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 10.--The Democratic Convention of the First District of Orsego County, held here to-day, nominated W. Caryl Ely, of Worcester, N.Y., for member of Assembly.

READING, Penn., Oct. 10.--Some time during last night a thief picked the locks and entered the apartments of three drummers at the American House,dragged at their clothing into the bathroom, and there rifled the pockets, securind as his booty ubout $50 in money, several watches, and other valuables.
SANDUSKY, Ohio, Oct.10.--Truman Fitch, a wealthy farmer living near Milan, in Sandusky County, commited suicide yesterday by taking laudanum. Family troubles are alleged to have caused the act.

FONDA, N.Y., Oct. 10.--At a special election this afternoon the citizens voted in favor of a water supply for the village which was recealy visited by several destructive fires. Most of the insurance companies canceled their policies.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct.10.--Two hundred years ago on the 15th day of October the little settlement at the head waters of the Blackstone River, near the beautiful Lake Quinsigamond, received the name of Worcester by act of the Great and General Court of Massachusetts Colony.

FONDA, N.Y., Oct. 10.--About threeyears ago Miss Vinnie Lansing came to this village from Amsterdam and took up her abode with her uncle, Dr. J.D. Beakley. She was a tall brunette, finely educated, had excellent musical abilities, and it was not long before she gained a host of friends including the best society of the village.
WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Oct. 10.--Walter Sherwood, who was nominated for Congress by the Democrats of the Sixteenth District, has positively declined the nomination.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 10.--Dr. C.C. Graham, of this city, celebrated the one hundredth anniversary of his birthday to-day. Dr. Graham was a Kentucky pioneer, and was personally acquainted with Daniel Boone.
COVINCTON, Ky. Oct. 10.--The seventh day of the Latonia Jockey Club races was warm and pleasant, but the track was not fast. There was a good attendance.

Dr. Leopold Damrosch, the musical director of the Metropolitan Opera House, returned from Europe yesterday, in the North German Lloyd steamship Ems. Dr. Damrosch sailed from New-York on Aug. 13 last, on the seemingly forlorn quest of organizing a company of German artists to give opera at the Metropolitan during the coming season.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 10.--The intercollegiate tennis tournment ended to-day with Brinleoy, of Trinity, winning second place in the singles by defeating Moffat, of Princeton. Yale has won first place in both singles and doubles. and Trinity second.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10.--In demolishing an old building on the top of East Rock (now a city park) workmen discovered several underground passages 30 or 40 feet long, 15 feet high, and 3 feet wide, which led to a subterranean vault 10 feet square and 5 feet high.

ALBANY, Oct. 10.--The Fitts or Draper Republicans to-day ratified the anti-Draper county nominations, naming Dr. John Swinburne for Congress and John Battersby for County Treasurer. Dr. Swinburne has now been nominated by all factions of Republicans and by the workingmen, and has a good chance of defeating Judge Van Alstyne, the present member, and thus redeeming the district.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 10.--A dispatch from Cedar Keys to the Times-Union says: "The body of J.A. Buckner, editor of the Gulf Coast Herald, at Tarpon Springs, was found in a bayou between Anclote and Tarpon Springs on Tuesday morning.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 10.--In politics the town has heretofore been largely influenced by the college. The students have always formed the bulk of the Republican majority. This year the result promises to be different.

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., Oct.10.--Five masked men, flourishing revolvers, battered down the door of the house of as farmer named Joseph Gates, in White Township, early yesterday morning, and compelled Mr. Gates, at the points of their pistols to give them over $1,100, which he had secreted. The robbers then hastily departed, firing their revolvers as they left the house.

Pretty girls sat on a raised platform at the Academy of Music last night and sang, during the evening, to a very large gathering of men and women, who were glad that the Very Rev. Theobald Mathew had been born.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10.--The Department of Agriculture reports that the October returns of corn average higher for condition than in the past five years, but not so high as in any of the remarkable corn years from 1875 to 1879 inclusive.

George Martin, proprietor of the Vanderbilt House, at Clifton, Staten Island, has not lived with his wife for several months. When Mrs. Martin left her husband the latter refused to allow his wife to take their little daughter with her.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10.--The arguments on the motion for a new trial in the case of James Dacey, who was found guilty of the murder of Alderman Michael Gaynor, of the Ninth Ward, at Woodstock, last week, were concluded today at Woodstock, and the motion was overruled.

PAYTA, Peru, Oct. 10, via Galveston.--A destructive fire originated here last night, consuming a quarter of the town. The fire started at 9 o'clock, and at 4 o'clock this morning the flames, fanned by a strong south wind, had consumed everything in a straight line from where they originated down to the beach.

The Republican majority in Ohio at the Presidential election of 1868 was over 41,000 and in 1872 over 37,000. In 1876 it fell to 7,516, but in 1880 rose to 34,227.

An unknown man, apparently English, shot himself in the right temple in Union-square at 11:30 o'clock last night. He died instantly. He was well dresed. and about30 years old.

Among the documents which the friends of Mr. Blaine have been industriously circulating is one entitled "Gov. Cleveland and the Catholic Protectory,"which has been sent exclusively to Roman Catholic priests throughout the country.
MARSEILLES, Oct. 10.--The ravages of cholera in this city are nearly over. No deaths from the disease are reported here to-day.

Last evening as Mrs. Harriet Hollister, wife of Timothy Hollister, of No. 24 South Aurora-street, was turning on the water from the faucet over the sink in her kitchen, using her right hand, her left hand being in contact with the iron lining of the sink, she was suddenly prostrated by a severe electric shock.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 10.--Surrogate Cook to-day handed down his decision in the Granger will case, admitting the will to probate. The case has been in litigation for a year past.

ALBANY., Oct. 10.--In the Court of Appeals to-day the following business was transacted: No. 244.--Nancy Weston, appellant, vs. Brayton Ives, President of the New-York Stock Exchange, respond ent: argued by James R. Marvin for appellant and Robert Sewell for respondent.
BOSTON, Oct. 10.--The case of Mrs. Heustis, charged with having stoleu $20,000 worth of diamonds in New-York, and for whom a requisition is asked, will be heard to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Oct. 10.--Special Agent Speese, of the Post Office Department, arrived here this morning and has made a thorough examination of the accounts of W.C. Wiley, Postmaster, who so mysteriously disappeared about 10 days ago. He found everything correct.

COLUMBUS, Oct. 10.--It would be an extremely gratifying thing to be able to predict to-night, three days before the State election, whether Ohio is to give a majority for the Democrats or the Republicans on Tuesday next.

Ex-Gov. Horatio Seymour has written a letter to the editor of the Freeman's Journal, of Cooperstown, N.J., in which he regrets that he cannot take an active part in the present contest on account of his health, and he expresses deep interest in the result. Mr. Seymour Sketches at some length the progress of the country since the civil war, and speaks of its present needs.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 10.--Five members of the Salvation Army, four of them women, were sent to the penitentiary to-night. The Salvationists were arrested for violating a city ordinance by singing and playingug upon tambourines on the streets. They demanded a jury trial and were convicted and sent to the penitentiary for 15 days. To-night five more Salvationists were arrested and locked up for the same offense. They will be tried to-morrow.

Robert H. Ramsgate, the bigamous diamond polisher who was arrested in New-York, and who pleaded guilty in Judge McGill's court in Jersey City the other day, was arraigned for sentence yesterday. His counsel asked for permission to withdraw the plea of guilty.

The attempt of George Franck,the Orange beer bottler, to force his way into Mrs. Ettinger's apartments during a recent absence of her husband has drawn attention a new to the suspicions that pointed him out as a possible participant in the murder of Phoebe Paullin on the Orange Mountains last Fall.

There was a blockade of the street-car lines in Church-street a day or two ago, and while half a dozen cars were jammed in together, a carpenter, with an armful of boards and a lot of tools, clambered on the rear platform of a Sixth-avenue car. "Here," said the conductor, "you can't bring all that stuff aboard." The carpenter got off and tried car after car with a like result.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 10.--The Allendale Cotton Mill in this city, operated by George Calder, will close to-morrow night for a week's suspension and will subsequently be operated only on half time, running every alternate week. This movement is due to the dullness of the market.

President Arthur on Thursday night entertained a number of personal friends until a late hour, and consequently was late in rising yesterday. During the day the President was called upon by Stephen B. Elkins, Commissioner Laimbeer, Prof. Doremus. Attorney-General Brewster, Morton McMichael, Schuyler Crosby, and J.Q. Quintard. The President went out during the afternoon and returned at 6 o'clock. He soon after left to attend a private dinner.

MONTREA, Quebec, Oct.10.--The success of Mr. Irving's second tour has so far surpassed his expectations. The Academy of Music here was crowded at" every performance, and the night that " Hamlet" was played all standing room was occupied, despite the serious discomfort caused by the heat.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Oct. 10.--A horrible crime has been brought to light at Troy, Ind., by the finding of the headless body of a woman in a cistern on the farm of Peter Backer. The body was nude. The head was found in a thicket a hundred yards from the cistern.

For some time past the Long Island Railroad officials have been suspicious of the honesty of several of the oldest conductors in the employment of the company, and about a month ago they placed detectives on their track. The detectives were not long in discovering that the conductors had united for the purpose of robbing the company.

Fathers Lavelle, Donovan, and Kelly, who respectively filled the office of deacon, sub-deacon, and master of ceremonies. The sermon was delivered by the Most Rev. We were shown on Friday afternoon a box of strawberries, picked from the vines of Mr. James Coleman, who resides near College Hill. They were of the Cumberland variety, fully ripe, and as fine as any picked during the season. Gardeners and others who saw them say it is a very rare occurrence to see such berries picked at this season of the year.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 12.--The body of George Boissard, a Frenchman, 54 years old, has been found in Mill River, below Platt's mills, Easton. It was lying in about a foot of water, and was clothed only in a shirt. Coroner Holt aad Dr. Clemens, medical examiner for Easton, decided that Boissard was not drowned.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 12.--Presidents John Taylor and George Q. Cannon, leaders of the Mormon Church, in an interview to-day repudiated the statements telegraphed from NewYork that the Mormon Church had appropriated money to aid in the election of the Democratic Presidential ticket, for which certain considerations were to be given in return. They assert that the statements have no foundation whatever in fact.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 12.--A severe hail, wind, and rain storm prevailed here this afternoon. Hailstones as large as ordinary marbles fell until the pavements and streets were almost covered, while the wind was of such velocity as to do great damage in the upper section of this city. The rainfall was also very heavy, and many cellars were flooded. The damage will reach several thousand dollars.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 8.--If the Prohibitionists in Michigan are as earnest in their purpose and as indifferent about which of the other parties may win as Mr. St. John, their candidate for President, then the State may be regarded as a doubtful one. Otherwise, it is reasonably sure to be Republican.

OWEGO, Oct. 7.--Tom Platt appears to have entirely abondoned his old stamping ground in Tioga County. He has not been seen in Owego but once since he crowded himself on to the platform in the Chicago Convention to indorse in his feeble way the nomination of the tattooed candidate.

NORWICH, Conn., Oct. 12.--The large Falls Cotton Mills of this place shut down over six weeks ago, and the outlook is that then will remain closed all Winter. Between 400 and 500 operatives were thrown out of work, and six weeks of idleness has reduced most of them to destitution.

WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 12.--The "naked man," a famous mysterious individual of this vicinity, who has frightened women and children by his occasional sudden appearance to them while traveling the road along the Naugutuck River, south of this city was captured yesterday, and thus was ended a mystery of many years.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 12.--On Wednesday evening next the Hon. Carl Schurz will address the citizens of Syracuse on the issues of the campaign at Shakespeare Hall. Mr. Schurz comes to Syracuse under the auspices and upon the invitation of the independent Republicans of the city.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 12.--Charles Johnson, a colored man, came near being burned to death at Osborn Cheseman's foundry, at Shelton, on Saturday. While pouring molten silver it flew into his face and burned him terribly, taking the skin from his face.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12.--Ed Roberts, a colored porter on the St. Paul Road, shot his wife Mattie three times in a disreputable house on Fourthavenue this evening, and she will probably die. Roberts left the woman six months ago because he thought her unfaithful to him, but he had repeatedly tried to induce her to live with him again.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12.--The Prohihition State Central Committee, of Kansas, have put H.L. Phillips at the head of their State ticket in place of A.B. Jettmore, who has declined the nomination for Governor.
Ex-Gov. H.C. Warmoth, of Louisiana, is at the Westminster Hotel.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 12.--C.M. Pyke's New-York Opera Company, after a short season of vicissitudes, came to grief last night.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 12.--It is announced to-night that Ex-President Woolsey has offered his resignation to the Yale corporation on account of his advanced age and increasing deafness. His resignation, however, has not yet been acted on.

BERLIN, Oct. 12.--The election agitation is increasing. A meeting which was to have been addressed by Prof. Virchow was dissolved by the authorities on account of a formal error in the notice of the meeting sent to the police.

THE THORN IN BLAINE'S SIDE. BALTIMORE, Oct. 13.--A mass meeting of the friends of Prohibition was held in Monument-square to-night, and in the throng outside, as well as on the stand, were a number of ladies. Ex-Gov. St. John, the Prohibition candidate for President, was cordially welcomed.

An important sale of thoroughbred horses was held yesterday at Easton's Horse and Cattle Exchange, Broadway and Thirty-eighthstreet. WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 13.--The Republicans in all parts of the State are confidently claiming the State. They claim that the reassessment scheme on the part of the Democrats, coupled with the decision of the Democratic Supreme Court in the Wheeling Intelligencer case, have so disgusted men of all parties that they are determined to oust the Democracy.

A bright and pretty little girl skipped lightly up to the witness stand at the Yorkville Police Court yesterday afternoon and gazed up confidingly into Justice Murray's face, while Agent Wilson, of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, told the following story: The girl's name is Margaret Ferrier. She was born in Dublin and is just 12 years of age.

PARIS, Oct. 13.--Gen. de l'Isle telegraphs that the wound in the leg which Gen. Negrier received in the engagement at Kep is so painful that it is necessary that that officer should take rest, and that he would therefore join the column. He continues: "The Chinese in the last engagement lost 1,000 men, including their Generals. Our victory was mainly due to the gallantry of the vanguard, under the command of Capt. Fortout."

BIRMINGHAM, Oct. 13.--The conservative demonstration in this city announced for today, involving meetings to be held at the Aston Grounds, the Town Hall, and in the skating rink, was prevented by an organized force of their opponents.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13.--A special dispatch from Reading, Penn., says the new Pennsylvania Schuylkill Valley Railroad recently made a canvass of the business places from Philadelphia to Conshohocken, soliciting shipments of freight by the new line.

BERLIN, Oct. 13.--The National Zeitung says that Emperor William has sent an autograph letter to the King of Portugal, informing him of the intentions of Germany, Russia, and Austria on the Congo question.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 13.--Loring McCauley, of Philadelphia, a youth of 18, to-day shot and wounded Mary Benson, aged 14, and then shot himself. Miss Benson, who lives with her widowed mother, first met McCauley at the Lancaster Watch Factory, where both were employed, in March last.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 13.--The ill-favored of both political parties swarmed into public view in astonishing numbers to-day. They came from the rookeries and the dives, and crowded up the steps of the Post Office building, which is just now a Blaine headquarters.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13.--Engine No. 56 of the Amboy Division of the Pennsylvania Railroad was pulling the Burlington accommodation train into Camden this morning at the rate of 25 miles an hour, when it ran into Engine No. 4 of the West Jersey Railroad, going with the train for Wenonah behind it at the same rate, at Third-street and Bridge-avenue.

There was a meeting last evening of the Executive Committee of the New-York Democracy at the Everett House, Francis M. Bixby in the chair, at which resolutions were passed in reference to the coming election.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13.--Benjamin G. Owen, Secretary of the Board of Directors of the Academy of Music, has defaulted. The amount stolen will reach nearly $800.
The Metropolitans found no difficulty in defeating the Indianapolis team on the Polo Grounds yesterday.

The French singers having departed, the home of English comedy was left vacant, therefore English comedy last night returned to its home.
PETERSBURG, Va., Oct. 13.--The large tobacco factory of Messrs. C.A. Jackson Co., one of the largest and most complete in the South, was destroyed by fire to-night.

In a communication sent to the Common Council yesterday, Mayor Edson points out a further reason why, in his opinion, the board should not grant to the Broadway Surface Railroad Company the franchise of a street railroad in Broadway.
Moody and Sankey, the evangelists, began a two days' Christian convention in Dr. Cuyler's Lafayette-Avenue Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.

Vance made an affidavit yesterday before the General Term of the Supreme Court in answer to the charge of Corporation Counsel Lacombe that he was unfitted to be a disinterested Commissioner in the determination of the Broadway Surface Railroad Company's application for right to construct its road.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 13.--Eugene Hammel, ladies' and gentlemen's furnishing goods, has made an assignment. His liabilities are $18,000 and his assets $10,000. The assignment was made to obtain an extension of time, and he will reopen.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 13.--The city is gay to-night with flags, steamers, and mottoes in anticipation of Wednesday's bicentennial celebration, and work of decorating will be continued all day to-morrow.

Since the repeal of the high duty on matches vast quantities of foreign matches have been introduced here. The wide difference between the English, the Swedish, the Italian, and the American matches has enabled a leading philosopher to trace in a very interesting way the connection between matches and religion.
A more enthusiastic audience than that which assembled in the Music Hall, in Brooklyn, last night to listen to reasons why Republicans should vote for Cleveland is seldom seen or heard.

The Jersey City police, having arrested all the persons supposed to be implicated, made public yesterday the circumstances of an outrageous assault committed upon Mrs. Mary McDonough by the Jersey-avenue gang of ruffians, between 12 and 1 o'clock Sunday morning.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 14.--The four Captains engaged for the Nile service have arrived from Manitoba, and will leave for their destination to-morrow via New-York, whence they will sail on a steamer of the White Star Line.

John Harper, 22 years old, of No. 68 Laight-street, attempted to commit suicide last evening by swallowing a small quantity of insect powder. He was taken to Chambers-Street Hospital, and at midnight had so far recovered as to be pronounced out of danger.

LONDON, Oct. 14.--The marriage of Miss Ida Therese, daughter of Capt. Foote, United States Navy, to Lord Montague Paulet, son of the Marquis of Winchester, was celebrated today at St. George's Church, Hanover-square. United States Minister Lowell and a large and fashionable audience were present atthe cermonies. After a wedding breakfast at Kensington Palace, the newly married pair started upon their wedding tour to Nice.

The Trunk Line General Passenger Agents met yesterday at the office of Commissioner Fink. The subject was the division of the immigrant business out of New-York. The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, which withdrew from the pool on Sunday last, received 6 per cent.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Oct. 14.--The Sixteenth Congressional District, composed of Ashland, Holmes, Huron, Lorain, and Richland Counties, gave 1,236 majority to Hoadly in 1883. Geddes, (Dem.,) for Congress, claims Ashland by 650; Holmes by upward of 2,000; Richland, basing the estimate ...

CAIRO, Oct. 14.--A caravan from Kordofan confirms the report that the Mahdi, hearing that the provisions at Khartoum are giving out, is gathering a strong force with which to invest the place and starve the garrison into submission.

Five attachments against the property of the Texas and Pacific Railroad Company in this city were levied by Deputy United States Marshal Holmes yesterday on warrants issued from the United States Circuit Court.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 14.--The fifth annual reunion of the combined associations of the Twenty-seventh New-York Volunteer Infantry and First Veteran Cavalry was held in this city to-day. It was a great success, being the largest gathering ever known here.

It is always wise to avoid postponing the performance of a duty until the last moment, and those voters who have not already registered will consult their own convenience as well as make their right to vote on Nov. 4 a certainty by attending to this important duty to-day.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14.--In a letter to Messrs. A.S. Chase and F.J. Brown, of Waterbury, Millionaire Gordon W. Burnham, of New-York, gives reasons for supporting Cleveland in preference to Blaine. Among the Republican leaders in Waterbury the letter, which has been freely shown by its recipients, has created extreme consternation.
The fund being raised in England for a memorial to the late Dr. Pusey now amounts to over $151,500. Canon Liddon has recently put his name down for a second donation of $2,500.

BOSTON, Oct. 14.--William C. Hickman was arrested this morning charged with the embezzlement of $1,500 from Alexander J. Bachman of New--York. The indictment alleges that on the 7th day of April last Bachman gave Hickman four checks, each of the value of $375, in trust for the payment of two promissory notes. Those checks were indorsed by Bachman, and the allegation is that Hickman kept the money.

CINCINNATI Oct. 14.--This has been throughout the most turbulent election day ever known in Cincinnati. The scenes at the voting precincts have been riotous and bloody. Bullets have been flying, clubs have been used, and men have been carried to the hospitals maimed and half dead. One murder has been committed outright by a United States Deputy Marshal.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 14.--Gov. Cleveland was busy at his desk as usual this morning, and while he no doubt felt considerable interest in the result of the battle of ballots in progress in Ohio, he gave no outward evidence of it. He has completed his preparations for his trip to New-York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14.--At the meeting of the International Prime Meridian Conference to-day, a resolution was adopted providing that longituae should be counted from the meridian of Greenwich in two directions up to 180 east longitude plus and west longitude minus.

BRADFORD, Penn, Oct. 14.--The Christy Oil Well made 5,200 barrels during the 24 hours ending at 2:30 to-day. If its production is reckoned from 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon it will greaty exceed that figure.

Applications for tickets of admission to the Academy of Music this evening--the occasion being the business men's Cleveland and Hendricks meeting--fairly overwhelmed the Committee of Arrangements yesterday. It is feared that the number of tickets issued will exceed by several thousand the capacity of the Academy. The arrangements for the meeting were fully completed last evening.

The discovery of a fire last evening on board the steamer Normandie, the crack vessel of the French Transatlantic Company, lying at her wharf at the foot of Morton-street, North River, caused great commotion among the officers and crew. The Normandie, which is commanded by Capt. Franguel, is to sail at 2 P.M. to-day for Havre. She is fully loaded, and was ready for sea last evening.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H. Oct. 14.--The schooner Statesman, 120 tons, went ashore on Odiornes last nignt in a heavy gale. The crew remained on board until this morning. The schooner and cargo will be a total loss. She was owned by William H. Mitchell, of New-York, and was coal laden with 220 tons, from New-York for Portsmouth. The crew were saved.

BRADFORD, Penn., Oct. 14.--Eighteen months ago, while counter clerk in the Western Union Telegraph office at Oil City, Mike Keating, by using the information which came into his possession and working the market, made a large fortune. To-day he "laid down" under a load of 30,000 barrels of oil, with cash differences of over $2,000.

After a canvass altogether unprecedented in the history of American politics, a canvass which has placed the full strength of their case before every voter in the State and left no appeal unused, no enticement untried, the Republicans have carried Ohio by a majority 6,000 less than that given to the Republican ticket in the October election of 1880.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14.--The pork-packing firm of Davies, Atkinson Co. has been levied upon for $25,000 by the Sheriff to-day, and its establishment at the stock yards is closed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14.--James E. Shober, a "sub" printer at the Daily Post office, was shot and killed this afternoon by William H. Phillips, a regular printer in the some office. Shober accused Phillips last night of depriving him of his place and indulged in foul language to him.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 14.--The fire in the syndicate mine, at Carbon Hill, was extinguished to-day. The effort to smother the fire in the mine at Sand Run is a failure, and the flames are still raging.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 14.--Teemer has accepted Gandaur's challenge to row a three-mile race with a turn, on Creve Coeur lake, near this city. The race is to be for $500 a side, Teemer to give Gandaur five seconds start. The race is to take place on Oct. 26.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 14.--The statue of John Harivard will be unveiled on the Delta, just west of Memorial Hall, to-morrow. Commemorative exercises will be held in Sanders's Theatre at 3 P.M., in which the Rev. Edward Everett Hale, D.D., the Rev. George E. Ellis, D.D., and President Eliot will take part.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 14.--The Fall meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club began to-day under very favorable auspices. The attendance was good, though there was a cold northwest wind. The track was in fine order. The winners of the day were Markland, Wanda, Loftin, Clonmel, and Bourke Cockran.

DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 14.--Returns for the city of Dayton are all in, giving the city 179 Democratic majority on the State ticket, a Republican gain of 898 over 1883. In one precinct of the Soldiers' Home the Republicans gain 118.

Tompkins, a grocer, who does business at the corner of Spring and Sullivan streets.

Esterbrook, Inspector of Buildings; ex-Police Justice Morgan, ex-Alderman John McClave, Excise Commissioner Morris, and Gilbert R. Hawes.

Gen. Butler will stump the State for himself until election day. He will start out tomorrow morning and will first speak on his working man's platform at Schenectady. He will not ride in an emigrant car on his tour. That he determined on at the outset. Standing in the Grand Central Station is the car that will carry him through the country.

An unusually large meeting of the Bar Association was held last evening. Many of the members present are seldom seen at the association's meetings. They undoubtedly appeared last night because some action with respect to the nominations to judicial offices was expected to be taken by the association.

Field, of this city, to restrain the latter from the further production of the comedy of "Nunky" was further heard in court here today before Judge Colt. William B. Lewis, Secretary and Cashier of the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, suddenly reeled and fell yesterday while walking on Fulton-street, Brooklyn, near the ferry. When lifted from the spot where he had fallen and carried to the office of the company near by he was still breathing heavily, but he died before a doctor could be summoned. Death is supposed to have resulted from heart disease.

A match at handball was played in Sweeny's court, No. 159 East Thirty-fifth-street, yesterday. The contestants were ex-Alderman Philip Casey, of Brooklyn, the champion of the world, and James Smith, the champion of St. Louis.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 15.--Both Democrats and Republicans turned out here this evening in honor of the victories in West Virginia and Ohio. The Democrats turned out by far the greatest number. The entire town was illuminated and the processions were applauded and cheered by crowds along the whole line of march.

A mass meeting and barbecue under the auspices of the Harlem Democratic Club was held last evening at Harlem River Park, Secondavenue and One Hundred and Twenty-seventhstreet. RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 15.--The steamer Defiance, of the Clyde Line, was burned this morning to the water's edge at New-Berne. Five hundred bales of cotton aboard were also destroyed. The loss on the cotton is $25,000, and on the steamer $25,000.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 15.--Col. Henderson, Chairman of the Indiana Democratic State Central Committee, says: "The result will have no outside effect, but will give Ohio to Blaine. At yesterday's meeting of the Board of Education Superintendent Jasper submitted his report, in which he stated that the public schools, exclusive of asylums and corporate schools, opened on Sept. 8 with an attendance of 122,234 pupils. Of the 3,035 teachers 2,956 were present.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15.--Kuichi Kuki, the newly appointed Minister from Japan, accompanied by his wife and K. Misaki, Secretary of Legation, arrived in this city to-day. He is the youngest man of his rank here, being only 33 years old.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15.--The second day of the races of the Fall meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club was very interesting, though the fields were small. The attendance was good, though the day was cold and uncomfortable. The winners of the day were Rica, War Eagle, Marmaduke, Fosteral, and Thackeray.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15.--The dog show of the National Breeders' Society begins to-morrow morning at Industrial Art Hall, and will remain open four days. Over 300 of the finest dogs in America and a large number imported from England for this exhibition arrived to-day.

COLUMBUS, Oct. 15.--The Republican majority in Ohio, as it appears to-night, with the returns nearly complete, turns out to be a very much less glorious one than it seemed last night, when the Blaine shouters in the streets were claiming anywhere from 18,000 to 30,000.

At the meeting of the Park Commissioners, yesterday, Dr. Henry D. Cogswell, of San Francisco, submitted a plan of the ice-water fountain which he proposes to present to the city of New-York. WASHINGTON, Oct. 15.--Not for several weeks have the male employes of the Government in this city felt so good as at this hour. Most of them roamed the streets until after midnight last night, and then went home happy because they were sure Ohio had gone Republican by a fair majority.

The Republican majority in Newark on Tax Commissioner was 1,651; on Water Commissioner, 1,554, and on Trustee of the City Home, 1,611. These are non-partisan offices, however, and the Democrats claim that they are not fair bases for estimates. They say that the Republican majority is really and only that shown on the total vote for Aldermen. The majority on the basis of that vote is only 611.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15.--On the 15th of July Capt. W.B. Chew, one of the oldest and best-known conductors on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, was arrested for embezzling the sum of $15.95, which he had received for railroad fares as conductor. The trial of the case began yesterday morning in the Criminal Court in this city, and concluded this afternoon, the jury, after being out 15 minutes, returning a verdict of not guilty.

The committee on the time and place for holding the next conference selected Washington, D.C. The date of the meeting is to be fixed by the Executive Committee.

CAICAGO, Oct. 16.--Senator Logan arrived home to-day after an absence of several weeks. He will speak at Elk Grove, Ill., on Saturday, whence he will go to Iowa, returning in time to be present with Mr. Blaine in Springfield, this State, on Oct. 24, and in this city the day following.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 16.--Miss Lizzie Wallace, of Newville, Cumberland County, in getting off a Cumberland Valley Railroad train, stepped in front of another train that was moving. Harvey Foster, a checkman, sprang to her rescue, but both were run down. Miss Wallace was cut to pieces, and died instantly. Foster had both legs mangled and almost torn off. He cannot recover.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 16.--At the conclusion of the Western New-York Methodist Conference, held in Medina, the question of politics came up and was generally discussed. St. John seemed to be the candidate most in favor, as was shown by the following paper:

MONTREAL, Quebec, Oct. 16.--It is rumored that Hinckley, the absconding Teller of the New-York West Side Bank, was in Montreal recently. It is said that he was closely watched during his stay. He, however, was notified of this fact by several New-York friends, and left the city hurriedly.

The people began assembling in the park in the forenoon. Many men came with their families, and by 12 o'clock more than 1,000 persons were scattered over the broad area of the dusty, verdureless picnic grounds.

CARMEL, N.Y., Oct. 16.--The Republicans of Putnam County to-day nominated Robert A. Livingston for Assembly, Edward C. Weeks for County Clerk, James A. Foshay for School Commissioner, and Abraham J. Miller for District Attorney.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16.--It needed only a glance at the newspapers this morning to warn Mr. Blaine's friends here that their joyful manifestations of yesterday were a trifle premature. This warning had a prompt effect, and by the opening of business hours at the various departments a genuine scare had set in.

The auction sale of Holstein cattle, imported by William Koch, took place yesterday at the Horse Exchange. This breed of animals is entirely different, both in appearance and disposition, from the Jersey cattle that are so highly prized by fanciers in this country.

The Republicans of the Tenth District of Hudson County have nominated Frederick Frambach for the Assembly. The Republicans of the Third District have renominated Assemblyman Samuel D. Dickinson.

The Most Rev. Archbishop Corrigan celebrated the mass and officiated at the solemn profession of Miss Mary E. Nugent, in religion Sister Mary de Sales, in the Order of Sisters of Mercy, in the chapel of St. Catherine's Convent, ...

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 16.--By the will of the late Francis P. Hurd, of Wakefield, just filed in the Probate Court, the following public bequests are made: Phillips Exeter Academy, $50,000; Massachusetts General Hospital, $10,000; Beebe Town Library, at Wakefield, $2,000.
The Republican County Convention to nominate city and county officers will meet at Republican Hall, No. 55 West Thirty-thirdstreet, this evening. Senator Frederick S. Gibbs will probably preside.

DOVER, N.H., Oct. 16.--A snowstrom lasting four hours and aggregating one and a hall inches occurred at Alton Bay this morning. Slight snowfalls are reported throughout Straf ford County, N.H., and York County, Me.

ALABANY, N.Y., Oct. 16.--The Hon. James C. Truman, of Binghamton, has been appointed Special Commissioner for New-York State, to look after the industrial and manufacturing exhibits at the World's Exhibition Cotton Centennial at New-Orleans.

The Democratic Congressional Convention of the Fourteenth District, comprising the 22 towns of Westchester County and the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards of this city, was held at Sing Sing yesterday afternoon.
NEW-ORLEANS Oct. 16.--The body of Mrs. Mallory was found in Lake Pontchartrain late to-night.

The tenth annual examination of the New-York Nautical School was held on board the school ship St. Mary's yesterday. The members of the council appointed by the Chamber of Commerce and their friends, to the number of 100, left the Barge Office shortly before 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, on the revenue steamer ...

BERNE, Oct. 16.--The Latin monetary Conference has been postponed to Nov. 25. RHEIMS, Oct. 16.--The vintage for 1884 is the best that has been seen in France since the famous vintage of 1874. The present year's wines will be delicate and full of bloom.

In April last the residents of Far Rockaway were startled by the attempt of Mrs. Birdsall, a well-known resident of the place, and widow of the late Peter Birdsall, for a number of years Deputy Surrogate of this city, to scald Estelle Pettit, the 10-year-old daughter of Mrs. Pettit, by throwing boiling water on the child.
GOUVERNEUR, N.Y., Oct. 16.--The Democratic Congressional Convention for the Twentysecond District to-day nominated George Hall, of Ogdensburg, for Congress.

The Wine and Liquor Dealers' Association of the First Assembly District of the City of New-York met yesterday in the Astor House and elected a new board of officers and Trustees. Adolf Neilson was made President; Hugh McManus. Vice-President; Hugh Dolan, Treasurer, and F.W. Linnemann, secretary.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17.--In response to an invitation from the students of Yale College. Prof. William G. Sumner addressed them to-night in North Sheffield Hall on "Independent Voting." After discussing the growth and future of the independent voter and the necessity for his existence, Prof. Sumner said:

QUEENSTOWN, Oct. 17.--The Guion Line steamer Nevada, Capt. Brewer, from New-York, Oct. 7, to Liverpool, arrived off here at 8:45 o'clock this morning. At noon on Wednesday last the discovery was made that a portion of the cargo was on fire.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 17.-The man arrested here some days ago for swindling the Rev. Dr. Rexford, and who gave the name of Thomas May, turns out to be ex-Gov. Moses, of South Carolina, having been identified by officers from Cambridge, Mass., where he is wanted.

Much dissatisfaction was expressed last evening at the meeting of the German Republican Central Committee with regard to the apparent indifference of the Republican National Committee as to whether or not the German Republicans of this city are to hold a mass meeting.
Mr. August Walthers will give a piano recital at the Long Island Historicat Society's building, Brooklyn, next Wednesday afternoon, Oct. 22.

Chairman Hensel, of the Pennsylvania Democratic State Committee, has issued a rallying address to the party which concludes thus: "The battle lines are now formed on a field that stretches across the entire country.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 17.--The body of an unknown man, with the head crushed, was found this morning near the railroad track, three miles south of Troy. In a pocket was a broken bottle that had contained liquor. The man is supposed to have belonged in Troy, and it is thought that he lay down on the track last night and was struck by a locomotive.

The extraordinary shrinkage in the majority claimed by the Blaine people the morning after the Ohio election has attracted general attention. SPRINGFIELD. Mass., Oct. 17.--The owl passenger train on the Boston and Albany Railroad, which leaves Albany at 8:40 P.M. and reaches this city at 12:40 A.M., ran off the track at Kinderhook, N.Y., and the engine went down a bank. Both tracks are blocked.

The Directors of the Academy of Music held a meeting yesterday afternoon to consider the question of advancing money to Col. Mapleson to enable him to make the necessary deposits for closing his contracts with Mmes. Patti and Nilsson.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17.--The Hon. William Daniel, of Maryland, the Prohibition candidate for the Vice-Presidency, spoke to-night in this city to an audience of about 100 persons. He goes from Washington to Alabama, and expects to remain in the Southern States until after the November election.

WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 17.--As far as heard from 23 counties of this State give Democratic majorities of 12,133. Twenty-two counties give Republican majorities of 9,277, leaving a Democratic majority of 2,856, with four counties to hear from, which may increase the Democratic majority 1,200. The Democratic plurality in 1880 was 16,136, and their majority 8,100 over the Republicans and Greenbackers. The total vote will surpass any in the history of the State.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17.--The extension of leave of absence on account of sickness granted Major Lewis Merrill, Seventh Cavalry, in special orders of May 29. has been still further extended six months on Surgeon's certificate of disability. Leave of absence for five months has been granted Capt. Mott Hooton, Twenty-second Infantry. Leave of absence for six months, on Surgeon's certificate of disability, has been granted Capt. George F. Foote, Eighth Cavalry.

Hickman.--Submitted under the twentieth rule. No. 8--Harriet Skidmore, et al., plaintiffs in error, vs. The Pittsburg, Cincinnati and St. Louis ...

ORILLIA, Ontario, Oct. 17.--This afternoon while watching the thrashers at George Rix's farm, near Bass Lake, Rix's two sons went into the mow to play. One of them, aged 10 years, tumbled into the mouth of the thrashing machine ans was immediately swept in and torn to pieces.
MONTPELIAR, Vt. Oct. 17.--A bill was introduced in the Legislature to-day by the opponents of capital punishment by hanging, providing for the execution of murderers by electricity.

CAIRO, Oct. 17.--Advices from Ambukol state that merchants who have arrived at that place confirm the reports that Gen. Gordon captured the towns of Shendy and Netemmeh on Oct. 6. They state that Gen. Gordon makes constant sorties from Khartoum.

The County Democracy's leaders held a conference at the New-Amsterdam Club last night, and appointed subcommittees to wait upon all the political organizations in the city except the Republicans and Tammany and ascertain the prospects of co-operation in nominating and electing a local ticket.
LONDON, Oct. 17.--Mr. James Russell Lowell will issue in one volume his recent address on Democracy and other papers, revised.

LIMA, Oct. 17, via Galveston.--Passengers from Arequipa report that Cesar Canevaro has gone to Bolivia, leaving Caceres in the dual character of General-in-Chief of the Army and Provisional President. Much alarm exists at Trujillo and the State troops are greatly excited. It is estimated that the loss on both sides in killed and wounded in the recent three days' fight was 400.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17.--Col. Ezra Taylor, one of Chicago's pioneer citizens, was brought before Judge Prendergast yesterday to be tried for insanity at the instance of his son, George L. Taylor, of the Fire Department. The Judge subjected him to a rigid examination, but the queries were answered in a manner not at all indicative of mental unsoundness.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 17.--After making some collections at Manville yesterday, George D. Batber, a Pawtucket grocer, was attacked at 11:30, while on his way home, by two men who had followed hin in a buggy, and who chloroformed him and robbed him $350.

Joseph Giarlino, an Italian, of No. 31 Mulberry-street, was in the Tombs Police Court yesterday, on the complaint of Francesca Piziarro, of No. 92 James-street, who said that he had broken into her trunk and had stolen her bank book and jewelry valued at $90.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 17.--A Tribune special from La Junta, this State, says: "Richard Simpson, the cashier of J.C. Jones Fisher's bank, of this place, has absconded, and, it is reported, took all the bank's available cash, amounting to several thousand dollars. Simpson stood high in the confidence of the people here. Officers are in pursuit of him.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct. 17.--A telegram from Sydney states that while the steamer Ocean King with the Canadian Nile contingent, was coaling at that port, most of the men became drunk and conducted themselves in a very disorderly manner. The Indians behaved the best of all, and caused no disturbance. Over the turbulent element the officers had no control.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 17.-The tragical death of Frank A. Burton and the lynching of the man who fired the fatal shots at La Crosse, Wis., last night created a most profound sensation in this city. Mr. Burton was the son of Capt. Burton, one of the oldest mariners on the great lakes, and was born in this city almost 40 years ago.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 17.--The body of Mrs. Annie Madison was found in her home in Covington, this morning, on the floor. She had been choked with a rope, and her throat had then been cut. Her husband, who was absent when the discovery was made, was sent for and arrested, but denied all knowledge of the deed. Her little boy says an old man with gray whiskers committed the crime.

PARIS, Sept. 25.--On the first of the coming month the convents open their portals to pupils, who then leave home and holiday for an austere abode, where they are taught much mannerism, a vast amount of religion, fancy work of exquisite outline, and some book lore besides the lives of the saints.

In the Court of General Sessions yesterday Francis McLoughlin, age 19, of No. 79 Goerck-street, was sentenced by Judge Gildersleeve to 15 years in State prison for fatally stabing John Heill, in a quarrel on Aug. 20, in front of No. 323 Delancey-street.

The reduction by the West Score Railway of its passenger rates between any points on its line one-half, or to the basis of 1 cent a mile, yesterday, was an open declaration of war against the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 17.--The first independent Republican rally of the campaign was held in Horticultural Hall this evening. Frederick Kimball called the meeting to order and J.H. Walker presided.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 17.--Benjamin Poe, a wealthy farmer living near Brownsville, Mo., was shot and killed at the house of Ben Dorman yesterday. Poe had been on a spree, and called at Dorman's house and made improper proposals to his wife.

CHICAGO, Oct.17.--Leaving out good to choice Steers, of which there was only here and there a load, the market for shipping Cattle to-day was exceedingly dull. The supply of rough half-fattened stock was larger than for some days previous, while the demand, because of the rather forbidding look of the Eastern markets, was cut down to smaller proportions than usual.
BOSTON, Oct. 17.--The force of Boston police which went to Wellesley County to rescue Mr. Dacey, the contrctor, from the Italian laborers employed by him, found him bound and confined in a barn.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 17.--The fires continue to burn in the woods and cranberry patches in Atlantic County west of Elwood. At the latter place the smoke was almost suffocating last night. Among the losses reportad are $15,000 by the Atlantic Cranberry Company, 275 acres of their bog being burned over.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17.--Mrs. Anna Moss and Mrs. Anna Turner, mother and daughter, are in the South Chicago Jail charged with arson. They lived alone in a frame cottage on Commercial-avenue, between Ninetieth and Ninety-first streets. About 1:30 o'clock this morning Officer Frank Callahan was passing back of the house when he met the elder of the two women.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 17.--The Prohibitionists of the Third Assembly District of Westchester County have nominated Stanton Cady, of Sing Sing, for member of assembly from that district, and Henry White, of Yorktown, for School Commissioner.

After leaving the Brooklyn Rink at midnight Thursday Gov. Cleveland drove over the bridge, reaching the Fifth-Avenue Hotel at 1 A. M. A light supper was served, after which he was occupied until 2 o'clock in looking over the correspondence which had accumulated during his absence at the festivities in Brooklyn.

WORCESTER, Oct. 17.--George D. Robinson, a Boston policeman, attempted to commit suicide at the Waverly House in this city last night, the ball from his pistol entering the left breast, near the heart. His age is 23, and he has a wife in Charlestown. He will probably die.

A number of finny-looking gentlemen scaled the steps of the Murray Hill Hotel, at Park-avenue and Forty-first-street, last evening. With phosphorescent eyes they glared around the corridors of the house and dived into the coat room. Presently they appeared in full evening dress, with black backs and broad white bosoms, looking like blackfish in the hey day of their pride.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17.--Hartford Independent Republicans are beginning to take an active interest in the campaign. While no formal organization has been made, the coming of Carl Schurz to the capital city next Monday night has caused a demonstration which has surprised even the most sanguine.

The discovery of a great electric spring in Ithaca, N.Y., was made purely by accident, and the discoverer has been careful not to publish his discovery until the plainest evidence of its great value was at his command.

SANTIAGO DE CHILA, Oct. 17, via Galveston.--The opening of the exhibition has been fixed for 1 P.M. on the 26th inst. The President, accompanied by his Ministers, will meet the municipal authorities who are to assist in the inaugural ceremonies.
Some miscreant smashed the signal box at Coenties-slip and Front-street, at 11:40 o'clock last night, and sent out a false alarm of fire. He was not arrested.
Yesterday Justice Patterson rendered a decision in the case of Frederick Linsley, of No. 520 Grand-street, who was arrested on the 3d ult. for selling oleomargarine for butter.

A few days ago myriads of smell black flies passed over the South Side. A swarm hovered around the steeple of St. John's Episcopal Church, on Hanover-street, for some time, attracting a great crowd of people.
ONEIDA, N.Y., Oct. 17.--The Syracuse Stars and the Uticas played a game to-day for the amateur championship of New-York Stats. The game resulted as follows: Syracuse Stars 13; Uticas, 4.

The Fourth Congressional District Republican Convention met last evening at Central Hall, on Fulton-street, Brooklyn, and nominated ex-Assemblyman Bernard J. Mulholland for Congress on the first ballot. No other candidate was placed in nomination.

MOBILE, Ala. 17.--The drought is now nearly 11 weeks old, and there are no indications of a change in the weather. The nights are cool and the days pleasant, with refreshing breezes, but the sky both day and night is cloudless.

At Groton yesterday Thomas B. and Lydia Miller Tarbell celebrated their sixty-first wedding anniversary. In 1873 their fiftieth wedding anniversary was celebrated, and on each recurring 15th of October a large family and a goodly number of friends have met at the old homestead.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 17.--William Catkins, Republican candidate for Governor of Indiana, has been quite ill at Lafayette for several days, but has so far recovered that, accompanied by his wife, he left this afternoon for Chicago. They will spend the night in that city and go to La Porte, their place of residence, tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17.--Ex-Gov. Thomas A. Hendricks will speak in this city on the 22d inst. by invitation of the local labor organizations. He will return to Indianapolis, and go to Springfield, Ill., on the 29th.

BERLIN, Oct. 17.--Wilhelm I., Duke of Brunswick, is believed to be dying. PESTH, Oct. 17.--Prime Minister Tisza, in his speech yesterday before the Hungarian Chamber of Deputies, said that no written treaty had been concluded between the three Emperors at Skierniwice, but their conference was a guarantee of the continuance of friendly relations between the three Empires.

BINGHAMPTON, N.Y., Oct. 17.--Patrick Fitzgerald, a workman on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, was found drowned this morning in a water course known as Brandywine Creek.

LONDON, Oct. 17.--Mr. Mapleson has engaged Mlle. Nevada for America at 300 nightly. The Mapleson troupe will sail for New-York on the steamer City of Berlin, which will leave Liverpool on the 23d inst. Mme. Patti and Signor Nicolini will go on the steamer Oregon, which will sail from Livercool on the 25th inst.

Mrs. Julia Ward Howe has accepted the position of President of the woman's department of the exposition at New-Orleans, much to the gratification of the managers and to that of the women of New-England, who are deeply interested in its success.
MANCHESTER, Oct. 17.--The Guardian, in its commercial article, says: "Cloths are fairly steadyShirtings are frim. Sales have been moderate. Yarns are flat, Business has been slight."

LONDON, Oct. 17.--The Foo-Choo correspondent of the Times telegraphs that another battle has been fought on the shore near Tamsui. Three thousand Chinese were killed, but the French loss was trifling.

The bronze statue of the Rev. John Harvard, presented to Harvard university by Mr. Samuel F. Bridge, of Boston, typifies a wonderful fact in the spiritual history of this country. The young clergyman, the Rev. John Harvard, came here in 1638, and in one year died of consumption.

EAST SAGINAW, Mich., Oct. 17.--It was about 10 o'clock this morning when Mr. Blaine's special train started from Saginaw for Bay City. He and Gen. Fremont were escorted through the city to a stand in the park, where, after a short speech by Senator Palmer, Mr. Blaine was introduced. He spoke very briefly, and then introduced Gen. Fremont. Both were received enthusiastically.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17.--The SurgeonGeneral of the Army, in his annual report to the Secretary of War, says that an increased amount of appropriation for the purchase of artificial limbs and appliances for the next fiscal year is necessary.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 17.--The last session of the National Charities and Corrections Convention was held to-day. President Letchworth announced the following Committee on Juvenile Delinquent Statistics: The Rev. Frederick H. Wines, Springfield, Ill.; Rev. H.H. Hart, St. Paul, and J.C. Jones. The Rev. J.L. Milligan read a paper by Dr. Stephen Smith, of NewYork, on the organization of a system of labor for chronic insane patients.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 17.--Ex-Senator Grady spoke to a large audience in the armory his evening. The armory was paid for and the band engaged by the Republicans, who endeavored in every possible way to fill the hall.

A hunter, while walking through the woods on the west slope of the Second Mountain at West Orange yesterday afternoon, discovered the body of a man. It lay in a growth of underbrush, and a pistol lay by its side, indicating a death by suicide.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 17.--A few miles from Schenectady, in Schoharie County, resides a married couple, the husband being considerably older than his wife. A well-dressed comfortable-looking German woman sat in the complainant's chair in Special Sessions yesterday, and near her stood her little daughter, pretty, fair haired, and 4 years old. Mrs. Matilda Levy was suing her husband, Abraham, who stood at the prisoner's bar, for abandonment.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 17.--An accident occurred to-day at New-Castle, near St. Clair, by which John F. Quinn, Jr., a prominent citizen of St. Clair, was instantly killed, and Capt. Joseph Denning, a veteran of the late war, was fatally injured.

SKOWHEGAN, Me., Oct. 17.--The trial of J.F. Walker for the murder of A.R. Daggett in June last was brought to a close to-day. the jury failing to agree. Walker, who had just been married, fired out of a window at a party who were serenading him and his bride and killed Daggett.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Oct. 17.--F.E. Warren, of this city, was nominated for Congress by the Wyoming Republicans to-day.
BATH, Me., Oct. 17.--Grace Church Parish has extended a pastoral call to the Rev. Dr. Robert N. Parke, of Brooklyn, N.Y.

The sloop yacht Bonita, off Bath, Long Island, capsized off Life-Saving Station No. 16, near Barnegat, early Wednesday evening. Paul Lacroix, the prolific French writer, known under the pseudonym of "Bibliophile Jacob," died yesterday. M. Lacroix was born at Paris, Feb. 27, 1806, and was educated at the college of Bourbon, where he published an edition of "Clement Marot" at the age of 18 years.

On the morning of April 25, 1882, Henry Worthington left his home, at No. 382 Jay-street, Brooklyn, at his usual hour of going to business. He has never been heard of since. He was the son of John Worthington, a druggist of 162 Fultonstreet, Brooklyn, where he has been in business for 40 years.

James D. Houston, of New-Orleans; exMayor Solomon Scheu, of Buffalo, and Senator Warfield, of Maryland, were visitors to the National Democratic Committee's headquarters yesterday. Mr. Houston's reception by the Democrats was most cordial.

Some interesting statistics on the subject of divorce have been put forward, the result of the duties of the Presidents of the Civil Tribunals during 1882. Drexel, Morgan Co., of this city; Drexel Co., of Philadelphia, and J.S. Morgan Co., of London, England, are now receiving subscriptions for $6,500,000 5 per cent. debenture bonds of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company.

MONROE, Mich., Oct. 17.--The Lutheran General Council held a missionary festival last evening, at which the Rev. H.C. Schmidt, a missionary, of India, made an address. This morning the council took up the report on the new English church book, and entered upon its discussion. This afternoon the annual reports of the Committees on Home and Foreign Missions were made to the council.
The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Rochester and Pittsburg Railroad will be held on Nov. 12. Thirteen Directors are to be elected, and there is likely to be an interesting contest.
MUNICH Oct. 17.--The Munich Allgemeine Zeitung states that the English Government has assured Prince Bismarck that it is not opposed to Germany's colonial policy.

A Coroner's jury yesterday held an inquest in the case of Michael Lacy, a waiter in the Jim Fisk restaurant in Chatham-street, who died soon after taking a dose of aconite prescribed by Dr. Felix A. O'Hare. The jury was composed of physicians. Dr. B.A. Witthaus, who analyzed the stomach, found a quantity of aconite in it.

The new Mackay-Bennett cable, one end of which arrived off Manhattan Beach on Thursday morning, is not yet landed, owing to another accident which occurred yesterday. The men on board the Faraday, the cable steamer, did not cease their work of coiling the cable on the rafts moored beside the ship until late on Thursday night.

BOSTON, Oct. 17.--In the United States District Court to-day Charles E. Brown, of Boston, aged 27 years, who pleaded guilty some time ago to passing counterfeit gilded shillings for English sovereigns, was sentenced to three months in the Fitchburg County Jail and to pay a fine of $10.
LONDON, Oct. 17.--When the curtain fell at the Princess's Theatre last night on the conclusion of Mr. Wilson Barrett's first production of "Hamlet," the audience demanded a speech from the tragedian.

COLUMBUS, Oct. 17.--There has as yet been no footing made of the total vote cast on Tuesday last. Official and unofficial returns show that the aggregate Republican pluralities are as follows: For Robinson, Secretary of State, 11,321; for Flickinger, member of the Board of Public Works, 17,476; for Johnson, Supreme Court Judge, 15,000.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Oct. 17.--At a conference of the anti-fusion Greenbackers this afternoon an address to the Greenbackers of Iowa was issued, urging the erasure of the names of all Democrats from the Electoral, State, Congressional, and county fusion tickets now in the field. The question of a full, straight Greenback ticket was discussed, but owing to the nearness of the election it was voted down.

Brig.-Gen. Benjamin Alvord, of the United States Army, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was born in Vermont and was graduated from the Military Academy at West Point July 1, 1833. He was brevetted Second Lieutenant of the Fourth Infantry and began his duties by garrison service at Baton Rouge, where he remained until 1835.

TRENTON, Oct. 17.--Incendiaries were operating in Chambersburg-street early this morning and two buildings were set on fire. The first place was the barn and stable of Charles McCoy, on Chambersburg-street, opposite St. Francis's Hospital.

BUENOS AYRES, Oct. 17, via, Galveston.-- The origin of the rupture between the Government and the Papal Nuncio was the latter's proposal to the Government not to allow the propagation of Protestant doctrines, and to recognize the right of Bishops to interfere in the schools. SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Oct. 17.--In the trial of Rudger Clawson, son of Bishop Clawson, for polygamy, Judge Zane to-day ruled that the admissions of the accused in regard to his second marriage were competent testimony.
