The Metropolitan Club defeated the NewYork League nine on the Polo Grounds yester day. The contest was not a very sharp one as regards fielding, but the Mets won the game by superior work at the bat. In this respect Esterbrook carried off the honors. He hit the ball safely three times, each for two bases.

The condition of the Metropoliton National Bank since the Seney failure has not been encouraging. Confidence was shaken, and officers of the bank are reported as taking anything but a cheerful view of the situation. Common report, while crediting the bank with being perfectly sound, has also credited it with losing money. The Directors have been considering whether it would not be advisable for the bank to go into liquidation.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 17.--A meeting was held at Taylor's Opara House this evening under the auspices of the Butler and West Club of this city. It was advertised that Gen. Butler would be present, and that was the means of attracting an audience which about half filled the lower part of the house.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 17.--Sam Baldwin, a teamster for the Daisy Mine, was found dead in a lonely gulch near the foot of Old Mosquito Pass, in the vicinity of Leadville, with a bullet hole in his head and his face battered to a jelly. He had been beaten, shot, and dragged some distance.

Alexander Martin Sullivan, the Irish leader, died yesterday in Dublin. He was the son of Mr. D. Sullivan, of Dublin, and of Bantry, County Cork, where he was born in 1830. During his youth Mr. Sullivan studied art, and until 1853 devoted himself to its pursuit as a profession. At that date, however, he formed his first connection with the newspaper and periodical press.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 17.--To-day was the fourth and last day of the Fall meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club, and the attendance was the largest of the meeting. The fields generally were not so large as to induce great interest, but altogether the occasion has been of much attractiveness. Since the meeting began not a jockey has been fined, suspended, or censured.
LONDON, Ontario, Oct. 17.--W. Lind Co., wholesale hatters and furriers, have assigned, with liabilities of $50,000; assets, about $30,000.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 17.--At Sparta, White County, this morning, Thomas J.R. Swafford, a Democratic member of the State Senate, was shot and mortally wounded by Monroe Hudson, a butcher, and jailor of the county.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 17.--Louis Kohler was found dead in bed at highland this morning. A bottle which had contained chloroform was under his pillow. He had been married 10 months and lived pleasantly with his wife. An inquest will be held to-morrow.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct.17.--The voting on the repeal of the Scott act in Charlottetown, Prince Edward Island, took place yesterday, and resulted in the act being sustained by 40 majority.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17, 1884. The delegates to the International Meridian Conference were entertained by the Secretary of State to-day by an excursion to Mount Vernon on the United States steamer Despatch. The resident diplomatic corps and a number of ladies were invited to accompany them. A luncheon was served on board and the Marine Band furnished music.

A boy was observed to cut his thumb half through, but, instead of crying, he burst into the most boisterous laughter. On being asked why he did so he replied : "Because I am so pleased." He was then asked why he was pleased, and his reply was: "Because I didn't cut it off altogether." This little fable is recommended to Republicans who are crowing over Ohio.

The New-York, Ontario and Western Railroad Company is about to issue $4,000,000 of 6 per cent, thirty-year bonds. A mortgage to cover the entire issue has been made to the Mercantile Trust Company, and is already recorded in New-York and New-Jersey.

READING, Penn., Oct. 17.--A decision rendered by Judge Sassaman to-day on a motion for an ingunction to prevent the Consumers' Gas Company from digging up the streets of the city to lay gas pipes and to establish gas works was favorable to the company. The new company, which is composed of outside capitalists entirely, will, it is said, begin the work of digging up the streets immediately. The city will probably appeal the case.

There died at Dunkirk a few days ago M. Malo, a local celebrity, whose career furnishes more than one passage of romantic interest. He was the son of an old inhabitant of that town who took out letters of marque under Napoleon I., and made large sums of money by privateering. The late M. Malo sought to emulate the exploits of his father, although in a somewhat different fashion.

The annual report of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company for the last fiscal year has just been issued in pamphlet form. The total earnings for the year are stated at $5,364,906, the operating expenses at $2,882,331, and the net earnings at $2,482,574.
PARIS, Oct. 18.--Rumors are current here to the effect that the French have gained another victory in Tonquin and that 450 Chinese fell in the engagement.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 18.--The hop, step, and jump match for $250 a side between Lawyer Sullivan, of Boston, and Thomas Burroughs, of this city, was easily won by Burroughs this afternoon. He made 48 feet 8 inches, and his opponent 45 feet 9 inches. Burroughs beat the record by 6 inches and is ready to jump any man in the world.

LIVERPOOL, Oct. 18.--The Guion Line steamer Nevada, from New-York, on which a fire broke out Wednesday, and which put into Queenstown yesterday, has arrived at her dock, and is now discharging her cargo, which was greatly damaged by the fire. The vessel is injured but little. The Captain denies that any panic occurred among the passengers or crew when the fire was discovered.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 18.--Some excitement was created this afternoon at the Pottsville Iron and Steel Company's mills in this city. When the employes were being paid they were informed that on and after the 1st of November a reduction of 10 per cent. in their wages would go into effect. What action will be taken in the matter will not be known until next week. The mills give employment to over 1,000 men and boys.

On Sunday, the 5th, an enormous pelican was noticed flying around over Rolla, and was finally seen by two students of the School of Mines to alight down in the railroad stock pond just north of town. Mr. Valliant procured a gun and shot the bird, which was the largest ever seen in those parts, measuring 9 feet from tip to tip.

--The mu seums of Germany bear witness to the dominion of the old Romans. From BudaPesth to Treves, from Cologne up to the higher Rhine, the earth has yielded of the conquering race buried arms, helmets, coins, bronzes, and marbles.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18.--About 300 Republicans attended the anti-Blaine meeting at the Court House at Camden, N.J., to-night. Herbert A. Drake, a Camden lawyer, who has been a Republican for many years, called the meeting to order.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 18.--In the Middlesex Court to-day, before Judge Scudder, Prosecuting Attorney Rice and Counselor Adrian asked leave to place their reply to the recent presentment of the Grand Jury on record.

WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 18.--The election returns are still incomplete. Careful estimates at Republican headquarters place the Democratic majority at about 5,000. It may be a little less. It will be two or three days before the remote counties can be heard from officially.
